battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Disruptor.description:
• Gengar's useful immunities and great support movepool give it a niche as an incredibly disruptive Pokemon, especially if taking the correct predictive risks.

  • Destiny Bond: Destiny Bond is excellent at making foes second guess attacking Gengar. When slower foes don't take the bait and use a setup move, Gengar can punish them with Encore.

  • Encore: Gengar's excellent speed makes it an especially disruptive user of Encore, being able to disrupt key threats such as Garchomp and Dragonite.

  • Icy Wind: Icy Wind's Speed control can give Gengar the upper hand against fast Focus Sash leads such as Flutter Mane, and lets Gengar outspeed faster threats that it may want to Destiny Bond, such as Meowscarada.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave is great at crippling faster sweepers if Gengar's Focus Sash is intact, and punishing fast, common switch-ins such as Roaring Moon.

  • Sludge Bomb: This covers Meowscarada and Fairy-types, in addition to being Gengar's most powerful attack.

  • Dazzling Gleam In addition to OHKOing Hydreigon after Stealth Rock damage, Dazzling Gleam is an appealing secondary STAB move when using Tera Fairy.

  • Focus Blast: Focus Blast is Gengar's best shot at beating Kingambit outside of Destiny Bond.

Other Options

  • Will-O-Wisp Gengar does a great job of burning bulky sweepers that Gengar can be forced to Destiny Bond against, such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Tera Annihilape.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal Gengar can turn slower Ghost-types such as Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Annihilape into easy Encore targets.

  • Fairy: A Dragon-type immunity gives Gengar new Encore targets and better threatens Dragon-types.

  • Flying: Earthquake is a common attack against Gengar, so Tera Flying can turn the tables effectively. It also takes advantage of common Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type lets Gengar surprise Espathra, letting it Encore Stored Power and potentially ruin its sweep.

Sheer Force.description: Gengar is a powerful offensive threat thanks to its high Special Attack, good Speed, and great coverage. Focus Blast provides perfect coverage with Shadow Ball and threatens RegenVest Roaring Moon and Hisuian Goodra. Nasty Plot makes Gengar even more threatening, as at +2, it can OHKO special walls like RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, being guaranteed to do so after a layer of Spikes, and Roaring Moon with Focus Blast, as well as OHKOing specially defensive Garchomp with Shadow Ball after two layers of Spikes. Gengar has a number of options for its last moveslot, such as Sludge Bomb—which helps against Volt Absorb Mandibuzz, as well as OHKOing Ogerpon-H and Ogerpon-W; Thunderbolt, which threatens Water- and Flying-types like Manaphy and Corviknight; and Knock Off to cripple opponents, especially RegenVest Pokemon like Manaphy and Roaring Moon that can switch into Gengar, by removing their items. Gengar still struggles against certain special walls like Unaware Blissey and RegenVest Goodra, so it pairs well with physically offensive teammates like Dragonite and Chien-Pao that can handle these Pokemon. Additionally, due to its defensive frailty, Gengar appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra that can switch in and take hits for it, as well as pivots like Meowscarda and Barraskewda that can safely bring it in on physical walls. Gengar also benefits from entry hazard setters, like Heatran and Garchomp which can chip down foes and make them easier for Gengar to OHKO.

Hadron Engine.description: Hadron Engine Gengar uses its excellent Special Attack, good Speed, and good coverage options to function as a dangerous wallbreaker, pressuring physical and special walls alike. Hadron Engine-boosted Thunderbolt threatens an OHKO on Water- and Flying-types such as Empoleon and Mandibuzz and 2HKOes RegenVest Manaphy, while Focus Blast threatens an OHKO on Heatran and a 2HKO on Blissey, RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, and Roaring Moon. Trick can be used to cripple more defensive switch-ins such as Blissey and RegenVest users, while Sludge Bomb threatens an OHKO on Primordial Sea Zapdos and Ogerpon-C while also potentially crippling switch-ins with poison. Fast wallbreakers such as Barraskewda, Azelf, and Meowscarada appreciate Gengar's ability to pressure their walls like Kommo-o, Empoleon, and Corviknight, allowing them to clean late-game, while in return they can safely let in Gengar by pivoting out of such walls as they switch in. Azelf's Psychic Terrain blocking priority is appreciated by Gengar, as it allows it to avoid an OHKO from Dragonite's Extreme Speed and 2HKO it back with Sludge Bomb. Gengar's ability to absorb Toxic Spikes is greatly appreciated by offensive teams especially, as they can otherwise be crippled by them. Gengar is OHKOed by most Pokemon faster than it, such as Azelf, Barraskewda, and Roaring Moon, and takes takes heavy damage from most priority moves, so defensive teammates such as Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Empoleon are appreciated, with Corviknight and Great Tusk being able to remove the entry hazards that Gengar is prone to being chipped down by. Gengar also appreciates Corviknight and Empoleon being able to safely pivot it in due to their low Speed.

Normalize.description: Normalize Gengar reliably sets Toxic Spikes, forces a bevy of switches including against slower setup sweepers, and can trap and remove opposing special walls for fast cleaners like Azelf. Skill Swap, which has the added benefit of going through Substitute, renders Gengar immune to most attacks; this either forces the foe to switch no matter how much setup it has accrued, giving Gengar a free turn, or if Gengar successfully landed Mean Look first, spells its foe's doom. Toxic Spikes forces progress even in situations where it is unable to reliably trap the opponent's special switch-in, such as against Roaring Moon, and forces Defoggers like Corviknight into a catch-22: stay in to remove Toxic Spikes and risk getting trapped, or switch out and accept that entry hazards stay up. Taunt and Trick are alternatives that allow Gengar to trap and remove targets it otherwise could not like Meloetta, Mandibuzz, and Blissey but relegate it to a trap-or-bust option. Gengar pairs exceptionally well with physical pivots that get it in on slow physical walls it can scare out; if the opponent then switches to their special wall, they risk losing it to Mean Look + Skill Swap. Fast special cleaners like Azelf appreciate both Toxic Spikes and opposing special walls being trapped and removed; Azelf also appreciates Gengar's ability to lure and trap most Dark-types. Gengar is unable to reliably trap and remove Roaring Moon, so robust checks to it like Great Tusk and Intimidate Corviknight are strongly recommended.

Choiced Attacker (Ghost).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Tera Pivot.description: Voltorb's elite Speed tier and STAB Volt Switch make it one of Little Cup's premier pivots, as well as an excellent offensive check to fast threats like Wingull and Crabrawler. Volt Switch lets Voltorb deal solid damage while preserving itself and capitalizing on the switches it forces with its Speed. Thunderbolt deals a stronger blow, invaluable against bulky Water-types like Mareanie, Quaxly, and Shellos, and is valuable for cleaning up weakened fast threats. Tera Blast, once Voltorb has Terastallized, gives it the heralded BoltBeam coverage and turns the tables on would-be checks like Toedscool, Mudbray, Diglett, and Wattrel. Because of Voltorb's limited coverage and the prominence of Ground-types, Voltorb often depends on Terastallization (or the threat of it) to function well in a match. Voltorb leans on a few utility options for its fourth move due to its limited movepool; Protect stops Nymble's First Impression from revenge killing it and can scout defensive Terastallizations, especially Tera Water on Toedscool. Taunt prevents setup and entry hazards from the likes of Pawniard, Surskit, and Glimmet, and Thunder Wave neutralizes setup sweepers and faster threats that Voltorb cannot OHKO. Voltorb pairs well with teammates that can switch into its Ground-type checks when it has not Terastallized. Toedscool is a natural partner thanks to its bulk, Ground resistance, and ability to remove entry hazards for Terastallized Voltorb, given its new Stealth Rock weakness. Drifloon's Ground immunity also supports Voltorb well. As a pivot, Voltorb appreciates the support of other pivots to continually put your opponent on the back foot. Nymble has a powerful STAB U-turn and often invites in Mareanie, which Voltorb can pressure. Wingull not only checks Ground-types with its dual STAB types and Ground immunity, but also appreciates Voltorb handling the bulky Water-types that check it.

Pivot.description:
Electrode's blazing Speed tier and ability to take advantage of Terastallization cement it a niche as an effective pivot and late-game cleaner. Taunt shuts down recovery attempts from checks like Gogoat, setup attempts from Pokemon like Rotom-F, and entry hazards from foes like Carbink and Tinkatuff. The move pairs well with Electrode's nature as a pivot, giving partners an easier time setting up without dealing with annoying status. Due to Electrode's relative fragility and the prevalence of entry hazards, Aftermath is more effective at punishing priority users like Alolan Dugtrio and Basculin, as they are much more afraid of the guaranteed chip damage when revenge killing Electrode than the potential paralysis that Static provides. Tera Blast Fighting is an solid option that lets Electrode revenge kill Alolan Dugtrio, Houndoom, and Rotom-F as well as dent walls like Hisuian Sliggoo and Dunsparce. Tera Blast Ice is very useful for hitting Ground- and Grass-types like Gabite and Gogoat, although its inability to OHKO Whiscash does hinder its viability. Tera Water increases Electrode's revenge killing capability against Fire-types like Charizard and Pyroar, as well as Alolan Dugtrio; however, it also leaves it susceptible to Electric-types like Raichu and opposing Electrode in the one-on-one matchup. Lastly, Tera Grass is useful for hitting Whiscash, Carbink, and Klawf all in the same slot, something no other Tera type allows Electrode to do, while Tera Ground is also an option to specifically hit Raichu.

Electrode fits best with strong mid-game wallbreakers that struggle to get in, such as Zangoose and Basculin. Not only do they enjoy the free turn on Pokemon such as Gogoat and Carbink, they can also break down shared checks such as Gabite, making it easier for Electrode to win late-game. Whiscash is a major annoyance for Electrode, as it is immune to Taunt and is the only viable Ground-type to not take super effective damage from either of Electrode's common Tera types; thus, a strong Grass-type like Gogoat or Sawsbuck is recommended as a partner. They can also potentially force Whiscash to Terastallize, removing its Electric immunity for Electrode. Other fast Pokemon like Alolan Persian and Rotom-F can form a VoltTurn core with Electrode, utilizing entry hazards and a good Speed tier to pivot into each other's checks, such as Flapple, Skuntank, and Misdreavus, racking up chip damage. Entry hazards from Pokemon like Whiscash and Tinkatuff also benefit Electrode, as it can constantly force in Pokemon like Gabite and Dunsparce, which do not use Heavy-Duty Boots, and wear them down faster.

Rain Dance.description:
Electrode's phenomenal Speed, which allows it to outrun the entire unboosted metagame, good utility options, and ability to quickly pivot out after setting up Rain Dance allows it to be PU's best lead for rain teams. Taunt can prevent opposing leads such as Sticky Web Masquerain, and Stealth Rock Alolan Dugtrio from setting up entry hazards and block Gogoat from attempting to set up to break the team in the early-game. Thunder is gives Electrode a powerful, accurate STAB move in rain. Explosion is normally used in the last slot, as it gives Electrode a nuclear option and gives a guaranteed free switch to a partner, but Volt Switch allows Electrode to pivot into a teammate after setting up Rain Dance to set up Rain Dance again.

Swift Swim sweepers like Golduck and Beartic are necessary teammates to exploit Rain Dance. Other Water-types such as Basculin and Wugtrio enjoy having their Water-moves boosted as well. Masquerain is a particularly notable partner, as it has its Hurricane made 100% accurate, it can set up on foes it could normally not set up on outside of rain, such as Pyroar and Camerupt and has its Water-type coverage boosted as well, letting it chip foes like Carbink harder. Electric-types such as Raichu and Rotom-F enjoy being able to use a 100% accurate Thunder and can offensively check the opposing Water-types that would want to take advantage of rain, such as Basculin. Other Rain Dance setters such as Murkrow and Golduck are helpful for Electrode to not have to exclusively set Rain Dance for its team.

Offensive Pivot.description: 20 Defense EVs allow Electrode-Hisui to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Scarf Bruxish Wave Crash. Fairy Tera Blast hits Dragon-types like Goodra and Tatsugiri. The given Speed outruns Jolteon.

Trick Room Wallbreaker.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Physically Defensive (Poison).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Physically Defensive Defogger (Poison).description:
Galarian Weezing finds itself serving a key role on Poison thanks to its high physical bulk, wonderful support moves, and, most critically, Levitate giving it a critical Ground immunity to deal with both offensive and defensive Ground-types, such as Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Mamoswine, without much worry. Its secondary Fairy typing is also a major boon for Poison, making it immune to Dragon, which gives it utility in absorbing high powered Dragon moves like Glaive Rush from Baxcalibur and completely checking Garchomp. It also provides a helpful resistance to Dark, giving it added bulk against Dark-types like Alolan Muk and Meowscarada. Strange Steam is used for its STAB attack, dealing solid damage and threatening Dragon-, Fighting-, and Dark-types such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon. Defog is incredibly valuable, being the only consistent form of entry hazard removal on Poison, which Galarian Weezing can easily switch in and use thanks to its immunity to Spikes and neutrality to Stealth Rock This also allows it to run Black Sludge to further increase its longevity. Pain Split acts as a form of recovery and offensive pressure, allowing it to drain away health from opposing walls such as Toxapex and Gliscor while healing itself back up. Will-O-Wisp threatens physical attackers from those that it walls like Great Tusk and Dragonite and impairs others that do threaten it like Iron Treads and Corviknight, making them much easier to handle.

Alolan Muk and Assault Vest Galarian Slowking are amazing teammates for Galarian Weezing that cover Galarian Weezing's biggest weakness: low Special Defense. As specially bulky tanks, they can switch into strong special attacks, such as Choice Specs Greninja's Extrasensory, while majorly appreciating Defog from Galarian Weezing to maximize their longevity. Alolan Muk handles Psychic- and Ghost-type attacks from foes like Flutter Mane, Spectrier, and Espathra with ease thanks to its Dark typing and STAB Knock Off. Meanwhile, Galarian Slowking can soak up hits from Heatran, Regieleki, and Volcarona while responding back with its myriad of coverage, as well as create traps with Future Sight, which Galarian Weezing can exploit with Strange Steam or use as a chance to Defog safely. Toxapex's Water typing allows it to switch into and wall the many Steel-types of the tier like Scizor, Tinkaton, and Empoleon. It also handles other powerful threats such as Chien-Pao and Ceruledge, using Haze to stop their setup and Infestation or Surf to do damage. Toxapex is also a valuable Knock Off absorber in the Dragon, Dark, and Ice matchups, preventing Galarian Weezing from losing its Black Sludge from foes such as Cyclizar, Sableye, and Alolan Sandslash. Amoonguss appreciates Galarian Weezing taking the stress off it in the Ground matchup and allowing for it to have a much easier time taking on threats, such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Mamoswine, after they have been burned. Amoonguss is also able to handle threats to Galarian Weezing like Gastrodon and Sandy Shocks. Thanks to Defog allowing Salazzle safe entry, it can threaten every Steel-type in the tier with a mix of its STAB Flamethrower and Toxic thanks to Corrosion, which puts Steel-types that try to threaten it, such as Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, on timers, and it means Galarian Weezing won't have to worry about them late-game. Glimmora can be used instead of Salazzle, as it also can use Toxic thanks to Corrosion, has Earth Power to hit Heatran, has Energy Ball to help out against Ground-types, such as Great Tusk and Gastrodon, and if its Air Balloon is still intact, it can inflict Toxic onto Clodsire with no fear. With Defog support, Choice Scarf Sneasler can come onto the field safely and fire off strong its strong STAB Close Combat and Dire Claw against threats like Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Enamorus. Okidogi also works well as a Fighting-type that majorly appreciates burn being spread to have an easier time setting up before tearing into threats like Kingambit and Heatran with its STAB moves. Defog support will also allow safe entry for Iron Moth, which melts Steel-types with its powerful Fire-type STAB attacks, such as Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Corviknight, as well as being able to eradicate Landorus if using Choice Specs with Overheat. Gengar is another solid Choice Specs user that can scare out Skeledirge, which otherwise uses Galarian Weezing for setup and can also deal with Landorus with Icy Wind.

Utility Wall.description:
Thunder Wave allows Chansey to cripple Fighting-types that love to switch in on it and threaten it out. Tera Ghost allows it to soft check a multitude of common physical attackers like Toxicroak and Tauros, while Tera Fairy grants it a great defensive typing against most of the metagame as well as a resistance to Fighting-type attacks.

Thanks to Chansey's ability to run Stealth Rock, Sandaconda and Bronzong can now use Coil and Iron Defense for added insurance against physical boosters. Chansey quickly falls against physical attackers, so physical walls like Avalugg, Sableye, and Sandaconda make for great teammates. Because Chansey is forced to run Eviolite, it requires hazard control from the likes of Avalugg and Braviary. Common switch-ins to Trick and Knock Off like Sandaconda and Sticky Hold Muk are also greatly appreciated against Pokemon like Sableye, Mesprit, and Bombirdier, as Chansey requires its Eviolite. Setup sweepers like Mesprit and Hisuian Sneasel tend to overwhelm Chansey, so Pokemon like Sableye and Choice Scarf Ditto make for amazing partners.

Pink Blob (Defensive).description: Thanks to its gargantuan Eviolite-boosted special bulk alongside a lack of relevant weaknesses, Chansey stands firmly as a formidable wall that blanket checks the metagame's special attackers, including Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona. Toxic lets Chansey whittle them down, especially in conjunction with repeated Seismic Tosses, while Thunder Wave punishes poison-immune foes like Heatran and Toxapex and cripples switch-ins such as Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Chansey can provide cleric support with Aromatherapy, especially since it can switch into status users like Clodsire and Rotom-W thanks to Natural Cure. However, Stealth Rock can be used if the team lacks another user, and Chansey can do it sufficiently by outlasting common entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T. Tera Steel allows it to reliably check Tapu Lele, Hatterene, and Tornadus-T, and it prevents Chansey from being poisoned. Chansey is generally reserved for bulkier builds that appreciate its defensive profile and can tolerate its overall passivity. Sturdy walls like Skeledirge, Buzzwole, Skarmory, and Corviknight can cover physical attackers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Kartana for Chansey. Skeledirge's Unaware helps against setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Mega Charizard X that attempt to use Chansey as setup fodder, while Corviknight's Defog alleviates Chansey from entry hazard pressure that would overwhelm it easily. Knock Off and Trick absorbers like Clefable, Toxapex, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo make sure that Chansey can keep its valuable Eviolite; Additionally, Mega Scizor helps deal with Psyshock Tapu Lele, Gholdengo threatens Calm Mind Hatterene, and Calm Mind Clefable overwhelms Heatran—especially if it's paralyzed—all of which are special attackers that can beat Chansey one-on-one.

Imposter.description: With Imposter, Chansey transforms into a far bulkier version of the opposing Pokemon, which can be further bolstered by Eviolite. This provides a myriad of benefits, including blanket checking most Pokemon, scouting sets, and PP stalling less threatening foes. While Eviolite is usually the best item, Covert Cloak is useful against Mortal Spin and Spirit Shackle users. The given moves offer the most utility in the rare situations Chansey is not transformed, like pivoting, acting as a cleric, and improofing special attackers. Offensive threats such as Mega Diancie appreciate the information Imposter Chansey provides through scouting, with special attackers also appreciating Imposter Chansey taking advantage of RegenVest users and potentially acting as an Imposter-proof. Imposter Chansey appreciates slow pivoting from Pokemon like Mega Steelix and Mega Swampert for safe scouting; these Pokemon can also provide Knock Off support, aiding against Judgment and Covert Cloak users that can otherwise defeat Imposter Chansey.

Pivot.description:
Armed with excellent Speed and STAB U-turn, Scyther is an elite pivot in NU. Dual Wingbeat targets opposing Scyther and the plethora of Grass- and Fighting-types found in the tier, such as Shaymin, Toxicroak, and Paldean Tauros-F. Close Combat strikes Steel-types like Orthworm and Copperajah as well as Coalossal. Alternatively, if your team needs extra late-game potential, Swords Dance helps Scyther sweep once its checks are weakened or removed. Tera Ground blocks Volt Switch from foes like Rotom-C and Jolteon while providing a resistance to Lycanroc's Accelrock, whereas Tera Flying greatly improves Dual Wingbeat's power, making it far easier to break physical walls such as Qwilfish and Sandaconda.

Scyther is an excellent facilitator for VoltTurn teams, pairing well with specially offensive pivots like Rotom-C, Galarian Articuno, and Magneton. These pivots can threaten physical walls like Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Orthworm; in return, Scyther can pressure special walls like Goodra and Assault Vest Hariyama. Entry hazard setters like Sandaconda, Bronzong, and Qwilfish can rack up residual damage against the aforementioned physical walls, making them easier to wear down over the course of a game.

Swords Dance.description:
Scyther is a terrific Swords Dance sweeper, courtesy of its fantastic Speed, good power, and variety of Technician-boosted moves. Dual Wingbeat scares off slower Grass- and Fighting-types, like Shaymin, Arboliva, Toxicroak, and Hariyama. Close Combat hits Steel- and Rock-types like Orthworm and Coalossal for super effective damage. Alternatively, U-turn lets Scyther pivot against physical walls like Sandaconda and Gligar, as well as Pokemon that resist Dual Wingbeat like Orthworm and Copperajah. Quick Attack lets Scyther OHKO faster foes like Jolteon and Salazzle after it Terastallizes and boosts with Swords Dance. Tera Grass removes Scyther’s 4x weakness to Stealth Rock and allows Scyther to 2HKO Sandaconda with +2 Trailblaze, while Tera Flying strengthens its Dual Wingbeat to frightening levels and makes non-resistant foes easy to get by.

Swords Dance Scyther is best used mid- to late-game, where it has a better chance of picking off sufficiently weakened physical walls like Gligar and Sandaconda. If U-turn is selected, VoltTurn pivots like Rotom-C, Jolteon, and Mesprit are excellent teammates, threatening out walls like Sandaconda and Qwilfish while providing additional utility or coverage. Revenge killers like Tauros and Choice Scarf Rotom-C can preemptively cause Scyther to Terastalize or stop its sweep altogether, so specific checks to them like Sandaconda and Goodra, respectively, can help preserve Scyther's longevity. Special wallbreakers like Goodra, Hoopa, and Salazzle can remove physical walls so Scyther can find better chances to sweep late-game.

Swords Dance (Bug).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Wallbreaker.description:
Close Combat hits Porygon2 and Rhydon harder than any of Tauros's other moves. Earthquake still hits Rhydon super effectively while also breaking through Skuntank without triggering Aftermath. Tera Blast Ghost reliably OHKOes Rotom and 2HKOes Palossand and Houndstone, but Throat Chop can be used to hit these foes without Terastallizing. Fire Blast covers both Orthworm and Houndstone and should be used with a Naive nature.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Tauros is a great wallbreaker and late-game sweeper thanks to its combination of Sheer Force + Life Orb attacks, good coverage, and solid Speed tier. Rock Slide hits Flying-types like Oricorio-F, Articuno, and Scyther. While both Earthquake and Close Combat hit Steel-types that otherwise come in safely, the former gives Tauros an advantageous matchup against Poison-types such as Qwilfish and Muk, whereas the latter hits Steel-types harder while also nuking Ice-types like Abomasnow and Glaceon. Tera Ghost makes Tauros immune to Fighting-type attacks from Medicham and Hisuian Sneasel, and Tera Blast lets it hit Psychic- and Ghost-types in Hattrem and Rotom for greater damage than its other attacks. Tera Fairy is another option that helps against Fighting-types, and Tera Blast Fairy lets it beat Sableye and Spiritomb, which can otherwise wall it. Assurance can be used instead in combination with Stealth Rock from a teammate to OHKO Rotom on the switch. Tera Normal with Body Slam can also be used to take care of checks like Sandaconda, which gets 2HKOed after Stealth Rock.

Qwilfish and Froslass are good partners for Tauros, as it usually can’t KO its checks off the bat, so Spikes support is greatly appreciated—along with having a switch-in to Fighting-type attacks. Jolteon and Rotom are also amazing partners, as they can, together with Tauros, overwhelm Sandaconda with their Tera Blast Ice or Trick, respectively. A pivot such as Mesprit or Assault Vest Eelektross can use U-turn to draw in switch-ins like Appletun, Blissey, and Bombirdier, which Tauros can take advantage of.

Bulk Up.description: Paldean Tauros is a terrific Bulk Up sweeper with its great Speed and wide offensive movepool. After using Trailblaze, Paldean Tauros outspeeds Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Rotom. Stone Edge is great coverage for common Fighting-resistant foes like Haunter, Scyther, and Drifblim, while Tera Electric lets Paldean Tauros hit the aforementioned Flying-types and Vaporeon with Tera Blast and offers an immunity to paralysis. Tera Rock Stone Edge and Tera Electric Tera Blast both allow Paldean Tauros to OHKO Drifblim. Leftovers aids its general longevity, while Lum Berry allows it to set up safely once against status users like Rotom and Drifblim. Offensive Pokemon like Choice Scarf Rotom and Zoroark appreciate Paldean Tauros forcing out foes like Umbreon and Chansey; in return, they can check Ghost-types like opposing Rotom and Drifblim. Defensive teammates like Vaporeon and Chansey can sponge special attacks and either help its longevity with Wish or its offensive capabilities with Thunder Wave.

Bulk Up (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

FIREFIGHTER (Defensive).description:
• Will-O-Wisp and Intimidate make Paldean Tauros-F a potent check to physical attackers, notably enabling it reliably check Chien-Pao and Kingambit.

  • Raging Bull: This provides a powerful STAB attack that can also break screens, allowing Paldean Tauros-F’s teammates to clean up more easily.

  • Body Press Body Press is valuable because unlike Close Combat, it doesn’t cause defense drops.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb allows Paldean Tauros-F to check Volcarona despite its meager Special Defense.

  • Bulk Up: While this set is unlikely to sweep, Bulk Up does give Paldean Tauros-F a good way to punish foes that attempt to sacrifice their Pokemon to it.

  • Tera Dependency - Very Situational: Paldean Tauros-F should generally avoid Terastallizing, as its typing is a big part of what lets it act as such a sturdy check to Kingambit and other massive threats, such as Baxcalibur.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry / Figy Berry: A quick burst of recovery from a berry fits playing this set a bit more recklessly.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: This allows Paldean Tauros-F to switch around more freely in after entry hazards are set.

  • Rocky Helmet: Paldean Tauros-F tends to force a lot of switches, so Rocky Helmet lets it get some useful chip damage when switching into moves like Chien-Pao's Crunch.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is a high value item that other Pokemon want, but the gradual recovery is useful.

Offensive Screen Smasher.description:
• Paldean Tauros-F is fast enough to outspeed key threats such as Mimikyu and Modest Chi-Yu, making an offensive set viable.

  • Raging Bull versus Flare Blitz: Raging Bull might not be as powerful as Flare Blitz, but its ability to break Reflect and Light Screen give Paldean Tauros-F a unique niche.

  • Flame Charge versus Trailblaze: Flame Charge gives Paldean Tauros-F an unexpected late-game win condition, letting it outspeed threats such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle. Trailblaze is often weaker, but the greater chip dagainst against Water-types such as Azumarill can be beneficial.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb's speed control is useful when sacrificing Paldean Tauros-F against a threat and prevents Dragonite from getting easy Speed boosts.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Despite this set's offensive nature, Will-O-Wisp is good for punishing Dragonite, Dragapult, and slower foes that may Terrastallize, such as Ting-Lu and Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Paldean Tauros-F makes major use of its unique typing defensively, so it only needs to Terastallize for situational win conditions.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type makes Paldean Tauros-F far less vulnerable to Rotom-W and Rotom-W, in addition to dealing with Focus Sash Breloom.

  • Fairy: When paired with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type means Dragonite will no longer wall Paldean Tauros-F without Teratsallizing itself.

Items

  • Eject Pack: With Close Combat, this will give Paldean Tauros-F a powerful, one-time use pivot option.

  • Life Orb: This high value item can be tough to slot in, but the increased power makes sweeping with a Speed boost much easier.

  • Mirror Herb: Mirror Herb punishes setup sweepers even more effectively and pairs especially well with Intimidate.

Assault Vest.description:
• With an Assault Vest, Paldean Tauros-F finds itself a niche checking Choice Band Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Iron Moth.

  • Raging Bull Despite Flare Blitz having more power, Raging Bull is Paldean Tauros-F's preferred STAB move as a result of its ability to break Aurora Veil, Reflect, and Light Screen, as well as the lack of recoil associated with the move.

  • Iron Head vs Stone Edge Iron Head is used because of its ability to hit foes that can Terastallize into Fairy-types, such as Dondozo and some Dragonite; it also provides a midground against Rock-types such as Garganacl and Tyranittar. It also is Paldean Tauros-F's best shot at OHKOing Flutter Mane without Terastallizing. However, Stone Edge can be used in lieu of it, as it is Tauros-F's best chance of defeating Iron Moth.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Terastallizing into a Steel-type allows Paldean Tauros-F to be immune to Acid Spray attempts from Iron Moth, as well as boosting the power of Iron Head. It also allows Paldean Tauros-B to defeat Flutter Mane more easily, as Flutter Mane would otherwise need lots of defensive investment to survive it.

  • Grass: Tera Grass prevents Azumarill's Liquidation from OHKOing Paldean Tauros-F, as well as providing a boost to Trailblaze.

  • Fire: Like Tera Steel, Tera Fire provides useful resistance to Fairy, notably Flutter Mane. It also allows Paldean Tauros-B to OHKO Flutter Mane that don't invest in bulk with Raging Bull.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 12 Atk / 76 Def / 36 SpD / 140 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread allows Paldean Tauros-B to defeat Flutter Mane with Trailblaze into Raging Bull. The Defense EVs allow it to beat Choice Band Chien-Pao after Intimidate one-on-one. The Speed investment allows Paldean Tauros-B to outpace Flutter Mane after Trailblaze.

Choice Band.description: This set is currently in copyediting. It can be found here.

Dragon Dance.description: Mega Gyarados is a powerful sweeper on hyper offense teams thanks to Dragon Dance, Mold Breaker, and its high Attack stat. Mega Gyarados also possesses a valuable defensive typing that helps against foes such as Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Kingambit. Mold Breaker lets Mega Gyarados break through foes such as Tera Fairy Gastrodon and Skeledirge, the latter being a troublesome foe for teammates such as Dragonite and Dragapult. Substitute allows Mega Gyarados to avoid status from foes such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W while also avoiding revenge killers such as Tapu Lele and Kartana. Alternatively, Earthquake lets Mega Gyarados break through Toxapex and Rotom-W. Taunt can also be used to deny recovery, Haze, and Iron Defense from Toxapex and Skarmory, though it is generally not preferred since it leaves Mega Gyarados vulnerable to Scald burns and revenge killers such as Tapu Lele. Mega Gyarados appreciates dual screen support from Tapu Koko, which allows it to set up more easily. In return, Mega Gyarados can pivot into Ground-type attacks from foes such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Mega Gyarados struggles against physical walls such as Skarmory, Ferrothorn, and Buzzwole, so it appreciates teammates such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant handling them. Entry hazard support from teammates such as Landorus-T and Glimmora helps weaken defensive foes such as Tangrowth and Tera Water Landorus-T for Mega Gyarados. Teammates such as Dragonite also appreciate Mega Gyarados weakening defensive foes such as Skeledirge and Ferrothorn so it can clean late-game.

Defensive Dragon Dance (Flying).description:
Outspeeds Great Tusk at +1, OHKO'es Flutter Mane with Waterfall at +1, 3HKO'ed by Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Rocky Helmet.description:
• Gyarados utilizes its unique typing alongside Rocky Helmet to cushion physical sweepers such as Scizor, Great Tusk and Palafin.

  • Taunt: Taunt forces foes such as Corviknight and Dondozo to attack Gyarados, constraining them to take Rocky Helmet chip while often dealing minimal damage themselves.

  • Waterfall versus Iron Head: Waterfall provides Gyarados with a reliable STAB move, but Iron Head works better with Thunder Wave thanks to its higher flinch chance. They can be run together, though usually at the cost of overall coverage.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake checks several common Gyarados switch-ins, such as Iron Hands and Magnezone.

  • Ice Fang: Ice Fang hits bulky Dragon-types such as Dragonite that otherwise can withstand attacks from Gyarados.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave combined with flinch moves like Waterfall and Iron Head can shut down foes for several turns at a time. It can also catch foes switching into Gyarados, though keep in mind that many prominent Gyarados checks are naturally immune.

  • EV Spread: This spread allows Gyarados to survive two unboosted Moonblasts from Flutter Mane and minimizes Stealth Rock chip. The Speed investment outspeeds 4 Speed Rotom formes and, when using Thunder Wave, outspeeds paralyzed Speed-boosting nature Dragapult.

Other Options

  • Dragon Dance: Rocky Helmet sets can still opt to utilize Dragon Dance for more offensive presence, but this usually involves cutting bulk to invest in Attack and Speed.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Gyarados has uses for Terastallization, losing its unique defensive typing jeopardizes its Rocky Helmet niche and makes it much harder to check its key targets. Terastallization must be timed properly if Gyarados is to get proper value out of it.

  • Steel: Tera Steel powers up Iron Head to more serviceable levels and makes it easier to OHKO bulky Flutter Mane.

  • Ground: Tera Ground prevents Gyarados from getting dismantled by its 4x Electric-type weakness and provides a sizable power boost to Earthquake.

Choice Scarf Revenge Killer.description:
Thanks to Ditto's signature ability Imposter, which also copies enemy stat changes, Ditto is one of the best revenge killers in the tier. Ditto's presence alone scares off sweepers like Baxcalibur and Azumarill from setting up. Ditto does not copy the enemy HP stat, so 248 HP EVs are used to minimize damage taken from entry hazards before transforming while maximizing Ditto's HP stat, as well as allowing Ditto to use Struggle 4 times before it faints. 252 Defense EVs minimize the damage Ditto takes from opposing Ditto in the extremely rare mirror matchup. Finally, a Relaxed nature coupled with 0 Speed IVs guarantees that Imposter will never activate first, which ensures that Ditto will have more Transform PP in the aforementioned mirror match.

Ursaluna is a great teammate for Ditto, as it can switch into walls and begin applying immediate pressure. Ditto also appreciates Ursaluna's unrivaled ability to punch holes in the opposing team, making a late-game Ditto sweep much easier. If Ditto copies certain targets like Chien-Pao and a majority of the opposing team is weakened, Ditto can win the game. Indeedee is a good teammate for Ditto, as its Psychic Surge ability prevents Ditto from being picked off by priority moves. Blissey is a nice partner for Ditto, as it can absorb status moves that would otherwise cripple Ditto and then shrug them off via Natural Cure. Blissey can also use Thunder Wave to slow down opposing Choice Scarf users that would otherwise Speed tie with Ditto such as Meowscarada and Enamorus Choice Specs Hisuian Zoroark is a powerful teammate that pairs well with Ditto, as Ditto can copy the stat boosts from setup sweepers that aim to take advantage of a Choice-locked Hisuian Zoroark. Cyclizar can be used to remove entry hazards so that Ditto can switch in frequently without getting chipped. Additionally, it is able to keep hazards away and use Shed Tail to bring Ditto in behind a Substitute and make it even more threatening. Maushold can use its high speed tier to lock Bulk Up users like Landorus-Therian that would otherwise be able to stall out Ditto. Additionally, Maushold is able to break down walls due to the sheer power of Population Bomb. Pivots are great teammates for Ditto because they can lure in targets for Ditto to copy. Choice Scarf Staraptor and Defensive Braviary are solid picks, as they can use U-turn to go right into Ditto. Braviary is also capable of using Defog to keep Ditto alive for longer.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Revenge Killer.description:
• Ditto is widely hailed as the best revenge killer and finds a small niche with a Choice Scarf.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Ditto rarely needs to Terastallize unless it is being threatened by Dragon Dance Dragonite's Extreme Speed at +3.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Ditto immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed, preventing it from defeating Ditto after three Dragon Dances.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: The safest option, Choice Scarf guarantees that Ditto will always outspeed the foe unless said foe is holding a Choice Scarf.
  • Focus Sash: A high-risk yet high-reward option, Focus Sash allows Ditto to switch moves at the cost of being nullified by entry hazards. However, it should be noted that Imposter doesn't copy Protosynthesis or Quark Drive boosts, making Focus Sash a lot less niche, as it allows Ditto to beat foes such as Flutter Mane more consistently assuming the field is clear of hazards.

EV Spreads

  • Effort Values: The given EVs maximize Ditto's bulk in the rare case of a mirror matchup.
  • Individual Values: 0 Speed IVs and a minus Speed nature is key to beating opposing Ditto, as the Ditto that moves last on the fourth turn will win the mirror.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Ditto is a niche revenge killer that can also be used to attempt a reverse sweep, but it must be wary of threats that may counter it with a surprise Terastallization, such as Tera Fairy Miraidon, Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Ice Iron Bundle, and Tera Water Gholdengo.
  • Ditto doesn't add much value to teams on its own outside of helping overwhelm opposing checks. It is also strongly prediction reliant.
  • Maximum bulk and minimum Speed allow Ditto to force opposing Ditto to trigger Imposter first and run out of PP quicker.
  • Tera Fairy defeats Choice Scarf Miraidon, Koraidon, and Walking Wake that may try to attack it with a Dragon-type move.
  • Ditto is rarely a reliable check for reasons explained earlier, so it appreciates support from backup checks, especially for potent threats that it fails to revenge kill such as Swords Dance Chien-Pao, Double Dance Miraidon, and Bulk Up Great Tusk. Thus, teammates like Toxapex, Skeledirge, Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Iron Treads are good picks.
  • Ditto's ability to revenge kill many strong threats makes teambuilding flexible, allowing offensive Pokemon like Miraidon, Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Koraidon to fit more easily.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

Imposter.description: Tera Steel makes Ditto immune to Toxic Spikes and take less from Stealth Rock. It also lets Ditto revenge kill Belly Drum Hariyama. A Quiet nature and the Special Attack investment is in case Ditto transforms into a Future Sight user like Slowbro.

Scarf Imposter.description: Ditto solidifies itself to once again be the goo that holds balanced and offensive Normal teams together thanks to its incredibly strong ability in Imposter. Reversing the momentum of fast offensive threats such as Iron Valiant, Mega Charizard X, and Excadrill allows Ditto to force counterplay against offensive teams. Ditto can also take advantage of entry hazard setters and removers, such as Ferrothorn, Kleavor, and Zapdos, using their own longevity or utility against them. In order to take advantage of Pokémon that use either Return or Frustration, such as Mega Altaria or Mega Pinsir, Ditto likes to run 128 Happiness instead of 252 or 0. Walls like Blissey and Porygon2 appreciate Ditto being able to prevent threats such as Baxcalibur and Spectrier from using them as setup fodder, while Ditto appreciates both defensive switch-ins and slow pivots via their use of Teleport. Mega Lopunny is a staple on Normal teams that accents Ditto's role expertly; many of the offensive threats and setup sweepers that revenge kill Mega Lopunny, such as Mega Charizard X, Kommo-o, and Galarian Moltres, are usually very weak to their own sets or coverage. Mega Lopunny can lure a threat in and pivot with U-turn, allowing Ditto to come in safely and transform. Ditto appreciates Mega Lopunny's Speed tier and fast pivot with U-turn, as well as potentially setting up Ditto with Encore Sets to stop foes from using Substitute or setting up completely. Hisuian Zoroark makes for another stellar teammate for Ditto, as Hisuian Zoroark disguised as a passive Pokemon, such as Blissey, or another offensive threat, such as Diggersby or Mega Lopunny, can lead to Hisuian Zoroark wallbreaking and netting KOs on vital foes, making it easier for Ditto to sweep once it has transformed. While Ditto is immune to Sticky Web, it is susceptible to other hazards such as Stealth Rock and Toxic Spikes, so forms of hazard control such as Staraptor or Cyclizar are appreciated. Staraptor is another defensive option, while Cyclizar can enable Ditto to utilize Transform with a Substitute from Shed Tail. Smeargle on more offense-oriented teams' pairs well with Ditto, as Smeargle can set hazards with Stone Axe or Ceaseless Edge and spread status with Nuzzle, Mortal Spin, or Spore, allowing Ditto to exploit the opposing team easier. Smeargle will usually give up Sticky Web when paired with Ditto so as to not hinder Ditto's revenge killing prowess.

Choice Scarf.description:
248 HP EVs ensure that Ditto will be able to use Struggle four times before fainting, and 252 Defense EVs minimize Struggle damage from an opposing Ditto. The minimum possible Speed allows Imposter to not activate first and therefore allow Ditto to have more Transform PP.

This is a sample set, stay tuned for future updates!

Calm Mind Sweeper.description:
The fastest Pokemon available in the tier, Jolteon is an amazing setup sweeper thanks to Calm Mind and its great coverage found through Terastallization. Volt Switch whittles down special walls like Copperajah and Goodra while safely bringing in a teammate better suited to taking them on such as Paldean Tauros-F or Bronzong. Tera Blast Fairy hits Goodra hard and makes Jolteon more resistant to Choice Scarf Fighting-types like Heracross and Passimian. Alternatively, Tera Blast Ice gives Jolteon a move to hit Ground- and Grass-types like Gligar, Sandaconda, and Arboliva super effectively.

Jolteon is quite frail, making it vulnerable to revenge killing from Choice Scarf users like Passimian, Bruxish, and Heracross. Physical walls like Gligar and Altaria help check them while also supplying Jolteon's team with utility like entry hazards and Defog. Jolteon also needs help with special walls like Copperajah, Goodra, and Bronzong, which require chip damage to be defeated. Use wallbreakers like Shaymin and Tatsugiri to weaken such foes.

Offensive.description: Mega Aerodactyl's unrivalled Speed tier, attacking prowess, and decent defensive profile make it a great all-around offensive threat in the metagame, outpacing and forcing out a huge portion of faster threats, such as Cinderace, Ceruledge, Galarian Moltres, and Enamorus lacking Choice Scarf. Earthquake provides Mega Aerodactyl with perfect neutral coverage, hitting Rock-resistant Pokemon as well as targets that are weak to it, such as Tyranitar, Zeraora, and Bisharp, allowing Mega Aerodactyl to threaten them. Dual Wingbeat provides a secondary STAB option that ensures Mega Aerodactyl hits important targets such as Buzzwole, Mega Venusaur, and Amoonguss super effectively. Taunt can be used instead to deny the likes of bulkier targets, such as Clefable, Skarmory, and Hippowdon, from accessing their healing moves, on top of shutting down setup options from specific setup sweepers, such as Mega Latias. Mega Aerodactyl can even serve as an effective Pursuit trapper; with the Tough Claws boost, it makes for an effective option to use against the likes of Iron Moth, Latios, and Alakazam. Roost is mandatory in the last slot to offset Mega Aerodactyl's Stealth Rock weakness while also allowing it to repeatedly switch into foes such as Cinderace and Iron Moth, resisting most of their attacks in the process. Mega Aerodactyl fits best on bulky offense and balance teams in need of an offensive backbone with solid secondary defensive applications. Bulkier Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Clefable, and Rotom-W appreciate Mega Aerodactyl's ability to relieve pressure in dealing with offensive threats which they may be overwhelmed by, such as Cinderace and Enamorus. In return, the former two provide hazard support to help Mega Aerodactyl secure damage rolls against Pokemon it would otherwise miss out on, such as against Autotomize Celesteela with Stone Edge and Mega Tyranitar with Earthquake, whereas the latter provides additional pivoting support, hazard removal in Defog to offset Mega Aerodactyl’s weakness to Stealth Rock, and the ability to take on several setup sweepers which it struggles to take on, such as Sand Rush Excadrill and Swords Dance Scizor. Similarly, other Pokemon that can remove entry hazards, such as Excadrill and Mandibuzz, are effective at ensuring Mega Aerodactyl isn’t being dug into by Stealth Rock. On the other hand, offensive Pokemon such as Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, Nasty Plot Hydreigon, and Tapu Bulu can benefit from Mega Aerodactyl's ability to check or remove faster Pokemon which they may be dissuaded by, such as Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Keldeo. Mega Aerodactyl's ability to force in defensive Pokemon can also lead to some interesting synergies with other offensive Pokemon, particularly when carrying Taunt; setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Enamorus, Bulk Up Buzzwole, and Swords Dance Iron Hands each benefit from Mega Aerodactyl's ability to lure in and weaken walls such as Skarmory, Tapu Fini, Slowbro, and Mega Venusaur.

Dragon Dance.description: Dragon Dance turns Mega Aerodactyl into a threatening sweeper, leveraging its combination of power, Speed, and coverage to great effect. It particularly preys on faster teams that over-rely on using faster speed control options to check most sweepers, such as Choice Scarf users Galarian Zapdos and Keldeo. Earthquake nails several Ground-weak targets in Excadrill, Tyranitar, and Bisharp after a Dragon Dance, OHKOing the latter. Dual Wingbeat, especially with the boost from Tough Claws, flattens many neutral targets after a Dragon Dance, such as Clefable, Slowking, Gastrodon, and Mega Latias, while also allowing it to beat walls such as Buzzwole and Tangrowth. Alternatively, Mega Aerodactyl can run Roost in the last slot to offset its lack of longevity, potentially grabbing multiple setup opportunities against weaker Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Clefable lacking Thunder Wave. Due to its offensive prowess, this Mega Aerodactyl set fits best on fast-paced teams as an effective mid-to-late game cleaner. Early-game wallbreakers such as Ceruledge and Iron Hands can help Mega Aerodactyl by opening up gaps in the opposition through their numerous offensive applications against walls which the latter may find itself being stopped by, such as Slowbro, Scizor, and Iron Defense Skarmory. Conversely, Mega Aerodactyl’s tendency to find opportunities against specific targets such as Ting-Lu and Mega Venusaur can also work to the benefit of other late-game cleaners, such as Booster Energy Iron Moth and Weakness Policy Latios. As Mega Aerodactyl often finds itself leveraging its bulk to make the most of its setup capabilities, teammates that can prevent entry hazards from going up, such as Taunt Mew, Excadrill, and Tapu Fini, make for excellent partners. Mega Aerodactyl also benefits from entry hazard support provided by the former two, as well as others like Spikes Sandy Shocks, which help it secure OHKOs against Pokemon such as Hydreigon after a Dragon Dance.

Offensive (Flying).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned

Curse.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defensive.description:
48 Speed EVs lets Articuno outspeed Modest Clawitzer. If slow pivoting is more desirable, though, Articuno can forgo Speed investment and instead bolster its bulk. Tera Dragon gives Articuno key resistances to Fire, Electric, and Water, thus allowing it to take on threats like Charizard, Rotom, and Floatzel. Tera Steel gives Farigiraf a much harder time overwhelming Articuno. Tera Fairy can also be used to check Fighting- and Dark-types like Passimian and Morpeko.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Special Wall.description:
Articuno solidifies itself as a top tier special wall in NU, thanks to its ability to take on scary wallbreakers such as Abomasnow, Clawitzer, and Appletun that can tear through slower teams. Haze helps stop setup sweepers like Farigiraf, Mesprit, and Lilligant, but Hurricane can be used to hit Pokemon like Appletun, Abomasnow, and Cryogonal harder while also helping against Fighting-types such as Hiusian Sneasel and Toxicroak in a pinch. U-turn lets Articuno pivot on incoming Ice-resistant foes like Magneton and Cryogonal while also generating momentum for offensive teammates on the switches Articuno can force against the bevy of Grass-, Water-, and Fighting-types in the tier. The given EV spread allows Articuno to outspeed maximum Speed Cacturne and Ursaring while maintaining as much special bulk as possible. Tera Ground gifts an Electric-type immunity, letting Articuno easily handle Rotom and Eelektross, and it gets a Stealth Rock resistance, which helps Articuno if it gets hit by a Knock Off; Tera Steel helps against setup sweepers such as Mesprit, Lilligant, and Farigiraf so that Articuno can use Haze without fear of being OHKOed; and Tera Fairy can be used to take care of Fighting-types which overwhelm it otherwise with their powerful STAB moves.

Articuno easily falters in the face of physical wallbreakers like Mabosstiff, Medicham, and Tauros, so Pokemon like Sandaconda, Sableye, and Mesprit to check them pair well with Articuno as they love a partner to tank special attacks. Electric-types like Magneton, Eelektross, and Rotom tend to overpower Articuno; therefore, partners like Appletun, Lurantis, and Eelektross pair well alongside it. Item displacement from Knock Off or Trick is very detrimental for Articuno’s longevity. To combat this, Knock Off absorbers like Sandaconda and Sticky Hold Muk work well to help it. Entry hazard support from Hattrem, Drifblim, and Lurantis also helps Articuno if it happens to lose its item. Wallbreakers such as Samurott, Bruxish, and Pyroar work well alongside Articuno, as it can take care of their checks like Cacturne, Appletun, and Qwilfish. Because Articuno beats Ground- and Grass-types, Electric-types pair well as partners, as they can create a VoltTurn core and whittle down each other’s checks.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Flying

Hurricane can be used over Substitute or U-turn as a way to make Articuno more threatening against foes such as Iron Valiant, Iron Defense Zamazenta, and Abomasnow; however, it has poor accuracy and using it foregoes the generally greater utility of these two moves. An alternative EV spread of 240 HP / 84 SpD / 184 Spe allows Articuno to outspeed maximum Speed Pelipper, Frosmoth, and Hisuian Braviary while still avoiding a 2HKO from Choice Specs Greninja.

Specially Defensive (Flying).description:
Articuno has carved itself an important position in Flying’s roster as the type’s premier special wall and Ice Beam sponge, serving as a bulwark against key foes such as Choice Specs Greninja, Choice Specs Dragapult, Calm Mind Ursaluna-B, Frosmoth, and Nasty Plot Slowbro, which are otherwise extremely threatening to Flying teams. Freeze-Dry is the only offensive move Articuno needs, pressuring many crucial targets throughout the metagame such as both Landorus formes, Toxapex, Quagsire, Ogerpon-W, Manaphy, and Enamorus. Aside from hitting Water-types for super effective damage, Freeze-Dry is also particularly useful on this relatively passive set due to its high 32 PP. This allows Articuno to stay threatening over longer games despite only using one attacking move as well as repeatedly fish for freezes against neutral targets such as Hatterene and Galarian Weezing. Substitute blocks Toxic from Toxapex, Quagsire, Clodsire, and Mandibuzz, allowing Articuno to duel these Pokemon and come out on top. Furthermore, Substitute combined with Roost and Pressure allows Articuno to stall out foes such as Frosmoth and Ursaluna-B, draining their PP so Articuno’s teammates can come in and take advantage of them. As an alternative to Substitute, U-turn can be used to make Articuno less passive and safely bring in teammates against faster foes, which is especially beneficial for teammates such as Choice Band Dragonite and Galarian Moltres. Haze rounds out this set by preventing Articuno from becoming setup fodder against foes such as Sinistcha, Ursaluna-B, Manaphy, and Hatterene. Furthermore, Haze can be used to neutralize Belly Drum Azumarill’s boosts, as with these EVs Articuno will always outspeed it and survive a +6 Aqua Jet from full HP. The given EVs allow Articuno to outrun uninvested Landorus-T, Adamant Torterra, and maximum Speed Azumarill while maximizing special bulk.

Gliscor is an excellent partner to Articuno, nullifying Electric-type attacks and Toxic aimed at Articuno, absorbing Knock Off to prevent the removal of Articuno’s Heavy-Duty Boots, and threatening Steel-types such as Heatran and Hisuian Goodra with its STAB Earthquake. In exchange, Gliscor appreciates Articuno taking Ice Beam from threats such as Greninja and handling Water-types such as Walking Wake and Manaphy. Alternatively, physically defensive Landorus-T complements Articuno by threatening Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Kleavor and absorbing Electric-type hits while forming a defensive core with it. Landorus-T similarly appreciates Articuno taking on foes such as Frosmoth and Ogerpon-W while being offensively threatening against Steel- and Fire-types that wall Articuno such as Empoleon, Ceruledge, and Hisuian Arcanine. Physically defensive Corviknight is another teammate that forms a defensive core with Articuno, serving as a check to many physical sweepers that would otherwise take advantage of it, such as Scizor, Baxcalibur, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit, especially if running Iron Defense. Moreover, Corviknight can block Toxic aimed at Articuno and clear Stealth Rock using Defog in the event that Articuno has its item removed. In return, Articuno can deal with various special threats that would threaten or take advantage of Corviknight, such as Choice Specs Dragapult, Manaphy, and Slowbro. The combination of Articuno, Corviknight, and specially defensive Gliscor also allows Flying to safely handle all standard variants of Flutter Mane, which is of great use due to how threatening this Pokemon can be to Flying teams if left unchecked. Moltres pairs nicely with Articuno, checking various physical threats such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Ogerpon-H, while Articuno answers Water-types for it. Zapdos and Thundurus-T can take out barriers to Articuno such as Empoleon and Corviknight with their Electric-type STAB moves; physically defensive Zapdos using Heat Wave can also answer Iron Treads and compounds nicely with Articuno’s special walling capabilities and neutrality to Ice. Setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragonite, Galarian Moltres, and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T enjoy Articuno removing impediments to their sweeping such as Quagsire, Clodsire, Slowbro, and Amoonguss. Choice Scarf Enamorus supports Articuno by revenge killing foes such as Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and both Urshifu formes, and can use Healing Wish to cure Articuno’s status condition and bring it back to full HP in a pinch. Galarian Zapdos is an alternative Choice Scarf user that also hits the aforementioned targets while lacking a Stealth Rock weakness, possessing the ability to pivot with U-turn, and being more useful against types such as Bug. Physically defensive Gyarados can also aid Articuno by serving as a response to sweepers like Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Dragonite; to return the favor, Articuno deals with Quagsire and Clodsire. It should be noted that this is by no means an exhaustive list of potential teammates for Articuno, as virtually every Flying option appreciates it soaking up Ice Beams and walling special threats.

Choice Specs (Electric).description:
Choice Specs Zapdos is a potent wallbreaker for Electric teams, being able to threaten Pokemon that give its teammates a hard time such as Great Tusk, Gastrodon, specially defensive Iron Treads, and Landorus-T. Aside from that, its Flying typing provides Electric teams an immunity to Ground and a resistance to Fighting. Hurricane is Zapdos's strongest STAB move, being able to OHKO Sableye, Amoonguss, and possibly Quagsire, and also being able to 2HKO physically defensive Skeledirge and Ursaluna. Zapdos can also take advantage of matchups against rain teams by being able to spam Hurricane without fear of missing. Volt Switch allows Zapdos to bring in teammates safely against special walls like Assault Vest Iron Hands, Assault Vest Galarian Slowking, and Heatran. Heat Wave provides Zapdos great coverage, allowing it to 2HKO Magnezone, as well as Klefki under Light Screen and Iron Treads. Static has a chance to paralyze Pokemon that make contact with Zapdos such as Dragonite and Mimikyu.

Sandy Shocks makes for a great partner, being able to provide entry hazard support with both Stealth Rock and Spikes, as well as being able to threaten Heatran with Earth Power. Regieleki is another great partner, as it is able to remove hazards with Rapid Spin so that Zapdos can switch in more often without losing a good amount of its health to Stealth Rock. It is also able to outspeed Pokemon that outspeed Zapdos such as Flutter Mane and non-Choice Scarf Greninja. Pokemon with great special bulk such as Assault Vest Galarian Slowking and Tyranitar can be tough for Zapdos, with the latter being able to threaten it with Stone Edge. Hence, Iron Hands pairs well with Zapdos, as it is able to threaten Galarian Slowking with Earthquake and Tyranitar with Drain Punch. In return, Zapdos can switch into anticipated Ground-type attacks from the likes of Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Magnezone is another great partner, being able to threaten Hatterene and Flutter Mane, as well as potentially winning the Chien-Pao matchup. Lastly, Zapdos's wallbreaking opens up sweeping opportunities for fast sweepers such as Nasty Plot Rotom-W and Choice Scarf Pawmot. Both of them can beat Landorus-T with Hydro Pump and Ice Punch, respectively, and Pawmot has the added merit of potentially reviving Zapdos with Revival Blessing.

SubRoost (Electric).description:
Substitute isnt broken by Toxapex's moves. 100 SpA EVs may be considered to increase bulk and always OHKO Urshifu-R.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defensive.description: Leveraging an incredible ability in Static accompanied by a powerful Volt Switch and Hurricane, Zapdos serves as a stellar defensive pivot. Zapdos effectively switches into physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, Kartana, and Great Tusk, discouraging them from attacking by threatening a chance of paralysis. Zapdos can Volt Switch out as it pleases because of common Ground-types like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and the aforementioned Great Tusk fearing its powerful Hurricane. Hidden Power Ice can be used to threaten Ground-types like the aforementioned Landorus-T and Garchomp while additionally hitting Gliscor harder and much more reliably than Hurricane. Carrying Heat Wave is recommended with Hidden Power Ice to maintain the ability to OHKO Kartana. These positive matchups into many Ground-types allow Zapdos to serve as a solid Defog user, but it struggles to beat bulkier Stealth Rock users such as Heatran, Mega Tyranitar, and Clodsire. Alternatively, Zapdos can forgo Defog for Heat Wave, allowing it to threaten Pokemon such as Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo. Tera Steel is utilized by Zapdos to flip its Rock- and Ice-type weaknesses versus Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar, Weavile, and Mega Diancie as well as check Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele in a pinch. However, it becomes weak to common Ground- and Fighting-type moves from Pokemon it wants to check. Tera Dragon is a alternative option to check Ogerpon-W and Urshifu-R in a pinch, and allow Zapdos to pivot or land a Hurricane on the aforementioned two. Teammates that appreciate the spread of paralysis, such as Mega Medicham, Urshifu-R, and Weavile, naturally pair well with Zapdos. Mega Medicham particularly pairs nicely with it, as Mega Medicham threatens Clodsire while enjoying Zapdos pivoting it into favorable matchups such as Heatran, with Zapdos punishing Tornadus-T and Mega Lopunny looking to revenge kill Mega Medicham in return. Pursuit users like Kingambit and the aforementioned Weavile are useful teammates to assist in chipping down Clodsire as well as punishing Dragapult. Rock-types like Mega Diancie and Mega Tyranitar threaten Zapdos, so teammates that mitigate these weaknesses, like Hippowdon and Gastrodon, are appreciated.

Offensive.description: Zapdos serves as a powerful wallbreaker while also sporting solid bulk in conjunction with Static to threaten common revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. In rain, it becomes even stronger, boasting a Water-type Weather Ball to threaten Gliscor, Garganacl, and Landorus-T and more accurate Thunder and Hurricane. Volt Switch allows Zapdos to freely pivot while doing very good damage, especially due to common Ground-types like Landorus-T and Great Tusk being greatly threatened by Hurricane. Hidden Power Ice allows Zapdos to hit Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Gliscor for massive damage. Heat Wave is used to surprise Ferrothorn trying to come in on a Thunderbolt or Hurricane as well as consistently threaten Mega Scizor. Flyinium Z allows Zapdos to KO chipped defensive Pokemon that would otherwise be out of range of a Hurricane. If Zapdos is not using Flyinium Z, then it can Tera Flying for stronger Hurricanes. Pokemon like Iron Boulder appreciate offensive Zapdos, as it can rack up chip damage on Pokemon that would otherwise annoy Iron Boulder, such as Garganacl, Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Ferrothorn. For rain teams, Zapdos can do good chunks of damage to Pokemon rain teams would otherwise struggle to break, such as Rotom-W and Ferrothorn. Galarian Slowking can comfortably take any of Zapdos's moves, and then set up a Future Sight, threaten to poison with Sludge Bomb, or pivot out into an offensive check with Chilly Reception. However, if Galarian Slowking is predicted to switch in, then Volt Switch can be used to gain momentum, allowing Zapdos to switch into something that can threatens Galarian Slowking like Great Tusk, Landorus-T, or Gliscor. Bulky Pokemon that resist one of Zapdos's STAB moves and then threaten Zapdos, like Heatran, Landorus-T, and Gliscor, can prove to be annoying. To help with this, Zapdos appreciates having teammates such as Gliscor and Ferrothorn.

Defensive.description: Zapdos serves as a valuable defensive pivot, checking many of the tier's physical wallbreakers and pivots like Dragonite, Great Tusk, and its Galarian counterpart. Discharge's nasty paralysis chance further increases the utility Zapdos provides and cripples switch-ins like Blissey and Hisuian Goodra. Heat Wave is an option over Hurricane to hit Iron Treads and Volt Absorb Corviknight while 2HKOing non-Well-Baked Body Kingambit. U-turn allows Zapdos to switch in on the aforementioned physical threats and pivot out to a wallbreaker that threatens them. Intimidate is an option to weaken hits even after Zapdos switches out and also allow it to act as a check to Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge. 108 Speed EVs notably allow it to outspeed Timid Volcanion and Adamant Slither Wing. Zapdos's inability to check Ice-types like Mamoswine and Chien-Pao and tendency to get worn down quickly makes other physical walls like Corviknight and Quaquaval great partners that can additionally switch into Knock Off from the likes of Great Tusk and Roaring Moon. Wallbreakers and pivots like Ogerpon-C, Azelf, and Barraskewda appreciate Zapdos's ability to switch into revenge killers like Roaring Moon, Choice Scarf Meowscarada, and opposing Barraskewda and pivot out, generating momentum for the team. If Zapdos is using Fluffy, a sturdy Fire-type check like Quaquaval or physically defensive Garchomp, which can switch into Pokemon like Cinderace and Ceruledge, pairs well with it.

No Guard.description: No Guard Zapdos is a potent offensive pivot that can reliably spread status with Zap Cannon. U-turn allows Zapdos to pivot while also gaining momentum for its team and can form a VoltTurn core with pivots such as Azelf and Barraskewda, although Heat Wave can be used instead to hit Steel-types such as Iron Treads and non-Well-Baked Body Kingambit. Pivots such as Roaring Moon, Iron Moth, and Meowscarada form a strong pivoting core with Zapdos, as Zapdos baits in Hisuian Goodra and Volt Absorb Empoleon allowing for free switch-in opportunities for these allies. Physical wallbreakers such as Great Tusk and Barraskewda are notable partners for Zapdos, as Zapdos threatens out Corviknight and Kommo-o while pivoting these teammates into Zapdos's checks such as Hisuian Goodra and Heatran, putting the opponent in a unfavorable position. Slow wallbreakers such as Great Tusk and Ceruledge benefit from Zapdos using Zap Cannon to paralyze opposing Pokemon. Slow pivots such as Corviknight switch in on strong offensive threats that Zapdos is scared of such as Ogerpon-C and Chien-Pao while providing Zapdos switch-in opportunities via U-turn. Zapdos struggles against strong special walls such as Garchomp and Volt Absorb Empoleon, so Pokemon that can threaten them out such as Great Tusk make excellent partners.

Choice Specs (Electric).description: With Choice Specs equipped, Zapdos's already amazing Special Attack is boosted to even greater heights, turning it into an incredible wallbreaker. Its Flying typing also grants an invaluable Ground immunity for Electric teams. Hurricane is Zapdos's most powerful move, threatening a variety of Pokemon that resist or are immune to Electric such as Mega Venusaur and Gastrodon. Heat Wave beats Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Iron Treads, and Ferrothorn, thus making it an incredible asset in the Steel and Grass matchups. Hidden Power Ice cleanly OHKOes Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Garchomp; alternatively, Hidden Power Grass can be used if reliably eliminating Gastrodon and Swampert is more important. Volt Switch lets Zapdos switch out of its checks like Tyranitar and Blissey, keeping momentum in favor of Zapdos's team. As dangerous as Zapdos is, it is highly susceptible to Stealth Rock; hence, Rotom-W is a great partner that can use Defog while also helping Zapdos beat Ground-types thanks to Hydro Pump. Iron Hands and Zeraora help Zapdos wallbreak by wearing down special walls like Heatran, Blissey, and Clodsire. Regieleki and Alolan Raichu can take advantage of Zapdos weakening teams and removing Ground-types so that they can clean up with their deadly Rising Voltage later in the game.
