Thanks to the sheer power of Tera Normal Extreme Speed, Dragonite is one of DOU’s biggest threats, threatening to KO a large portion of the metagame. Dragonite also has excellent coverage, allowing it to hit any Pokémon that aren't afraid of Extreme Speed, such as Gholdengo and Iron Treads. Dragonite’s Dragon/Flying allows it to take attacks such as Chi-Yu's Heat Wave and Palafin's Jet Punch while also granting it immunity to Earthquakes from Garchomp and Great Tusk. Tera Normal also allows it to survive threatening Dragon- and Ice-type attacks. Inner Focus lets Dragonite avoid Attack drops from Intimidate and flinches Fake Out. Dragonite is most commonly paired with Chien-Pao, as Sword of Ruin lowers the Defense of foes, allowing Extreme Speed to deal more damage. This pairing is preferred by offensive teams but can fit on other archetypes that desire power and priority. Due to Dragonite's heavy dependence on Extreme Speed, Pokemon that can block priority moves such as Farigiraf, Tsareena, and Indeedee-F limit its effectiveness. Dragonite also struggles against Pokémon with high physical bulk that can take an Extreme Speed and threaten it in return such as Great Tusk, Iron Hands, Amoonguss, and Garganacl. Additionally, Dragonite is greatly hindered by Stealth Rock, which nullifies Multiscale and limits its longevity.

their changes
doublesou.comments:
Other Options

  • Life Orb can be used on offensive teams that need Dragonite to be capable of switching moves while still dealing lots of damage.
  • A mixed Life Orb set with Hurricane is a viable set on rain teams. Life Orb or Sharp Beak allows Dragonite to threaten an OHKO on Amoonguss.
  • Iron Head Dragonite is useful on teams that want increased damage against Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl and Sylveon.
  • Running an Assault Vest on Dragonite gives it more bulk and allows it to switch between moves at the cost of decreasing its offensive presence.
  • Weakness Policy Tailwind Dragonite can use Multiscale to tank a hit and leverage speed control while dealing increased damage.

Choice Band.description:
• Extreme Speed allows Dragonite to KO opposing priority users such as Murkrow and Palafin before they can move.
  • Dragon Claw gives Dragonite a strong STAB move in positions where using Extreme Speed is undesirable. It also threatens an OHKO on opposing Dragonite and Garchomp.
  • Ice Spinner allows Dragonite to remove the priority-blocking Psychic Terrain, threaten an OHKO on opposing Dragonite and Garchomp, and hit the many Ground-types in the tier super effectively.
  • Alternatively, Facade allows Dragonite to avoid the damage reduction from being burned and is boosted by Tera Normal.
  • One of Fire Punch, Stomping Tantrum, or Earthquake is wanted to damage Steel-types. Fire Punch allows Dragonite to hit Grass- and Ice-types such as Amoonguss, Abomasnow, and Chien-Pao, while Earthquake allows it to hit Rock-, Electric-, and Fire-type Pokemon such as Glimmora, Iron Hands, and Armarouge. Earthquake is most useful on teams with teammates that are immune to Ground-type attacks.
  • The given EV spread maximizes Dragonite's damage and bulk, as it does not need to invest in Speed thanks to Extreme Speed's priority.
  • Multiscale can be used over Inner Focus on teams that want additional bulk and have a method of entry hazard removal.
  • Choice Band lets Dragonite focus on spamming Extreme Speed and boosts its damage immensely.

Dragon Dance (Flying).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Nasty Plot.description:
• Mewtwo is a niche wallbreaker by courtesy of its access to Nasty Plot and usable Speed stat letting it outspeed Pokemon like Arceus and most Eternatus variants. Its ability to dismantle common defensive Pokemon, like most Arceus formes, and discourage Pokemon like Zacian-C from switching in, makes it a very hard Pokemon to deal with defensively.
  • However, Mewtwo's Speed stat leaves it outsped by common Pokemon like Zacian-C, Koraidon, Miraidon, and Flutter Mane, all of which can heavily damage, if not outright OHKO, it.
  • Grass Knot hits Mewtwo's biggest roadblock in Ting-Lu for massive damage.
  • Flamethrower retains the hit on Zacian-C and Tera Steel Clodsire for big damage while also damaging other Tera Steel Pokemon like Giratina-O.
  • Taunt allows Mewtwo to stop Defog attempts from the likes of Giratina-O and Corviknight while also denying recovery attempts from Skeledirge and Arceus formes. Moreover, Taunt also permits Mewtwo to antilead Ribombee and deny its Sticky Web, being one of the few Pokemon that can accomplish this without losing an important chunk of HP in the process.
  • Earth Power can be used instead to greatly damage Zacian-C, Skeledirge, and tera Steel Pokemon like Clodsire.
  • Tera Steel allows Mewtwo to resist both of Zacian-C's STAB moves while also resisting Extreme Killer Arceus's Extreme Speed, which is particularly important, as Extreme Killer Arceus is a very common offensive answer to Mewtwo.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots allows Mewtwo to ignore entry hazards like Spikes and, most importantly, Toxic Spikes. Leftovers can be used instead as Mewtwo's only form of recovery. Lastly, Life Orb can be used to greatly increase Mewtwo's damage output, allowing it to have a favorable chance of OHKOing Ting-Lu after a Nasty Plot. A Modest nature can be used to ensure Mewtwo OHKOes Ting-Lu and Extreme Killer Arceus at +2 and works best on Sticky Web teams, as on them Mewtwo doesn't mind the loss in Speed and can break holes in teams more easily.
  • It is advised to get Mewtwo on the field via smart double switches or U-turn from teammates like Koraidon, as per its underwhelming defensive typing, it doesn't get many opportunities to freely switch in. Once in the field, Mewtwo should dish out as much damage as possible or use Nasty Plot to break important Pokemon, like Calm Mind Arceus formes. Against faster foes without pivoting moves like Zacian-C, Mewtwo can freely Terastallize into a Steel-type to resist both of its STAB moves and hit back hard with an Earth Power or Flamethrower.
  • Mewtwo struggles against faster foes, like Zacian-C, Koraidon, and Flutter Mane. Because of this, Pokemon like Landorus-T, Skeledirge, and Clodsire make for good partners. Landorus-T and Clodsire in particular help Mewtwo by spreading entry hazards, allowing it to net some KOs that it would normally miss, such as against Arceus-Steel, a Pokemon that now gets OHKOed by a +2 Flamethrower after a single layer of Spikes.

Choice Specs.description:
• Choice Specs Mewtwo is a strong and decently fast wallbreaker that crucially outspeeds Arceus. Its power and coverage give Mewtwo the ability to OHKO or 2HKO just about every Pokemon in the tier.
  • However, Mewtwo can easily be revenge killed by Miraidon and Koraidon, both of which outspeed and threaten a KO on it after Stealth Rock.
  • Psystrike capitalizes on the lack of Psychic-resistant foes, as even Zacian-C struggles to take more than two Psystrikes. It also helps against Calm Mind Arceus, especially Tera Poison variants.
  • Ice Beam hits Pokemon like Giratina-O and Tera Flying users like Zacian-C. Mewtwo can use Tera Fire to resist Tera Flying Zacian-C's STAB moves and OHKO it with Ice Beam after minimal chip damage.
  • Flamethrower hits Zacian-C and Tera Steel users. Koraidon's sun can ensure the OHKO on Zacian-C as well as 2HKO on max HP Arceus.
  • Grass Knot is mainly used for hitting Mewtwo's worst enemy, Ting-Lu. It also hits Arceus-Ground, Kyogre, and Groudon much harder than Ice Beam, potentially scoring OHKOes if they run more offensive spreads.
  • Tera Fire gives Mewtwo useful resistances against common revenge killing options like Koraidon's Flare Blitz and Zacian-C's STAB moves. If sun is active, Tera Fire Flamethrower can 2HKO bulky foes such as Clodsire and Koraidon.
  • Choice Specs Mewtwo's most important partner is Koraidon, usually with Choice Scarf. Koraidon helps power up Mewtwo's Flamethrower and lures in Mewtwo's favorite targets such as bulky Arceus formes and other physical checks.
  • Defensive partners like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Skeledirge, Gliscor, and Landorus-T are appreciated to check threats like Miraidon, Koraidon, and Zacian-C.
  • Miraidon and Calm Mind Arceus variants appreciate Mewtwo's effectiveness at breaking through specially bulky Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Iron Treads, and defensive Arceus formes.

Demon Mew (Double Dance).description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

Cosmic Power.description: Mew is a potent late-game wincon that can bolster its already impressive defensive profile with Cosmic Power, shrugging off most hits after a few boosts. Mew has near-perfect coverage with Stored Power and Body Press, with the latter able to crucially smash Steel- and Dark-types like Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile, which would otherwise exploit it. Covert Cloak is a must for Mew to avoid being worn down by Garganacl’s Salt Cure and help against being burned by Scald from the likes of Toxapex. Tera Poison grants Mew an immunity to Toxic, removing the biggest roadblock to its sweep, allowing it to beat the likes of Heatran, Clodsire, and Gliscor. The given EV spread lets Mew outspeed non-Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Since Mew is very passive while setting up, it is prone to being overwhelmed by Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Garchomp or used as setup fodder by Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Tornadus-T, thus making it crucial that Mew sets up or Tera at the right time. As such, teammates like Toxapex, Skarmory, and Zapdos are much appreciated to help check those Pokemon for Mew. Taunt from Tornadus-T and Heatran and Trick from Choice Specs Iron Valiant shut Mew down, so having teammates like Gliscor, Gholdengo, and Mega Scizor help deal with them. Gholdengo, in particular, is hard for Mew to deal with, as it can boost at a faster rate than Mew while taking a fully stacked-up Stored Power with ease and being immune to Body Press. Therefore, teammates that can threaten or Pursuit trap it such as Garchomp and Kingambit are very appreciated. Toxapex uses Haze to sit on Mew and forces it to Tera to avoid Toxic, thus overwhelming or removing Toxapex with the likes of Gholdengo, Garganacl, and Heatran allow Mew to set up and win.

Nasty Plot.description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf Regenerator.description: Choice Scarf Regenerator Mew is a strong utility pivot that checks fast physical attackers with the combination of Will-O-Wisp + Volt Switch while still pressuring defensive cores with entry hazards and Trick. Ice Beam can be used as an alternative to Spikes to pressure Pokemon like Garchomp and Landorus-T. Trick can be used to neutralize support Pokemon and defensive pivots like Corviknight while serving as an emergency stop to bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Enamorus-T. 136 Speed EVs with a Timid nature ensure that Mew outspeeds Chien Pao, Hisuian Electrode, and +1 Jolly Quaquaval, as well as positive natured Slither Wing and Heatran after Trick. Bulky teammates like Corviknight, Garganacl, Zapdos, and Skeledirge benefit from Mew's ability to spread burns and set hazards, allowing them to absorb more hits from physical attackers and whittle down these attackers more quickly; Mew can also pressure fast attackers like Meowscarada and Talonflame that they struggle with. Additionally, late-game cleaners like Chien-Pao, Hisuian Arcanine, and Quaquaval benefit from Mew's ability to chip defensive switch-ins and hinder walls by giving them a Choice Scarf.

Prankster.description: Prankster Mew is a good dual screens lead for hyper offense teams thanks to its good bulk, Speed, and movepool. Taunt blocks foes such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Iron Treads from setting entry hazards, Corviknight from clearing screens with Defog, and opposing setup sweepers like Volcarona from taking advantage of free turns. U-turn lets it pivot into its teammates and potentially re-set screens later in the game. Stealth Rock or Spikes can be used over U-turn to chip foes for teammates to KO. 96 Speed EVs and a Jolly Nature ensure that Mew always moves first against opposing leads like Prankster Corviknight and Masquerain, allowing Mew to hinder them with Taunt. Prankster Mew should only be used as a dual screens lead on hyper offense teams. Teammates such as Chien-Pao, Polteageist, Volcarona, and Roaring Moon all appreciate screens, which allow them to easily set up and make them less susceptible to revenge killers. The aforementioned Pokemon also provide good options for Mew to pivot into and gain momentum. Dark-type Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Meowscarada, and Chien-Pao are immune to Prankster Taunt and can take advantage of Mew, so counters to them such as Zamazenta-C and Triage users, like Enamorus-T and Ursaluna, are good teammates.

All-Out Attacker.description: Life Orb Mew is a very dangerous mixed wallbreaker that can decimate various walls with its colorful coverage. Ice Beam hits Ground- and Flying-types such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Zapdos. Gunk Shot 2HKOes Scream Tail, which otherwise switches into Mew freely. Close Combat takes care of Blissey and Steel-types such as Hisuian Goodra, Kingambit, and Heatran. Flamethrower 2HKOes non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight and Zamazenta-C, dissuading the latter from using Mew as setup fodder. A Mild nature helps Mew exert as much pressure as possible with Ice Beam and Flamethrower, while a Hasty nature most notably lets it outspeed Hydreigon and Speed tie Zapdos. Magic Guard negates chip damage from Life Orb and entry hazards, helping Mew stay healthy for longer and allowing it to better utilize its natural bulk to come into play. Sheer Force is an alternative particularly if Mew is used alongside a teammate with Magic Guard, such as Hisuian Electrode. It greatly increases Mew's power, notably letting it OHKO Garchomp and Iron Treads and pressure otherwise solid checks such as Meloetta, at the cost of its longevity. Bulky pivots such as Corviknight, Quaquaval, Iron Treads, and Meloetta can take on fast threats to Mew such as Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Iron Moth and switch Mew in safely. Fast offensive pivots such as Meowscarada and Sandy Shocks are also strong partners that can give Mew opportunities to come into play and clean up late-game after it softens up their checks. Garchomp and Ting-Lu can set entry hazards to help Mew break down its checks over time.

Desolate Land.description: Hisuian Typhlosion is a solid wallbreaker, exerting great offensive pressure with its great typing and offensive STAB move combinations. Eruption is Hisuian Typhlosion's go-to move, as Choice Specs boosts it enough to 2HKO common specially defensive walls such as Meloetta, Blissey, and Hisuian Goodra. Shadow Ball hits Fire-immune foes like Well-Baked Body Corviknight as well as Primordial Sea users like Volcanion, Zapdos, and Kilowattrel. Focus Blast notably 2HKOes RegenVest Roaring Moon and OHKOes Well-Baked Body Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads. A Modest nature guarantees that Choice Specs Hisuian Typhlosion can 2HKO the previously mentioned special walls, but Timid can be used to outspeed max speed Quaquaval and Ceruledge. Choice Scarf and a Timid nature can turn Hisuian Typhlosion from a wallbreaker into a potent revenge killer that outspeeds and OHKOes other fast targets like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Hisuian Electrode. Hisuian Typhlosion is very frail and struggles greatly against entry hazards, which also reduce Eruption's base power, so teammates that can clear hazards and pivot into it safely like Corviknight and Iron Treads are essential. Hisuian Typhlosion also has a mediocre Speed stat without Choice Scarf, so partners that can provide speed control like Regieleki, Chien-Pao, and Hisuian Electrode are also appreciated.

Utility (Poison).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Belly Drum.description:
Azumarill provides a versatile defensive answer for its frailer teammates while maintaining a strong offensive presence that pulls its weight on hyper offense. Maximum HP with Sitrus Berry highlights Azumarill’s naturally exceptional defensive typing, allowing it to serve as a one time check to OU staples such as Dragapult, Hydreigon, Roaring Moon, and Walking Wake. Belly Drum is an incredibly threatening option that lets Azumarill take advantage of the switches it forces from Pokemon such as Hydreigon to get setup opportunities. It is also a threatening late-game sweeper, as it can outspeed and OHKO defensive walls such as Clodsire, Slowking, and Garganacl while KOing most neutral faster targets such as Gholdengo and Iron Valiant with a +6 Aqua Jet. The threat of Belly Drum also lets Azumarill force uncomfortable mind games against Pokemon it can force out like weakened Great Tusk. Encore can be run over Liquidation to lock foes into undesirable moves to create more setup opportunities; this should be run with maximum Speed investment. Tera Water lets Azumarill OHKO even resisted targets such as Greninja, Meowscarada, and Dragapult with +6 Aqua Jet, as well as OHKOing Amoonguss and KOing Toxapex after Stealth Rock.

Azumarill serves as a valuable late-game sweeper for offense teams. Strong special attackers such as Iron Valiant and Greninja can help pressure Water-resistant foes such as Toxapex and Amoonguss to allow Azumarill to sweep without needing to Terastallize while providing Azumarill with setup opportunities against their checks like Dragapult and Hydreigon. Other setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Roaring Moon complement Azumarill, appreciating Azumarill's ability to break Amoonguss and Toxapex and wearing down each other's checks like Dondozo and Skeledirge. Entry hazard support from Pokémon like Glimmora and Garchomp provides the necessary chip damage to turn near OHKOs into true OHKOs on resisted Pokémon such as Roaring Moon, Dragapult, and Meowscarada with Tera Water +6 Aqua Jet. Azumarill can pair well with teammates like Grimmsnarl and Orthworm that provide it with more setup opportunities. Pelipper is also a strong partner for Azumarill, as rain provides an extreme damage boost, giving it the ability to avoid needing to Terastallize versus Pokemon such as Toxapex, Dragapult, and Amoonguss.

Choice Band.description:
Equipped with a Choice Band, Azumarill becomes a powerful wallbreaker strong enough to do significant damage to the opposing team. Combine that with Huge Power, priority from Aqua Jet, and the boost to STAB that comes from Tera Water, and Azumarill goes from powerful to extremely threatening for any ill-prepared team. Ice Spinner as coverage is useful to hit Amoonguss and Water Absorb Clodsire, while Superpower is an alternative to deal with Steel-types like Kingambit and Orthworm that would be harder to damage without it. 140 Speed EVs allow Azumarill to outspeed Corviknight and Skeledirge. The remaining 116 EVs in HP increase its survivability. This, along with the incredible defensive typing of Water / Fairy protecting it from the many Dragon-type threats roaming the tier, such as Dragapult and Walking Wake, gives it the opportunity to safely switch into many otherwise frightening Pokemon. Tera Water and Fairy are for powering up the Choce Band-boosted STAB attacks Azumarill uses. Tera Water is preferred to get the extra boost to Aqua Jet, but Tera Fairy can also be used to reduce the continual damage from Garganacl's Salt Cure.

Choice Band Azumarill is best used on offensive teams and benefits from the support of Pokemon that can open up opportunities for it to break holes. Pokemon like Dragapult and Rotom-W can be excellent teammates by making ample use of pivoting moves throughout a game to let Azumarill in safely. Special attackers like Iron Valiant and Iron Moth can be helpful to break through walls like Dondozo that Azumarill would otherwise struggle with. Faster Pokemon like Cinderace and Roaring Moon are useful as speed control to help cover Azumarill's low Speed. Most importantly though, entry hazards help Azumarill wear down tougher foes to be picked off later in the battle, so hazard setters like Great Tusk and Glimmora, as well as spinblockers like Gholdengo, are always appreciated teammates. Defensive Pokemon that have the tools to deal with Azumarill, like Rotom-W, Toxapex, and Dondozo, are the biggest thorns in Azumarill's side. Having another wallbreaker like Dragonite and Tera Electric Iron Valiant on the team can help mitigate some of these issues.

Assault Vest.description:
Azumarill leverages its good bulk and typing to check key special attackers such as Walking Wake, Hydreigon, and Greninja while maintaining a powerful offensive presence. An Assault Vest offers a noticeable increase to Azumarill's special bulk, letting it check a wider pool of special attackers such as Hisuian Zoroark and Dragapult while also granting it greater flexibility in its attacking options compared to Choice Band. Liquidation and Play Rough serve as Azumarill's primary STAB attacks, possessing fantastic neutral coverage and hitting many threats such as Dragonite, Walking Wake, and Iron Valiant for super effective damage. Aqua Jet allows Azumarill to revenge kill weakened foes such as Great Tusk and Iron Moth. Ice Spinner is a powerful coverage option, 2HKOing many of Azumarill's common switch-ins such as Amoonguss and Water Absorb Clodsire. Ice Spinner's ability to remove Terrain also makes it particularly useful against opposing Psychic Terrain teams. Tera Water increases the power of Azumarill's Water-type STAB moves, letting it pick off foes such as Iron Moth from higher ranges with Aqua Jet and allowing its Liquidation to 2HKO Hatterene and OHKO offensive Great Tusk. However, Tera Water does come with noticable drawbacks, namely removing Azumarill's immunity to Dragon-type moves and resistances to Fighting- and Dark-type moves, which can make it a shakier check to Walking Wake and Greninja.

Assault Vest Azumarill's talents will best be used by more offensive teams looking for a temporary answer to the aforementioned special threats. Partners at risk of being revenge killed by Walking Wake and Iron Valiant, such as Great Tusk and Hydreigon, will greatly appreciate Azumarill's ability to act as a buffer against these Pokemon. Despite Azumarill's good bulk, its tanking prowess can often be undermined by its vulnerability to passive damage from entry hazards and Rocky Helmet. Great Tusk is therefore an excellent partner, providing Rapid Spin support and being able to lure and remove Rocky Helmet from Pokemon such as Corviknight with Knock Off. Meowscarada is also an excellent ally, being able to shut down opposing entry hazard setters with Taunt while also providing Knock Off support. Furthermore, both Great Tusk and Meowscarada can support Azumarill by laying down entry hazards, which it will greatly appreciate given its ability to force switches. Ting-Lu can similarly lay down multiple layers of entry hazards and ease pressure exerted onto Azumarill in dealing with threats such as Dragapult and Iron Moth. Teammates that can bring Azumarill in safely with a pivoting move, such as Cinderace and Dragapult, are also recommended. Cinderace can assist Azumarill in dealing with entry hazards via Court Change, while Dragapult can deal with Orthworm, which may sometimes use Azumarill as an entry point to pass Shed Tail. In return, Azumarill can check key Pokemon such as Greninja that would threaten them. Azumarill greatly struggles against bulky Water-types such as Rotom-W, Toxapex, Dondozo, and Tera Water Garganacl. Hydreigon can exploit both Toxapex and Garganacl's passivity to set up with Substitute and Nasty Plot, though it must be wary of switching in against Toxic and Salt Cure. Breloom can pressure Dondozo and Tera Water Garganacl with Bullet Seed, while Covert Cloak Gholdengo matches up quite nicely against Garganacl and opposing Breloom and can pivot into Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W.

• Azumarill distinguishes itself as a Water-type with its access to Superpower, Fairy-type STAB moves, and priority Aqua Jet.
  • Superpower lets Assault Vest Azumarill defeat most Iron Bundle and most Magnezone.
  • Aqua Jet finishes off low health foes and allows Azumarill to outplay Disable users like Dragapult and Iron Valiant and Sturdy Pokemon like Magnezone and Counter Donphan.
  • The HP and Special Defense EVs, along with Assault Vest and a Careful nature, allow Azumarill to defeat Timid Choice Specs Iron Moth and non-Thunder Choice Specs Magnezone.

Choice Band.description:
• Superpower gives Azumarill good chances to defeat Speed-boosting Booster Energy Iron Bundle.
  • Aqua Jet OHKOes Iron Moth, while Fling lets Azumarill remove its Choice Band to avoid losing to Disable Dragapult.
  • The Special Defense investment, HP investment, and a Careful nature allow Azumarill to defeat most Iron Bundle.
  • Alternatively, an EV spread of 104 HP / 160 Atk / 244 Def with an Impish nature lets it defeat Chien-Pao, but this spread is less reliable versus Iron Bundle.

Stall.description:
• Chilling Water allows Azumarill to chip the foe down while reducing their Attack, giving it better chances versus Taunt Great Tusk.
  • Sap Sipper lures in Grass-types such as most offensive Choice Band Meowscarada.
  • The HP, Special Defense investment, and Calm nature allow Azumarill to defeat Timid Choice Specs Iron Valiant most of the time.
  • Use Charm or Amnesia to lower the foe's damage output until Azumarill is forced to use Rest.

Belly Drum Sweeper (Fairy).description:
Azumarill is Fairy's premier setup sweeper with immense damage output thanks to Huge Power alongside Belly Drum, which allows Azumarill to handle threats to the type such as Glimmora and Iron Treads. Aqua Jet patches up its below-average Speed tier and threatens faster threats like Iron Moth, Sandy Shocks, and Flutter Mane. Aqua Jet can also sweep late-game, especially against types that lack Water-resistant Pokemon like Steel. Play Rough breaks through sturdier threats that are not OHKOed by Aqua Jet like Hydreigon and Iron Hands. It also threatens opposing Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Dragalge. Liquidation can be used over Play Rough to OHKO Pokemon like Corviknight, Unaware Clodsire, and Bronzong after Belly Drum. Ice Spinner specifically hits Water Absorb Clodsire and Amoonguss for super effective damage. Body Slam is also another option to significantly threaten Toxapex at +6 Attack while still being able to target the aforementioned Clodsire and Amoonguss for neutral damage. Trailblaze can be used to always beat Quagsire as well. 4 HP EVs are given to make Azumarill's HP an even number so when it activates Belly Drum from full HP, it can activate its Sitrus Berry immediately.

One of Azumarill's best partners on Fairy teams is Klefki. Klefki sets up dual screens, which leads to Azumarill having an easier time setting up and sweeping. Klefki also sets Spikes for Azumarill, allowing Azumarill to secure KOs easier after a Belly Drum, particularly against Amoonguss and Toxapex after one layer of Spikes. Klefki also hinders Azumarill's offensive checks like Breloom with Thunder Wave. In return, Azumarill threatens opposing Fire- and Ground-types that threaten Klefki like Cinderace and Great Tusk. Azumarill forms a potent offensive core with Flutter Mane, which threatens the physical walls that may impede Azumarill's sweep like Unaware Quagsire and Toxapex, while Azumarill handles special walls like specially defensive Ting-Lu, Assault Vest Iron Hands, and Blissey. Azumarill also appreciates Iron Valiant as an offensive partner, as special sets can answer physical walls like Dondozo and hinder Azumarill's checks like Toxapex by using Trick, and—like with Flutter Mane—Azumarill can deal considerable damage to threats like Clodsire and Gholdengo. Magic Bounce Hatterene also assists Azumarill, as it bounces back entry hazards—particularly Toxic Spikes—which limits Azumarill's sweeping capabilities. Hatterene also has a strong matchup into Ground, Poison, and Water teams; Azumarill appreciates the latter two, since Hatterene is able to threaten Pokemon like Amoonguss and Toxapex.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Offensive.description:
• With a fantastic typing that checks key threats like Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu and a good STAB priority attack, Azumarill is a common choice for a team's bulky Water-type.

  • Superpower: Superpower often forces Azumarill to switch out, but it deals massive damage to the important Iron Bundle.

Other Options

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner lets Azumarill deal serious damage to Water Absorb Clodsire and does more against Dragonite before it Terastallizes.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Azumarill has a fantastic typing that it normally wants to keep, but it being rather weak to Iron Bundle is a major issue that can force it to Terastallize.

  • Water: Tera Water not only makes it easier to clean weakened teams with Aqua Jet, but it also lets Choice Band Azumarill OHKO uninvested Flutter Mane with Aqua Jet.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Assault Vest Azumarill a much better matchup against Iron Bundle, no longer being weak to Freeze-Dry and OHKOing it after Stealth Rock damage with Play Rough.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives Azumarill a vital immunity to Will-O-Wisp, as well as letting it deal massive damage to Corviknight with Tera Blast.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Azumarill deal massive damage to Dondozo, Toxapex, and Corviknight, plus it OHKOes Iron Bundle.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Azumarill beat Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Rotom-W.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest lets Azumarill act as a decent Chi-Yu check, with only +2 Life Orb Overheat even coming close to OHKOing.

  • Choice Band: The big power boost from Choice Band gives Azumarill an 81.3% chance to OHKO Rotom-H with Aqua Jet, and it lets it pick off major foes such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk more easily.

Belly Drum.description:
• Azumarill's excellent typing and access to priority Aqua Jet make it one of the best Belly Drum users in the metagame.

  • Liquidation: Liquidation remains a strong Water-type STAB move and makes Azumarill more usable in matchups where Belly Drum can't be used. When boosted by Belly Drum, Liquidation is fully capable of punching through bulky Steel-types—like Corviknight—that Play Rough can't.

  • Encore: Encore can create an opening to use Belly Drum against slower, more passive foes, such as Ting-Lu, though the decreased offensive coverage can hurt in the long run.

  • Belly Drum Usage: While finding a safe opportunity to use Belly Drum can be tough, Azumarill can cushion hits well from and set up on popular sweepers like Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, given that they don't have a Tera type that counters Azumarill. Azumarill can still hit hard even without Belly Drum, so don't force it if the situation looks too dangerous.

  • EV Spread : 244 HP EVs are used to give Azumarill an even HP number, guaranteeing that Sitrus Berry activates after Belly Drum. The extra EVs are put into Speed to prevent Speed ties with opposing 4 Speed Azumarill.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Belly Drum is inherently risky; smart Tera usage can cushion an attack during setup or provide a stronger coverage option when Belly Drum simply isn't viable to use.

  • Water: Tera Water combined with Belly Drum gives Aqua Jet nightmarish power. After Stealth Rock chip, it can even OHKO Iron Bundle!

  • Fire: Tera Fire blocks Will-O-Wisp, and the Tera Blast coverage can hit Steel-types like Scizor and Corviknight hard even without Belly Drum.

  • Grass: Tera Grass turns both Grass- and Electric-type weaknesses into resistances, and when combined with Tera Blast, it makes dealing with Unaware Dondozo and Rotom-W much easier. It can also be used to block Spore and set up Belly Drum for free, but this must be done with discretion, as Spore users like Loaded Dice Breloom may just attack and leave Azumarill heavily wounded after Belly Drum.

  • Electric: Tera Electric with Tera Blast is Azumarill's best option to beat Toxapex, and it still deals big damage to Unaware Dondozo and Corviknight.

Substitute + Encore.description: • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Z-Belly Drum (Fairy).description: Azumarill's presence is greatly appreciated on Fairy teams, where it tends to be the Z-Crystal user of choice and a good answer to the Fire, Ground, Rock, Poison and Steel matchups. Z-Belly Drum guarantees a +6 boost to Azumarill's already impressive Attack, turning it into a redoubtable setup sweeper with access to priority, and it can even offer a second setup opportunity if Azumarill gets forced out with its Z-Move unused. Aqua Jet is Azumarill's answer to threats that outspeed it, such as Volcarona, Tapu Koko, and Nidoking. Aside from dealing with Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Slowbro, and Sinistcha, Knock Off is Azumarill's best coverage option against walls that resist its other attacks, such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex and Water Absorb Clodsire. Breakneck Blitz coming off Return beats Mega Venusaur as well as Icium Z Toxapex, which doesn't fear Knock Off. Alternatively, Liquidation could be used as a stronger STAB option for slower foes like Iron Hands, Ting-Lu, and Celesteela, which is important if a Jolly nature is used. Ice Spinner is an alternative that can be used to defeat both Ting-Lu and Mega Venusaur after some chip, along with getting rid of Psychic Terrain to allow for Aqua Jet to be used without being blocked. Klefki is an amazing partner for Azumarill, offering a Poison immunity and dual screens support to ease setup and spreading Spikes to chip the opposing team. Mega Diancie helps in the Fire and Flying matchups and provides entry hazard control, contributing to keeping Azumarill healthy as well as providing Stealth Rock to help its wallbreaking. Tapu Koko deals with Water-types such as Pelipper and Toxapex, making Azumarill's sweep easier down the line, and it also handles Steel- and Flying-types like Celesteela and Corviknight should Azumarill opt for Return. Tapu Bulu also aids in the Water and Electric matchup, handling foes like Quagsire and Rotom-W that Azumarill can struggle to bring down. Iron Valiant deals with most Fighting-types and, when paired with Tapu Koko, outspeeds and defeats faster foes such as Mega Lopunny and Mega Swampert under rain, but it competes with Azumarill for a Z-Crystal. Tapu Lele handles Poison-types like Mega Venusaur and Clodsire, but be cautious of Psychic Terrain preventing Azumarill from using Aqua Jet. Babiri Berry Clefable can be used as an alternative to Tapu Lele for checking Scizor, and it also handles Mega Venusaur well, as it can use it as setup fodder.

Physically Defensive.description:
Quagsire is a notable physical wall thanks to its ability Unaware, which allows it to ignore boosts from setup sweepers like Salamence and Scizor. Toxic puts many notable Pokemon in the tier on a timer such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon. Quagsire ideally wants Spikes over Stealth Rock to force more chip damage on potential switch-ins; however, Stealth Rock is fine as an alternative if none of its other teammates can afford to fit it into their moveset. Alternatively, Ice Beam with a Relaxed nature allows Quagsire to 2HKO Hawlucha after Stealth Rock and lets it beat Substitute + Dragon Dance Tera Flying Tyranitars. The passive recovery of Leftovers allows Quagsire to check Choice Band Tyranitar and Mimikyu more easily; however, if the team can not fit entry hazard removal, Heavy-Duty Boots is much more appealing. Quagsire only uses Terastallization defensively to check certain dangerous offensive threats. Tera Poison grants Quagsire a perfectly accurate Toxic and a poison immunity while also allowing it to handle Grass-types and offensive threats that use Grass-type moves such as Tsareena, Trailblaze Scizor, and Seed Bomb Pawmot. Tera Ghost allows Quagsire to beat Maushold by becoming immune to Population Bomb as well as check Slither Wing and Lucario more easily. Tera Ghost also has the added benefit of letting Quagsire serve as a spinblocker against spinners such as Tsareena.

Quagsire primarily fits on balance, stall, and bulky offense teams as a defensive glue that holds these teams together. Common teammates for Quagsire include Stealth Rock setters such as Tinkaton and Tyranitar, which can allow Quagsire to run Spikes. Both can check Gengar, special Salamence, and Iron Jugulis, which pose a threat to Quagsire. Tinkaton can also use Knock Off on Heavy-Duty Boots users such as Sticky Hold Gastrodon, Scream Tail, and Wo-Chien to rack up more damage from Quagsire's Spikes. Scream Tail is another Pokemon that complements Quagsire, as it is able to handle special Salamence as well as Gallade, while Quagsire is able to keep Bisharp and non-Trailblaze Scizor in check. Talonflame is another ideal partner for Quagsire as it can check Tsareena and Giga Drain variants of Wo-Chien. Blissey on stall teams is also a strong partner for Quagsire by virtue of walling almost every special attacker in the tier such as Iron Jugulis, Noivern, and Sandy Shocks.

Physically Defensive (Water).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Unaware Wall (Ground).description:
Quagsire is an excellent option for Ground teams due to its physical bulk and Unaware, checking a wide range of physical attackers like Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur. Earthquake in conjunction with Toxic wears down Pokemon like Dragonite as well as Quaquaval and Brambleghast, as they commonly switch in to remove Quagsire's entry hazards. Stealth Rock or Spikes wear down threats like Greninja, Iron Valiant, and Scovillain. Body Press is a viable alternative to deal more damage to Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Kingambit.

Quagsire's ability to wall setup sweepers like Dragonite, Azumarill, and Mimikyu is heavily appreciated by its teammates. Water Absorb Clodsire switches into attacks from Greninja, Meowscarada, and Kilowattrel. Iron Treads is an invaluable teammate to remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin and checking Fairy-types like Hatterene and Flutter Mane. Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Sandy Shocks value Quagsire's entry hazards, as it aids in their wallbreaking. Choice Scarf Great Tusk checks Choice Specs Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Greninja and removes held items from Sableye, Corviknight, and Amoonguss to make them more susceptible to Quagsire's entry hazards. Garchomp threatens Grass-types like Amoonguss, Toedscruel, and Brambleghast with its Fire-type coverage and wears down walls such as Toxapex. Sandy Shocks is valued as a Water-type answer, threatening Pelipper, Dondozo, and Slowking as well as Corviknight. Furthermore, it beats Fire teams with Power Gem by taking advantage of sun with Protosynthesis.

nu.overview: Umbreon's amazing utility movepool and peerless bulk make it a top-notch support Pokemon and check to many top tier threats, like Bruxish, Qwilfish, and Mabosstiff. Despite its great bulk, Umbreon's offenses are quite lackluster, though this can be somewhat alleviated by STAB Foul Play to punish setup sweepers attempting to exploit Umbreon's passivity, like Coil Eelektross and Bulk Up Ursaring. Setup sweepers that don't mind taking a Foul Play, like Calm Mind Dudunsparce and Quiver Dance Oricorio, can easily take advantage of it. Umbreon also dislikes the plethora of Fighting-types in the tier, like Toxicroak, Medicham, and Paldean Tauros.
nu.comments:
Other Options

Umbreon has a myriad of utility options at its disposal, including being able to set up with Calm Mind. Unfortunately, due to Umbreon's terrible Special Attack, a Calm Mind set typically requires too many boosts to be effective. Umbreon can fit two utility moves if it chooses to use Moonlight instead of Wish and Protect, but the limited PP can become a detriment in longer games. Umbreon can beat setup sweepers that typically take advantage of it, such as Quiver Dance Oricorio and Calm Mind Vaporeon, with Tera Ghost and Curse. Umbreon can also use Taunt and a few extra Speed EVs to stop setup sweepers like Sandaconda and Vaporeon or other support Pokemon like Vespiquen and Muk from using their own status moves. Lastly, Umbreon can trap an unsuspecting foe with Mean Look and wear it down with Foul Play or even drop its stats with Tickle to more easily take it out.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: NU has a plethora of Fighting-types, such as Crabominable, Medicham, and Sneasel-Hisui. Umbreon can Terastallize to reverse this weakness, but that always comes with a new set of weaknesses and removes the option to Terastallize later. Other Pokemon like Scyther and Zangoose have a powerful Close Combat that can threaten Umbreon as well.

Opposing Utility Moves: Regardless of Synchronize, a poisoned Umbreon, whether by Toxic or Toxic Spikes, is extremely impaired and struggles to fulfill its role. Trick from a Choice Scarf Haunter or Rotom can completely ruin Umbreon despite it being a suitable check to them otherwise. Taunt from Pokemon like Bombirdier, Qwilfish, and opposing Umbreon can limit Umbreon to only an exploitable Foul Play.

Special Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers that don't mind Foul Play, mainly special attackers like Oricorio, Vivillon, and a Terastallized Farigiraf can easily boost against Umbreon.

Wish Support.description:
Set Details

Foul Play is surprisingly powerful with STAB, letting Umbreon threaten even neutral physical attackers. Umbreon's immense bulk lets it spread status with Thunder Wave or Yawn to support its teammates, and Wish can keep teammates that lack reliable recovery such as Perrserker and Eelektross healthy. While Pokemon like Tera Ground Oricorio and Coil Eelektross are immune to Thunder Wave, Yawn can shut down their setup attempts nicely. Synchronize can deter or punish careless status moves used by the likes of Dudunsparce and Drifblim. Umbreon prefers a Poison or Fairy Tera type to turn the tables on Fighting-types and take U-turn better. Tera Poison also provides a Fairy resistance and an immunity to Toxic and Toxic Spikes from common users like Muk, Qwilfish, and Vespiquen.

Umbreon appreciates Drifblim and Qwilfish for their Fighting resistance. Drifblim can remove entry hazards and take advantage of Umbreon's status moves with Hex, while Qwilfish can consistently punish Fighting-type moves and U-turn from Pokemon like Passimian and Scyther with Poison Point and Rocky Helmet. Bruxish and Rotom appreciate Umbreon's resistance to Ghost- and Dark-type attacks and its ability to inflict paralysis and sleep.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Wish Tank.description:
• Umbreon's high bulk allows it tank a slew of offensive Pokemon. Alongside excellent utility moves, Umbreon can generate tempo while surviving even surprise Tera-boosted attacks.

  • Foul Play: In such a physically leaning format, Foul Play is a strong reliable move to chip the opponent's Pokemon. In particular, it punishes Dragon Dance from Lum Berry Dragonite.

  • Wish and Protect: Wish + Protect provides excellent recovery opportunies for both Umbreon and its teammates. With Leftovers's animation as well, its great at stalling out the timer. Protect also scouts for U-turn and Tera.

  • Yawn: Yawn's ability to force switches generates extra Leftovers recovery and generates momentum for its teammates.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave has excellent synergy with Wish. If the opponent's Pokemon is unable to attack on the turn Umbreon uses Wish, Umbreon can easily pass the Wish to a teammate.

  • Taunt: Umbreon can Taunt opposing walls and deny their recovery, with foes such as Hippowdon and Corviknight being especially vulnerable.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Despite its incredible bulk, Umbreon's Fighting- and Fairy-type weaknesses are exploitable by several top threats and often needs to be removed.

  • Fairy: In a heavily Dragon-centric metagame, Tera Fairy on defensive Pokemon is highly valuable. Removing Umbreon's Fighting- and Fairy-type weakness also helps deal with Sacred Sword Chien-Pao and Mimikyu.

  • Poison: Tera Poison resists Fighting, Bug, and Fairy and provides an immunity to Toxic, but makes it more vulnerable to Earthquake from the likes of Dragonite and Baxcalibur.

Items

  • Leftovers: Combined with Protect, Leftovers keeps Umbreon healthy and a little less reliant on Wish.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet's chip damage is serviceable, but many top physical threats have suitable non-contact moves they can use on Umbreon, especially after Umbreon Terastallizes.

Abilities

  • Inner Focus: Inner Focus avoids flinches from Chien-Pao and Kingambit, making Umbreon a more reliable check.

  • Synchronize: Synchronize punishes attempts to burn Umbreon.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Bold: With Terastallization, this spread allows Umbreon to tank a majority of the physical metagame.

  • 172 HP / 252 Def / 60 SpD / 20 Spe with Bold: If running Taunt, 20 Speed EVs outpace Skeledirge and Corviknight while retaining all-around bulk.

Tailwind.description:
• Foul Play punishes the metagame's strong physical attackers, most notably 2HKOing Adamant Dragonite and Garchomp. Brave Bird is an alternative option that handles Flying-weak Pokemon such as Meowscarada, Lilligant, and Breloom with ease.

  • Murkrow's Haze allows it to check dangerous threats, such as Dondozo, Nasty Plot Gholdengo, and Swords Dance Garchomp. Haze can also reset its partner's stat drops from the likes of Intimidate, Parting Shot, and Snarl, or attacks that lower the user's stats.

  • Taunt allows it to also disrupt support Pokemon such as Lilligant, Talonflame, and Amoonguss, as well as crippling Pokemon such as Iron Defense Garganacl. Quash is also a viable option to maintain speed control even in Trick Room, and it can neutralize threats such as Maushold and Garchomp in opposing Tailwind.

  • Other viable, but not as prominent, options for Murkrow include Protect and Perish Song. Protect allows it to scout the opponent and block Fake Out. Perish Song is an interesting option that gives Murkrow a win condition alongside its supportive roles and can force switches before that.

  • Eviolite gives Murkrow the bulk needed to stay on the field and disrupt the opponent with Haze and Taunt. Focus Sash can be used when Murkrow is expected to be KOed quickly, for example Murkrow can also hold Covert Cloak to bypass Fake Out.

  • 52 Speed EVs allow Murkrow to get the jump on Annihilape in Tailwind, and the overall bulk investment allows Murkrow to survive Tera Normal Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Timid Gholdengo's Thunderbolt.

  • Tera Ghost allows Murkrow to bypass Fake Out on sets not running Covert Cloak, while Tera Dark adds more power to Foul Play in rare late-game one-on-one scenarios and it keeps Murkrow's immunity to Prankster status moves.

Specially Defensive.description:
Slowking is a specially defensive pivot with access to Chilly Reception, allowing it to keep momentum relatively safely due to the combination of its low Speed and Regenerator. Chilly Reception can also be used for cancelling the effects of opposing weather such as rain and sun while also enabling offensive Ice-types due to snow's Defense boost. Surf is its most reliable STAB move, being necessary to sucessfully check Iron Moth and Iron Valiant. Future Sight threatens more defensive teams when paired with physical wallbreakers such as Cinderace, as it threatens opposing defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Amoonguss. Thunder Wave can alternatively be run alongside Surf, preventing Slowking from being setup fodder for Volcarona and Dragonite. Slowking runs maximum Special Defense EVs in order to switch into a variety of other special attackers such as Walking Wake, Rotom-W, Volcarona, and Hatterene. It also lets Slowking make use of Chilly Reception and Thunder Wave for dynamic counterplay. The investment also gives Slowking more opportunities to safely pivot in front of Pokemon that aren't immediately threatening but can beat it long-term, such as Gholdengo, Garganacl, Hisuian Zoroark, and Choice Specs Dragapult. 0 Speed IVs in tandem with a Sassy nature maximize the odds of slow pivoting in front of foes, which is important to nearly guarantee safely bringing in other teammates. Slowking can utilize Tera Water to remove its Bug-, Ghost-, and Dark-type weaknesses, enhancing its matchup against Gholdengo, Dragapult, Greninja, and Volcarona while also allowing it to absorb U-turn better. Additionally, it also boosts Surf's damage output. Tera Fairy turns the tables on Dragapult and Greninja, allowing it to wall their Choice Specs sets reliably.

Slowking fits on balance teams due to its exclusive access to Chilly Reception, as they can take advantage of both the snow and momentum generated by it. Slowking enjoys being paired with Pokemon that can generate momentum, such as Cinderace, Rotom-W, and Sandy Shocks. This helps its team to pivot around Garganacl to avoid being worn down by its Salt Cure. Slowking is naturally paired with physically defensive walls with good synergy, such as Great Tusk, Amoonguss, and Corviknight, which answer many of Slowking´s checks such as Kingambit, Meowscarada, and Roaring Moon. Slowking is generally vulnerable to becoming fodder for Orthworm, since it can't paralyze targets through Orthworm´s passed Substitutes. As such, Pokemon like Infiltrator Dragapult and Unaware Pokemon like Skeledirge and Dondozo are logical Slowking teammates that fix this issue, with Unaware teammates in particular being crucial for answering setup sweepers like Belly Drum Azumarill and Swords Dance Iron Valiant that are present on hyper offense teams. Dark-types like Kingambit can check and occasionally switch into special attackers that have an advantage against Slowking like Nasty Plot Gholdengo, Choice Specs Greninja, and Choice Specs Dragapult, creating good defensive synergy without lacking offensive capabilities.

Defensive Pivot.description: Thanks to its solid special bulk and excellent longevity between Slack Off and Regenerator, Slowking establishes itself as a passable pivot in the metagame. It can switch into foes like Tornadus-T and non-Toxic Heatran, and it can even scout for Choice Specs users such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele. Future Sight + Teleport or Chilly Reception lets Slowking support its frail offensive teammates such as Mega Lopunny and Dragapult, giving them safe switch ins and amplifying their wallbreaking prowess afterwards. Teleport is a much more reliable way of pivoting, as its higher PP makes it more valuable in longer games and it provides Slowking's teammates with a safe switch in against Ferrothorn and other Teleport users like Blissey and Slowbro. Alternatively, Chilly Reception's snow helps disrupt weather teams like sun and rain as well as support Ice-type teammates like Kyurem and Weavile with its Defense boost. Tera Fairy improves Slowking's matchup against Dragapult and Tapu Koko and maintains its Fighting resistance against Mega Lopunny, while Tera Dark lets it better stomach Ghost-type attacks from Gholdengo and Dragapult at the cost of being weaker against Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Both Tera choices importantly prevent Slowking from being Pursuit trapped by Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. Wallbreakers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Kingambit appreciate Slowking's slow pivoting, with the looming Future Sight pressuring their switch-ins like Toxapex, Buzzwole, and defensive Great Tusk. Moreover, Slowking switches into their revenge killers, notably Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Defensive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Tangrowth cover foes like Weavile, Tapu Koko, and Kartana, respectively; Ferrothorn and Tangrowth also deal with rain wallbreakers like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda that would otherwise overwhelm Slowking despite its Water resistance, with the latter in particular forming a Regnerator core with Slowking.

Specially Defensive.description: Defense avoids OHKO from Krookodile’s Knock Off.

Pivot.description: Galarian Slowking has valuable qualities in being a defensive pivot due to its high special bulk, Regenerator, and great defensive typing; these qualities let it check, cripple, and pivot around threats like Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Volcarona, and also pressure and take advantage of defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Garganacl with Future Sight. Sludge Bomb lets it deal with Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele while also letting it fish for poison on Pokemon like Zapdos and Moltres. Chilly Reception lets Galarian Slowking mess with weather like rain and sun while also letting it pivot around offensive Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y, Tapu Koko, and Iron Valiant. Thunder Wave lets Galarian Slowking cripple Pokemon who would use it as setup fodder such as Volcarona and Tornadus-T. Ice Beam lets Galarian Slowking significantly dent Ground-types like Landorus-T and Gliscor, while Flamethrower can let it hit Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor in a pinch. Slack Off gives Galarian Slowking reliable recovery to handle the aforementioned threats long-term. Tera Steel lets Galarian Slowking handle Tapu Lele even better and let it pivot out into a teammate or damage them with either Flamethrower or Sludge Bomb, respectively. 0 Speed IVs let it pivot out last against slower Pokemon like Ferrothorn. More physically defensive sets can be used as well, but even with Galarian Slowking's great special bulk, it cannot sponge special attacks as well as specially defensive. Tera Water lets it take a Fire Blast from Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona and Thunder Wave in return, or pivot out on them as well. Galarian Slowking is very vulnerable to Pursuit trappers like Mega Tyranitar and Weavile, so teammates that can handle them such as Ting-Lu and Mega Scizor are well appreciated. Urshifu-R and Mega Lopunny are notable abusers of Future Sight from Galarian Slowking, appreciating it pressuring and exploiting their checks like Toxapex, Moltres, and Zapdos.

Assault Vest.description: With an Assault Vest equipped, Galarian Slowking functions as an incredibly bulky pivot that easily checks Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, Mega Charizard Y, and Kyurem. Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn, while Scald lets it punish foes with a potential burn, most notably Pokemon like Landorus-T and Mega Tyranitar. Ice Beam lets it immediately threaten switch-ins like Gliscor, but leaves it vulnerable to Heatran. Earthquake can be used to hit Heatran, but using it does come at the cost of not having the utility of a move like Scald. 248 HP EVs optimize Regenerator recovery, and in tandem with 224 Special Defense EVs, it lives 2 Fire Blasts from Mega Charizard Y after Stealth Rock. Tera Steel and Tera Water improve matchups against Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Mega Charizard Y, respectively. Both types also give it a Pursuit neutrality, leaving it less vulnerable against Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Weavile. Galarian Slowking appreciates Pokemon that can absorb Knock Off to preserve its Assault Vest, so Pokemon like Mega Lopunny and Gliscor make for good teammates. The latter forms a good core with Galarian Slowking, punishing and gaining information on passive and offensive Pokemon throughout a game due to the duo's prolonged longevity. Entry hazard removal helps Galarian Slowking not be ruined by Spikes, so Defoggers like Moltres and Zapdos help it not be chipped as much.

Assault Vest (Psychic).description:
Guarantees a 2HKO on Heatran after Stealth Rock damage.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview: This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

AV Tank.description:
• Thanks to its great Special Defense, unique typing, and Regenerator, Galarian Slowking functions well as an Assault Vest user.

  • Assault Vest: While Galarian Slowking has access to Slack Off, Regenerator can provide some recovery if needed, and an Assault Vest increases its Special Defense to titanic levels.

  • Future Sight: Future Sight is Galarian Slowking's strongest move and provides phenomenal field pressure due to hitting two turns after it's used, allowing for combinations with another teammate's move.

  • Eerie Spell versus Psychic: Psychic offers more PP, while Eerie Spell depletes the PP of the last move used by the opponent by 3, which can be useful when fighting against opponents with low PP moves, such as recovery moves.

  • Acid Spray: Acid Spray makes Galarian Slowking much less passive and prone to setup against opponents that aren't immune, and the Special Defense drops can be deadly when combined with Future Sight, alongside making Galarian Slowking harder to check defensively.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake is Galarian Slowking's best option against Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, even when using a Calm nature.

  • Ice Beam: Ice Beam allows Galarian Slowking to hit Ground-types such as Ting-Lu, Landorus-T, and Ursaluna for more damage than its Psychic STAB moves.

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower hits other Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Corviknight.

  • Calm versus Sassy: If using Earthquake, a Sassy Nature lets Galarian Slowking have a shot at 3HKOing max HP Hisuian Goodra, though at the risk of getting outsped by Amoonguss. A Calm Nature has better odds at Speed tying or outspeeding Amoonguss.

Other Options

  • Psyshock: Despite having little synergy with Acid Spray, Psyshock hits Flutter Mane and Clodsire the hardest before factoring Special Defense drops.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Calm / Sassy: This EV spread focuses on Galarian Slowking's ability to take special attacks to the point where powerful super effective hits such as Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball only has a chance of 2HKOing it 75.4% of the time.

  • 252 HP / 28 Def / 84 SpA / 140 SpD / 4 Spe with Modest / Quiet: This spread survives Jolly Choice Band Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes while OHKOing it with Eerie Spell.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Galarian Slowking is perfectly able to function without Terastallization, but it can boost its defensive profile.

  • Normal: A well-timed Tera Normal can severely hamper opponents hoping to take down Galarian Slowking with Ghost-type moves.

  • Poison: Tera Poison removes Galarian Slowking's weaknesses to Ghost-, and Dark-type attacks, and it boosts Sludge Bomb and Acid Spray's power.

  • Grass: Tera Grass turns Galarian Slowking's Ground weakness into a resistance, can help it take Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes better, and provides a handy immunity to Spore.

Defensive.description:
Defensive Misdreavus is the glue that holds PU together because of its ability to deal with many of the strongest physical attacking presences in the metagame, such as Lycanroc-N, Alolan Dugtrio, and Perrserker. It has a very strong type for this tier, with very few Pokemon able to hit it for super effective damage. It is also the best Rapid Spin blocker in PU because of this. Will-O-Wisp is great for crippling physical attackers like Lycanroc-N, Gabite, and Alolan Dugtrio. Choosing to run Thunder Wave over Will-O-Wisp can make dealing with Alolan Dugtrio and Gabite more difficult. With Misdreavus able to spread status so well, Hex is the best choice for its STAB move. Power Gem is quad effective against Articuno, Masquerain, and Charizard; it also hits other popular Pokemon like Houndoom, Pyroar, and Rotom-F for super effective damage. Thunderbolt can be opted for instead to better hit Water-types like Golduck, Lumineon, Basculin, and Quaxwell. Taunt is also an option over the two attacking moves to disallow setup sweepers such as Gogoat and Carbink from boosting in front of Misdreavus; it also works well at stopping entry hazard setters such as Carbink, Gabite, and Camerupt. The EV spread allows for better recovery with Pain Split by keeping Misdreavus's HP a bit lower than if 252 HP EVs were used while still keeping its overall bulk by adding the EVs taken from HP into both defensive stats. 56 Speed EVs let it out speed neutral natured Honchkrow and Flapple, as well as Timid Glimmet and uninvested Drakloak. Tera Fighting and Tera Fairy both work well to provide a resistance to Dark-type moves from Pokemon like Honchkrow and Alolan Persian. Although, Tera Fighting leaves Misdreavus vulnerable to Flying-type moves from Articuno, Charizard, and Masquerain and Psychic-type moves from Rabsca and Indeedee-F. On the other hand, Tera Fairy leaves it vulnerable to Steel-type moves from Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio. Tera Electric is great for boosting Thunderbolt and giving Misdreavus zero weaknesses with its ability. Tera Rock boosts Power Gem, letting it OHKO Charizard and Masquerain.

Misdreavus works well on balance teams looking for a catch-all defensive Pokemon to deal with many of the metagame's top threats. It also works great on entry hazard stacking teams since it is not bothered by the top Rapid Spin user, Quaxwell. Misdreavus thrives when given teammates like Carbink, Dachsbun, and Tinkatuff to deal with Dark-types such as Alolan Persian, Houndoom, and Skuntank. These same Dark-type threats, Alolan Persian, Houndoom, and Skuntank, can help deal with Ghost-type foes like Banette, Drakloak, and opposing Misdreavus. Specially defensive walls like Articuno, Carbink, and Tinkatuff form a nice core with Misdreavus since it can cover physical Pokemon that give them trouble, like Lycanroc-N, Perrserker, and Alolan Dugtrio. Knock Off absorbers and status absorbers are highly recommended to keep Misdreavus healthy enough to deal with all of these Pokemon. Status absorbers are the likes of RestTalk Gabite, Dragonair, and Zangoose, while Knock Off absorbers are usually Dark-types like Alolan Persian and Skuntank.

Offensive.description:
Misdreavus is capable of becoming a fearsome sweeper while still retaining its defensive and utility properties, which allow it to switch into a wide range of threats and spinblock effectively. Calm Mind can be used with Draining Kiss and Tera Fairy to turn Misdreavus into a bulky wallbreaker that is difficult to wear down due to Misdreavus's great natural bulk, HP recovery from Draining Kiss, and immediate access to status moves. Tera Fairy is notable for preventing threats like Nasty Plot Alolan Persian from immediately threatening it, and its toolset lends it easy setup opportunities against Gabite, one of the best phazers in the metagame, as well as other passive targets like Dachsbun and Carbink. Alternatively, Nasty Plot can be used along with either Draining Kiss or Power Gem to make Misdreavus more immediately threatening, with Power Gem primarily targeting Fire-types like Pyroar and Houndoom that it would otherwise struggle with as well as specially defensive Articuno. Hex benefits greatly from Misdreavus's ability to spread status and can be amplified with additional status spreaders on the team; alternatively, Shadow Ball can be used on Nasty Plot sets for greater immediate damage output. Will-O-Wisp is useful for preventing targets like Skuntank and Honchkrow from revenge killing it before Terastallization as well as increasing its ability to take hits from Quaxwell. Thunder Wave is another option that cripples special walls like Articuno and opposing setup sweepers like Masquerain. Substitute can also be used as the last move to facilitate setup on forced switches and prevent Skuntank and Rotom-F from crippling it with Toxic or Trick, but it usually gets more value from spreading status. An alternative EV spread of 128 HP / 128 SpA / 252 Spe with a Timid nature can be used on Calm Mind variants for easier setup and more reliable spinblocking.

Misdreavus's effectiveness at spinblocking naturally makes it a great fit on entry hazard stacking teams alongside setters like Whiscash, Carbink, and Masquerain as well as strong wallbreakers like Basculin and Rotom-F. Ground-types like Whiscash and Gabite can reliably switch into offensive checks like Alolan Dugtrio and Houndoom as well as Pokemon that may cripple Misdreavus with Thunder Wave or Encore, such as Tinkatuff and Raichu. Carbink can reliably switch into and deal with Dark-types like Houndoom and Alolan Persian that Nasty Plot variants in particular struggle with greatly before Terastallization, and it can also absorb Knock Off. Gogoat can form an effective bulky setup core with Misdreavus, as they deal with each other's checks, like Basculin and Gabite, respectively, and they pressure mutual targets like Articuno and Carbink better together. Thunder Wave users like Alolan Persian and Tinkatuff can facilitate sweeping for Misdreavus by powering up its Hex; the former can also bring it in safely with Parting Shot and ease the pressure of handling Perrserker, and the latter can create setup opportunities with Encore. In addition, both of these can situationally switch into Knock Off from Pokemon like Banette and opposing Tinkatuff.

Entry Hazard Support (Bug).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Physically Defensive.description: 64 Speed EVs are to outspeed Adamant Tyranitar.

RegenVest.description: RegenVest Mega Steelix is a reliable soft-check to the vast majority of the tier thanks to its massive mixed bulk and great typing. It's also slower than almost everything, making it a valuable slow pivot. Gigaton Hammer deals surprising damage, scaring out dangerous foes like Mega Diancie and entry hazard removers like Arceus-Fairy. Knock Off dissuades Imposter users from switching in and removing Covert Cloak and Heavy-Duty Boots helps it rack up passive damage. Stone Axe helps support offensive allies by setting Stealth Rock and also chunking Ho-Oh for major damage, while Mortal Spin allows Mega Steelix to remove hazards in a pinch and offers similar chip damage potential. While Mega Steelix's mixed bulk is good, it relies heavily on Assault Vest to check things and is often unable to wall anything long-term; as such, teammates like defensive Arceus formes are recommended to help check foes like Mega Diancie and Palkia-O. A major issue with Mega Steelix is Imposter, as its move selection is very annoying to Imposter-proof, and in slower games where Eviolite is less necessary, Imposter users can use it as a relatively safe source of Regenerator recovery. Fur Coat Arceus-Poison is the most effective all-around Imposter-proof, but Jungle Healing users and Steel-types like Celesteela can also work.

Tank.description:
Max HP and 8 Defense EVs takes any attack from +2 Cobalion barring All-Out Pummeling. 32 Attack Evs guarantee an OHKO on Houndoom-Mega.

This is a sample set, stay tuned for future updates!

Physical Wall.description: Qwilfish is a premier physical wall in the tier owing to its great defensive typing and abilities, as well as a bevy of amazing utility moves including the highly coveted Spikes and Toxic. Qwilfish can wear down the opposition with its combination of Spikes and Toxic and even prevent Defog and recovery moves with Taunt. Waterfall is used over Liquidation to potentially cause flinching, which works wonders in conjunction with Toxic, although Surf can be used for a 2HKO on Sandaconda and more damage on other physically bulky Pokemon like Drifblim and Klawf. Despite Intimidate being such a high-value ability, Qwilfish typically prefers Poison Point to punish U-turn from the likes of Passimian and Scyther while not activating Passimian's Defiant in the process. Protect can be used with Leftovers for some extra recovery and also to scout moves from Choice item users like Rotom, Bruxish, and Zoroark. Upon scouting these Pokemon, Qwilfish can invert its weakness to Electric- or Psychic-type moves with a timely Terastallization to a respective Ground or Dark typing, letting it spread more poison and set more Spikes. Umbreon is a great defensive partner, sponging general special attacks while boasting an immunity to Psychic. In return, Qwilfish heavily punishes Fighting-type attacks and U-turn, while also resisting Fairy. Phasers like Dragon Tail Dudunsparce and Eelektross make great use of the Spikes Qwilfish sets up, racking up damage for a faster Pokemon to more easily sweep. Choice Scarf Passimian takes advantage of hazard damage while also punishing Defog with its Defiant ability.

Defensive.description:
With access to a deep utility movepool, great defensive abilities, and Eviolite, Hisuian Qwilfish can take on many offensive threats. Intimidate is useful to weaken physical attackers, allowing it to tank strong neutral attacks from the likes of Ursaring and Tauros. Hisuian Qwilfish can also make use of Poison Point to punish contact moves, even generally commitment-free moves like Scyther's and Mesprit's U-turn. Barb Barrage is preferred over stronger options like Poison Jab and Gunk Shot thanks to its high chance to poison, as well as dealing double damage to a poisoned target. Taunt dismantles setup sweepers such as Eelektross while also preventing Defog. Haze is an option over Taunt to prevent setup sweepers like Tera Steel Mesprit and Eelektross from exploiting Hisuian Qwilfish's passivity. Toxic can also be run over Taunt to take advantage of Defog users removing your Spikes and cripple opposing walls like Appletun, Articuno, and Eelektross. Crunch is an extra STAB option that beats Ghost- and Psychic-types like Froslass, Rotom, and Bruxish. Alternatively, Crunch punishes teams that have no grounded Poison-type or entry hazard control. Tera Grass enables Hisuian Qwilfish to set more Spikes against Sandaconda and gives Hisuian Qwilfish a resistance to Volt Switch, allowing it to more easily beat Rotom and Eelektross. Alternatively, Tera Ghost lets it spinblock Cryogonal and Avalugg. 56 Speed EVs allow Hisuian Qwilfish to outspeed maximum Speed Cacturne as well as neutral-nature Abomasnow and Farigiraf; Jolly allows Hisuian Qwilfish to always outspeed the latter two.

Wallbreakers like Tauros and Mesprit benefit from Spikes weakening checks like Sandaconda and Hisuian Qwilfish that are somewhat easy to put in 2HKO range. To maximize the effect of Spikes and keep them up as long as possible, Hisuian Qwilfish appreciates help from Rotom, Cryogonal, and Articuno, which all put pressure onto Defog users like Braviary and Lurantis. Without Terastallizing, Hisuian Qwilfish folds to Sandaconda and other strong physical attackers that can switch into it like Toxicroak, Hisuian Sneasel, and both Tauros formes. To help solve this issue, Pokemon such as your own Sandaconda, Hattrem, and Drifblim can pivot into their attacks and threaten them with paralysis or burn. Hisuian Qwilfish is hindered by losing its Eviolite via Knock Off or Trick; pair it with Pokemon that can afford to lose their item such as Sandaconda, Sableye, and Sticky Hold Muk.

Swords Dance.description:
Hisuian Qwilfish is a potent rain sweeper. It has neutral coverage for every foe in NU bar Toxicroak and outspeeds every relevant revenge killer under rain. Even outside of rain, it's still a good option for late-game sweeping because its coverage and Eviolite-boosted bulk give it good leverage against most countermeasures the opponent could have. The major selling point to this set is Liquidation, as it always OHKOes Sandaconda after Hisuian Qwilfish uses Swords Dance and Terastallizes.

If you're using Hisuian Qwilfish on a rain team, pairing it with rain setters like Sableye, Electrode, and Whiscash is a must. Additionally, you'll want Floatzel, which is great at weakening potential checks like Tera Water Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Avalugg. Golduck is also a staple of NU rain teams and benefits from Hisuian Qwilfish weakening Toxicroak. If you're not using a rain team, simply pair Hisuian Qwilfish with wallbreakers like Medicham, Hisuian Sneasel, and Bruxish. Spikes support from options like Froslass and Cacturne helps too to weaken checks like Terastallized Sandaconda and Toxicroak.

Choice Band.description:
With a Choice Band, Scizor can efficiently act as a strong offensive pivot and a revenge killer against fast offensive threats. This is achievable with Bullet Punch in tandem with Technician, as it revenge kills Dragonite, Roaring Moon, and Iron Valiant. Bullet Punch can also remove slower threats such as Hatterene and Tera Fairy Kingambit. Close Combat grants Scizor coverage against Pokemon such as Iron Treads, Kingambit, and Garganacl and provides strong neutral coverage against foes like Rotom-W and Corviknight, especially if not running the corresponding coverage move. Thief is a good way for Scizor to deal a good amount of damage against Gholdengo, while Trailblaze can be used to deal with defensive Water-types like Rotom-W lacking Will-O-Wisp and Dondozo. Tera Steel is Scizor's best option for a Tera type, since it not only gives a boost to Scizor's Bullet Punch but also makes Scizor resistant to Stealth Rock. Alternatively, Tera Electric + Tera Blast can be run to hit Flying- and Water-types such as Toxapex, Dondozo, Corviknight, and Tera Flying Kingambit. 20 Speed EVs are run in order for Scizor to outspeed Corviknight.

Offensive teams appreciate Scizor's wallbreaking and revenge killing abilities. Scizor gets easily forced out by Great Tusk as well as Fire-types such as Skeledirge, Cinderace, and Volcarona. Therefore, Water-types such as Rotom-W and Azumarill make for good teammates. Rotom-W in particular synergizes well with Scizor, since the two of them can form a potent VoltTurn core. Azumarill also greatly appreciates Scizor pivoting into it. In return, Scizor can check Grass-types they struggle against like Breloom and Meowscarada. Scizor appreciates teammates that allow it to wallbreak much more easily, so entry hazard support from Pokemon like Garchomp are greatly appreciated. Gholdengo is another good teammate, since it can keep hazards on the field for Scizor to exploit in order to sweep late-game. If Scizor isn't running Thief, it can easily be checked by Gholdengo, so Dark-types like Kingambit pair well with Scizor. However, if Scizor is running Thief, it can struggle against Water-types, so Grass-types like Breloom, Meowscarada, and Tera Grass Volcarona make for good teammates. Scizor's lack of longevity means it can struggle with hazards, so hazard removers like Great Tusk, Cinderace, and Corviknight make for good teammates. Most of Scizor's damage output comes from Bullet Punch, so it dislikes Pokemon like Rotom-W, Corviknight, and Gholdengo switching into it. Thus, Pokemon that can counter them such as Meowscarada for the former, as well as Iron Moth for the latter two make for good teammates. Finally, setup sweepers such as Dragapult, Dragonite, and Roaring Moon appreciate Scizor muscling through walls like Garganacl, Tera Fairy Skeledirge, and Ting-Lu. They also appreciate the defensive utility Scizor brings with its ability to check Choice-locked Meowscarada and Calm Mind Iron Valiant.

Utility Pivot.description:
Scizor can function as a utility pivot due to its high Attack, good coverage, and ability to force switches from the likes of Iron Valiant. Due to its typing, it can check Dragonite, which is a phenomenal offensive threat in OU. Bullet Punch dents Garganacl and Iron Valiant, as well as being able to revenge kill sweepers such as Roaring Moon and Dragonite. Dragonite's Extreme Speed does very little to Scizor in return, and Scizor can break Multiscale on Dragonite. Close Combat nails Kingambit and deals decent damage to Ting-Lu, and while U-turn 3HKOs Ting-Lu, Close Combat can 2HKO if Stealth Rock is up. Alternatively, Defog improves Scizor's matchups against entry hazard users such as Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Great Tusk. Thief hits Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Ceruledge for super effective damage, as well as being Scizor's strongest option against Toxapex. Swords Dance can power up Bullet Punch and U-turn, allowing Scizor to break through Garganacl. Tera Steel powers up Bullet Punch, which is key in OHKOing Iron Valiant after Stealth Rock. Heavy-Duty Boots makes pivoting easier by ignoring entry hazards.

Scizor best fits on bulky offense and balance teams, as these appreciate a pivot which can force switches to bring in frail wallbreakers. Iron Valiant and Dragapult appreciate the momentum that Scizor provides, as they are 2HKOed by many common attacks. In return, they can handle physical walls that Scizor has trouble getting past such as Great Tusk and Dondozo. Scizor also appreciates entry hazard support from teammates such as Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Ting-Lu, as Scizor puts pressure on the opposing team with U-turn, forcing more switches and helping rack up more damage with hazards. Scizor also suffers from a lack of recovery, so defensive teammates such as Toxapex are appreciated, as they can help take pressure off of Scizor. Dragapult and Rotom-W form a good pivot core with Scizor, with Scizor luring Skeledirge and Dragapult luring Ting-Lu.

Swords Dance.description:
With Swords Dance, Scizor serves as a deadly wallbreaker and revenge killer for offensive teams. Close Combat is crucial to 2HKO defensive Rotom-W and defensive Great Tusk, as well as blow through Steel-types such as Kingambit and Iron Treads. Tera Blast paired with Tera Electric has a good chance to 2HKO Dondozo and can OHKO Toxapex, Alomomola, Corviknight, and offensive Gholdengo after a Swords Dance. Tera Electric also removes Scizor's Fire weakness, improving its matchup against Volcarona and Iron Moth, and grants it crucial resistances to Roaring Moon's Acrobatics and Iron Valiant's Thunderbolt. Alternatively, Quick Attack with Tera Normal gives Scizor a tool to pick off offensive Pokemon that resist Bullet Punch, such as Volcarona, Quaquaval, and Greninja. 180 Speed EVs allow Scizor to outspeed defensive Great Tusk and Rotom-W, while 76 HP EVs improve its bulk enough to survive Tera Flying Acrobatics from Roaring Moon.

Scizor is best utilized on fast, offensive teams that appreciate its ability to wear down common defensive cores and keep opposing sweepers such as Roaring Moon and Booster Energy Iron Valiant in check. Glimmora and Great Tusk can set entry hazards to help chip Pokemon like Garchomp and defensive Gholdengo into range of Scizor's attacks. Grimmsnarl can ease Scizor's sweep by setting up screens and appreciates falling back on Scizor to handle threats such as Iron Valiant.
