Special attackers like Iron Moth, Gholdengo, Greninja, and Iron Valiant can deal with the physical walls that check Scizor, such as Dondozo, Skeledirge, and Great Tusk. Scizor's ability to lure Dondozo and take it out with Tera Blast makes it an excellent partner for other physical sweepers that struggle with it, such as Dragonite and Kingambit. Conversely, Breloom is an excellent partner for Quick Attack Scizor that handles Dondozo and appreciates Scizor keeping Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Dragapult in check.

Offensive Swords Dance.description: Accounting for its diverse movepool, priority options, and huge base Attack, Scizor makes for an incredibly threatening wallbreaker and cleaner on more offensive teams. Furthermore, Scizor's Steel typing and decent bulk also complements its ability to keep many faster threats in check, such as Enamorus, Mega Latias, and Alakazam, while using them as setup fodder. Knock Off allows Scizor to break past Slowbro and Skeledirge while also OHKOing Victini and Ceruledge; it can even prove useful for removing items from several soft checks otherwise reliant on them, such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Cinderace and Leftovers from Iron Hands. Dual Wingbeat is usually preferred in the last slot for its coverage against specific physical walls able to blank its other attacks, such as Buzzwole, Mega Venusaur, and Tangrowth, but Close Combat can be used instead to deal more damage to Steel-types such as Skarmory, Magnezone, and Bisharp, putting immense pressure on the former at +2 while OHKOing the latter two unboosted. Quick Attack can also be used to give Scizor an extra priority attack, allowing it to finish off weakened foes that would otherwise resist Bullet Punch, such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Zeraora, although its lack of coverage can leave Scizor to struggle with breaking through the aforementioned defensive targets. Due to its lack of longevity and early- or mid-game prowess, this Scizor set usually fits best on select offensive teams that appreciate its versatility in being able to deal with faster threats. Entry hazard support from the likes of Excadrill and Lead Mew can help push several Pokemon, such as Iron Moth, Tyranitar, and Tapu Fini, into Scizor's KO threshold. Scizor also appreciates specific teammates that can help weaken or take advantage of Fire- and Steel-types, such as Iron Hands, Meteor Beam Nihilego, and Swords Dance Ceruledge, as it can often be dissuaded from sweeping by their presences in a vacuum while they remain healthy. Conversely, other late-game cleaners such as Swords Dance Bisharp, Z-Celebrate Victini, and Dragon Dance Mega Aerodactyl appreciate Scizor's own ability to force damage onto shared checks such as Hippowdon, Skarmory, and Choice Scarf Keldeo while allowing Scizor to forgo its late-game approach if attacking early may be more optimal for enabling the rest of its teammates.

Bulky Swords Dance.description: Scizor's excellent defensive typing, longevity with Roost, and priority in Bullet Punch can let it serve as an excellent bulky attacker, allowing it to reliably check Pokemon such as Alakazam and Mega Latias throughout a game while retaining its ability to sweep with Swords Dance once opposing walls are appropriately weakened. U-turn allows Scizor to provide pivoting support for its teammates on a forced switch, and in conjunction with Buginium Z, it even gives Scizor access to a one-time nuke that prevents it from switching out, allowing it to KO the likes of Amoonguss and Mandibuzz at +2 after slight chip damage. Alternatively, Knock Off can be used to remove important items from the likes of Cinderace, Celesteela, Salamence, and Iron Hands, allowing it to finish these Pokemon off more easily. Buginium Z is usually the preferred item for its aforementioned power boost to U-turn, on top of reducing damage taken from Bisharp's Knock Off, but Heavy-Duty Boots is an alternative that offsets Scizor's vulnerability to entry hazards. The given EV spread hits an extra Attack point, allows Scizor to reduce the amount of damage taken from attacks such as Excadrill's Earthquake and Mandibuzz's Foul Play and outspeeds Skeledirge and Skarmory. Scizor's pivoting capabilities in tandem with its ability to check faster threats are appreciated by defensive Pokemon otherwise vulnerable to the overwhelming offensive pressure exerted by them. Walls such as Ting-Lu, Rotom-W, and Slowbro are particularly helpful in this regard; Ting-Lu can check Fire-types such as Ceruledge and Iron Moth while setting up entry hazards to help Scizor cripple the opposing team more effectively, whereas Rotom-W and Slowbro can help maneuver around Fighting-types in Galarian Zapdos and Buzzwole while providing Scizor with additional pivoting support. Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Enamorus, Choice Specs Latios, and Nasty Plot Hydreigon, each appreciate Scizor's ability to provide safe entry with its U-turn or threaten the removal of items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Slowking and Assault Vest from Tangrowth if running Knock Off, helping in return by opening up the conditions required for Scizor to successfully sweep teams late-game. While Scizor can help teams out in checking faster threats, its lack of initial power on Bullet Punch outside of super effective hits, particularly against bulkier targets such as Galarian Moltres and Autotomize Celesteela, can leave a lot to be desired. As such, partners that can deal with these specific Pokemon, such as Mega Tyranitar, Thunder Wave Clefable, and defensive Tapu Fini, manage to help out in this regard.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band provides Scizor with immediate power on its attacks, allowing it to be more proficient as a wallbreaker, pivot, and late-game cleaner all at once. Bullet Punch puts substantial pressure on win conditions such as Calm Mind Clefable, Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar, and Tapu Bulu, outright OHKOing the latter from full HP. Knock Off allows Scizor to remove important items from Pokemon otherwise reliant on them to deter it, such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Salamence and Rocky Helmet from Buzzwole and Amoonguss. Pursuit takes advantage of Scizor's excellent typing against several Psychic-type Pokemon to trap them, most notably Mega Latias, Choice-locked Latios, and Slowking. Alternatively, Close Combat and Dual Wingbeat are options to pose a more immediate threat to their respective targets, such as Excadrill and Magnezone with Close Combat and Buzzwole and Mega Venusaur with Dual Wingbeat. Scizor fits best on bulky offense teams that can best take advantage of its strong momentum-grabbing capabilities and cleanup potential. Pivots such as Rotom-W, Cinderace, and Sandy Shocks can help Scizor by threatening the physical walls used to stifle it, including Skarmory and Buzzwole; in return, Scizor can help force damage onto walls that normally handle these pivots, such as Tangrowth and Blissey. Scizor also appreciates strong entry hazard removal options to avoid being worn down quickly, including Defog from Rotom-W, Tapu Fini, and Volcanion and Rapid Spin from Excadrill; the aforementioned Defog users are also capable of taking advantage of Fire-types that may pose a threat to Scizor, such as Cinderace and Ceruledge. On the other hand, entry hazard support from the likes of Clefable, Ting-Lu, and Sandy Shocks is imperative to increase the overall impact of Scizor's pivoting capabilities as well as extend its capacity to revenge kill threats like Galarian Moltres and Dragon Dance Salamence with Bullet Punch.

Bulky Swords Dance.description: Mega Scizor is a premier option for bulky offense teams looking for a check to common foes such as Rillaboom, Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele while also acting as a solid wincon—after a Swords Dance, Bullet Punch threatens many frail foes even without investment. Knock Off provides item removal against counters such as Toxapex, Volcarona, and Skeledirge; removing key items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers makes threats like these much easier for allies to deal with. U-turn alternatively allows Mega Scizor to function as a potent pivot; It can rack up chip damage while providing free points of entry for wallbreakers, since it switches easily into Fairy-types like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant among others. Roost provides valuable recovery, letting Mega Scizor shrug off chip damage from Stealth Rock and stray Knock Offs. The given defensive EVs allow Mega Scizor to always avoid a 2HKO from Mega Lopunny's Close Combat after Stealth Rock, while the Speed EVs allow Mega Scizor to outspeed uninvested Heatran. Mega Scizor's Knock Off support is valued greatly by allies such as Hisuian Samurott, which has a much easier time beating checks after they have had their Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots removed. Rotom-W notably forms a strong VoltTurn core with U-turn Mega Scizor, pivoting out on each other's checks to rack up chip damage. Mega Scizor has the added benefit of absorbing Knock Off for its team, so allies like Volcarona and Tornadus-T need not fear their key items being removed. However, Mega Scizor is countered by Fire-types like Heatran and Mega Charizard Y that threaten to OHKO it, so allies that can soak up these attacks such as Heatran itself and Toxapex are recommended.

Offensive 2 Attacks.description: Offensive Mega Scizor with Roost has the best of both worlds in terms of power and longevity, relying on offensive power to benefit its team. Close Combat hits most Steel-types like Heatran, Skarmory, and Ferrothorn for massive damage and is good neutral coverage for Rotom-W and Manaphy. Knock Off is an option over Roost to hit Skeledirge and Zapdos, while Sand Tomb is another option to beat Toxapex while also maintaining a good matchup into Heatran, but Roost is more useful in a majority of cases. The given EVs allow Mega Scizor to outrun uninvested Moltres and defensive Landorus-T. Offensive Mega Scizor is a good fit on offensive teams that appreciate its defensive utility, though limited, along with its ability to act as a cleaner with +2 Bullet Punch. It can be used to outspeed and heavily chip threats such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Rotom-W, letting the team break through these foes, especially as they have no reliable form of recovery. Since Mega Scizor can check Fairy-types like Iron Valiant, Clefable, and Tapu Lele, partners like Garchomp and Heatran synergize well, as they also switch into Fire-types like Volcarona for it. Without Knock Off, however, Mega Scizor is walled by bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo, so allies like Zapdos are good partners.

Choice Band (Steel).description:
Outspeeds Adamant Kingambit.

This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Swords Dance (Bug).description:
Thanks to its Steel typing, solid bulk, powerful STAB priority, and decent coverage moves, Scizor answers types such as Fairy, Ice, Rock, Ground, and Water. Swords Dance allows Scizor to OHKO the likes of Dragapult and Cyclizar. Technician-boosted Bullet Punch is Scizor's most spammable attack, serving as a priority STAB move to revenge kill sweepers like Belly Drum Azumarill and Flutter Mane. Close Combat answers Steel teams and threaten slower walls like Ting-Lu and Corviknight. Trailblaze allows Scizor to outspeed threats like Great Tusk and Hydreigon at +1 Speed and hits Quagsire and Gastrodon. Fury Cutter provides an additional Technician-boosted STAB move and is mainly used in tandem with Metronome to break Dondozo. Thief offers coverage and allows Life Orb Scizor to answer Gholdengo and 2HKO Skeledirge thanks to the boost from Technician, though Life Orb isn't recommended outside of these scenarios. Alternatively, Metal Coat enhances the power of Bullet Punch without drawbacks. The EV spread maximizes Scizor's damage output and allows it to outspeed uninvested Rotom forms and Adamant Azumarill.

Volcarona is the perfect partner for Scizor, as it's less threatened by Fire-types and can sweep through most Steel, Psychic, and Ground teams. It takes care of Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Klefki; in return, Scizor handles Rock-types like Glimmora and Lycanroc-D and weakens the opposing team to facilitate Volcarona's late-game sweep. Slither Wing offers great coverage against types that Scizor struggles to beat, threatening Electric- and Rock-types with Earthquake, Flying- and Water-types with Wild Charge, and Steel-types with Flare Blitz or Close Combat. Similar to Scizor, Lokix gets two powerful STAB priority moves in First Impression and Sucker Punch which, paired with Tinted Lens, allow it to OHKO faster threats like Greninja, Gengar, and Kilowattrel after chip damage. These priority moves, along with Masquerain's Sticky Web support, allow Bug teams to compensate for their generally slower Speed tier. Another good partner to Scizor is Guts Heracross, which can sponge status moves targeting its teammates and sweep through teams that have been weakened by Scizor. With its combination of Sleep Powder and Energy Ball, Vivillon can take out threats that give Bug teams trouble, particularly Dondozo. Rabsca and Forretress provide substantial support; Rabsca's Revival Blessing offers Scizor a second chance at breaking down the opponent's team, while Forretress's entry hazard stacking and Rapid Spin combination allows its teammates to switch in more safely and make holes in the opposing team.

Choice Band (Bug).description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis has been updated for Regulation E of Battle Stadium Singles. Note that The Indigo Disk Expansion releases on December 14th, so expect some movepool changes and a few new Pokemon to be introduced to the ruleset by then.

If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

Pivot.description:
• Thanks to its high Attack, great defensive typing and solid bulk, Scizor is an effective bulky pivot that can also punish faster foes with Technician-boosted Bullet Punch, such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, Alolan Ninetales, and Baxcalibur.

  • Knock Off versus Thief: Beyond being a fantastic support move, Knock Off is a great option against Gholdengo. Thief does offer more consistent damage than Knock Off though, thanks to Technician.

  • Dual Wingbeat: Dual Wingbeat is Scizor's best option against Ogerpon-H as well Fighting-types like Annihilape and Urshifu formes. For Choice Scarf sets, it's especially useful for OHKOing Breloom through its Focus Sash.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat is Scizor's best option to hit opposing Ursaluna-B and Chi-Yu as well as Steel types, even when using defensive EV spreads.

Other Options

  • Trailblaze: Besides gaining a useful Speed boost, Trailblaze does good damage to Urshifu-R and Rotom-W.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Terastallization can be quite helpful in either cleaning teams or preparing against Scizor's classic Fire-type issues, the power of its priority and pivoting don't make it needed for it to function consistently.

  • Water: Tera Water turns its Fire weakness into a resistance, giving Scizor a fighting chance against dangerous Fire-types such as Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, and Heatran.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is ideal for more offensive Scizor variants, making Bullet Punch an even better cleaning tool. Tera Steel also softens Scizor's weakness to Fire, letting it avoid the OHKO from attacks like Flutter Mane's Mystical Fire.

  • Flying: Increasing Dual Wingbeat's power with Terastallization nets Scizor some useful new OHKOs against offensive Urshifu formes and Annihilape.

  • Fire: Tera Fire is a great response most Ogerpon-H sets, and the burn immunity is especially helpful against Heatran.

  • Dragon: While not an incredible defensive typing, Tera Dragon is fantastic against most Fire and Water Pokemon that give Scizor trouble.

Items

  • Assault Vest: While much less immediately threatening than Choice Band, Assault Vest lets Scizor more comfortably switch into stray special attacks like Gholdengo's and Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball or Rotom-W's Volt Switch, improving its longevity.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band lets Scizor function as a scary late-game cleaner, especially with Tera Steel-boosted Bullet Punch. The high damage output also helps Scizor to break down walls for its teammates.

  • Choice Scarf: Despite Scizor's low Speed, Choice Scarf with a Jolly nature will make it just fast enough to outspeed key threats like Ogerpon-H and Chi-Yu. Just note that Scizor is still slow enough that Bullet Punch is still preferable over other Steel-type attacks.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet is perfect for more defensive Scizor, letting it continually switch into weaker physical attacks and wear down the team with U-turn and residual damage.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 92 Atk / 164 SpD with Adamant: This spread is meant to be used with Assault Vest, letting Scizor almost always avoid a 2HKO from Modest Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball. It also maintains enough Attack investment to always OHKO uninvested Chien-Pao after Stealth Rock chip.

  • 236 HP / 68 Atk / 204 Def with Adamant: This spread avoids an OHKO from Tera Dark Life Orb Chien-Pao, is not 2HKOed by Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast, and reduces the amount of residual damage Scizor receives thanks to the HP stat being 1 lower than divisible by 16.

  • 236 HP / 68 Atk / 204 Def with Adamant: This bulky spread lets Scizor survive +2 Life Orb Adamant Tera Ghost Mimikyu's Shadow Claw.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Def with Impish: Defensive Scizor might seem strange, but when paired with Rocky Helmet, it becomes an effective pivot that can survive extreme attacks: it avoids the OHKO from Choice Band Tera Dark Chien-Pao's Crunch as well as the 2HKO from Adamant Landorus-T's Earthquake. Just note that this will make Scizor focus more on pivoting than revenge killing with Bullet Punch.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Scizor's Speed with Choice Scarf will at least speedtie with the rare Meowscarada, and outspeed important threats like Ogerpon formes and Garchomp.

Minor Optimizations

  • Slow U-turn: Scizor already has a very slow U-turn, but Scizor can drop the Speed investment from any spread and run a Speed IV of 27 to underspeed opposing Scizor and the rare Chesnaught.

Swords Dance.description:
• Scizor's incredible power and good typing make it one of the premier priority sweepers, being able to sweep through huge threats such as Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao!

  • Close Combat: Close Combat lets Scizor smash through Ursaluna-B and Ting-Lu, and 2HKO Corviknight after a boost.

  • Knock Off: Knock Off is Scizor's best bet against Gholdengo, in addition to being a great support move in general.

  • Dual Wingbeat: After a boost, Dual Wingbeat smashes through bulky Fighting-types like Urshifu-R and Annihilape.

  • U-turn: While pivoting doesn't gel well with sweeping, it makes this kind of Scizor very adaptable, and is especially effective at getting away from Pokemon that threaten with residual damage, like Wo-Chien and Garganacl.

Other Options

  • Trailblaze: Trailblaze will 2HKO even the bulkiest Rotom-W without a boost and deal good chip damage to Dondozo. The Speed boost also comes in handy considering how crowded Scizor's Speed tier is.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium / Low: Terastallization works very well at shutting down common methods of revenge killing or walling Scizor, but its typing is good enough to function without Terastallization. If using U-turn, Scizor can focus on pivoting in some matches, making Terastallization even less needed.

  • Water: Tera Water lets Scizor ambush Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Heatran with a resistance and is especially handy against Fire-types when using Tera Blast.

  • Steel: Boosting Bullet Punch is Scizor's best ticket for revenge killing and late-game sweeping, and it retains its Flying-type resistance into powerful Tera Flying Choice Band users like Dragonite and Landorus-T.

  • Fire: Tera Fire ensures that Siczor's hard work won't get ruined by Will-O-Wisp, in addition to stopping revenge kills from common Fire-types like Ogerpon-H and Heatran.

  • Dark: Tera Dark can cushion Shadow Ball from Gholdengo and Flutter Mane, giving it an extra turn to set up or hit back with Tera-boosted Knock Off.

  • Electric: Tera Electric is Scizor's best shot of breaking past Toxapex and Urshifu-R with Tera Blast, and it does good chip damage to Dondozo.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry and 244 HP EVs: Sitrus Berry trades late-game sweeping power for new setup opportunities, such as avoiding a 2HKO from Modest Gholdengo that lack Choice Specs and a good chance of avoiding a 2HKO from Timid Rotom-W's Hydro Pump. Make sure to run 244 Speed EVs to gain an even HP number, letting Sitrus activate after getting hit by Ruination once.

  • Life Orb: While Life Orb does compromise Scizor's bulk, it's worth it for being able to OHKO Iron Bundle with a boosted Bullet Punch. Boosted Close Combat will also OHKO even physically defensive Ursaluna-B, and it has good shot of OHKOing physically defensive Ting-Lu.

  • Rocky Helmet: Best used with U-turn, Rocky Helmet transforms this Scizor into a good bulky pivot that has the surprising option to sweep late-game.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 28 Atk / 204 Def / 20 SpD / 4 Spe with Adamant: This bulky spread avoids the OHKO from Adamant Tera Ghost Life Orb Mimikyu's +2 Shadow Claw. When used with Sitrus Berry and 244 HP EVs, it also avoids the 2HKO from Modest Gholdengo's Shadow Ball.

  • 236 HP / 228 Atk / 20 Def / 20 SpD / 4 Spe with Adamant: This spread gives Scizor enough bulk to survive Tera Dark Life Orb Chien-Pao's Crunch, and less residual damage if using U-turn. It also avoids a 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast. With Sitrus Berry, Modest Gholdengo's Shadow Ball is also no longer a 2HKO.

  • 228 HP / 124 Atk / 156 SpD with Adamant: This Sitrus Berry optimized spread avoids a 2HKO from Jolly Chien-Pao's Crunch, Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump, and Modest Choice Specs Tera Fairy Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Def with Impish: This defensive spread is best used with U-turn and Rocky Helmet, making Scizor function more like a bulky pivot that can sweep late-game.

  • 60 HP / 252 Atk / 196 Spe with Jolly: If using Trailblaze, this spread outspeeds Ogerpon formes after a boost.

Minor Optimizations

  • Slow U-turn: When running U-turn, Scizor can drop the Speed investment from any spread and run a Speed IV of 27 to underspeed opposing Scizor and the rare Chesnaught.

Offensive Swords Dance (Steel).description: Mega Scizor makes for a strong wallbreaker and sweeper on Steel teams thanks to its access to Swords Dance, high Attack stat, and well-rounded bulk. Bullet Punch is Mega Scizor's strongest STAB move, and its priority allows it to revenge kill faster threats such as Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny. Close Combat is Mega Scizor's strongest coverage move, enabling it to more easily beat Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Heatran. After a Swords Dance boost, Mega Scizor becomes strong enough to 2HKO Celesteela, opposing Mega Scizor, and physically defensive Gastrodon. Knock Off removes essential items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Tornadus-T and Black Sludge from Toxapex, and it also provides Mega Scizor with strong coverage against Aegislash, Skeledirge, and Gholdengo. Alternatively, Trailblaze can also be used to 2HKO bulky Water- or Ground-type Pokemon most other Steel-types struggle with such as Mega Swampert and Gastrodon, as well as potentially OHKO Azumarill and Rotom-W after a Swords Dance boost and Stealth Rock damage. 132 Speed EVs are invested in order for Mega Scizor to outspeed Jolly Azumarill as well as Hydreigon and Urshifu-S after a Trailblaze. Heatran and Ferrothorn are great teammates because they are able to set entry hazards to wear down incoming foes, and Heatran also has the added benefit of providing a Fire immunity thanks to its ability. Ferrothorn can also provide passive healing for Mega Scizor via the use of Leech Seed. In return, Mega Scizor is able to threaten faster Fighting-types such as Sneasler and Iron Valiant with Bullet Punch. Gholdengo is able to threaten Toxapex and Tapu Lele, and it along with Aegislash can also hinder foes with Toxic and Thunder Wave respectively if they are running defensive sets, easing set up for Mega Scizor. In return, Mega Scizor can remove Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Ting-Lu, and Galarian Moltres. Specially defensive Celesteela is an excellent special wall that can wall Choice Specs Tapu Lele and Mega Altaria, while also being able to spread status and use Leech Seed to aid Mega Scizor in its sweeping. As Mega Scizor is more vulnerable to hazards compared to other Steel-types, it appreciates hazard removal from the likes of Corviknight, Excadrill, and Iron Treads. Excadrill and Iron Treads also have the added merit of handling Fire-types like Victini and Ogerpon-H. Excadrill can also bypass Mega Sableye's Magic Bounce and inflict poison on it thanks to Mold Breaker, while Iron Treads can threaten both Landorus formes with Ice Spinner.

Sticky Web (Rock).description: Shuckle is an essential member of any hyper offensive Rock team due to its access to Sticky Web, which allows teammates such as Mega Diancie and Terrakion to dominate the Steel and Dark matchups. With Mental Herb, it isn't scared to set up entry hazards in front of common Taunt users such as Deoxys-S and Zeraora. Encore shuts down setup sweepers such as Mega Scizor and bulky walls such as Hippowdon and Ferrothorn, locking them into their setup and recovery moves. Shuckle can generate momentum after setting up hazards by using Final Gambit, allowing teammates such as Shell Smash Omastar, Mega Diancie, and Choice Band Tyranitar to come in and start exerting pressure. Toxic can also be used to punish more passive Pokemon such as Gastrodon and Hippowdon. Mega Diancie can bounce back any hazards or status moves directed at Shuckle and provides amazing offensive pressure and coverage against Poison-, Steel-, and Dragon-types. Sticky Web allows Choice Band Tyranitar to outspeed Choice Specs Gholdengo and Nidoking, both of which are threats to Rock. Omastar and Minior benefit from Stealth Rock breaking potential Focus Sashes and are great partners to have in the Grass and Fighting matchups. Thanks to Sticky Web, Omastar outspeeds Sand Rush Excadrill after one shell smash and +1 Spe Nihilego outspeeds Barraskewda in the rain. Power Herb Nihilego is able to sweep teams as well with Meteor Beam and amazing coverage. Thanks to Sticky Web, Choice Scarf Terrakion outspeeds Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Greninja, which are threats to Rock teams. Hisuian Arcanine is able to deal massive damage, OHKOing Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Heatran, Mega Gallade, and Corviknight after Stealth Rock.

Sticky Web Setter.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

Swords Dance.description: Mega Heracross uses its gigantic Attack stat alongside Swords Dance to be a powerful wallbreaker, pressuring common physical walls like Skarmory and Mega Venusaur. Swords Dance boosts Mega Heracross's Attack to incredible heights and lets it OHKO a majority of the Pokemon in the tier, including walls like Skarmory and Hippowdon. Close Combat OHKOes threats like Cinderace and Mega Tyranitar while 2HKOing bulkier Pokemon like Iron Hands and Skarmory. Rock Blast threatens Flying-types such as Enamorus, Salamence, and both Thundurus formes, as well as Fire-types like Iron Moth and Ceruledge that could otherwise take Close Combat and force Mega Heracross out. Pin Missile threatens Slowbro and Mega Venusaur, while Substitute lets Mega Heracross avoid Will-O-Wisp from Mega Sableye, capitalize from the forced switches it generates, and ease prediction against Pokemon it forces out. Physical cleaners like Swords Dance Scizor appreciate Mega Heracross being able to threaten their switch-ins, such as Skarmory and Mega Venusaur, allowing them to sweep late-game. Mega Heracross is prone to being revenge killed by faster threats like Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Enamorus, so teammates that can deal with them such as Tapu Fini, Mega Tyranitar, and Celesteela, respectively, are appreciated. Fire-type partners like Cinderace and Iron Moth can threaten Buzzwole, which walls Mega Heracross; Poison-types like Amoonguss can threaten Fairy-types like Tapu Fini and Unaware Clefable, which also wall it.

Life Orb compensates for Sneasel’s naturally middling damage output and makes taking its hits more difficult. Eviolite augments Sneasel’s bulk, which can translate to setup opportunities against threats like Morpeko. However, both options are generally less consistent than Heavy-Duty Boots, which lets Sneasel freely switch in and out to wear foes down or revenge kill weakened targets like Skuntank and Tauros. Tera Ghost makes Sneasel immune to Fighting-type attacks from the likes of Hisuian Sneasel and Passimian, allowing it to either retaliate with a strong attack or set up on them.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Trailblaze lets Hisuian Sneasel outspeed potential revenge killers like Choice Scarf Passimian and Rotom. Substitute is useful for turning Muk and Weezing into setup fodder. Lash Out hits Ghost-types like Rotom, Tera Ghost Orthworm, and Sableye and should be used alongside Tera Dark. Tera Fire protects Hisuian Sneasel from being burned and, when used with Tera Blast, lets it break through Houndstone. In addition to pairing well with Lash Out, Tera Dark also turns the tables on Psychic- and Ghost-types like Choice Scarf Indeedee and Haunter. Tera Blast Psychic is a niche option to more immediately bypass Muk, opposing Hisuian Sneasel, and Weezing. Tera Grass gets rid of Hisuian Sneasel's Ground weakness and also powers up Trailblaze.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Choice Band.description:
Shadow Claw and Lash Out both target Ghost-types like Rotom, though Shadow Claw comes with the added benefit of hitting opposing Hisuian Sneasel neutrally. Tera Dark makes Hisuian Sneasel immune to Psychic-type moves from Alolan Raichu and Indeedee and also powers up Lash Out. Tera Blast with Tera Psychic or Tera Fire offers great coverage against Muk, Tera Poison Arboliva, and Houndstone.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Choice Scarf.description:
Tera Fighting makes Close Combat more reliable for cleaning mid- to late-game, but Tera Ghost can be used instead to OHKO Rotom after Stealth Rock with Shadow Claw.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Choice Item.description:
Hisuian Sneasel is one of NU's premier revenge killers, regardless of the item it holds. Choice Scarf sets are wonderful because they reliably beat Calm Mind Jolteon, a feat most other Choice Scarf users fail to do because they're specially offensive. On the flipside, Choice Band sets retain great revenge killing potential because Hisuian Sneasel is so naturally fast, and they're very effective wallbreakers to boot thanks to their solid coverage. For the Pokemon Hisuian Sneasel can't consistently defeat like Tera Ghost Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Sableye, Switcheroo provides a good means of limiting their defensive capabilities. Picking its Tera type is fairly arbitrary, though Tera Fighting lets Choice Band Hisuian Sneasel 2HKO Sandaconda with Close Combat and Choice Scarf Hisuian Sneasel 2HKO Toxicroak after Stealth Rock; alternatively, Tera Dark provides defensive utility against Mesprit, ensures Night Slash OHKOes Rotom after Stealth Rock, and denies Sableye's Prankster Will-O-Wisp.

Despite Choice Scarf and Choice Band Hisuian Sneasel being somewhat different in function, their teammates are pretty similar. Both benefit from teammates like Clawitzer, Rotom, and Mesprit that can take advantage of Sandaconda so they feel less inclined to Terastallize and deal with it themselves. Where they differ is that Choice Scarf Sneasel is far more suited as a late-game cleaner and, as a result, is more reliant on wallbreakers like Guts Ursaring, Magneton, and offensive Appletun to weaken its checks. On the other hand, Choice Band Sneasel prioritizes its role as a wallbreaker and supports late-game sweepers like Dudunsparce and Trailblaze Scyther.

Swords Dance.description:
Hisuian Sneasel is one of NU's most dangerous setup sweepers; with Swords Dance and Trailblaze, very little can stop it if it obtains both boosts. Even some of its sturdiest checks in Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Tera Poison Appletun can struggle to keep up, and offensive answers like Choice Scarf Mesprit and Rotom become unreliable because they're slower after a single Trailblaze. Tera Grass is fantastic for turning non-Glare Sandaconda into setup fodder and giving Trailblaze the extra power needed to beat Rotom, but Tera Dark enables Hisuian Sneasel to run Night Slash, giving it a better matchup against Ghost-types in Eviolite Haunter, Drifblim, Sableye, and Terastallized Sandaconda while also making it harder for Choice Scarf Mesprit to revenge kill it.

Hisuian Sneasel's Eviolite-boosted bulk, although not stellar, is enough to let it set up on resisted attacks. So, pairing it with pivots like Bombirdier, Rotom, and Braviary that can bring it in against foes like non-Thunder Wave Qwilfish, Muk, and non-Glare Sandaconda if you're using Tera Grass is recommended. Keep in mind, though, that the Sandaconda matchup can be difficult with Terastallization available to your opponent; teammates like Tera Ice Jolteon, Swords Dance Scyther, and Guts Ursaring that can force it to take damage or Terastallize early-game make it far less threatening.

RestTalk.description:
Bulk Up can be used over an attacking move so that Ursaring doubles as a setup sweeper, though this limits its coverage and thus makes it less self-sufficient. Running 88 Speed EVs lets Ursaring outspeed uninvested Weezing. Ursaring can also run specially defensive EV spreads to act as a special wall.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Flame Orb.description:
Shadow Claw threatens Rotom, an otherwise solid offensive check to Ursaring. Earthquake hits Skuntank without triggering Aftermath and deals more damage to Houndstone than Shadow Claw. Protect lets Ursaring immediately activate Flame Orb, but Trailblaze lets it outrun foes like Skuntank, Morpeko, and Pyroar. Tera Normal further powers up Facade but offers nothing defensively. Tera Ghost and Tera Fighting boost Shadow Claw and Close Combat, respectively, and also flip the matchup against Fighting- and Dark-types like Passimian and Skuntank.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

nu.overview: Ursaring is an amazing wallbreaker in NU. Eviolite + Bulk Up Ursaring makes for a fantastic sweeper, while Flame Orb sets make great use of Trailblaze, which makes Ursaring more difficult to revenge kill, and makes for a great status absorber for its teammates. However, Bulk Up Ursaring only has room for one attack, leaving it lacking in coverage, and Flame Orb Ursaring's poor defenses and Speed leave it subject to easy revenge killing.
nu.comments:
Other Options

Ursaring can use Toxic Orb to benefit from Quick Feet, but this set often falls short in both Speed and power. Bulk Up Ursaring can forgo Sleep Talk in favor of another coverage move, but this leaves it quite vulnerable after Rest. Crunch can be used over Play Rough for overall better coverage, but Tera Fairy's defensive attributes and STAB Play Rough are better in most situations. Ursaring can drop a setup move altogether on the RestTalk set, making for a great special tank with a little extra coverage, typically using Body Slam for STAB and Play Rough or Crunch to hit Ghost-types.

Checks and Counters

Anti-setup Pokemon: Bulk Up Ursaring is quite hard to get going against common anti-setup Pokemon like Haze Vaporeon, Strength Sap Drifblim, and Trick Rotom. Tera Fairy at least allows Ursaring an immunity to Dragon Tail, but there are plenty of Encore, Haze, and similar utility move users available that can make it difficult for Ursaring to sweep.

Fighting-types and Coverage: NU is teeming with Fighting-types ready to punch Ursaring in the face; Medicham, Toxicroak, Passimian, and Paldean Tauros pressure Ursaring to switch out or Terastallize for fear of being KOed. Pokemon with Fighting-type coverage like Scyther and Eelektross can chunk Ursaring enough to force it to use Rest before it can accumulate enough boosts to be a threat.

Bulk Up.description:
Set Details

Ursaring only gets to pick one offensive move, so Play Rough is preferred for its great offensive coverage and lack of immunities, but Body Slam has more immediate damage and can spread paralysis. With Tera Fairy, Ursaring inverts its weakness to Fighting and gains STAB on Play Rough. Tera Ghost takes subverting its weakness to the extreme, turning the tables on the many Fighting-types in the tier. 88 Speed EVs outspeed Vaporeon and Umbreon, which hamper Ursaring with Haze or Foul Play. The remaining EVs are put into Special Defense to allow Ursaring to wall special attackers while boosting Defense with Bulk Up.

Although its bulk often prevents it from being outright overpowered, Ursaring's setup attempts can be thwarted by utility Pokemon such as Haze Muk and Vaporeon and Encore Cacturne and Zoroark. Wallbreakers like Medicham and Zoroark and entry hazard setters like Qwilfish and Sandaconda assist in breaking through and wearing them down. Knock Off users like Bombirdier, Klawf, and Passimian can leave Eviolite Ursaring vulnerable to following attacks. Knock Off absorbers like Sandaconda and Umbreon make for great teammates. Because it lacks Heavy-Duty Boots or Leftovers to offset hazard damage, Ursaring appreciates hazard control from the likes of Drifblim and Lurantis. Pokemon vulnerable to status infliction like Toxicroak and Vaporeon appreciate the fact that Ursaring punishes the use of status moves like Will-O-Wisp from Drifblim and Glare from Sandaconda.

Trailblaze Sweeper.description:
Set Details

Trailblaze lets Ursaring take advantage of passive Pokemon like Chansey and Vaporeon to outspeed faster threats like Scyther and Zoroark after one use and Choice Scarf Passimian after two. Guts Facade easily 2HKOes physically bulky Pokemon like Sandaconda and Dudunsparce. Tera Ghost allows Ursaring to effectively bait Fighting-type moves and boosts Shadow Claw, which can be used to hit Ghost-types like Drifblim and Rotom. Swords Dance allows Ursaring to muscle past setup sweepers like Coil Sandaconda, Eelektross, and Curse Muk while also giving Facade enough power to defeat Steel-types like Perrserker and Tera Steel Eelektross. Alternatively, Close Combat immediately threatens Steel-types like Perrserker and Tera Steel users like Appletun and Eelektross. Tera Fighting and Tera Grass are alternative options used to boost Ursaring's other moves. Tera Grass notably improves Ursaring's matchup against physically bulky Pokemon like Sandaconda and Vaporeon.

Slow pivots like Eelektross and Perrserker help Ursaring enter the battlefield safely, mitigating its frailty and burn-induced timer. Healing Wish from Chansey or Indeedee-F can allow Ursaring another opportunity to shred through the opposition. Oricorio-F and Drifblim can ease the matchup against Fighting-types and use Defog to ensure Ursaring takes minimal damage when hitting the field, and Oricorio-F also has U-turn to bring in Ursaring more often.

Specially Defensive Wall (Ice).description: Piloswine is one of Ice teams' best specially defensive walls, capable of filling some of Ice teams' biggest roles of being an entry hazard setter and Electric immunity. Thick Fat coupled with Eviolite gives Piloswine tremendous bulk, with which it can check dangerous Fire-type threats to Ice such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y by disposing of them with Rock Slide. 12 EVs in Attack guarantees an OHKO on offensive Volcarona. Another one of Piloswine's amazing traits is its Ground typing, which makes it a great asset in the Electric matchup by preventing a Volt Switch onslaught while also letting it hit Electric-types super effectively with STAB Earthquake. Toxic is an option to put defensive switch-ins such as Skeledirge and Rotom-W on a timer, helping Piloswine's teammates overpower them, but Roar is an alternative choice to force out threats that may use it to set up, such as Mega Scizor, and to rack up hazard damage from its Stealth Rock and Cloyster's Spikes to wear down threats such as Urshifu-R and Mega Venusaur. Piloswine appreciates Alolan Ninetales's snow and Aurora Veil, which let it wall the opposition more easily. Piloswine is, however, extremely vulnerable to Water-types, so partnering it with Kyurem or Arctozolt is appreciated, as they can easily break Water teams. Substitute Baxcalibur also threatens Poison teams, which can cripple Piloswine with Toxic. Weavile with a Z-Crystal is also a good Knock Off absorber for Piloswine, as losing Eviolite ruins Piloswine; Weavile also forces immense progress by removing key items from Celesteela and Skeledirge, which become susceptible to Stealth Rock afterwards, or outright breaking through them with a Z-Move. Galarian Darmanitan and Shell Smash Cloyster can threaten Steel teams with Flare Blitz and Hydro Pump or Hidden Power Fire, respectively. The Stealth Rocks and Toxic spread by Piloswine also accentuates the breaking power of teammates such as Swords Dance or Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Belly Drum Cetitan. IronPress Avalugg and defensive Cloyster with Hidden Power Fire are also good partners in being able to shut down Mega Scizor. Avalugg, Articuno, and Cloyster are also capable of removing entry hazards, with the latter two also being able to pivot in Piloswine with U-turn and Teleport, respectively.

Physically Defensive (Steel).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Physically Defensive (Flying).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defensive.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Skarmory is a great physical wall in the metagame thanks to its impressive defensive typing and great physical bulk allowing it to handle threats such as Excadrill and Scizor among other foes. Skarmory also serves as a valuable Spikes user thanks to it being able to set up against threats such as Buzzwole, Blissey, and non-Flamethrower Clefable. The combination of Iron Defense and Body Press is Skarmory’s preferred choice to make progress against teams, as it allows it to stonewall threats such as Scizor, Bisharp, and Tyranitar while also further pressuring threats such as Blissey and Hippowdon. Dropping Iron Defense and Body Press for Whirlwind or Toxic and Brave Bird respectively is also an option on more offensive teams to pressure threats such as Buzzwole and Mega Venusaur more effectively while also offering extra team support by phasing or spreading poison damage. However, this comes at the cost of being far more passive against Excadrill and lacks a proper response to Bisharp and Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar. On stall teams, Skarmory has the choice of running Defog in place of either Spikes or Iron Defense and can also run an EV spread of 248 HP / 76 Def / 184 Spe with an Impish nature to outspeed Choice Band Tyranitar, allowing it to boost or safely heal up before Tyranitar can 2HKO it. Skarmory’s main item of choice is Rocky Helmet to get residual damage off against foes with U-turn such as Scizor and Galarian Zapdos while also chipping setup sweepers such as Mega Tyranitar, but it can also run Shed Shell on bulkier playstyles such as balance and stall in order to avoid being trapped by Magnezone. Skarmory can struggle a lot against special attackers such as Latios and Enamorus, so specially defensive walls such as Blissey, Chansey, and specially defensive Skeledirge are good partners to shore up that weakness. Mega Tyranitar is another good partner, since it can switch into and Pursuit trap threats that pressure Skarmory such as Iron Moth and Hisuian Zoroark. Common pivots that take advantage of Skarmory such as Cinderace, Thundurus, and Thundurus-T also hate being Pursuit trapped by Mega Tyranitar. Skarmory also has issues against Fire-types such as Cinderace and Victini, so bulky Water-types such as Slowbro, Slowking, Gastrodon, and Alomomola can help deal with them. Electric-types such as Thundurus, Thundurus-T, Sandy Shocks, and Zeraora can also threaten Skarmory, so bulky Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon are good partners to hinder them, but bulky Grass-types such as Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Mega Venusaur also work as teammates at the cost of being unable to block Volt Switch. The aforementioned Ground-types can also form strong entry hazard stacking cores with Skarmory that bulkier playstyles such as stall enjoy greatly. Offensively, wallbreakers such as Cinderace, Iron Hands, Latios, and Galarian Zapdos make for good partners, since they appreciate Skarmory's Spikes helping them chip their checks so they can wallbreak easier.

Skarmory's huge physical bulk and valuable defensive typing allow it to check common physical attackers like Mega Lopunny, Kartana, Weavile, and Dragonite. Its immunity to Toxic and Spikes further accentuates its defensive capabilities, making it a very resilient wall. Aside from granting Skarmory an adequate offensive presence, Iron Defense + Body Press lets it beat and contest with Attack-boosting foes like Mega Scizor, Garchomp, and Kingambit that attempt to break past it. Rocky Helmet punishes the physical attackers it’s tasked to check, notably Mega Scizor, Mega Lopunny, and Landorus-T's U-turn and Great Tusk and Excadrill’s Rapid Spin. Tera Dragon allows it to check Mega Swampert, Urshifu-R, Victini, and non-Dragon Claw Mega Charizard X better at the cost of being weaker against Weavile and Garchomp. Tera Fighting lets Skarmory deal with Kingambit more comfortably. The EV spread allows Skarmory to outspeed Mega Mawile and maximum speed Kingambit. Skarmory fits on defensive builds, ranging from balance to stall. Special walls like Garganacl and Hippowdon are necessary to cover threats like Dragapult and Volcarona that would exploit Skarmory's poor special bulk. Hippowdon is an exceptional partner, as it also deals with foes like Zapdos, Tapu Koko, Mega Charizard Y, as well as mixed attackers like Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant. Moreover, they form an entry hazard-stacking core with Skarmory by providing Stealth Rock and spreading further chip damage with Salt Cure, Toxic, and sand to slowly crumble the opposition. Pokemon like Mega Charizard X, Iron Hands, and Zamazenta are a few physical attackers that Skarmory can struggle with; Toxapex, Clefable, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge, respectively, help handle them. Its inability to threaten Gholdengo can be covered by teammates like Kingambit and Clodsire. Late-game cleaners or bulky setup sweepers like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, and Gholdengo appreciate Skamory's Spikes chipping down their checks like Great Tusk, Garganacl, and Kingambit, respectively; Gholdengo also prevents most entry hazard removal attempts due to its typing and Good as Gold.

Nasty Plot.description:
Thanks to its strong offensive typing, access to setup moves, and useful coverage, Houndoom establishes itself as a high level offensive threat in the PU metagame. Fire Blast allows Houndoom to have some extra power and can be especially useful in situations where boosting with Nasty Plot is not possible. It also helps Houndoom to muscle through targets that either are extremely bulky or naturally resist Dark Pulse, such as Tinkatuff. Alternatively, Flamethrower provides a less powerful but more consistent Fire-type STAB attack and eliminates the risk of a missed Fire Blast prematurely ending Houndoom's sweep. Sludge Bomb gives Houndoom a strong special coverage move able to hit certain targets for neutral or super effective damage that would otherwise wall Houndoom handily, such as Carbink, Dachsbun, and opposing Houndoom. Sucker Punch gives Houndoom a safe option against faster, weakened targets that threaten to revenge kill it, such as Dugtrio, Alolan Dugtrio, and Basculin, although one must be wary of these Pokemon's access to their own priority. Trailblaze is another option, allowing Houndoom to remedy its underwhelming Speed and become a much more threatening sweeper, either through a well-timed prediction or by finishing off a weakened target. Heavy-Duty Boots is mandatory on this set to offer Houndoom opportunities to use Nasty Plot, since it is already relatively frail. Flash Fire both sets it apart from and allows it to combat fellow Fire-type attackers such as Pyroar, Charizard, and opposing Houndoom, allowing it to safely switch in on their Fire-type STAB moves while also boosting the power of its own. In a similar manner, it can also take advantage of Will-O-Wisp from targets such as Midreavus and Rotom-S. Tera Dark increases the power of Dark Pulse even further while also removing key weaknesses to Rock, Water, and Ground. Tera Grass offers a resistance to the latter two while also increasing the power of Trailblaze and pairing well with Houndoom's natural Fire immunity. Lastly, Tera Poison increases the power of Sludge Bomb, increasing damage against foes such as Carbink and Dachsbun while also providing a resistance to STAB moves from Pokemon such as Skuntank. Also of note, Houndoom should only use a Hasty nature if it is running Sucker Punch; otherwise, it should use a Timid nature and 0 Attack IVs.

Houndoom's greatest challenge is its rather disappointing Speed, especially compared to other Fire-type wallbreakers like Charizard and Pyroar, so a Sticky Web setter such as Masquerain is greatly appreciated. Houndoom also greatly appreciates teammates like Perrserker and Skuntank that can handle Dachsbun and Carbink, especially if it opts not to run Sludge Bomb. Similarly, teammates that can handle bulky Water-types such as Lumineon and Whiscash are welcome, as while Houndoom can do relatively good damage to these Pokemon with Dark Pulse, doing so is extremely risky without a Nasty Plot boost or a defensive Tera. Therefore, Grass-types such as Gogoat and Thwackey are natural partners, with Houndoom especially appreciating the latter's ability to set Grassy Terrain, both allowing Houndoom some passive recovery and lessening the damage from opposing Earthquakes. Fast revenge killers, such as Electrode and Raichu, and Choice Scarf users such as Golduck, are also excellent teammates, as they are able to handily dispose of targets that Houndoom has already heavily damaged.

Swift Swim.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Choice Band.description:
• Earthquake beats Bellibolt, Iron Moth, non-Air Balloon Iron Hands, and Sandy Shocks.
  • Gunk Shot beats most Sylveon sets, non-Encore + Disable Iron Valiant, and Azumarill.
  • Ice Shard is for Garchomp and Roaring Moon.
  • Head Smash OHKOes Talonflame and most Iron Bundle.
  • Play Rough beats Choice Band Annihilape and Choice Band Ting Lu.
  • Counter OHKOes Choice Band Slither Wing thanks to Donphan surviving an attack with Sturdy, as well as Attack Booster Energy Slither Wing if it doesn't use Bulk Up turn 1.
  • Donphan can also run an alternative spread of 32 HP / 248 Atk / 96 Def / 132 Spe with a Adamant Nature. The HP and Defense EVs allow Donphan to survive a hit from Mold Breaker Choice Band Haxorus and 2HKO it with Ice Shard. The Speed EVs allow Donphan to outspeed uninvested Skeledirge.
  • While using Head Smash beats non-Substitute Volcarona, using it against Substitute Volcarona can lead to Donphan losing, so it should use Earthquake instead.

Endeavor.description:
• Sturdy and Sitrus Berry allow Donphan to always get a Substitute up. This allows Donphan to beat Choice item Pokemon like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao, regardless of whether they go for an OHKO or not.
  • Earthquake is Donphan's strongest STAB move, beating Pokemon like Magnezone and Clodsire.
  • EVs are put into Attack and Defense to deal the most damage and help with physical attackers, since physical attacks rarely activate Sturdy.
  • 0 Speed IVs allow Donphan to be as slow as possible, which lets Substitute be used after slow threats like Dondozo and Garganacl move, creating a free turn to use Endeavor or Substitute again. 0 Special Defense IVs are used to activate Sturdy more often.
  • Donphan should almost always use Substitute turn 1. Donphan should continue to use it until its HP does not allow it to do so, proceeding to use Endeavor + Ice Shard to go for the KO.
  • An exception to this rule is that if Donphan can 2HKO with a combination Earthquake and Ice Shard, it should do that instead, such as against Choice item Dragapult, Magnezone, and Clodsire.

RegenVest.description: Assault Vest Donphan is a solid special pivot that can check the likes of Sandy Shocks while also removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Knock Off cripples switch-ins and can support offensive teammates. Body Press is used as a coverage option for Earth Eater Kingambit and Iron Treads, which would otherwise wall Donphan. Offensive Pokemon susceptible to hazards such as Chien-Pao and Dragonite appreciate Donphan's spinning capabilities. Physically defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Garganacl also pair well with Donphan, as it can handle special attackers like Sandy Shocks that threaten them. Donphan can be prone to residual damage, so it's recommended to pair it with a Wish user like Scream Tail or Florges to extend its longevity.

Physically Defensive.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

The Duck.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Entry Hazard Lead.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Pink Blob (Specially Defensive).description:
• Blissey functions as an blanket check to special attackers on balance and stall teams, being especially useful against hard-to-check special threats such as Calm Mind Miraidon, Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Walking Wake.
  • Seismic Toss is Blissey's only way to reliably deal damage to most opposing Pokemon, while Shadow Ball is able to do decent damage to Flutter Mane.
  • Thunder Wave is extremely useful to cripple common switch-ins such as Koraidon and can also find use against Flutter Mane and Terastallized Miraidon.
  • Blissey is a reliable setter of Stealth Rock, which can free up moveslots on Great Tusk and Iron Treads, but you should note that opposing Great Tusk and Iron Treads as well as Corviknight have little difficulty clearing entry hazards on Blissey.
  • The Tera Type is quite flexible. Tera Ground is very useful against Calm Mind + Parabolic Charge Miraidon sets, as it completely negates their recovery and allows Blissey to force out them out.
  • Tera Fire gives Blissey the ability to better take on Chi-Yu, with Heavy-Duty Boots negating the Stealth Rock weakness.
  • Tera Ghost provides a Fighting-type immunity and allows Blissey to switch out of Dugtrio and Gothitelle.
  • Solid defensive walls such as Skeledirge, Great Tusk, Dondozo, Scream Tail, and Dachsbun are good teammates to take on physical attackers like Koraidon that commonly come in on Blissey.
  • Blissey is not capable of handling all Miraidon sets on its own, so Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Iron Treads are heavily recommended teammates. In turn, these Ground-types have less pressure on them to stay healthy and can focus more on setting entry hazards.
  • Care should be taken against Miraidon and Iron Bundle, which often use pivoting moves or Taunt to gain momentum on Blissey. Proper prediction with Blissey's teammates may be required to handle this.
  • As a result, Rocky Helmet is an option, as it does damage to U-turn, Flip Turn, and Electro Drift users, making Miraidon and Iron Bundle unable to pivot on Blissey for free. If running Rocky Helmet, make sure you have plenty of Pokemon that can deal with entry hazards, such as Corviknight, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Hatterene.
  • Flutter Mane is difficult for Blissey to reliably check due to Taunt and Psyshock sets, so Corviknight and Garganacl can help pick up the slack. In return, both appreciate Blissey being a safe switch-in to Iron Bundle.

Utility Wall.description:
Blissey's incredible special bulk allows it to check the tier's most dangerous special attackers such as Mesprit, Rotom, and Magneton along with setting Stealth Rock and being the only viable cleric. Stealth Rock is Blissey's most popular utility move because it lets other Stealth Rock setters run different sets alongside Blissey. Thunder Wave gives Blissey a way of punishing physical attackers such as Toxicroak, Paldean Tauros, and Scyther for switching in. However, this leaves you vulnerable to Pokemon such as Rotom and Haunter, so Shadow Ball can be used to threaten them instead. Heal Bell allows Blissey to relieve its team of status, helping against bulkier teams that may use Toxic. Any two-move combination of Stealth Rock, Thunder Wave, Shadow Ball, and Heal Bell can work depending on your team structure. Tera Ghost helps Blissey against many physical attackers, including Toxicroak, Hisuian Sneasel, and Tauros, and makes it easy to paralyze them on the following turn. Alternatively, Tera Fairy gives Blissey an incredible generalist typing that still helps it tank Fighting-type attacks.

Pairing Blissey with physical walls such as Sandaconda, Avalugg, and Sableye can help Blissey circumvent its low physical bulk. Stealth Rock Blissey also opens up frees up Sandaconda to run Coil sets instead. Additionally, Taunt users such as Froslass and Hisuian Qwilfish can beat Blissey by shutting down its recovery and utility moves. Having additional Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Bombirdier and Eelektross that can check these Pokemon helps Blissey substantially. Lastly, item disruption from Knock Off and Trick can be troubling for Blissey; without Heavy-Duty Boots, it's liable to being chipped down overtime by entry hazards, while Trick from Choice item users such as Rotom completely cripples Blissey. As a result, having a Knock Off absorber like Sandaconda or a Trick absorber like Sticky Hold Muk is great to support Blissey.

Calm Mind.description:
Blissey is able to run Calm Mind to set up against the tier's setup sweepers and wallbreakers such as Oricorio-P and Magneton, forcing them out while threatening common switch-ins such as Toxicroak and Rotom. Shadow Ball is Blissey's main offensive tool, threatening out Ghost-types like Rotom and Haunter. On the other hand, Dazzling Gleam and Stored Power can be used together for more overall damage output, allowing it to beat opposing Blissey and Braviary. Thunderbolt and Ice Beam can be used as well thanks to their useful coverage against Pokemon like Sandaconda and Bruxish, but they don't synergize well with Blissey's common Tera types. Tera Ghost ensures that Shadow Ball OHKOes non-Eviolite Haunter while also giving Blissey more opportunities to set up against Fighting-types it would otherwise be weak to, such as Hisuian Sneasel, Medicham, and Toxicroak. Tera Fairy also gives Blissey defensive traits such as resisting Fighting- and Dark-type attacks while boosting the power of Dazzling Gleam.

Blissey appreciates help from physical walls such as Qwilfish, Sableye, and Sandaconda, which are able to punish common Fighting-types that threaten Blissey like Hisuian Sneasel, Medicham, and Paldean Tauros. Blissey always wants to keep its item, so Knock Off absorbers like Sandaconda and Sticky Hold Muk and Trick absorbers like Choice Scarf Rotom pair well with it. Blissey also enjoys item displacement support, so Knock Off users like Bombirdier and Sableye make for good teammates. If you are running Tera Fairy with Dazzling Gleam and Stored Power, you will lack power against Magneton and Tera Steel Appletun. This opens up room for your own Fighting-types like Hisuian Sneasel and Toxicroak, which also threaten Appletun before Terastallizing.

Pink Blob.description: Blissey's immense special bulk, useful utility moves, and reliable recovery allow it to function as a niche specially defensive pivot, as it checks threats such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Mega Charizard Y. Seismic Toss allows Blissey to pressure anything that isn't a Ghost-type with meaningful damage. Toxic is the preferred option to cripple Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona. Thunder Wave can also be used to annoy fast threats like Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. It also allows Blissey to status Steel-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Kartana. Teleport allows Blissey to safely pivot in teammates like Dragapult, Zamazenta, and Mega Medicham. However, Blissey is an acceptable Stealth Rock user if no other fits on your team. Shadow Ball can be considered as a niche option to break Dragapult's Substitutes and chip offensive Gholdengo, but it usually isn't worth dropping other moves. Tera Fairy gives Blissey a Fighting resistance in exchange for negligible Poison and Steel weaknesses, and it reduces the damage it takes from Pursuit users like Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. This should be used if Blissey absolutely has to take on a Fighting- or Dark-type like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, or Weavile. Blissey's defensive profile makes it a liability into certain Ghost-types, specifically Dragon Dance Dragapult and Gholdengo. Kingambit is a great option that deals with the former two threats while also benefitting from Blissey bringing it in safely with Teleport. Other wallbreakers like Tapu Lele, Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Mega Medicham also appreciate pivot support and benefit from Blissey spreading Thunder Wave. A switch-in to powerful physical attackers, like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Mega Medicham, and Kingambit, is necessary. Options like Toxapex, Slowbro, Skarmory, and Great Tusk can help out on this front. Knock Off is irritating for Blissey, as losing its Heavy-Duty Boots is quite detrimental to its pivoting efforts. Options such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor can help out in this regard.

Defensive.description:
With the highest HP stat in all of Pokemon, an extremely impressive Special Defense stat, and access to important utility moves, Blissey is one of the best special walls in the entire tier, as well as being Normal's best Stealth Rock setter. Seismic Toss is the best move for Blissey to deal consistent damage and not be a completely passive Pokemon despite being ineffective against Ghost-types. Shadow Ball can be used over Seismic Toss in order to not be completely useless against Ghost-types. Stealth Rock helps Blissey's offensive teammates like Ursaluna and Maushold have an easier time getting KOs. Thunder Wave is used to slow down opposing Pokemon so that Blissey's slower, wallbreaking teammates, such as Ursaluna, have an easier time making progress. Alternatively, Healing Wish can be used over Thunder Wave in order to heal one of Blissey's teammates to full health, gaining momentum and making an end-game sweep easier.

Wallbreakers like Ursaluna and Choice Specs Hisuian Zoroark are great teammates for Blissey, as they are capable of dealing with the defensive Pokemon that Blissey is unable to beat, such as Sableye, Toxapex, and Dondozo. In return, Blissey can switch into attacks to keep the wallbreakers safe. Ditto and Blissey make a great pair, as, thanks to Natural Cure, Blissey is able to switch in to status moves that would otherwise cripple Ditto, such as Will-O-Wisp from Sableye, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W, as well as Thunder Wave from Gholdengo, then get rid of the status via Natural Cure. Ditto is also capable of dealing with setup sweepers that would otherwise threaten Blissey such as Baxcalibur and Dragonite. Thunder Wave is also a great option to use on opposing Choice Scarf users like Iron Valiant and Meowscarada so Ditto will not have to worry about Speed ties. Hisuian Zoroark is a great teammate for Blissey, as the immunity to Fighting-type moves is extremely valuable. Hisuian Zoroark is also able to burn opposing physical threats like Urshifu-R and Dragonite, which would otherwise make quick work of Blissey, as well as dealing with Ghost-type Pokemon which Blissey cannot damage without Shadow Ball. Hisuian Zoroark's Knock Off can also help Blissey wear down targets by making them vulnerable to entry hazards and removing Leftovers and Black Sludge recovery. Moreover, Hisuian Zoroark can disguise itself as Blissey and catch foes such as Iron Hands, Zamazenta and Sneasler off guard. Cyclizar is a good teammate for Blissey, as Blissey can switch into the fast special attackers that would otherwise threaten Cyclizar such as Flutter Mane and Choice Scarf Walking Wake. Cyclizar also carries Knock Off, which, as mentioned previously, works well with Blissey. Choice Specs Cyclizar outspeeds and threatens to OHKO non-Choice Scarf Iron Valiant, which would otherwise threaten Blissey, with Hyper Voice. Finally, Braviary and Staraptor can function as alternative switch-ins to Fighting-type Pokemon like Quaquaval and Great Tusk and retaliate with their STAB-boosted Brave Bird. Braviary uses Defog to keep Blissey and teammates safe from hazards, while Staraptor is a more offensive Choice Scarf user able to threaten Fighting-type Pokemon.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Calm Mind Support.description:
• The old reliable special wall is still viable, but it now takes a more active role through the use of Calm Mind.

  • Shadow Ball: Ghost-types like Nasty Plot Gholdengo and Swords Dance Mimikyu are still common options used against Blissey. This makes Shadow Ball a consistently strong option, particularly after a couple of Calm Mind boosts.

  • Tera Blast: Tera Blast is a very flexible attacking option, giving reliable STAB before Terastallizing and providing new offensive coverage thereafter.

  • Fling with Flame Orb: This is a surprising option to burn common Blissey switch-ins like Great Tusk, though failing to use it right away will force switching out to get rid of the burn. Fling also gets rid of Choice items from Trick users.

  • Stealth Rock: Stealth Rock remains a trusty support move for Blissey, punishing teams that are forced to switch around Blissey and its teammates.

Other Options

  • Fling with Toxic Orb: This is as close as it gets to Blissey regaining Toxic, though getting badly poisoned is devestating if Blissey is the last Pokemon around, making it a risky option.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Blissey is known for shrugging off big special hits with ease. However, its presence at team preview often attracts hard counters, and Tera is one way of dealing with that.

  • Dark: Dark Tera ruins Espathra's attempts to break through Blissey with Stored Power, at least forcing a Calm Mind war instead of a total loss. Blocking the occasional Psyshock from foes like Nasty Plot Gholdengo is also a plus.

  • Ghost: The Fighting-type immunity comes in handy for Blissey and prevents it from being trapped, though it does become more vulnerable to Gholdengo.

  • Fire: Tera Fire puts the brakes on Choice Specs Tera Fire Chi-Yu’s wallbreaking parade, ruining its ability to reliably 2HKO Blissey.

  • Flying: With the Flying Tera type, Blissey gains a handy resistance to Fighting and no longer has to worry about Fissure from Dondozo.

Items

  • Leftovers: As is the case with most walls, Leftovers’ passive recovery is a great supplement to Softboiled and helps Blissey be less passive itself.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak lets Blissey set up against Garganacls that lack Body Press. It also blocks flinches from Chi-Yu’s Dark Pulse as well as the Special Defense drop from Espathra’s Lumina Crash.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Def / 252 SpD with Calm or Bold: Beyond making Tera Blissey that much harder to break by foes like Espathra and Chi-Yu, going all-in on Special Defense means less frequent Softboiled uses against special attackers, especially with Leftovers.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spd with Bold: Maximizing both HP and Defense gives Blissey a little extra boost in physical bulk.

Bulky Offense.description: • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Special Wall.description: Magic Guard Blissey is a solid wall and utility Pokemon that can effectively shrug off most viable special attackers, but it struggles against the tier's premier physically offensive options. Although it excels at switching into special attacks, it is left with rather passive options mainly chosen to maximize the potential of its teammates. Soft-Boiled is its essential recovery option that keeps it healthy to continue absorbing damage in the future. Heal Bell, Stealth Rock, and Thunder Wave are Blissey's utility options, allowing it to act as a cleric, entry hazard setter, or status spreader, respectively, to set up its teammates for success. Finally, Shadow Ball is a niche option that prevents Blissey from being passive against Ghost-types like Skeledirge, Hisuian Typhlosion, and Ceruledge. Well-Baked Body can be used instead of Magic Guard, improving its matchup against Fire-types like Magic Guard Volcanion and Heatran, as well as completely walling Skeledirge. Teams that use Blissey should also opt to carry a physical wall like Corviknight, Quaquaval, or Fluffy Landorus-T, as their ability to absorb physical attacks is valuable for preserving it as a special wall. Blissey can offer offensive teammates the ability to thwart their revenge killers with its switching unimpeded by entry hazards and damaging status conditions.
