Sableye is a good choice for Dark teams due to its Fighting immunity, great array of utility moves such as Will-O-Wisp and Taunt, and reliable recovery, letting it disrupt opposing teams and assist its teammates in either breaking through opposing teams or staving off attacks. Prankster Will-O-Wisp lets Sableye neutralize threats to Dark-type teams such as Great Tusk and Dragonite by burning them before they can make a move. Taunt lets it shut down set up attempts from Pokemon such as Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Bulk Up Corviknight or hinder opposing defensive Pokemon, such as Toxapex and Clodsire. Taunt also blocks entry hazards from going up, which is huge for Dark due to its lack of entry hazard control. Alternatively, Encore lets Sableye halt the aforementioned setup attempts and gain more momentum from them. Knock Off capitalizes on the switches that Sableye forces by knocking off crucial items from Pokemon such as Toxapex or Dondozo. Alternatively, Night Shade deals steady damage throughout the game. Finally, Recover gives Sableye longevity to continually check the aforementioned threats. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Sableye come in and out without worrying about residual damage from entry hazards.

Some great teammates for Sableye include Skuntank and Kingambit, as both of them boast a critical neutrality to Fairy that lets them take hits such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant's and Flutter Mane's Moonblasts and force both out. In return, Sableye can complement Skuntank's chip damage from Toxic Spikes through its utility moves and ease Kingambit's setup through item removal and spreading burns. Ting-Lu is another good teammate, as it can set entry hazards to further wear away at the opposing team while also acting as an emergency soft check to Fairy-types if it is running Heavy Slam. Reciprocally, Sableye can accentuate the effect of Ting-Lu's entry hazards by removing Heavy-Duty Boots and taking Fighting-type moves such as Slither Wing's and Great Tusk's Close Combats. Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Greninja all greatly appreciate Sableye's ability to grind down the opposing team with Knock Off and Will-O-Wisp, while also liking Sableye's ability to hinder walls such as Toxapex and Dondozo and keep entry hazards off the field with Taunt. Lokix is a decent teammate, as it greatly assists in the Dark-type mirror matchup, where Sableye can do nothing due to Prankster being nullified by Dark-types.

All-out Attacker.description: Thanks to Huge Power and an impressive movepool, Mega Mawile is one of the strongest wallbreakers in the metagame. Its typing, paired with Intimidate, allows it to switch comfortably into Pokemon like Tornadus-T, Clefable, Kartana, and Weavile and subsequently exert tremendous offensive pressure. However, Mega Mawile suffers with four-moveslot syndrome and is slow, leaving it to be revenge killed by faster foes like Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Heatran. Thunder Punch hits bulky Water-types like Toxapex, Slowbro, and Dondozo while Ice Punch deals massive damage to Landorus-T and Gliscor. Sucker Punch accomodates for Mega Mawile's poor Speed, allowing it to pressure Pokemon like Dragapult and Gholdengo. Fire Fang hits Mega Scizor while Brick Break threatens Heatran, with both moves pressuring Ferrothorn. The given EV spread allows Mega Mawile to outspeed Mega Scizor. Even with Intimidate, Mega Mawile is relatively frail. Pivots like Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T can bring it in safely against Pokemon with which they struggle like Clodsire, Ferrothorn, and Ting-Lu. Fast cleaners and revenge killers like Weavile, Choice Scarf Kartana, and Dragapult appreciate Mega Mawile's ability to break walls such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Clefable. In return, they are able to pressure more offensive builds. Mega Mawile appreciates entry hazard support to weaken foes like Mega Scizor, Heatran, and Dondozo, making setters like Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp good partners.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Mega Mawile is a deadly wallbreaker and sweeper, as it becomes nearly unstoppable after a boost in conjunction with Huge Power. Its good defensive typing in tandem with Intimidate ensures that Mega Mawile can safely get off a Swords Dance boost against foes like Tornadus-T and Weavile. Knock Off, paired with Play Rough, allows Mega Mawile to hit most Pokemon in the tier for neutral damage while also supporting its team by removing items. However, Thunder Punch is a decent alternative, as it OHKOes Toxapex after a Swords Dance while also heavily chipping foes such as Dondozo and Skarmory. Sucker Punch makes up for Mega Mawile's awful Speed and lets it pressure Pokemon like Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Tornadus-T. The given EV spread allows Mega Mawile to outspeed Skarmory. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Ting-Lu lets Mega Mawile KO faster threats with Sucker Punch after a Swords Dance and chip damage, such as Mega Lopunny, Landorus-T, Mega Swampert, and Garchomp. It also appreciates pivot support from Slowbro, Landorus-T, and Rotom-W to enter the field safely. Since Mega Mawile is relatively frail, partners such as Landorus-T and Garchomp provide strong defensive checks to common threats in Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Heatran.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Medicham is a solid revenge killer and late-game cleaner. Pure Power gives Medicham an edge over Passimian, one of its main sources of competition, by allowing its Close Combat to 2HKO bulky foes like Vaporeon before Terastallization. Zen Headbutt's Base Power is good against foes like Tera Fairy Chansey, but Psycho Cut is an alternative that doesn't make contact, which helps against Rocky Helmet users, Drifblim, and Poison Point Qwilfish. Thunder Punch and Ice Punch hit Bruxish and Sandaconda respectively, and Flying-types like Drifblim and Oricorio-F. Trick punishes defensive switch-ins like Sandaconda and is especially beneficial to use against bulky teams, since they are generally slower than Medicham anyway. Tera Fighting enhances Medicham's wallbreaking and cleaning potential by powering up Close Combat, and it lets Medicham resist Toxicroak and Bombirdier's Sucker Punch. Partners that commonly run Choice Scarf, such as Zoroark and Rotom, can revenge kill foes instead of Medicham early-on, keeping its set a mystery. Zoroark can also use Illusion to lure in and eliminate Ghost-types, which reduces how many predictions Medicham needs to make, while Rotom checks Flying-types and blanks Sandaconda and Choice Scarf Toxicroak.

Wallbreaker.description: Medicham's damage output is unrivaled thanks to Pure Power in tandem with Life Orb or a Choice Band. Zen Headbutt is a powerful STAB option that hits Poison-types like Qwilfish and Muk, as they can easily take a Close Combat. Psycho Cut is a weaker alternative that avoids contact effects like Poison Point and Rocky Helmet from the likes of Qwilfish and Sandaconda. Trailblaze allows Medicham to pull off sweeps and patch up its offensive shortcoming in its middling Speed. Trick is used with Choice Band to cripple walls such as Drifblim and Tera Fairy users like Chansey and Umbreon. Ice Punch is great neutral coverage for walls like Drifblim and Sandaconda. Tera Fighting gives Choice Band sets a favorable roll to KO Sandaconda after minimal chip or a single layer of Spikes. Tera Steel allows Medicham to defensively check fast revenge killers like Scyther and Zangoose on top of boosting Bullet Punch's damage output. Medicham struggles against bulky Ghost-types like Drifblim and Rotom, which makes Zoroark, Choice Scarf Rotom, and Haunter great offensive partners. Special sweepers like Dudunsparce, Oricorio, and Jolteon appreciate Medicham's ability to break past Chansey, Umbreon, and Vaporeon. Medicham also enjoys pivots like Scyther, Rotom, and Eelektross; it especially likes the latter two, which threaten out Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Drifblim.

Mega Medicham is a tremendously strong wallbreaker due to Pure Power, strong STAB moves, and coverage. Fake Out lets Mega Medicham chip down and revenge kill Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko. It also can let Mega Medicham stall out rain, Toxic, and Terrain on foes, all while putting opponents into range for one of its stronger attacks safely. Ice Punch lets Mega Medicham get rid of Landorus-T and Dragonite, which can enable it to freely use its STAB moves. Bullet Punch can be used to snipe Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Diancie, and Weavile, and it also removes revenge killers like Tapu Koko and Mega Lopunny after chip damage. Thunder Punch can be used to hit Slowbro, and in tandem with Electric Terrain, it can 2HKO Pokemon like Gholdengo and Victini. Alternatively, Thief can be used to immediately damage the aforementioned Pokemon, so it can use its STAB moves more. Due to Mega Medicham’s frailty and mediocre Speed tier, it is easily revenge killed. Defensive partners like Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, and Ferrothorn help check threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult. Knock Off and Pursuit users like Kingambit and Weavile also support Mega Medicham, as they break through Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon Mega Medicham struggle with, such as Slowbro, Victini, Gholdengo and Skeledirge, allowing it to consistently use its STAB attacks. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Ferrothorn benefit Mega Medicham, as it forces a lot of switches and entry hazards wear down checks quickly. Tapu Koko is a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it handles Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Slowbro reliably and powers up Mega Medicham's Thunder Punch. Tapu Lele can also be a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it powers up Zen Headbutt to insane levels, but blocking Fake Out and Bullet Punch from being used can be problematic. Pokemon like Volcarona and Kartana appreciate Torandus-T, Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Gholdengo being pressured constantly by Mega Medicham, enabling them to wreak havoc once the checks are removed or chipped.

Defensive Utility.description: Fire Spin and Grass Tera Blast can effectively lure otherwise undesirable matchups like Sandaconda and Vaporeon. 88 Speed allows Camerupt to outspeed the likes of Muk, Crocalor, and Perrserker

Trick Room Offense.description:
• This set makes full use of Torkoal's nuclear power. Eruption vaporizes nearly anything without a resistance or immunity to Fire after Terrastilization. Heat Wave gives it a mostly-reliable spread option after taking damage. Earth Power hits opposing Fire-types and gives Torkoal a single-target option to get around Wide Guard.

  • Tera Fire is the go-to option to maximize Torkoal's damage. Tera Flying and Grass removes its weaknesses, which helps greatly against the ever-frequent Ground-type attacks, but are generally not worth it.

  • Solar Beam is an option to hit Water-types meaningfully and to hit Rock- and Ground-types a little harder than Earth Power. Tera Blast is a niche option if Torkoal is running Tera Flying, turning the tables on Tera Grass Armarouge and Ceruledge attempting to wall it. Choice Specs would push Torkoal's offensive capabilities onto another planet, but it makes Torkoal even easier to exploit with Wide Guard, Flash Fire, and attacks in general—it can't viably run Protect.

Sun Setter.description:
Torkoal is an essential member of Fire teams, providing valuable role compression by setting up sun and Stealth Rock, removing entry hazards, and tanking physical attacks. STAB Lava Plume provides decent damage and a high chance to burn, which proves particularly useful against physical attackers like Mimikyu and Iron Hands. Body Press allows Torkoal uses Torkoal's high Defense to heavily damage the likes of Kingambit, Blissey, and Tyranitar, as well as preventing Roaring Moon and Hydreigon from setting up freely. Alternatively, Yawn can be used to force a switch, allowing Torkoal to freely bring a teammate that can benefit from the sun. Heat Rock provides more turns of sun for allies to benefit from, but Heavy-Duty Boots greatly increases Torkoal's longevity. If using the latter, getting fewer turns of sun also allows Fire teams to better manage opposing Protosynthesis sweepers, such as Flutter Mane or Sandy Shocks.

Thanks to Chlorophyll and its unique typing, Scovillain pairs well with Torkoal, as the sun allows it to outspeed and KO foes such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Quaquaval. Choice Specs Scovillian can significantly damage to Toxapex with Solar Beam and even 2HKO Clodsire in the sun with Flamethrower. Cinderace is another wallbreaker that thrives under the sun and appreciates Stealth Rock chipping at the opposing team. It can run Court Change, allowing for more entry hazard control if you're running Heat Rock Torkoal, or use a Choice Scarf to defeat foes like Flutter Mane and Choice Specs Greninja. Iron Moth can use sun and Fire Blast to OHKO foes such as Iron Jugulis and Sableye. Ceruledge scares out Flutter Mane, which can otherwise become problematic due to Power Gem and Protosynthesis boosting its Speed in sun. Thanks to its great defensive stats and Unaware, Skeledirge is an amazing partner for Torkoal, handling setup sweepers such as Curse Dondozo and Belly Drum Azumarill for it. Also, sun weakens Water-type moves for Skeledirge and boosts its Torch Song. Rotom-H can tank special hits Torkoal can't withstand from the likes of Iron Valiant, as well as providing a valuable Ground immunity, which allows it to come in on foes such as Clodsire, Sandy Shocks, and Ting-Lu. Volcarona can dismantle Dark-type teams and occasionally weaken physical attackers thanks to Flame Body.

Sun Support.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

Nasty Plot.description:
Grumpig is not viable in PU, but this is considered its best set.

136 Speed EVs let Grumpig outspeed Modest Glaceon. 44 SpA EVs allow unboosted Tera Ground Grumpig to KO offensive Skuntank with Earth Power after Stealth Rock damage.

Offensive Spikes.description: Cacturne is an amazing offensive Spiker in NU. Due to its strength and typing, it finds many opportunities to switch in on and threaten tier staples like Sandaconda, Qwilfish, and Drifblim. Cacturne is also good at taking advantage of Water-types like Bruxish and Floatzel thanks to Water Absorb, giving it more chances to set up Spikes and dish out heavy damage. Dark Pulse reliably pressures Defoggers like Drifblim and Lurantis as well as Magic Bounce Hattrem. A Naive nature lets Cacturne outspeed Modest Clawitzer without sacrificing any power. Braviary is an excellent teammate for Cacturne, since it dissuades Defog attempts with Defiant and reliably pressures special walls. In return, Cacturne offers Braviary safety from Bruxish, offensively checks Ghost-types, and can facilitate late-game cleaning with Spikes. Setup sweepers like Hisuian Sneasel and Vivillon become much harder to stop when backed by Spikes and also match up well against Defoggers like Braviary and Lurantis.

Dragon Dance.description: Thanks to its good Attack, powerful Pixilate-boosted STAB moves, Speed, and good defenses, Mega Altaria serves as a potent late-game setup sweeper primarily seen on offense and hyper offense teams. It can outspeed foes like Cinderace, Mega Latias, and Thundurus after one boost, and it stands out over other sweepers due to its ability to set up on Choice-locked Latias and Hydreigon. Pixilate-boosted Frustration serves as Mega Altaria's best move due to its power without any drawbacks that helps against the plethora of Fighting-, Dark-, and Dragon-types, OHKOing Hydreigon, Mega Heracross, and Galarian Zapdos and 2HKOing Iron Hands, Buzzwole, Mega Latias, and Mega Tyranitar. Earthquake pairs well with Frustration, as it can help deal with the Steel-types that resist the former, 2HKOing Excadrill, Hisuian Goodra, and Jirachi, and it can also be useful to hit Fire-types like Iron Moth and Skeledirge. Roost lets Mega Altaria set up on defensive targets like Slowbro, Buzzwole, and Skarmory long-term, and it can help to stay healthy in the face of hazards. Mega Altaria perfers to have Natural Cure instead of Cloud Nine to avoid status from targets like Mew and Gastrodon. This given EV spread allows Mega Altaria to outspeed Cinderace and Alakazam at +1. Mega Altaria can have a hard time breaking through some Poison- and Steel-types like Mega Venusaur, Amoonguss, Celesteela, and Skarmory, making offensive Fire-types like Victini, Ceruledge, and Cinderace good supporting teammates. Teammates on offense and hyper offense teams like Iron Moth, Thundurus, and Azumarill make for good partners, being able to threaten out Pokemon like Tapu Bulu, Tapu Fini, and Hippowdon. Offensive pivots such as Cinderace, Sandy Shocks, and Thundurus-T make also good partners for Mega Altaria, as they can bring it in to threaten out Dragon-types, such as Latias and Hydreigon, and pivot it into defensive Pokemon like Buzzwole to give Mega Altaria an opportunity to set up. Mega Altaria appreciates entry hazard removal options and entry hazard setters, notably suicide leads on hyper offense teams like Excadrill, as well as Salamence on offense teams, which can help to keep Mega Altaria healthy and make it easier to sweep. Stealth Rock chip also enables Mega Altaria to guarantee an OHKO like Mega Latias. In return, Mega Altaria can help against their checks like Buzzwole, Mega Latias, Cinderace, and Galarian Zapdos. Mega Altaria can have great synergy with Pokemon like Rotom-W, which can check the Steel-types that threaten it like Celesteela and has the ablilty to pivot Mega Altaria in.

Offensive Dragon Dance (Dragon).description: Mega Altaria's unique typing and offensive potential allow it to serve as a valuable setup sweeper that checks threats like Kommo-o, Roaring Moon, Iron Hands, and Keldeo. Pixilate-boosted Return checks the aforementioned Dragon-types as well as Fighting- and Dark-types such as Terrakion, Mega Sableye, and Mandibuzz. Earthquake is essential coverage, as it hits Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran and Magnezone and—in conjunction with Return—eases the Dark and Electric matchups. Roost increases Mega Altaria's longevity so it can continuously Dragon Dance throughout the match or use its bulk to switch into threats. The given EV spread allows Mega Altaria to survive Mega Lopunny's Triple Axel. Choice Specs Kyurem is a great teammate, as it breaks past the likes of Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo for Mega Altaria. Garchomp sets up Stealth Rock and Spikes, wearing down Mega Altaria's switch-ins. Kommo-o breaks past Steel-types like Skarmory, Aegislash, and defensive Celesteela as well as other troublesome walls like Toxapex and Hippowdon for Mega Altaria. Roaring Moon threatens obstacles such as Mega Diancie, Choice Specs Greninja, and Skeledirge.

Dragon Dance.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Toxic Boost.description:
Zangoose is a high risk, high reward physical breaker capable of tearing through walls if it predicts correctly, but is punished severely by Toxic damage and entry hazards if it doesn't. Close Combat hits Steel-types like Perserrker and Tinkatuff that could come in on Facade, as well as being its best tool against Carbink. Night Slash catches Ghost-types like Misdreavus and Banette that would otherwise switch into Zangoose safely and punishes Tera Ghost from Pokemon like Gabite and Whiscash. Quick Attack lets Zangoose kill fast Pokemon like Charizard, Raichu, and Choice Scarf Rotom-F. Swords Dance turns Zangoose into an even more powerful breaker, OHKOing foes like Tinkatuff and Dachsbun at +2, at the cost of being unable to deal with faster Pokemon, making it a good choice against bulkier teams that lack faster Pokemon. Protect lets Zangoose scout Choice Scarf users like Lycanroc-N and Rotom-F as well as consistently activate Toxic Orb, but it is much less consistent overall than the other two options. Toxic Orb is the only item that can activate Toxic Boost on Zangoose, which pairs wonderfully with Facade. Tera Normal gives Zangoose a solid boost of power on Facade and Quick Attack, which is especially useful on sets lacking Swords Dance. It also gives Zangoose an easier time KOing frail, faster Pokemon like Pyroar and Houndoom.

Zangoose suffers heavily from the chip damage it accrues, so ways to mitigate this are helpful. Dachsbun is useful for its ability to pass Wish to Zangoose, helping it stay alive and break for a longer time; it is also useful for coming in on Pokemon that force Zangoose out like Alolan Persian and Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N. Fast Taunt users like Electrode and Pyroar can prevent entry hazards from foes like Perserrker and Tinkatuff, limiting the amount of chip damage that Zangoose takes. Electrode can also bring Zangoose in on its checks, like Gogoat and Dunsparce, to help it break. Offensive partners like Sawsbuck and Indeedee-F can help Zangoose overwhelm shared checks like Misdreavus and Tinkatuff, and Indeedee-F's Healing Wish is useful for giving Zangoose more chances to break, although Psychic Terrain from Indeedee-F pairs poorly with Zangoose's Quick Attack. Zangoose also benefits heavily from Sticky Web from Pokemon like Spidops and Masquerain, as being able to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Golduck and other fast Pokemon like Alolan Dugtrio is a massive boon for it.

Defensive.description:
Whiscash is a defensive entry hazard setter with great typing and solid bulk. Stealth Rock can help chip common foes such as Misdreavus, Choice Scarf Rotom-F, and Haunter. However, even though Spikes don't affect the aforementioned Pokemon, it does better at hitting Rock-resistant threats such as Tinkatuff, Gabite, and Alolan Dugtrio. Earthquake can be used over Earth Power for the slightly higher damage, especially against special setup sweepers like Calm Mind Spiritomb and Wyrdeer, but Earth Power is generally preferred for inflicting better damage on physical walls like Klawf, Perrserker, and Alolan Persian and being unaffected by Grassy Terrain set by Thwackey, a common switch-in to Whiscash. Ice Beam is great for doing a chunk of damage on Grass-types like Gogoat, Flapple, and Dartrix. Surf is an option over Ice Beam, landing better damage on neutral targets instead of the previously mentioned foes. Stone Edge is great in the last slot to cover the likes of Charizard, as well as preventing setup sweepers like Rotom-F and Masquerain from taking advantage of Whiscash's relative passivity. Stealth Rock can be opted for instead to compress both forms of entry hazards into one Pokemon, possibly freeing up another team slot. Protect is used for scouting and gaining a bit more Leftovers recovery, but it is not very useful when running the more popular Heavy-Duty Boots. Oblivious allows Whiscash to set up hazards even against Taunt users like Alolan Persian and Misdreavus. Tera Poison is great for removing Whiscash's 4x weakness to Grass, with the added benefit letting it absorb Toxic Spikes. Tera Ghost turns it into a spinblocker in a pinch. The EV spread focuses on Special Defense over Defense because it makes for a better matchup against Volt Switch users like Rotom-F, as well as other special attackers like Alolan Persian and Fire-types like Charizard.

Whiscash appreciates spinblockers like Misdreavus and Spiritomb to keep its entry hazards up against Rapid Spin users like Quaxwell. Whiscash appreciates Charizard and Honchkrow's ability to deal with Grass-types; in return, it can take on the Rock- and Electric-types like Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N and Electrode. Grass-types like Gogoat and Dartrix also make for great teammates, as Whiscash can take on Fire- and Poison-types like Charizard, Houndoom, and Skuntank that threaten them. Its presence as an Electric-immune to help the likes of Masquerain and Honchkrow is superb, as it has the typing and bulk to take hits from the coverage moves that Pokemon like Raichu, Rotom-F, and Electrode carry. Dachsbun, Crabominable, and Carbink all benefit from Whiscash, as it can take Steel-type hits from Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio for them. With a lot of the tier being weak or neutral to Rock, Whiscash finds itself having the typing to help the likes of Charizard, Masquerain, and Rabsca avoid dealing with Lycanroc-N, Dugtrio, and Gabite. It does find a lot of trouble handling Misdreavus, as it lacks the super effective coverage to get past its bulk. This is why pairing it with a Dark-type like Skuntank or Alolan Persian can be beneficial. Since Whiscash doesn't have recovery, it really doesnt like taking Will-O-Wisp from said Misdreavus, and Charizard or Toxic from Skuntank. As a result, status absorbers like Chansey, Dragonair, and Tinkatuff make for great teammates.

Don't Use Banette.description: Don't use Banette. You have better Megas to choose.

Special Wallbreaker.description:
Salamence stands out as one of the premier Pokemon in the tier thanks to its defensive and offensive presence. Its typing, bulk, and ability in Intimidate make it one of the best responses to physical threats like Slither Wing, Lucario, and Scizor. Hydro Pump blows away foes like Hippowdon, Tyranitar, and Sandy Shocks while providing a strong neutral hit on Tinkaton and Scizor. Flamethrower hits the aforementioned Steel-types, alongside others like Bisharp and Tinkaton. Flamethrower also hits Brambleghast without reaping the downsides of using Draco Meteor. Heavy-Duty Boots removes Salamence's Stealth Rock weakness, which allows it to switch in more freely against threats it needs to check. Terastallizing is primarily used defensively to improve its matchups against common offensive Pokemon. Tera Water allows Salamence to resist Bullet Punch from Scizor and still retain a Water-type resistance against Floatzel. Tera Steel improves the matchup against Tinkaton, turns Salamence into a decent Staraptor and Maushold check, and provides a resist to many forms of priority in the tier such as Accelerock from Lycanroc-D and Bullet Punch from Scizor. Tera Dragon should be used to help break through sturdier Pokemon like Gastrodon and Slowking more easily.

Pawmot and Scizor can help remove Gastrodon, Tyranitar, and Scream Tail— all of which Salamence struggles to break past—while also serving as more reliable checks to Bisharp. Faster Pokemon such as Pawmot, Sandy Shocks, and Lycanroc-D can revenge kill or force Salamence out, so partners like Hippowdon and Quagsire are appreciated, both also acting as decent Knock Off absorbers against Grafaiai and Tinkaton. Quagsire can also provide Spikes support to help wear down some of the aforementioned special walls as well as put them on a timer with Toxic, as well as reliably check most Swords Dance Scizor and Lucario if Salamence isn't Tera Steel.

Dragon Dance.description:
Dragon Dance makes Salamence one of the scariest sweepers in the tier thanks to its great offensive typing. Outrage is a powerful STAB move that helps muscle through sturdier walls like Gastrodon and Hippowdon after a boost; however, Dragon Claw is a weaker alternative that doesn't have the downside of being locked in. Earthquake provides perfect coverage to deal with Tyranitar, Tinkaton, and Bisharp. Dual Wingbeat helps break through Scream Tail better and can pick off weakened Flying-types like Noivern and Iron Jugulis without locking into Outrage. Roost is an alternative that provides longevity against Pokemon like Slither Wing and Lokix. It is best used alongside Intimidate on bulkier teams that need the defensive utility of Salamence's typing. Otherwise, Moxie is preferred, as it can easily let Salamence snowball through a team. Tera Steel lets Salamence set up on Tinkaton—though it must be wary of Encore—and provides needed resists to many priority moves like Accelerock, Bullet Punch, Ice Shard, and Extreme Speed from Lycanroc-D, Scizor, Weavile, and Lucario.

Quagsire is very problematic due to Unaware ignoring any Dragon Dance and Moxie boosts. Pawmot can remove Quagsire with Seed Bomb, Scizor can lure it in and remove it with Trailblaze, and Sandy Shocks can threaten to OHKO with Tera Blast after Terastallizing into a Grass-type. Sandy Shocks can also help remove physically defensive Hippowdon, which is especially helpful if it's running Roar. Sandy Shocks and other entry hazard setters such as Tyranitar can wear down Pokemon like opposing Tyranitar and Scream Tail into range of its attacks. Gengar is a fantastic wallbreaker to pair with Salamence, as it can forcefully remove Grafaiai, which can be a massive hindrance due to Prankster Encore limiting setup opportunities. Gengar also spinblocks alongside the aforementioned entry hazard setters and weakens Tyranitar and Tinkaton into Earthquake range.

Choice Scarf (Flying).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Specsmence Returns.description:
• Salamence finds a niche for itself among other special attacking Dragon-types due to an incredible ability in Intimidate and a useful typing that provides a handy Fissure immunity.

  • Hurricane versus Air Slash: Hurricane's accuracy may not be very reliable, but the sheer damage output makes it worth it. Air Slash is much weaker than Hurricane, but the more reliable accuracy and flinch chance make it a reasonable alternative. It becomes especially attractive if using Tera Flying.

  • Hydro Pump: If not using Tera Fairy, Hydro Pump is a reasonable choice that deals massive damage to Hippowdon and Fire-types without risking Draco Meteor.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Not only does Tera Fairy give Salamence an edge against many Dragon-types, but it also pairs extremely well with Intimidate, transforming Salamence into an effective hit-and-run threat.

  • Steel: Tera Steel comes in handy against Dragon- and Fairy-types alike, though the added weaknesses to Ground and Fighting make it less effective at taking physical hits with Intimidate.

  • Flying: Air Slash becomes much easier to justify with Tera Flying, and if you're willing to risk it, Hurricane can be used to become almost impossible to wall with Choice Specs.

  • Fire: Tera Fire doesn't offer as much defensive utility, but the powerful STAB attacks come in handy against Steel-types like Corviknight.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon trades defensive advantages for an extremely powerful Draco Meteor that catches defensive foes like Dondozo by surprise.

Items

  • Choice Specs: With Salamence already standing at a decent Speed tier, it can get away with Choice Specs, making it extremely difficult to wall outside of using Blissey.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf trades wallbreaking power for the ability to get the jump on major offensive threats, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Garchomp.

Physically Offensive.description:
• Salamence is somewhat overshadowed by other physical Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Dragapult, but it has a trick up its claws: Dual Wingbeat, which OHKOes Breloom and Meowscarada through their Focus Sash.

  • Earthquake versus Fire Blast: Earthquake is the best option for hitting Steel-types such as Gholdengo hard, but Fire Blast is Salamence's best shot at 2HKOing Corviknight.

  • Dragon Dance: After a boost, Dual Wingbeat's Focus Sash slaying powers go into overdrive, being able to bust through Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Great Tusk.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, a boosted Dual Wingbeat has a 75% chance to OHKO offensive Mimikyu through its disguise! It also means Salamence no longer needs a boost to OHKO Great Tusk and Flutter Mane.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Tera Blast Salamence OHKO Azumarill and Iron Bundle, and potentially 2HKO Dondozo after Stealth Rock damage.

Abilities

  • Intimidate: While Salamence isn't particularly bulky, Intimidate makes setting up far easier when paired with a Flying Tera type that removes Salamence's common weaknesses.

  • Moxie: With Moxie, Salamence has the potential to seriously punish Breloom leads or snowball through teams even without Dragon Dance.

Mixed Attacker.description:
• Salamence's great mixed offenses, Intimidate, and decent Speed give it a niche as a powerful wall breaker.

  • Dual Wingbeat: Dual Wingbeat lets Salamence OHKO Breloom regardless of its Focus Sash, something very few Pokemon can do.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor deals massive damage to Dondozo, usually doing more than 50% to physically defensive ones.

  • Substitute: Substitute makes the Dondozo match-up even better, making Yawn a non-issue. It's also a good way to scout Terastallization against slower threats.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type covers a lot of Salamence's weaknesses and makes dealing with Mimikyu, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane much easier.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Salamence a great match-up against most Dragon-types, and pairs especially well with Intimidate to turn Salamence into a good hit-and-run attacker.

  • Fire: With a Fire Tera type, Salamence gains a resistance to Fairy-type attacks and deals massive damage to Assault Vest Magnezone.

  • Electric: Tera Electric gives Salamence a great tool against Dondozo with Tera Blast.

  • Dragon: While this Tera type fails to help Salamence much defensively, it makes Draco Meteor 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo.

Defensive Defog.description: 240 Speed EVs should be used to outrun Hydreigon and Hisuian Arcanine when using Draco Meteor.

Dragon Dance.description: Thanks to its great Attack, good coverage options, and ability to outpace foes such as Mega Aerodactyl, Alakazam, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon at +1, Salamence is a good setup sweeper on offense and hyper offense teams, being able to serve as both a mid-game wallbreaker and a late-game cleaner. Fly alongside Flyinium Z provides Salamence a powerful one-time nuke that can outright OHKO Flying-weak foes like Mega Venusaur and Buzzwole and neutral targets like Mega Sableye, Tapu Fini, and Gastrodon at +1. Outrage is an alternative when not using Flyinium Z that helps deal with opposing Dragon-types like Mega Latias, Latios, and Hydreigon, though it does have the downside of locking in Salamence, which can allow the opponent to respond with a Fairy-type like Tapu Fini, Clefable, or Enamorus. Earthquake helps against Steel-types like Excadrill, Aegislash, and Bisharp that resist both its STAB moves, and it can also help to chip down other Ground-weak foes like Skeledirge and Mega Tyranitar. Substitute lets Salamence make use of switches it forces against foes like Mega Venusaur and Buzzwole and take advantage of some defensive Pokemon like Hippowdon and Amoonguss; it can also provide a safety net for mispositioning with Fly or Outrage and avoids status from targets like Chansey, Mega Sableye, and Mew. Alternatively Fire Blast hits Skarmory and can also hit Grass- and Steel-types like physically defensive Tangrowth, Celesteela, and Scizor. If Salamence isn't using Fly, Life Orb boosts the damage of all of its moves, OHKOing Mega Latias and Rotom-W with Outrage. Salamence prefers running Moxie as opposed to Intimidate, due to its usefulness on offensively-oriented teams. Salamence has a hard time breaking through Fairy-types like Tapu Fini and Clefable, due to their typing and super effective moves, making it pair well with other offensive Pokemon like Thundurus and Swords Dance Cinderace, which can overwhelm these foes. When not running Fly, Salamence can also struggle to break through Grass-types like Tangrowth and Mega Venusaur, making Fire-types like Ceruledge and Victini also good partners. Salamence can also pair well with entry hazards from setters like Ting-Lu, Mega Tyranitar, and Skarmory, as Fly and Outrage are guaranteed to OHKO foes like Buzzwole and Thundurus-T after Stealth Rock chip. Due to Salamence's Stealth Rock weakness, it appreciates Pokemon that can provide anti-hazard measures, notably dedicated leads like Excadrill, as well as Taunt Mew, while Salamence can deal with Pokemon that can threaten them like Celesteela and Hydreigon. Salamence can be very prone to getting revenge killed by faster targets like Mega Aerodactyl, Alakazam, and Choice Scarf Enamorus, meaning it appreciates bulky partners like Slowbro and Mega Venusaur, appreciating the former's pivoting and the latter's tank-like nature, as well as Pokemon that can set up on the aforementioned targets like Scizor, Mega Latias, and Celesteela.

Choice Band (Psychic).description:
96 Speed EVs outspeeds Adamant Azumarill.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2024.overview:
• Latias is an exceptional Tailwind setter thanks to its great bulk, defensive typing, Levitate, and solid Speed. It also checks common threats such as Landorus and Urshifu-R.

  • Assault Vest Kingambit is a great partner, beating most of Latias's counters like Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and, to an extent, Incineroar. It also makes great use of Tailwind, and Latias beats most of its counters as well.

  • Latias can be very tough to remove especially if it Terastallizes into a Poison-type, which, when combined with Levitate, has only one weakness and many valuable resistances. This becomes extra apparent when using Recover, which lets it clean up late-game when positioned well, especially if Mist Ball gets some Special Attack drops.

Bulky Tailwind Setter.description:
• Ice Beam is great coverage in general and very important for OHKOing Landorus, one of Latias's best and most important matchups.

  • Rocky Helmet lets Latias punish common and important moves like Fake Out and U-turn. It also breaks Chien-Pao's Focus Sash if it opts to run Ice Spinner and heavily discourages the prevalent Urshifu-R from attacking it.

  • The Speed EVs allow it to outspeed max Speed Landorus, the Special Attack EVs let it OHKO Urshifu-R and Landorus more consistently, and the rest of the EVs are used to optimize its bulk.

  • Tera Poison, when paired with Levitate, makes Latias very difficult to break, as Psychic-types, besides opposing Latias, are not common, and the Poison typing offers resistances to many relevant offensive types, the most important of which being Fairy, because of Flutter Mane.

Mega Calm Mind.description: Mega Latias's impressive bulk, speed tier, and defensive typing make for a superb setup sweeper. This also allows it to find points of entry against common offensive threats such as Iron Moth and Keldeo. Calm Mind boosts Mega Latias' naturally high Special Attack and Special Defense to astounding levels, ensuring that it can easily withstand moves such as Clefable's unboosted Moonblast and Choice Scarf Hydreigon's Dark Pulse to sweep weakened teams. Psyshock is crucial to ignore defensive boosts from Calm Mind variants of the aforementioned Clefable while also breaking past special walls such as Blissey and Chansey more easily, preventing them from crippling Mega Latias with status moves. Aura Sphere provides Mega Latias with important coverage against most Dark- and Steel-types, hitting Pokemon such as Tyranitar, Bisharp, and Excadrill super effectively. Alternatively, if Tyranitar is handled adequately by Mega Latias's teammates, Mystical Fire can be used to deal more immediate damage to the likes of Scizor and Celesteela instead. Mega Latias fits best on defensive and balance teams, which can provide it with the longevity needed to gain proper setup opportunities. Entry hazard support from the likes of Skarmory and Gastrodon can help wear down opposing walls that would otherwise be difficult to break through late-game, such as Tapu Fini. Similarly, wallbreakers such as Choice Band Iron Hands can make for good options to take advantage of these Pokemon, especially when Mega Latias lacks Mystical Fire to deal with the former. However, although Mega Latias is able to switch into Pokemon like Iron Hands, its lack of initial power can leave it vulnerable to being overwhelmed by their boosted attacks in return. Thus, Speed control options such as Choice Scarf Hydreigon and Tapu Fini, in addition to certain defensive walls like Unaware Skeledirge are extremely valuable in providing backup against such foes. Conversely, paralysis support from the likes of Clefable is also notable, as they can limit faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Hydreigon and Cinderace from being able to overwhelm Mega Latias with super effective hits late-game.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Latias is an effective form of speed control that sets itself apart from other Pokemon the same role, such as Choice Scarf Galarian Zapdos, with its unique utility options. Draco Meteor serves as its main STAB attack, letting Latias revenge kill most neutral targets such as Thundurus-T and opposing Latias. Psyshock is a more spammable STAB move that also lets it clean weakened teams and threaten Fighting-types as well as Iron Moth. Psychic is very similar, trading a chance to OHKO Iron Moth for a 2HKO on Iron Hands and a slightly higher damage output against most neutral targets. Healing Wish is especially helpful to bulky Pokemon that lack reliable recovery such as Iron Hands and Tapu Fini. It can also grant offensive Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar another opportunity to sweep or wallbreak. Trick is Latias's preferred fourth move, allowing it to cripple otherwise unbreakable foes such as Blissey and Chansey. An alternative is Mystical Fire, which lets Latias threaten the Steel-types that resist its STAB combination, like Aegislash and Excadrill. Its Special Attack-lowering effect makes it especially useful against certain boosting threats such as Autotomize Celesteela. Defog is another alternative, letting Latias clear hazards for its team; however, the fact that Latias loses to most Stealth Rock users such as Mega Tyranitar and Excadrill makes it somewhat unreliable in this role. Latias fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that want a revenge killer and appreciate Latias's utility. Latias struggles the most against special walls like Blissey and Slowking, making physical wallbreakers such as Bisharpand Galarian Zapdos mandatory partners. Fighting-types such as Buzzwole are useful to threaten Mega Tyranitar, which takes minimal damage from Latias's attacks and can trap it with Pursuit; they can also take out Steel-types like Excadrill, something especially important if Latias forgoes Mystical Fire. Latias's ability to force in and cripple special walls with Trick makes a good partner for special attackers like Clefable.

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Calm Mind.description: Mega Latias uses its solid bulk and defensive profile to take advantage of and set up on Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Mega Charizard Y, and Urshifu-R. Most notably, it uses its solid Speed stat to outspeed and threaten Pokemon like Kartana, Mega Medicham, and Garchomp. These traits, in combination with its diverse movepool, make Mega Latias an acceptable wincon. Psyshock lets Mega Latias hit strong specially defensive walls such as Chansey and Slowking-G while also allowing it to threaten other setup sweepers such as Clefable and Volcarona. Aura Sphere removes threatening Dark-types such as Kingambit and Weavile while also preventing Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn from safely dealing with it. Mystical Fire can be used to threaten Gholdengo while still threatening Kingambit and Weavile somewhat, but it leaves it vulnerable to Mega Tyranitar, Heatran, and Hydreigon. Alternatively, Ice Beam + Thunder can be used on Mega Latias to give it perfect coverage and let it threaten Pokemon like Landorus-T and Gliscor, but it lacks immediate power, notably leaving it unable to threaten any Pursuit trappers. Pokemon such as Buzzwole and Toxapex form good defensive cores with Mega Latias, handling Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Kingambit for it while Mega Latias deals with Mega Charizard Y and Zapdos in return. Offensive teammates such as Kingambit and Great Tusk are also useful for pressuring checks such as Weavile, opposing Kingambit, and Gholdengo. Spikes support from the likes of Skarmory and Clodsire can be used to wear down checks to Mega Latias such as the aforementioned Kingambit and Gholdengo. Mega Latias is prone to being chipped down by Toxic and Stealth Rock, so teammates that deal with that weakness such as Gliscor, Toxapex, and Gholdengo are appreciated; the former provides valuable Defog support for it.

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Special Wallbreaker.description: Latios is an elite wallbreaker thanks largely to its raw power. Its powerful STAB move in Draco Meteor allows Latios to demolish all but the sturdiest neutral targets, including Tyranitar, Gastrodon, and Hippowdon. It can leverage its solid Speed stat versus common offensive Pokemon such as Victini, Galarian Zapdos, Sandy Shocks, and Blacephalon as well as its numerous useful resistances to create opportunities to unleash devastating moves. Psyshock is preferred over Psychic to defeat specially defensive Pokemon such as Blissey and Chansey more easily. Trick is used on Choice Specs sets to cripple would-be walls such as Jirachi and Clefable, while Roost allows Life Orb variants to offset the item's recoil. Mystical Fire is preferred on Latios to hit Steel-types such as Excadrill, Aegislash, and Celesteela. It can also choose to use Thunderbolt to flip important matchups such as Tapu Fini, Slowking, and physically defensive Clefable while also providing a consistent way to damage most Steel-types. Choice Specs is preferred to maximize damage output, but Life Orb can also be chosen in order to enable switching moves, at the cost of the ability to eliminate Pokemon such as Tyranitar and Hippowdon with Draco Meteor. Latios's ability to blow away physical walls makes it an excellent partner to any physical wallbreaker. Latios appreciates opportunities to fire off powerful attacks, so Pokemon with pivoting moves such as Cinderace, Galarian Zapdos, and Scizor make for good partners. Latios struggles with Choice Scarf users able to force it to switch, such as Tapu Fini, Blacephalon, and Latias, as well as Pokemon able to naturally outspeed it such as Cinderace and Alakazam. These weaknesses can be alleviated with defensive pivots able to switch into these threats, such as Clefable, Celesteela, Hippowdon, and Skarmory, depending on foe. Latios also pairs well with supportive Pokemon like Clefable and Mega Tyranitar that are able to help it break through walls through utility moves such as entry hazards or Knock Off. Latios pairs especially well with Fighting-type wallbreakers such as Buzzwole, Galarian Zapdos, and Iron Hands due to their favorable matchups into the Steel- and Dark-types looking to switch into Latios's STAB moves. In return, Latios offers a Psychic resistance and a favourable matchup into physically defensive Pokemon such as Skarmory, Slowbro, and opposing Buzzwole.

Double Dance.description: Access to Calm Mind and Stored Power make Latios an overwhelming setup sweeper. It makes use of the synergy between its boosting moves and Weakness Policy to punish opponents both for choosing to attack it and for choosing not to attack it. Stored Power allows Latios to take advantage of stat boosts even versus Unaware Pokemon such as Clefable and Skeledirge. Aura Sphere is chosen to threaten the only Pokemon able to survive a boosted Stored Power: Dark-types like Bisharp, Tyranitar, and Hydreigon. Latios fits best on hyper offense teams, which require support from Pokemon such as Excadrill and Mew that can set entry hazards for Latios to secure important KOs late-game. It struggles with strategies able to interrupt its setup without activating Weakness Policy, such as phazing moves from Skarmory and specially defensive Pokemon able to trade hits with Latios such as Scizor and Celesteela. Setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar and Scizor aid with overwhelming Steel-types, while Z-Celebrate Victini and Meteor Beam Celesteela can threaten the Steel-types once they have been forced in. Pokemon halted by Unaware users appreciate Latios's ability to boost past them, namely Dragon Dance Mega Aerodactyl and Swords Dance Cinderace.

Mega Attacker.description: Mega Latios's gargantuan Special Attack, excellent bulk for an offensive Pokemon, and Speed tier that outpaces common wallbreakers suchas Thundurus-T, Keldeo, and Enamorus make it powerful threat that can terrorize offensive and defensive Pokemon alike. Aura Sphere is essential for its role, targeting Dark-types, notably 2HKOing the Tyranitar formes and OHKOing Bisharp, foes that can otherwise Pursuit trap Mega Latios. It also targets Steel-types such as Excadrill. Shadow Ball hits opposing Psychic-types such as Latios and Latias. Alternatively, Thunderbolt targets Water-types such as Tapu Fini and Flying-types such as Celesteela; additionally, while Mega Latios doesn't need Thunderbolt to threaten Enamorus and Skarmory, it always OHKOes them after Stealth Rock. Both options have the added benefit of pressuring Slowbro and Slowking, which otherwise stonewall and can pivot out on Mega Latios. Recover lets Mega Latios stay healthy, allowing it to check foes such as Keldeo and Iron Hands throughout a game. Mega Latios best fits on bulky offense teams looking for a fast offensive threat that has strong defensive utility. It has massive competition with Mega Latias, which is a much better setup sweeper thanks to its massive bulk, so teams using Mega Latios must utilize the instant offensive power it provides. Mega Latios is helpless against certain special walls such as Chansey and Blissey, making physical wallbreakers such as Scizor and Iron Hands necessary partners. Pursuit trappers like Tyranitar and Bisharp are notably effective at removing these walls. While it isn't helpless against Dark-types, foes like Mega Tyranitar and Bisharp can still easily win the one-on-one thanks to their bulk or access to Sucker Punch, making Fighting-types such as Buzzwole and Galarian Zapdos good partners for their ability to check and remove them. Mega Latios can be revenge killed by faster foes such as Choice Scarf Enamorus and Hydreigon, making bulky teammates such as Amoonguss and Celesteela useful teammates. Based on its choice of coverage, Mega Latios is either walled by Psychic-types like Latios and Latias or certain Water- and Flying-types like Calm Mind Tapu Fini and Celesteela. The aforementioned Pursuit trappers are excellent at removing the former. Ghost-types like Hisuian Zoroark can also work well at KOing these foes. Against the latter group, Electric-types such as Iron Hands and Zeraora can eliminate them. Given that many of Mega Latios's checks lack recovery and don't hold Heavy-Duty Boots, entry hazard setters like Mew, Excadrill, and Mega Tyranitar can help it break through them.

Offensive.description: Mega Latios is a powerful wallbreaker that breaks through common defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex, Landorus-T, Rotom-W, and Clodsire using its impressive coverage and high Special Attack while also having a good Speed tier to deal with Pokemon like Garchomp and Urshifu-R. However, Mega Latios slightly suffers from four-moveslot syndrome, and while it cannot run all the coverage it wants, this doesn't hinder its effectiveness much. Aura Sphere is a must have in a tier plagued by Kingambit, as it easily Pursuit traps and KOes Mega Latios, and it also allows Mega Latios to hit other Steel-type Pokemon like Heatran and Ferrothorn. Mystical Fire allows it to secure the OHKO on Ferrothorn while also hitting Mega Scizor and Gholdengo, but it struggles more against the likes of Tera Grass Heatran, Dragonite, Tera Dragon Toxapex, and Slowbro. Ice Beam allows it to check Ground- and Dragon-types like Landorus-T, Garchomp, Gliscor, and Dragonite, but it will then have difficulty with the likes of Slowbro, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo. Substitute lets it bypass status and also bait a Tera or Sucker Punch from Kingambit and neutralize the aforementioned Slowbro, but Mega Latios then gets walled by most, if not all, of the previously mentioned checks. Roost allows it to more consistently check Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Mega Charizard Y while also letting it consistently wallbreak throughout the course of a game. Mega Latios fits well on bulky offensive teams that can utilize its ability to break through defensive cores such as Toxapex and Gliscor, which opens up opportunities for allies like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant to wallbreak as well. However, it is easily checked by faster threats that can OHKO it like Iron Valiant, Enamorus, Dragapult, and many Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo and Tapu Lele. It is also walled by specific tanks like Heatran, Toxapex, Dragonite, or Slowbro, depending on its coverage. Therefore, it appreciates partners that can deal with the aforementioned Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Heatran, Clodsire, and Ferrothorn. Entry hazard support is also incredible at allowing Mega Latios to rack up chip damage by the switches it naturally forces, and its checks like Heatran, Slowbro, and the like have reduced longevity when switching into hazards and become easier to break, so allies like Samurott-H, Landorus-T, or Heatran assist well. Mega Latios also pairs well with the likes of Tapu Lele and Kartana, weakening their shared Steel-type checks so that the latter two can clean up end-game.

Stored Power.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!
