Triple Axel threatens common switch-ins such as Gliscor and Mandibuzz, while Return is Mega Lopunny's hardest-hitting move against most Psychic- and Fairy-types, such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Blissey is a great teammate, taking on the likes of Volcarona and Zapdos thanks to its bulk while offering support in the form of Stealth Rock, Toxic, and Teleport. Staraptor switches into Fighting-type attacks from Pokemon like Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Tapu Bulu, and its access to Defog and U-turn also prolongs Mega Lopunny's longevity and lets it switch in unscathed. Special attackers like Hisuian Zoroark and Porygon-Z are able to break past physical walls Mega Lopunny can't, like Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Slowbro. Hisuian Zoroark also prevents Fighting-types from spamming their STAB moves aimed at Mega Lopunny.

Wallbreaker (Normal).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive.description: Mega Lopunny is a powerful, fast Pokemon that cements itself as one of the best all-out attackers in the metagame. It's a fantastic revenge killer thanks to its high-Base Power STAB moves and its ability, Scrappy. Fake Out is a fantastic priority move that inflicts meaningful chip damage onto offensive foes such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko, putting them all range of Frustration. U-turn provides momentum and allows Mega Lopunny to pivot out of its checks safely, such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk, and bring in its teammates. Alternatively, Quick Attack can be run to enhance Mega Lopunny's revenge killing capabilities, which helps against faster threats such as Dragapult and Booster Energy Iron Valiant. Triple Axel can also be run over U-turn to hit Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Tornadus-T, though this forgoes more consistent utility. Mega Lopunny sits very well on bulky offense teams, as they benefit from its Speed and pivoting abilities. Therefore, offensive Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, Dragapult, and Weavile all pair very well with it, forming great offensive cores by wallbreaking alongside Mega Lopunny. Mega Lopunny loses to Choice Specs Dragapult, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Zamazenta. Because of this, defensive Pokemon like Landorus-T, Heatran, and Gholdengo are appreciated in checking these threats; the former two also set entry hazards, further increasing Mega Lopunny's damage output in conjunction with Fake Out.

Utility.description:
Memento can support setup sweepers like Hisuian Sneasel, Farigiraf, and Veluza, which hyper offensive teams especially appreciate. Toxic is an option over Taunt to more quickly wear down walls like Rhydon and Hisuian Avalugg. Toxic Spikes punish teams that are mostly grounded or lack Heavy-Duty Boots, though it can be inconsistent with how common Poison-types, notably opposing Skuntank, are.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Physically Offensive.description:
Skuntank hosts powerful STAB options, priority, and an array of status moves, making it a great offensive threat and support Pokemon. Furthermore, Skuntank's great defensive typing makes it a solid switch-in for foes like Gogoat and Indeedee-F. Crunch is Skuntank's best way to hit targets such as Misdreavus and Indeedee-F, but if instead running only two attacks, Skuntank can use Poison Jab over Gunk Shot for a reliable attack alongside Sucker Punch. Taunt can stop moves from slower foes that may try to abuse or cripple Skuntank such as Tinkatuff's Thunder Wave, Carbink's Iron Defense or Trick Room, as well as entry hazards from both. Toxic is another way to threaten bulky threats like Misdreavus if not running Crunch, Carbink, Gogoat, and Alolan Persian. Toxic Spikes punishes foes that don't hold Heavy-Duty Boots such as Gabite and Choice item Basculin, although it can be less reliable with the abundance of Heavy-Duty Boots in the metagame. If Skuntank is no longer needed, Aftermath allows it to punish contact moves from foes like Honchkrow and Flapple. Tera Dark makes Sucker Punch a more reliable revenge killing option while further boosting Crunch's damage. Tera Ground allows Skuntank to serve as a Volt Switch blocker and pairs well with Tera Blast to hit opposing Skuntank and Tinkatuff. Tera Flying can lure Ground moves like Charizard and Dugtrio's Earthquake to more easily pick them off in addition to removing Skuntank's weakness to Ground.

With Skuntank only weak to Ground-types like Whiscash, allies that can absorb Ground-type attacks such as Gogoat, Flapple, and Rotom-F come in handy. Whiscash also makes a good partner to help with threats like Alolan Dugtrio and Tinkatuff, while Skuntank can deal with said Grass-types. Skuntank's Toxic and Toxic Spikes pair well with bulky Pokemon like Dachsbun and Chansey to stall out foes. Dachsbun's Wish and Chansey's Heal Bell also help with longevity. Misdreavus is a notably great teammate, as it offers a Ground immunity, can cripple threats such as Gabite and Perrserker with Will-O-Wisp, and can spinblock. Misdreavus can also run Hex to benefit from any poisoned foes. Item removal, such as Banette's Knock Off and Indeedee-F's Trick, can get rid off foes' Heavy-Duty Boots to benefit Toxic Spikes. Indeedee-F can also help with Skuntank's longevity via Healing Wish, although it is notable that its Psychic Surge temporarily hinders Skuntank's Sucker Punch. While being the best Toxic Spikes setter, Skuntank is also the best way to remove Toxic Spikes with the lack of hazard removal in the metagame. This is appreciated by non-Heavy-Duty Boots Pokemon like Gabite and Assault Vest Crabominable.

Specially Defensive (Poison).description:
Skuntank fills a very important role on Poison teams by packing a much-desired Psychic immunity, which allows it to switch into Psychic-type moves from many common threats such as Greninja, Flutter Mane, and Hatterene. It proceeds to force them out with its hard hitting Poison Jab-which can spread poison around, while Sucker Punch picks them off should they be weakened enough. Protect is also very valuable in scouting their coverage moves, letting Skuntank accumulate Black Sludge recovery, and stalling out poison damage. Aftermath punishes contact attackers like Kingambit and Azumarill, which allows teammates such as Toxicroak to safely come in and finish them off. Skuntank can run Play Rough to threaten common Dark-types of the metagame, such as Chien-Pao and Hydreigon.

Physically defensive Amoonguss and Toxapex are valuable teammates that deal with the physical attackers that threaten Skuntank, like Mimikyu, Quaquaval, and Dondozo. Amoonguss also deals with threatening Ground-types such as Great Tusk, Quagsire, and Sandy Shocks thanks to its good bulk, Grass-type STAB move, and Ground neutrality. Toxapex, on the other hand, deals with threats like Chien-Pao, Cloyster, and Scizor with Infestation and Haze while laying down Toxic Spikes. Specially defensive Clodsire complements Skuntank by dealing with special attackers it can't handle by itself, such as Gholdengo, Magnezone, and Volcarona. Iron Moth deals with the multitude of Steel-types like Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Corviknight that Skuntank can't do much against. Corrosion Glimmora and Salazzle help cripple Steel-types and opposing Poison-types with Toxic, with each also providing different utilities; Glimmora packs Poison's only entry hazard removal thanks to Mortal Spin, which allows Skuntank to come in safely, while Salazzle's Encore acts as a counterplay against powerful setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Kingambit.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

Iron Defense (Psychic).description:
Will never be OHKOed from full HP by an unboosted Chien-Pao's Crunch.

This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Trick Room.description:
Tera Blast Fairy breaks through opposing Fighting-types like Virizion and Hariyama as well as Dark-types like Wo-Chien. Psyshock covers Fighting-types without requiring Spiritomb to Terastallize and also hits Tera Poison Wo-Chien. Tera Steel offers Spiritomb several key resistances as well as an immunity to poison, which can translate to additional setup opportunities. Tera Blast can be used alongside Tera Steel to beat Articuno, Cryogonal, and Tera Fairy users, though it doesn't have many other practical applications.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Stealth Rock.description:
Gabite's good Eviolite-bolstered bulk and defensive typing make it a premier Stealth Rock user and an effective check to threats like Skuntank, Raichu, and Lycanroc-N. With its decent Attack and STAB Earthquake + Dragon Tail, Gabite is deceptively hard to switch into and exploit, which gives it an easier time setting Stealth Rock and negating offensive pressure. Rough Skin adds to the support Gabite provides, helping it further wear down physical threats like Basculin and Zangoose for its teammates to finish off. Stone Edge nails Charizard and Articuno and also hits Rotom-F. Dragon Tail is useful against setup sweepers like Gogoat and Tera Fighting Carbink, but Gabite can use Swords Dance instead to double as a bulky wallbreaker. The investment in bulk lets Gabite avoid the 2HKO from Lycanroc-N's Play Rough after Stealth Rock and Charizard's Hurricane at full. 28 Speed EVs allow Gabite to outspeed defensive Misdreavus. Tera Ghost helps against Normal-types like Zangoose and Squawkabilly, provides an immunity to Carbink's Body Press, and lets Gabite spinblock. Tera Fairy is another option that staves off Dark- and Dragon-types like Alolan Persian and Flapple. Alternatively, Tera Steel offers useful resistances like Ice, Flying, and Grass and also lets Gabite come in freely on Toxic and Toxic Spikes.

Because of its unique blend of offense and defense, Gabite fits well on multiple playstyles. Ice-types like Rotom-F and Articuno are the biggest threat to Gabite and must be accounted for when using it. Charizard, Rotom-F, and Carbink are checks to such Pokemon and appreciate having their switch-ins worn down by Stealth Rock, with Charizard and Carbink also offering Gabite backup against Grass- and Fire-types, respectively. If Carbink runs Spikes, it can even form an entry hazard stacking core with Gabite. Pyroar is another option for checking Ice-types that also pressures Tera Fairy Misdreavus, which is really good at exploiting Gabite, and appreciates Gabite coming to its aid against threats like Alolan Dugtrio and Lycanroc-N. Wallbreakers that struggle against Steel-types, such as Indeedee-F and Honchkrow, benefit from Gabite's presence and can also check Misdreavus for it. Cleaners and revenge killers like Electrode and Choice Scarf Basculin love being paired with Gabite, since its ability to effortlessly spread chip damage can give them an easier time picking foes off.

RestTalk.description:
Gabite can opt to run a RestTalk set due to its great bulk and phazing ability. This set helps give Gabite longevity in its phazing role because of its recovery option, which also helps it handle its checks with greater ease. Dragon Tail helps with removing setup sweepers or passive Pokemon that Gabite can't deal with such as Gogoat, Misdreavus, or Vigoroth. However, its phazing ability is also impactful when there are entry hazards on the opponent's field. Rest gives Gabite recovery, while Sleep Talk keeps it from being too passive. 28 Speed allows it to outspeed non-invested Misdreavus, while 116 Special Defense makes Special Charizard's Hurricane a 3HKO. It still has enough physical bulk for Lycanroc-N's Play Rough to only be a 3HKO after Stealth Rock damage. Gabite has the ability to turn into a spinblocker with Tera Ghost, making it an option to keep its team's hazards stay on the field. Tera Fairy helps cover its Dragon-type weakness, which Dragonair and Flapple can exploit, while also providing it a resistance to the strong Dark-types in PU like Alolan Persian, Skuntank, and Houndoom. Tera Steel turns all of its weaknesses into resistances, but be aware of threats it normally can deal with becoming a problem like Alolan Dugtrio, Lycanroc-N, and opposing Gabite.

RestTalk Gabite works best on balance and entry hazard stacking teams. Gabite can also fill the role of status absorber, able to take Misdreavus's or Charizard's Will-O-Wisp, Skuntank's Toxic, and Alolan Persian and Tinkatuff's Thunder Wave. It lacks the ability to be a heavy damage dealer with this set, so Pokemon that can hit it super effectively don't have much trouble coming in on it. The likes of Quaxwell, Mareanie, and Lumineon are appreciated for helping take what would be 4x super effective Ice-type attacks from Whiscash, Golduck, and Crabominable. In return, Gabite helps them with an Electric immunity from the likes of Raichu and Rotom-S. Tinkatuff and Perrserker can also help with these threats as well as covering Gabite's other issues with Flapple and Dragonair. Gabite does well at coming in on the premier Fire-type attackers in the tier: Charizard, Pyroar, and Houndoom. Offensive teammates such as Gogoat, Sawsbuck, and Nasty Plot Rotom-F appreciate its presence on their team as a switch-in for the aforementioned Fire-types, or else they struggle to set up. With many of the tier's top Pokemon having a 4x weakness to Rock, such as Articuno, Charizard, and Masquerain, Gabite can pair well with them, because it walls the likes of Lycanroc-N and Dugtrio which typically carry Rock coverage.

TankChomp.description:
Garchomp is a formidable tank that can reliably set multiple layers of entry hazards while still possessing an adequate offensive presence itself. Notably, it matches up well against common spinners like Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Glimmora, especially as it can punish them from doing so with Rocky Helmet + Rough Skin. This combination is also valuable to spread chip damage onto physical attackers like Kingambit and Dragonite and punish pivots such as Cinderace and Corviknight. Dragon Tail forces out setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Tera Flying Kingambit, and Air Balloon Gholdengo, and it works extremely well to force entry hazard damage onto foes such as Tera Fairy Garganacl, Dondozo, and Iron Valiant. Tera Ghost is used to completely spinblock Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Alternatively, Tera Steel lets it emergency check Dragapult, Meowscarada, and block Glimmora's Mortal Spin, while Tera Water allows it to deal with Gholdengo, Scizor, and Hatterene better.

Garchomp fits best on hazard stacking teams that range from bulky offense to offense. Gholdengo is a near-necessary teammate that can prevent most attempts of entry hazard removal, and it can make use of them itself to chip down checks like Tera Water Garganacl, Amoonguss, and Clodsire. Knock Off users like Meowscarada and Great Tusk can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Amoonguss, Kingambit, and Dragonite to make them susceptible to Garchomp's entry hazards; Great Tusk in particular provides Rapid Spin as well, which removes entry hazards on your side of the field and subsequently maintains your own entry hazards up the opponent's side. Offensive Pokemon like Greninja, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant tend to force multiple switches and enjoy entry hazards chipping down their checks such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, Clodsire, and Garganacl. Substitute Skeledirge is a fantastic teammate that can take advantage of entry hazards itself, use its defensive profile to cover Fairy- and Ice-types like Iron Valiant and Alolan Ninetales, threaten Defog Corviknight from removing entry hazards, and pressure Hatterene, which would otherwise prevent Garchomp's antics and use it as setup fodder.

ChainChomp (Mixed).description:
Mixed Garchomp is a fantastic wallbreaker that can threaten common walls such as Great Tusk, Dondozo, Toxapex, and Clodsire. Draco Meteor hits physical walls. Great Tusk and Dondozo in particular are hit hard by Draco Meteor, with Great Tusk pressured while switching in to remove entry hazards and Dondozo's Unaware letting Garchomp freely use Draco Meteor multiple times on it. Fire Blast covers Steel-type Pokemon such as Corviknight and Air Balloon Gholdengo, the former of which would otherwise switch into Garchomp and clear entry hazards. Stealth Rock is generally preferred if a team does not have another Stealth Rock user, but Spikes can be used to capitalize on the switches that Garchomp forces. A Rash nature makes Garchomp much harder to switch into, even letting it OHKO defensive Great Tusk after one layer of Spikes, but Naive can be used to outspeed Hydreigon and Speed tie opposing Garchomp. Tera Fire is the preferred Tera type, due to it powering up Garchomp's Fire Blast and providing it a resistance to attacks such as Iron Valiant's Moonblast and Hatterene's Draining Kiss, as well as an immunity to Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W, Dragapult, and Skeledirge. Tera Steel similarly flips Garchomp's type matchup, providing it with a useful Dragon and Fairy resistance while maintaining its Stealth Rock resistance.

Garchomp fits on offensive teams thanks to its ability to set entry hazards and wear down common defensive Pokemon, such as Toxapex, Clodsire, and Dondozo, with Life Orb-boosted attacks while keeping entry hazards up against common hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Corviknight. Sweepers such as Kingambit, Dragon Dance Dragapult, Calm Mind Iron Valiant, Iron Moth, and Bulk Up Great Tusk appreciate Garchomp breaking holes in the opposing team early-game. Garchomp is forced out by Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant and Tera Fairy Garganacl, as well as Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon without using Terastallization, so support from Steel-type partners is appreciated to switch into these Pokemon. Kingambit is another good partner because it takes on Dragapult and appreciates Garchomp wearing down Great Tusk and Dondozo. Hatterene and Tera Fairy Skeledirge can also take on these Dragon-types while spreading further passive damage with Magic Bounce or Will-O-Wisp. Garchomp can also form a hazard stacking core with lead Meowscarada or other Stealth Rock users such as Great Tusk and Ting-Lu, and Garchomp can pressure common Rapid Spin users. Gholdengo is a great partner for Garchomp, since it blocks most forms of hazard removal while appreciating Garchomp soft checking Iron Moth. Garchomp is also prone to being worn down quickly thanks to Life Orb recoil, entry hazards, and being prediction reliant, so teammates that can clear hazards are appreciated. These include Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads, which all appreciate Garchomp wearing down their common switch-ins such as opposing Great Tusk and Rotom-W.

Swords Dance.description:
Garchomp makes for a powerful physical wallbreaker with Swords Dance, using its Attack boosts to ensure OHKOs against a number of foes in the metagame. Garchomp’s incredible STAB combination of Dragon / Ground can annihilate most walls and defensive cores at +2, with Earthquake reliably knocking out bulky Pokemon like Toxapex, Kingambit, defensive Gholdengo, and Garganacl, and Dragon Claw hitting a vast majority of foes that resist Earthquake, such as Rotom-W and Breloom. Dragon Claw is preferred to Outrage, as it doesn’t provide free switch-in opportunities to prominent Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant and Hatterene. Substitute is essential for letting Garchomp block incoming status, especially from foes it cannot always OHKO, such as Skeledirge, non-Foul Play Amoonguss, and Rotom-W. Substitute can be set up on a forced switch to ensure Garchomp gets a chance to use Swords Dance, and can be set up for free against U-turns from slow pivots like Corviknight. Leftovers allows Garchomp to heal off Substitute damage, giving it more chances to use it. With Rough Skin, Garchomp punishes Great Tusk using Rapid Spin and U-turn from pivots like Cinderace. Tera Ground allows Garchomp to hit much harder with Earthquake, giving it the extra power to OHKO Hatterene, Garganacl after Stealth Rock chip, and potentially Amoonguss and offensive Great Tusk sets at +2. Alternatively, Tera Steel is a more defensive option used to resist Iron Valiant's Moonblast and Dragapult's Draco Meteor, the latter being very important, as Infiltrator allows it to bypass Garchomp’s Substitute.

Garchomp is a solid wallbreaker on balance and bulky offense teams, due to its power complemented by defensive utility from Substitute, Leftovers, and decent bulk that gives it opportunities for consistent use throughout a battle. Garchomp mainly struggles against Corviknight, as well as exceptionally bulky physical walls such as Dondozo and Great Tusk. Special wallbreakers like Greninja, Iron Valiant, and Iron Moth threaten these walls to Garchomp and therefore make excellent partners. Dragapult can also provide much-needed special offense while pressuring Dondozo and Corviknight with Draco Meteor and Flamethrower, forming a dangerous Dragon-type spam core with Garchomp and providing speed control that Garchomp cannot, especially against foes like Iron Valiant and Greninja. Additionally, Dragapult can use U-turn to scout a forced switch and safely bring Garchomp into battle against foes like Clodsire and Kingambit. Entry hazard setters like Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Glimmora are great partners, as they allow Garchomp to secure KOs against opponents like Tera Fairy Garganacl and Amoonguss, which it otherwise cannot OHKO at +2. Glimmora and Great Tusk are especially good for this role, as they can both remove hazards that hinder Garchomp’s wallbreaking potential, and the latter can cripple Corviknight by removing its Leftovers with Knock Off. Fast sweepers, such as Roaring Moon, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult, can easily revenge kill Garchomp, especially when its Substitute is down. A defensive backbone made up of Pokemon like Clodsire and Corviknight is essential for Garchomp’s team. Lastly, Garchomp gives great support to late-game and sweepers like Dragapult that appreciate foes like defensive Gholdengo, Toxapex, and Clodsire being removed.

Offensive Stealth Rock.description: Swords Dance Garchomp serves as a fearsome wallbreaker and effective Stealth Rock setter, capable of blowing past common defensive staples such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Zapdos with its combination of Earthquake and a coverage option in Outrage or Stone Edge, in tandem with their respective Z-Crystal. Garchomp's positive matchup versus the latter three in turn allow it to set and maintain Stealth Rock very well. Additionally, Garchomp’s solid natural bulk and good typing lets it find opportunities to set up on Pokemon like Heatran, Volcarona, and Iron Moth. Outrage with Dragonium Z gives Garchomp a stronger option that can notably OHKO Landorus-T at +1 while also OHKOing Great Tusk and Zapdos at +2. However, the Z-Move can require prediction if the opponent has a Fairy-type lest Garchomp become trapped into Outrage and easily revenge killed by foes such as Mega Diancie, Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant. In comparison, Stone Edge bolstered by Rockium Z provides a more consistent attack for Garchomp outside of its Z-Move while hitting foes such as Skarmory, Celesteela, and Corviknight harder than its Dragon-type Z-Move counterpart. Offensive teammates who can exploit the wallbreaking capabilities of Garchomp such as Mega Lopunny, Kartana, and Dragonite are appreciated, while teammates such as Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Ferrothorn give Garchomp a solid option to fall back on in the face of revenge killers such as Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele.

Mixed Attacker.description: These sets are currently up for reservation for a revamp; please check out the C&C thread for more information!

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Though Garchomp benefits tremendously from Rocky Helmet deterring Rapid Spin, Focus Sash is an alternative item choice that can allow it to serve as a pure suicide lead, getting hazards up against foes that would normally OHKO it such as Flutter Mane and Greninja. Leftovers is also an option to extend Garchomp's longevity. Fire Blast run in conjunction with a Naive nature can be used over Spikes to threaten Avalugg and Forretress and catch Corviknight off guard. An EV spread of 232 HP / 36 Def / 240 Spe allows Garchomp to survive a +2 Poltergeist from Ceruledge; however, Garchomp will no longer outspeed Sandy Shocks using this. A Roseli Berry can be used with Iron Head and 96 Attack EVs to allow Garchomp to lure and remove Flutter Mane at the cost of rendering Garchomp generally less effective against the metagame as a whole.

Entry Hazard Support (Dragon).description:
Garchomp is a staple of offensive Dragon teams, serving as an unrivaled entry hazard setter, phazer, and threat to key foes such as Iron Treads, Cinderace, Jirachi, and Iron Hands. It excels at getting up multiple layers of entry hazards due to its good bulk and Speed, powerful STAB Earthquake, and access to Rough Skin. The combination of Rough Skin and Rocky Helmet is fantastic for deterring Rapid Spin from foes such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads. It should be noted that if Rapid Spin causes the user to faint due to contact damage, it will not clear entry hazards, making Garchomp particularly adept at keeping hazards up. Moreover, Garchomp has enough bulk to survive an unboosted Ice Spinner from Iron Treads and Quaquaval, so it is relatively unafraid of the metagame’s most common spinners. Outside of warding off spinners, Rocky Helmet + Rough Skin renders Garchomp broadly threatening to physical attackers in general, punishing U-turns from foes such as Sneasler and Cinderace, causing non-Punching Glove Urshifu-R to nearly KO itself from full HP if it uses Surging Strikes on Garchomp, and breaking Dragonite's Multiscale. Dragon Tail rounds out this set by allowing Garchomp to deal good chip damage while forcing out spinners such as Great Tusk and Quaquaval and phazing setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Scizor. The switch forcing capabilities of Dragon Tail synergize incredibly well with this hazard stacking set, enabling Garchomp to rack up entry hazard damage on the opposing team as it repeatedly forces foes out.

While Garchomp is excellent at deterring Rapid Spin by itself, Dragapult provides further security for its entry hazards by acting as a true spinblocker. Moreover, Choice Specs Dragapult greatly appreciates Garchomp’s entry hazards pushing foes into KO ranges and punishing switches, bolstering the already formidable offensive pressure these sets create. Dragapult further enjoys Garchomp’s ability to take on Kingambit, Assault Vest Iron Hands, and Alolan Muk, while Garchomp is grateful for Choice Specs Dragapult threatening Corviknight and thus preventing Defog. Alternatively to Choice Specs, Hex Dragapult can also become an extremely threatening late-game cleaner when combined with Garchomp's entry hazards, and the burns it spreads further help accumulate chip damage on the opposing team. Additionally, Dragapult serves as a crucial check to Iron Defense Zamazenta, which Garchomp cannot phaze if it's behind a Substitute. Hisuian Goodra makes a great pairing with Garchomp, being able to soak up the Ice and Fairy moves aimed at Garchomp from foes such as Alolan Ninetales, Flutter Mane, and Iron Valiant while crushing them in return with its Heavy Slam. Hisuian Goodra can also tank a hit from Chien-Pao and OHKO it in retaliation with Body Press, soak up hits from Choice Specs Greninja, and handle opposing Choice Specs Dragapult. In exchange, Garchomp can duel physical threats such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Sneasler for Hisuian Goodra. Dragon’s various setup sweepers such as Baxcalibur, Kommo-o, Hydreigon, and Dragonite all greatly value Garchomp’s entry hazards pushing foes into KO ranges and breaking the Focus Sashes of foes such as Ceruledge and Breloom, enabling their sweeps. Of these, Kommo-o is especially notable, as its Vacuum Wave can OHKO Chien-Pao at neutral and Greninja following a Clangorous Soul and Throat Spray boost, both of which are incredibly deadly to Garchomp. Choice Scarf Roaring Moon is a great partner to Garchomp, appreciating Garchomp’s entry hazards and ability to wear down Great Tusk and Iron Treads facilitating its late-game cleaning. Roaring Moon in turn supports Garchomp by smashing through Flutter Mane and opposing Dragapult, as well as opening up foes such as Toxapex and Amoonguss to hazard damage by removing their Heavy-Duty Boots with its brutal STAB Knock Off. Choice Scarf Walking Wake appreciates Garchomp’s entry hazards in the same vein while removing threats such as Landorus, Gliscor, Great Tusk, +1 Baxcalibur, and Chien-Pao. If instead using Choice Specs, Walking Wake’s synergy with Garchomp increases even further, as it can blast through Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Rotom-W with its powerful STAB attacks and coverage. Walking Wake can also use Flip Turn to pivot Garchomp in against foes such as Toxapex and Alolan Muk. Cyclizar can clear entry hazards from its side of the field while keeping Garchomp’s up with Rapid Spin; it can also prevent Defog from Corviknight and Mandibuzz with Taunt and remove Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off. Dragalge can compound on Garchomp’s entry hazards with its own Toxic Spikes and use its Fairy neutrality and fierce Adaptability-boosted Poison-type moves to eradicate Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant, Azumarill, and Clefable.

Swords Dance (Ground).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

All-Out Attacker.description:
• Garchomp's fantastic Speed tier and power means it doesn't have to set up to be dangerous.

  • Stone Edge versus Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb is fairly weak, but the speed control can be very useful on Choice Scarf variants if sacrificing Garchomp, and its an excellent fit on the bulkier Assault Vest sets. Stone Edge deals massive damage to common Tera Flying Pokemon such as Gholdengo, and it prevents it from being walled by Tera Fairy Rotom-W.

  • Iron Head: With Tera Steel, Iron Head lets Garchomp beat Tera Fairy Levitate foes such as Rotom-W, and lets it deal massive damage to other common Tera Fairy Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Wo-Chien.

Other Options

  • Crunch: Crunch lets Garchomp deal massive damage to Air Balloon Gholdengo, though it doesn't cover much else.

  • Fire Fang While weak, this is Garchomp's best option against Corviknight when not Tera Fire.

  • Stealth Rock: Using Stealth Rock with a Choice item is very risky, but it can be an unexpected way to get hazards up.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low / Medium: If using Choice Scarf Garchomp, it's fully capable of revenge killing threats without needing Terastallization, only worrying about Ice Shard from Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur. When using the slower Choice Band and Assault Vest variants, Terastallization becomes more important for avoiding revenge kills.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is a fantastic defensive Tera Type for Garchomp with key resistances to Ice and Fairy, and it makes Iron Head a much more powerful option.

  • Fire: When combined with Tera Blast, Tera Fire lets even Choice Scarf Garchomp possibly 2HKO Corviknight. The Fairy and Ice resistance is also very helpful.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy goes all in on the Dragon immunity, no longer being worried about common Fire and Ground coverage from other Dragon-types like Dragonite.

  • Ground: The incredible power boost Earthquake gets from Tera Ground is worth considering, with Choice Band possibly 2HKOing physically defensive Dondozo with it.

  • Electric: Tera Electric not only lets Garchomp deal more damage to Dondozo and Corviknight, but it getting rid of all of Garchomp's old weaknesses is especially helpful for Assault Vest sets.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With Choice Scarf, Garchomp is able to outspeed and revenge kill key threats, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Choice Specs Iron Moth, making it a potent late-game cleaner as well.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band trades revenge killing for wallbreaking, letting Garchomp reliably 2HKO Skeledirge and deal massive damage to Corviknight with Fire-type Tera Blast.

  • Assault Vest: Garchomp's solid bulk makes it shockingly hard to revenge kill when carrying an Assault Vest, especially when using a specialized EV spread.

Bulkier EV Spread

60 Atk / 204 SpD / 244 Spe with Adamant: This Assault Vest optimized EV spread lets Garchomp survive Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast from full health, while outspeeding Modest Chi-Yu, Jolly Baxcalibur, and Jolly Great Tusk.

Offensive.description:
• Thanks to its good bulk, unique Speed tier, and excellent use of Terastallization, Garchomp is a solid offensive threat.

  • Outrage versus Dragon Claw: Outrage is by far Garchomp's strongest STAB move, but the lock-in effect makes it very vulnerable to Fairy-types such as Mimikyu.

  • Swords Dance: The classic Swords Dance Garchomp still makes sense in this metagame, making it deal incredible damage to bulky foes like Ting-Lu and Azumarill

  • Fire Fang versus Tera Blast: Despite its low base power, Fire Fang is Garchomp's best shot at breaking past Corviknight after a Swords Dance. If Garchomp is almost always Terastallized on your team, Tera Blast can be used instead.

  • Stealth Rock: Despite the offensive nature of this set, Garchomp is still a great setter of Stealth Rock, especially when using Focus Sash.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium / Low: While Garchomp isn't slow, it's typing leaves it very vulnerable to major speedy threats like Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle, which is an issue Terastallization can flip on its head. If using Focus Sash, Terastallization becomes far less needed.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type has excellent synergy with Garchomp's typing, letting it more effectively tackle faster Dragon-types, Iron Bundle, Mimikyu, and Ice Shard from the likes of Baxcalibur and Cloyster.

  • Fairy: Fairy is an even stronger option against Dragon-types, and gives Garchomp a better matchup against Great Tusk.

  • Fire: While the Stealth Rock weakness is unfortunate against bulkier teams, a Fire Tera type lets Life Orb Garchomp OHKO Corviknight with a +2 Fire Fang 93.8% of the time.

  • Ground: While the defensive synergy with Garchomp's former typing isn't that strong, a Ground Tera type lets Garchomp become more of a hit-and-run attacker with Earthquake, dealing good damage to Dondozo before being forced out by Yawn.

Items

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Garchomp deal with major status users more easily, such as Breloom and Rotom-W.

  • Focus Sash: Surviving shocking attacks with Focus Sash gives Garchomp new sweeping and revenge killing potential, and makes it a reliable setter of Stealth Rock if needed.

  • Life Orb: This is the best option for damage output.

Entry Hazard Setter.description:
• While Garchomp is known for its offensive prowess, its access to incredible tools like Rough Skin, Dragon Tail, and a good Speed stat make it a viable alternative to Ting-Lu as a entry hazard setter.

  • Earthquake versus Bulldoze: Bulldoze brings utility against Choice Scarf and naturally fast grounded opponents, but its lower Base Power makes Garchomp more passive against bulkier Pokemon.

  • Dragon Tail: Dragon Tail has marvelous synergy with setting up hazards, making it the prime choice for a Dragon-type STAB despite the lowered priority.

  • Spikes: thanks to its Speed and Dragon Tail, Garchomp is arguably the best Spikes setter in the metagame! Just make sure using it is worth the cost of losing coverage for the team.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: If using Tera Fairy, this can help Garchomp muscle past Great Tusk, a foe that can threaten to Rapid Spin your hazards away. It also will now OHKO Chien-Pao after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Iron Head: Beyond pairing well with Tera Steel, Iron Head prevents Garchomp from being walled by Tera Fairy Rotom-W.

Other Options

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb is a good alternative speed control option for Bulldoze thanks to hitting Flyging-types like Dragonite, but it can be difficult to fit in.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: This Garchomp's bulk means it can set up hazards against a wide variety of foes, but Terastallization will be needed to take on some major physical threats, such as Chien-Pao, Azumarill, and Baxcalibur.

  • Fairy: Fairy Tera type provides Garchomp with an immunity to Dragon-type attacks, and is a big help against Chien-Pao and Great Tusk.

  • Steel: Terastallizing into a Steel-type makes Garchomp resist Dragon-, Ice- and Fairy-type attacks, making it a safer lead against opposing Dragon-type leads and Iron Bundle, at the cost of being vulnerable to Tera Fire Dragons and Fighting- and Ground-types.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Garchomp a vital Ice and Steel resistance without making it weak to Fighting, making it a fantastic option against Chien-Pao, Gholdengo, and Baxcalibur, at the cost of being less effective against Iron Bundle compared to other Tera types.

EV spreads

  • 252 HP / 244 Def / 12 Spe with Impish: This simple looking EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Life Orb Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash when Garchomp has Terastallized, while outspeeding Adamant Breloom and the rare Timid Magnezone.

  • 188 HP / 236 Def / 84 Spe with Impish: This EV spread lets Garchomp survive Adamant Dragonite's Outrage while also outspeeding it.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Jolly: While this spread doesn't take physical hits as well, it lets Garchomp outspeed Modest Chi-Yu, Jolly Baxcalibur, and Jolly Great Tusk.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Combined with Rough Skin, Rocky Helmet severely punishes contact moves.

  • Sitrus Berry: This prevents Choice Band Dragapult from OHKOing Garchomp, as it activates after the first hit, and the HP recovered doesn't allow the second one to get the KO, unless Dragapult is Terastallized into a Dragon-type.

  • Red Card: With Red Card, Garchomp will be able to phaze foes Terastallizing into a Fairy type once.

  • Safety Goggles: This Garchomp has particularly big issues against Breloom, Amoonguss, and Brute Bonnet, so the Spore immunity granted by this item is quite useful.

Specially Defensive.description: With solid defensive stats, a great defensive typing, and powerful phazing in Dragon Tail, Garchomp is a choice entry hazard setter and special wall, capable of switching into and pivoting around powerful attackers like Iron Moth, Zapdos, Sandy Shocks, and Gengar. Stealth Rock is an option over Spikes if a teammate like Ogerpon-H or Sandy Shocks is already running the latter move. Swords Dance can turn Garchomp into a potential wallbreaking threat, notably OHKOing unboosted Zamazenta-C and threatening a 2HKO on defensive Kommo-o and RegenVest Manaphy at +2, while Fire Blast chips Corviknight and Earth Eater Gholdengo. A Sassy Nature is preferred if running Fire Blast, sacrificing Speed to avoid a cut to Special Attack. Regenerator allows Garchomp to come in repeatedly over the course of a game. Strong attackers like Tail Glow Manaphy, Dragonite, and Zamazenta-C appreciate the entry hazards set by Garchomp softening up foes to be more vulnerable to their powerful attacks while also appreciating the defensive backbone Garchomp provides. Corviknight is an ideal partner for Garchomp, handling monstrous physical threats like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon, while Garchomp handles special attackers like Iron Moth, Zapdos, and Heatran in return. Garchomp is vulnerable to being overwhelmed by foes such as Walking Wake, Manaphy, and Hisuian Electrode, especially without Regenerator, so Pokemon that can handle these powerful special attackers like Blissey, Empoleon, and Hisuian Goodra make great teammates.

Mixed Attacker.description: Mixed Attacker Garchomp is a reliable entry hazard setter that packs enough power and Speed to consistently deter common hazard removal options like Corviknight and Great Tusk from safely switching in. Draco Meteor is the STAB move of choice, surprising offensive Great Tusk with a 2HKO, while Fire Blast 2HKOes Corviknight. Download is a niche option over Regenerator, letting it secure a 2HKO on Mandibuzz and offensive Manaphy with Draco Meteor while also freeing your Regenerator slot for a teammate like Kommo-o or Great Tusk, but it comes at the cost of cutting into Garchomp's longevity. Life Orb notably guarantees the 2HKO on specially defensive Garchomp with Draco Meteor. Offensive threats like Manaphy, Azelf, and Iron Moth appreciate Garchomp for its entry hazards and ability to threaten common defensive foes, chipping them down to be picked off later in the game. Defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Zapdos, and RegenVest Manaphy appreciate Garchomp outspeeding and threatening powerful offensive threats such as Great Tusk, Ceruledge, and Sandy Shocks, while Garchomp appreciates these defensive partners handling the faster attackers like Azelf and Chien-Pao that force Garchomp out. Garchomp is worn down very easily by hazards and appreciates Rapid Spin users like Great Tusk and Quaquaval and Wish support from Scream Tail, allowing it to come in repeatedly over the course of the game while greatly improving its longevity, especially if running Download. Garchomp also struggles to break through common defensive foes like Scream Tail and Earth Eater Empoleon, so it appreciates teammates such as Gengar and Zamazenta-C, which can break down these walls.

Physically Defensive.description: Garchomp is an excellent entry hazard setter that checks many of the tier's Fire-types like Cinderace, Talonflame, and Ogerpon-H lacking Play Rough. Stealth Rock is an option over Spikes if a teammate like Ogerpon-H is carrying the move. Swords Dance allows Garchomp to threaten hazard removers like Quaquaval and act as a potential wincon late-game, while Dragon Tail forces switches, racking up entry hazard chip damage and preventing setup, and Liquidation hits both Landorus formes and Levitate Iron Treads and chips Corviknight. Regenerator allows it to switch in more times throughout a game to find opportunities to set up entry hazards or Swords Dance, while Well-Baked Body punishes Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge for clicking their strong STAB moves and increases its walling capabilities. Garchomp's inability to check threats like Chien-Pao and Galarian Zapdos facilitates another physical wall like Corviknight or Zapdos, which can switch into them and pivot out. Garchomp's inability to check special threats like Azelf, Gengar, and Walking Wake makes special walls like RegenVest Manaphy and Goodra great partners if Garchomp is not using Regenerator; if Garchomp is using Regenerator, Blissey and Empoleon are alternative options as special walls.

Setup Sweeper.description: Mega Garchomp is an incredibly powerful wallbreaker and sweeper with favorable matchups against common physical walls like Miraidon and Arceus-Poison. Shift Gear and Tidy Up increase its offensive power and help offset Mega Garchomp's poor Speed, allowing it to outspeed common physical walls; the former ensures Mega Garchomp outspeeds Deoxys-A, while the latter provides role compression by removing entry hazards. Jungle Healing helps offset accumulated chip damage and Life Orb recoil while also removing crippling status conditions like burn and poison. This allows Mega Garchomp to much more freely switch into Mortal Spin users like Arceus-Poison and Miraidon not running a Dragon-type attack. Life Orb, Adaptability, and an Adamant nature provide a crucial power boost, letting unboosted Mega Garchomp OHKO Mega Steelix and 2HKO Fur Coat Arceus-Poison. If desired, Defense EVs can be lowered to allow Mega Garchomp to always OHKO Eviolite Imposter Chansey with +1 Glaive Rush. Mega Garchomp pairs well with other physical wallbreakers like Choice Band Mega Mewtwo X to heavily pressure Fur Coat users like Yveltal and Arceus-Ghost; in return they appreciate Mega Garchomp handling Arceus-Poison and Miraidon. Teammates, such as Magic Bounce Mega Audino, can limit Strength Sap recovery from opposing physical walls like Fur Coat Arceus-Ghost and Yveltal, allowing Mega Garchomp to eventually break through them. Mega Garchomp can be Imposter-proofed by Fur Coat users like Arceus-Fairy and Arceus-Ghost.

Choice Band.description: Thanks to an excellent offensive typing and Attack, Mega Garchomp is an incredibly strong wallbreaker that, thanks to its Ground typing, resists Stealth Rock and can naturally destroy foes that competitors like Kyurem-B can't. Adaptability, which Mega Garchomp can afford to run thanks to its Ground STAB, gives a strong power boost that Imposter users aren't immune to, while Mold Breaker ignores Fur Coat on targets like Arceus-Ghost; Sword of Ruin fares worse into Imposter users than Adaptability, but it boosts Glacial Lance’s and Gigaton Hammer's damage. Gigaton Hammer hits Pokemon like Arceus-Fairy and Mega Audino, making them shaky switch-ins, while Glacial Lance can be used on Mold Breaker sets to OHKO Yveltal after slight chip damage. Because of its low Speed and lack of longevity, Mega Garchomp appreciates slow pivots like RegenVest Mega Steelix and Primal Kyogre. Mega Garchomp can be Imposter-proofed by the likes of Fur Coat Arceus-Fairy and Yveltal.

Magic Guard.description: Lucario is a devastating mixed wallbreaker, capable of tearing apart most defensive cores with ease thanks to its strong STAB moves and great mixed attacking stats. Close Combat and Steel Beam have excellent neutral coverage together and hit common walls like Hisuian Goodra and Scream Tail on their weaker defensive stat. Focus Blast 2HKOes standard Corviknight, while Aura Sphere provides a more consistent special attack. In the final moveslot, Nasty Plot allows Lucario to overwhelm slower teams, while Stone Edge provides coverage for Skeledirge and Zapdos. Bullet Punch is also an option that can turn the tables on would-be revenge killers such as Chien-Pao and Meowscarada after some chip damage. Naive is the recommended nature due to its ability to always outspeed Quaquaval and at worst Speed tie with Hisuian Arcanine. Lucario is best used as a mid-game wallbreaker that can pave the way for sweepers like Zamazenta-C and Hisuian Electrode by breaking through Pokemon like Corviknight and Garchomp. Lucario also heavily benefits from slow pivots like Meloetta, Corviknight, and Landorus-T; in return, they switch into Pokemon that threaten Lucario out, like Zapdos, Iron Treads, and Cinderace. While Lucario has limited switch-ins, the ones it does have, like Toxapex and Skeledirge, are very effective without using niche coverage options, so partners that can threaten them, like Zapdos and Quaquaval, are recommended; they can also bring Lucario in on their checks, like Goodra and Corviknight, with U-turn.

Stealth Rock.description:
Hippowdon makes for a great mixed wall by virtue of its bulk, typing, and access to reliable recovery. Its superb bulk enables it to check some of the metagame’s most dangerous threats in Pawmot, Salamence, Tyranitar, and Sandy Shocks. It also provides value through Sand Stream to help combat rain teams if given momentum to get in freely, as it can't hard switch into Water-types. Stone Edge enables Hippowdon to pressure Flying-types like Iron Jugulis and Salamence, in addition to being able to beat Taunt Dragon Dance Tyranitar even after it Terastallizes. Roar is also an option, as it allows Hippowdon to phaze setup sweepers like Polteageist in a pinch and synergizes well with entry hazards. Leftovers is the preferred item, as its residual healing improves Hippowdon's overall longevity and preserves Slack Off's PP. The given spread with an Impish nature and Leftovers avoids a 2HKO from Life Orb Pawmot and prevents Hippowdon from being KOed by Hurricane into Draco Meteor from Salamence after Stealth Rock while avoiding a 2HKO from Sandy Shocks without Stealth Rock. Rocky Helmet is also an option to punish physical attackers, primarily U-turn users and Maushold. A specially defensive spread is an option to handle Gengar if Pawmot is less of a concern. Tera Rock pairs well with its sand, as the Special Defense boost it receives gives it a strong matchup versus special attackers like Gengar, Salamence, and Noivern. Additionally, Tera Rock boosts Hippowdon’s Stone Edge to put more pressure on targets like Salamence. After Hippowdon has Terastallized, it is threatened by Pawmot, Sandy Shocks, and Tyranitar, so be careful when Terastallizing. Tera Ghost is an option that makes Hippowdon a strong response versus Slither Wing, Lucario, and Maushold and lets it spinblock against Donphan. Tera Fairy is an option that grants Hippowdon a generally good defensive typing, including a Fighting resistance, and makes it less vulnerable to Greninja. After becoming a Fairy- or a Ghost-type, Hippowdon is unable to check Gengar, and in the case of the latter, Tyranitar sets running Crunch as well. Tera Dragon makes Hippowdon an effective answer to rain teams through the useful Water-type resistance it provides.

Hippowdon most commonly fits on bulky offense or balance teams for its walling capabilities. Talonflame and Noivern make for good partners, as they are capable of grabbing momentum with U-turn off of opposing Decidueye and Wo-Chien swapping in to exploit Hippowdon. Hippowdon can in return easily absorb Knock Off from the likes of Tinkaton in order to preserve the Heavy-Duty Boots they both depend on. Wo-Chien is also a solid pick for a partner as a nice fit on most balance teams, as well as an answer to bulky Water-types that may attempt to annoy Hippowdon. In particular, Wo-Chien’s RestTalk set is capable of swapping in on Quagsire easily, as it is able to shrug off Toxic. Wo-Chien can also relieve pressure from Hippowdon, as it can take on Sandy Shocks. Tinkaton also makes for a good partner, as it is able to take a lot of the pressure off of Hippowdon by taking hits from Gengar and specially offensive Flying-types such as Iron Jugulis, Noivern, and Salamence. Tinkaton is also capable of providing useful Knock Off support by removing opposing Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots to enable Hippowdon’s Stealth Rock and sandstorm damage to stick. In return, Hippowdon being able to carry Stealth Rock means that Tinkaton does not need to run it itself and can fit a more useful option. Assault Vest Cyclizar is able to check Greninja and Wo-Chien for Hippowdon and keep Spikes or Toxic Spikes off the field from the former.

Mixed Wall.description: Attack EVs OHKO Excadrill, Defense EVs are adjustable for Pokemon like Cinderace and Mega Tyranitar

Defensive.description: Hippowdon is a bulky Ground-type wall and Stealth Rock setter able to switch into threatening offensive Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Mega Charizard Y. It can find plenty of time to set up Stealth Rock and spread chip damage with Toxic and its ability Sand Stream. Sand Stream also allows Hippowdon to disrupt opposing weather, which is bolstered by its positive matchup against every other weather setter. Toxic notably nets a ton of chip damage on Defoggers attempting to get rid of Hippowdon's Stealth Rock and Ground-Immune Pokemon switching into Earthquake, such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, and Mega Charizard Y. Hippowdon can Terastallize into the Steel typing to avoid Toxic in addition to Grass-, Water-, and Ice-type attacks while maintaining its sand immunity and Stealth Rock resistance. Even beyond the simple type matchup chart changes, it allows Hippowdon to more easily check its targets such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Lele, Zapdos, and Mega Diancie. Maximum Special Defense EVs are ran due to Hippowdon having more valuable special targets than physical, namely the aforementioned Pokemon. Mega Lopunny and Tornadus-T appreciate Hippowdon's presence, as it checks both Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zapdos while setting up Stealth Rock to help wear down their checks. Defensively, Hippowdon supports Pokemon such as Garganacl and Skarmory; Garganacl appreciates the sand and its attached benefits and Skarmory appreciates the sturdy Ground-type anchor and special wall. Hippowdon struggles to fend off strong physical attackers like Kingambit, Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Mega Gyarados. For this reason, it pairs exquisitely with strong physical walls such as Skarmory and Buzzwole. Hippowdon also suffers from a Spikes vulnerability, meaning it appreciates Defog support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Zapdos.

Sand Setter.description:
A mixed defensive spread lets Hippowdon comfortably take on attacks from threats like Gouging Fire and Latios.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Stealth Rock Support.description:
• Hippowdon remains a solid Stealth Rock setter, distinguishing itself from Ting-Lu with access to Yawn and consistent recovery.

  • Sand Stream: The passive damage caused from Sandstorm is excellent for breaking Focus Sashes and Multiscale on Dragonite, but be careful as the same applies to your own team if Hippowdon leaves the field prematurely.

  • Whirlwind: This is a more direct phazing option than Yawn, and it is helpful against dangerous setup sweepers that may run Lum Berry, such as Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Slack Off: Slack Off greatly increases Hippowdon’s longevity and is useful if you need it to repeatedly switch into physical attackers like Dragonite, but Hippowdon is often more focused on support than walling, so it isn’t always worth sacrificing a moveslot.

Other Options

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb not only provides helpful speed control, but also pops Air Balloon on foes Hippowdon would otherwise struggle with, such as Gholdengo.

  • Fissure: Hippowdon isn't quite as good at using Fissure as Dondozo and Garganacl, and it can be difficult to fit in, but it does severely punish passive play.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Hippowdon’s typing and immense bulk already make it very difficult to dislodge, but Tera is an option if needing to cushion off some of the most powerful sweepers the meta has on offer.

  • Water: Tera Water improves the lead matchup with Chien-Pao by resisting Icicle Crash, and overall is a strong defensive type that still takes good advantage of Hippowdon’s imposing bulk.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives several key resistances and allows specially defensive Hippowdon to avoid a 2HKO from Iron Bundle that lack Choice Specs. It’s also notable for letting Hippowdon retain immunity to its own Sandstorm chip.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry’s burst recovery is what allows properly invested Hippowdon to avoid 2HKO’s from some of the meta’s strongest attackers.

  • Leftovers: If Hippowdon is able to execute an extended Yawn loop, Leftovers passive recovery is a great boon. Such loops can often force the opponent to sacrifice something to sleep to prevent Hippowdon from healing up to full.

  • Rocky Helmet: While Hippowdon’s support focus makes this a less common item choice, Slack Off combined with smart usage of Terastallization can make this item work to surprising effect.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD with Careful: Patching up Hippowdon's weaker Special Defense is extremely useful against special attackers. With this maximized spread, Hippowdon has a 6.3% chance of surviving Timid Gholdengo's +2 Make It Rain, always survives Modest Chi-Yu’s unboosted Overheat, and avoids the 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane’s Moonblast if using Sitrus Berry.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Impish: A physically defensive spread means not even Choice Band Dragonite’s Outrage will be able to 2HKO Sitrus Berry Hippowdon.

Fluffy.description: Fluffy Hippowdon is a remarkable physical wall thanks to its defensive stats, reliable recovery in Slack Off, and pure Ground typing, letting it check offensive threats like Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing. Whirlwind prevents foes like Talonflame from setting up. Rocky Helmet punishes the physical attackers it checks and lets it pseudo-spinblock Cyclizar and Iron Treads; alternatively, Leftovers gives it extra recovery without having to waste Slack Off PP. 25 Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight, allowing it to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Specially defensive walls like Corviknight, Florges, and Blissey can compensate for Hippowdon's poor Special Defense and check foes like Chi-Yu and Greninja. In return, they appreciate Hippowdon dealing with Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing.

Swords Dance.description: Toxicroak stands out as a very potent late-game sweeper thanks to Swords Dance and Dry Skin, which allow it to switch in and set up on common Water-types like Vaporeon and Qwilfish. Its access to Sucker Punch allows it to revenge kill threats like Choice Scarf Medicham, Bruxish, and Rotom, though it has to be aware of the former two's Tera types and the latter's Will-O-Wisp. Tera Dark gives it a useful Psychic immunity to better the odds versus opposing Bruxish while increasing the power of Sucker Punch. Alternatively, Tera Fighting Toxicroak is able to OHKO Sandaconda, which usually checks it, after a Swords Dance. Toxicroak struggles against the aforementioned Drifblim and Rotom and, without Tera Fighting, Sandaconda. Teammates such as Vaporeon, Eelektross, and Rotom can switch in on its checks and bring it into battle safely. Pokemon that appreciate Toxicroak's presence include Oricorio, Clawitzer, and Bruxish, as they struggle against bulky Pokemon that lose to Toxicroak like Vaporeon, Umbreon, and Chansey.

Nasty Plot.description:
Thanks to its access to Nasty Plot, Toxicroak can threaten Pokemon like Sandaconda and Drifblim that beat physical variations of it. Dark Pulse enables it to get around Pokemon that resist its STAB combination, including Ghost-types like Drifblim, Rotom, and Spiritomb as well as Poison-types like Muk and Qwilfish. Alternatively, Vacuum Wave is a solid STAB move with priority to help it revenge kill faster threats like Zoroark, Lycanroc, and Tera Ice Jolteon. Tera Fighting heavily increases Focus Blast's already high damage output, allowing Toxicroak to rip through bulkier teams. Tera Fighting Toxicroak can run a Modest nature to give it a favorable chance to 2HKO Muk at +2 with Focus Blast; however, it becomes noticeably slower, getting outpaced by Mabosstiff, Bombirdier, and Braviary. Tera Dark Toxicroak better checks Bruxish while also boosting Dark Pulse's power.

Without the use of its Tera type, Toxicroak struggles against bulkier teams that often include Muk or Crocalor, so Pokemon that put pressure on them like Sandaconda and Bruxish pair well with it. Bruxish, as well as other Water-types like Clawitzer, appreciate Toxicroak checking bulky Water-types like Vaporeon and Qwilfish. Toxicroak often relies on Spikes from users such as Qwilfish, Vespiquen, and Cacturne to chip away at foes that it can't handle on its own. Since Toxicroak can lure in and remove Ghost-types like Rotom and Drifblim, Pokemon like Scyther and Coil Eelektross appreciate its support.

Choice Scarf.description:
Toxicroak differentiates itself from other Choice Scarf users, such as Passimian, by virtue of its defensive utility, being immune to Water-type attacks and absorbing Toxic Spikes. It also doesn't Speed tie with other common Choice Scarf attackers, namely Passimian and Medicham. Close Combat and Gunk Shot can sweep through even remotely weakened teams, especially with a Tera-Fighting Close Combat. Gunk Shot hits Fairy-types that resist Close Combat such as Dachsbun, Florges, and Tera Fairy Drifblim. Earthquake threatens Poison-types such as Muk and Qwilifish. Rock Slide hits Pokemon such as Drifblim and Vespiquen, which may otherwise be troublesome for Toxicroak to deal with. Despite its low-Base Power, Ice Punch is a relatively safe midground option that lacks the type immunities Toxicroak's other moves have while hitting common checks like Sandaconda, Drifblim, and Scyther for decent damage.

Toxicroak struggles with Pokemon that are not threatened by its STAB combination, such as Rotom, Drifblim, and other physical walls such as Sandaconda. Powerful special attackers like Eelektross, Zoroark, and Pyroar can alleviate this issue.

Swords Dance (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defensive Pivot.description:
Lumineon's combination of an excellent defensive typing, handy utility options with U-turn and Encore, good Speed tier for a pivot, and nifty ability to check special attackers such as Pyroar and Spiritomb allows it to become a decent pivot. Ice Beam is valuable coverage, hitting foes such as Gabite and Dartrix for super effective damage. U-turn allows Lumineon to tank a hit for teammates to get them in safely. This pairs well with Encore impairing Pokemon such as Whiscash or Masquerain attempting to set up entry hazards or boost their stats. Storm Drain allows Lumineon to blanket check some Water-type attackers such as Choice-locked Basculin and Golduck. Tera Grass is normally preferred, giving Lumineon a resistance to Grass- and Electric-type attacks that it would otherwise fear from Pokemon such as Gogoat and Raichu. Alternatively, Tera Dragon can give the same resistances as well as an added resistance to Fire-type attacks in exchange for a resistance to Ground-type attacks. Tera Ghost is an option to wall Quaxwell and check offensive Normal-types such as Zangoose and Pyroar better. Lumineon normally uses a specially defensive EV spread with a Calm nature to take on threats such as Pyroar, Houndoom, and Alolan Persian well, but a more physically defensive EV spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with a Bold nature allows Lumineon to take on physically offensive foes such as Dragon Dance Charizard, Basculin, and Perrserker better.

Lumineon's best partners are ones that appreciate having a pivot to tank hits for them and allow them in safely as well as ones that enjoy Lumineon's ability to tank Water-type attacks. Setup sweepers such as Nasty Plot Haunter, Gogoat, and Quiver Dance Masquerain enjoy Lumineon's ability to help them come in safely to set up and sweep. Fire-types like Charizard and Pyroar form a strong core with Lumineon, with Lumineon absorbing the Water-type attacks from Pokemon such as Basculin they fear, and in return they break Grass-type threats like Gogoat and Sawsbuck that Lumineon would struggle against. Other Pokemon with pivoting moves such as Alolan Persian, Perrserker, and Electrode can form a VoltTurn core with Lumineon, with Alolan Persian in particular completing a powerful defensive core with by tanking physical hits Lumineon can normally struggle with. Ground-types like Alolan Dugtrio and Gabite can be useful switch-ins to Electric-types like Raichu, allowing Lumineon to be a more powerful pivot.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

Snow Setter.description: 88 Speed EVs are to outrun maximum Speed invested Choice Specs Arboliva and defensive Pokemon such as Alomomola.

Special Attacker.description:
Abomasnow is an amazing bulky wallbreaker thanks to its nearly unresisted STAB moves, coverage, and Aurora Veil alongside Snow boosting its defenses. Giga Drain is used for longevity, but Leaf Storm in tandem with Eject Pack works well to pivot and bring in a setup sweeper that can take advantage of its Aurora Veil. Earth Power takes care of Steel-types that can easily switch into Abomasnow safely like Magneton and Tera Steel Appletun. Ice Shard can be used to finish off Pokemon like Scyther and Mesprit, but it can be a wasted moveslot at times because you give up coverage or Aurora Veil. Leech Seed can be used to trade hits more easily with Blissey, which walls Abomasnow otherwise. A Timid nature is key to outspeed Modest Magneton and neutral-nature Samurott. A Choice Specs set can be run, but being locked into one move can be somewhat detrimental due to its Stealth Rock weakness and loss of bulk. Tera Ground helps with boosting Earth Power damage output and gives Abomasnow an Electric immunity for Magneton and Rotom, which use it to gain momentum otherwise.

Great partners for Abomasnow are ones that can take care of its Fighting- and Flying-type weaknesses like Scyther, Qwilfish, and Rotom. Hattrem and Drifblim are also exceptional partners that, along with tanking Fighting-type attacks, deny entry hazards for non-Heavy-Duty Boots Abomasnow's longevity. Swords Dance Bruxish and Nasty Plot Mesprit are two good offensive partners that can take advantage of Abomasnow's Aurora Veil once Abomasnow takes care of their checks in Cacturne and Magneton. Tauros and Alolan Raichu also appreciate Abomasnow taking care of their checks like Lurantis and Sandaconda and, in turn, can help with breaking through Steel-types.

Swords Dance.description:
Thanks to its decent Attack stat in combination with Swords Dance and priority Ice Shard, Abomasnow can be a dangerous setup sweeper that takes advantage of the surprise factor that comes with the set, as it usually uses Swords Dance as a special wall like Blissey, Cryogonal, and Eelektross switches in. While Wood Hammer is more powerful, Seed Bomb can be used over it to still threaten Blissey without recoil. Ice Shard picks off weakened, faster threats like Scyther, Hisuian Sneasel, and Lilligant. Earthquake hits the Steel-types that resist Abomasnow’s STAB moves like Magneton and Tera Steel Appletun. Tera Fire allows Abomasnow to resist hits from Scyther, Pyroar, Magneton, and opposing Abomasnow, giving it a free turn to setup or attack while also granting an immunity to Will-O-Wisp from the likes of Drifblim and Rotom. Tera Ground can be used instead to boost the power of Earthquake, give Abomasnow a Stealth Rock resistance, and surprise Electric-types using Volt Switch.

Ice Shard allows Abomasnow to take out offensive checks like Hisuian Sneasel and Scyther after a Swords Dance boost with minimal chip. To get this chip, Rocky Helmet Pokemon like Qwilfish and Sandaconda work well with Abomasnow, enabling it to facilitate a sweep. Flying- and Fighting-types like Scyther and Toxicroak threaten Abomasnow out, so checks like Rotom, Sableye, and Sandaconda pair well alongside it. Choice Scarf Mesprit pairs well with Abomasnow, threatening Fighting-types out and giving Abomasnow a second chance to sweep with the aid of Healing Wish. Articuno acts as a hard wall for Abomasnow, as it gets a Defense boost in snow and access to Haze. Pokemon like Magneton and Rotom can take advantage of Articuno by threatening it with Volt Switch to obtain momentum and crippling it with Trick, respectively. Pyroar also deals with Articuno quite well with Taunt, blocking Articuno’s Roost, in combination with Will-O Wisp, which lets Pyroar chip away at it.

Aurora Veil (Grass).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Hail Setter (Ice).description:
Thanks to its ability to set snow and Aurora Veil, Abomasnow is a valuable choice for Ice-type teams. Its Grass typing provides a way to deal with Water-types such as Azumarill, Basculegion, and Quagsire. Giga Drain is its main STAB move, dealing damage while providing recovery for Abomasnow. Alternatively, it can use Grass Knot in replacement of Giga Drain, allowing it to 2HKO Dondozo. Earth Power allows Abomasnow to hit Steel- and Fire-types, 2HKOing Kingambit and Torkoal and OHKOing offensive Heatran on the switch. The given EV spread allows Abomasnow to outspeed defensive Rotom-W, bulky Gholdengo, and Adamant Azumarill. Abomasnow can run either Icy Rock for more snow turns, which is preferred in Cetitan teams, or Light Clay for more Aurora Veil turns.

Cetitan highly appreciates Abomasnow's snow, as it can utilize Slush Rush to outspeed threats such as Iron Moth, Walking Wake, and Iron Treads. With Earthquake, it serves as a good sweeper against Poison, Steel, and Fire teams, which Abomasnow struggles to go against. Other setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Chien-Pao, Frosmoth, Baxcalibur, and Cloyster enjoy the Defense boost in snow, increasing their survivability and letting them set up and sweep the opposing team. Cloyster is able to survive a Choice Band-boosted Sacred Sword from Chien-Pao under snow and hit it back with a +2 Rock Blast. Baxcalibur is able to survive an Iron Head from Kingambit and 2HKO it with Earthquake. Chien-Pao acts as a strong wallbreaker that appreciates being able to take hits under snow due to its frailty. Frosmoth deals with the Water-type matchup along with Abomasnow, being able to set up a Quiver Dance and sweep the opposing team. The snow also allows the aforementioned setup sweepers to survive revenge killing attempts from foes such as Sucker Punch Kingambit and Extreme Speed Dragonite. Froslass provides team support in Taunt and its own hazards in Spikes, as well as Destiny Bond, which can take out a foe and give Abomasnow a free switch-in. Avalugg's great Defense and access to Rapid Spin make it a great teammate under snow, checking the likes of Kingambit, Iron Treads, and Urshifu-R while also acting as hazard control for its team.

vgc2023.overview:
• Snow lets Abomasnow carve itself a niche in the current metagame.

  • Abomasnow is a decent offensive support Pokemon with Aurora Veil, which partners well with various Ice-types such as Baxcalibur, Cetitan, and Glaceon, as they gain a Defense boost in snow.

  • Abomasnow's offensive typing is well-suited in a metagame filled with Ground-, Dragon-, and Water-types such as Garchomp, Hydreigon, and Rotom-W.

  • Despite the Defense boost in snow, Abomasnow is still fairly specially frail with a poor set of weaknesses that leave it vulnerable to some of the most common special attackers in the format like Gholdengo and Armarouge.

Support.description:
• Giga Drain gives Abomasnow some longevity when behind Aurora Veil and lets it beat the likes of Rotom-W and Palafin, which resist Blizzard. Earth Power is an alternative that hits Fire- and Steel-types like Torkoal and Gholdengo, notably OHKOing the former when Terastallized.

  • Abomansow runs items that help it overcome its crucial weaknesses. Focus Sash allows it to take any one hit, such as Rotom-H's Overheat, letting it set up Aurora Veil. Babiri Berry serves a similar purpose, allowing it to survive Gholdengo's Make It Rain and Tera Steel Hydreigon's Flash Cannon.

  • The Speed investment allows Abomsnow to outspeed Garchomp while in Tailwind.

  • Water is the primary Tera type used by Abomasnow, turning its Fire and Steel weaknesses into resistances. Ground is an alternative Tera type that allows it to fire off STAB-boosted Earth Powers, catching its common checks by surprise.

Choice Band.description: Weavile's potent STAB combination and great offensive stats give it an excellent place in the National Dex metagame, with its ability to threaten teams offensively and Pursuit trap Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Galarian Slowking, easing matchups for teammates such as Sneasler and Tapu Lele. Triple Axel threatens OHKOs on offensive Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y, Kartana, and Sneasler and 2HKOs on physically defensive Ferrothorn after minimal chip damage. Knock Off is a powerful STAB option that heavily damages switch-ins predicting Triple Axel such as Rotom-W, Heatran, and Alomomola. Ice Shard gives Weavile some form of speed control and helps finish off weakened foes that normally threaten it such as Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko, as well as boosted Pokemon such as Tera Flying Unburden Sneasler and Tera Grass Volcarona. Furthermore, Weavile's longevity, and therefore its offensive pressure, is limited by its weakness to Stealth Rock, so Defoggers such as Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Tornadus-T are all very helpful. Mega Scizor's U-turn and Alomomola's Flip Turn are also appreciated to bring Weavile in safely, due to its frailty. In return, Weavile helps these Pokemon out by getting rid of thorns such as Great Tusk, Gliscor, and Mega Charizard Y, letting Scizor have a larger role offensively, as well as removing Pokemon like Gholdengo and Zapdos for Alomomola, which can use Alomomola as setup fodder and threaten an OHKO with Thunderbolt or Volt Switch to gain momentum, respectively. Mega Medicham and Iron Valiant are both excellent partners for Weavile, taking care of Toxapex, as well as bulky Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn, with Weavile Pursuit trapping Gholdengo for both of them or forcing it to Terastallize. Although Tera Dark is the preferred Tera type in order to mitigate Weavile's weakness to Stealth Rock and boost Knock Off to absurd levels, Tera Ice can also be used, making Ice Shard an extremely threatening priority move, able to even 2HKO Pokemon that pressure Weavile such as Tapu Koko and Iron Valiant.

Swords Dance.description: Weavile is a niche Swords Dance user, being able to use its high Speed in conjunction with powerful STAB moves in Triple Axel and Throat Chop or Knock Off to break or clean amply weakened teams. Darkinium Z with Throat Chop gives Weavile a powerful option to break through the likes of Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Alomomola, especially when boosted; meanwhile, Heavy-Duty Boots provides it with better longevity and lets it use Knock Off instead, giving Weavile a more powerful utility presence for its team by removing Heavy-Duty Boots or Leftovers from the aforementioned foes. Tera Dark is used with Heavy-Duty Boots to make up for the power lost from the lack of a Z-Move, while notably shedding Weavile's weakness to Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch and Ferrothorn's Gyro Ball. Weavile can help teammates break through bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Alomomola, naturally making Mega Lopunny and Urshifu-R quality teammates, as they can clean up with ease after this. Weavile, however, struggles to find opportunities to use Swords Dance versus more offensive teams, so Mega Lopunny also helps by easing the matchup versus frailer offensive teams. Weavile can be answered by defensive Terastallization from Ground-types such as Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Great Tusk, so Tapu Koko, which can freely fire off strong Electric-type attacks once these foes Terastallize, work well in conjunction with Weavile. Additionally, Tapu Koko denies Dondozo, another check to Weavile, the ability to use Rest as it summons Electric Terrain.

Swords Dance (Ice).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Ice).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Magnezone combines its ability to trap and remove certain Steel-types with potent special wallbreaking prowess that lets it rip through common defensive staples such as Tapu Fini, Clefable, and Mega Tyranitar. It is an effective pivot with Volt Switch, though it must be wary of Ground-types like Hippowdown and Excadrill switching in. Hidden Power Grass primarily targets Gastrodon and Quagsire, and it also hits other, rarer Pokemon that share their type combination like Swampert. Hidden Power Fire is an alternative to hit Excadrill on the switch and also OHKO Scizor after trapping it. Magnezone best fits on offense teams looking for a means to remove Steel-types, primarily Skarmory and Celesteela. Removing the former enables numerous physical attackers, such as Mega Tyranitar and Scizor while removing the latter enables teammates such as Latios and Enamorus. Pivots such as Slowking can form effective pivoting cores with Magnezone, helping it safely switch into foes like Slowbro and Clefable; physically attacking pivots like Scizor can notably lure Skarmory in. Due to Skarmory possessing Sturdy and Body Press, Stealth Rock support from teammates such as Mega Tyranitar and Clefable greatly aids Magnezone. Magnezone struggles to take on Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Ting-Lu, and depending on its choice of coverage, it's walled by Ground / Water types like Gastrodon or Ground / Steel types like Excadrill, making Grass- and Water-types such as Mega Venusaur and Keldeo useful partners. Magnezone struggles to break through special walls like Chansey and Blissey, making the aforementioned physical wallbreakers useful; Pursuit trappers such as Mega Tyranitar and Bisharp are especially effective at removing these foes, and they appreciate Magnezone's pivoting capabilities.

Substitute + 3 Attacks.description: Substitute lets Magnezone take advantage of switches from foes it forces out such as Tapu Fini and Clefable and exploit status moves like Amoonguss's and Celesteela's Leech Seed. Hidden Power Grass targets Gastrodon, Quagsire, and some rare foes like Swampert. Electrium Z powering up Thunderbolt helps Magnezone break through certain foes it traps such as Scizor and specially defensive Celesteela; Steelium Z primarily helps against Ground- and Grass-types such as Hippowdon and Mega Venusaur. Magenzone best fits on offense teams looking to remove certain Steel-types, namely Skarmory and Celesteela. This enables numerous teammates such as Mega Tyranitar and Scizor. Since it fears taking Skarmory's Body Press and Celesteela's Flamethrower upon switching in, a pivot that can lure them in like Galarian Zapdos or Scizor is a great partner. A Stealth Rock setter like Clefable can let Magnezone avoid Sturdy to OHKO Skarmory. Magnezone is completely helpless against Excadrill, so Grass- and Water-types such as Tangrowth and Slowbro can help by dealing with them. After removing opposing Steel-types, Magnezone isn't particularly useful, though it's still a reasonably strong special wallbreaker, especially if it still can use its Z-Move. It struggles with special walls like Blissey and Chansey, so physical wallbreakers, notably Pursuit trappers like Mega Tyranitar, can help by removing them.

Choice Scarf.description: Magnezone carves itself a niche thanks to Magnet Pull, which allows it to trap and remove Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Kartana, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory, potentially forcing the latter three to Terastallize so teammates such as Kartana and Tapu Lele can beat them. Volt Switch lets Magnezone maintain momentum while eliminating foes such as Skarmory and chipping Heatran, which cannot be trapped and removed consistently.
