Poison Fang hits Grass-types like Cacturne and Appletun while also badly poisoning common walls like Vaporeon and Umbreon. Crunch targets Psychic-types like Hattrem and Oricorio-P while also securing the OHKO on Farigiraf. Tera Dark further boosts Strong Jaw-boosted Crunch and helps Bruxish get past the aforementioned Cacturne and Vaporeon. Tera Fairy coupled with Tera Blast helps its matchup versus Cacturne while also resisting Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Toxicroak and Honckrow. Teammates should be pivots that bring Bruxish safely on the field like Eelektross, Passimian, and Rotom. Pokemon like Oricorio and Clawitzer appreciate Bruxish targeting their checks like Chansey and Eelektross.

Swords Dance.description: Strong Jaw-boosted Psychic Fangs and Crunch turn Bruxish into a dominant offensive force in NU. It also has Aqua Jet, which lets it revenge kill weakened faster threats like Zoroark and Choice Scarf Passimian and sweep after boosting with Swords Dance. Bruxish's Speed tier is also great, allowing it to outspeed Rotom, Mabosstiff, and Bombirdier. Tera Blast can be used in the fourth moveslot in conjunction with Tera Fairy to give Bruxish a better defensive typing while also being able to beat common walls to it like Cacturne and Tera Dark Toxicroak and Vaporeon. Tera Dark combined with Strong Jaw, however, gives Crunch a deadly bite with it becoming a third STAB move to nail opposing Bruxish and Veluza. Alternatively, Tera Water makes Aqua Jet even more dangerous for the aforementioned faster threats. If Bruxish is not running Tera Fairy + Tera Blast, having a partner like Toxicroak or Rotom to deal with Tera Dark Toxicroak and Vaporeon is appreciated.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Bruxish outspeeds other common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Rotom-C, making it a very effective late-game cleaner. While it forgoes boosting elements like Choice Band and Swords Dance, Bruxish still boasts a good offensive presence with its powerful STAB moves. Choice Scarf Bruxish can surprise and OHKO common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Rotom-C that expect to be faster, so teammates that appreciate their removal like Jolteon and Sneasel.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Drain Punch is a good option to hit special walls like Ting-Lu and Heatran harder and increases longevity; however, without Vacuum Wave, Dragon heavily struggles against Ice and Dark, specifically against Chien-Pao and Play Rough Meowscarada. Boomburst, also activating Throat Spray, allows Kommo-o to hit Pokemon resistant to Dragon and Fighting like Iron Valiant and Galarian Weezing. An EV spread of 24 HP / 68 Def / 212 SpA / 204 Spe outpaces Dragapult after a Clangorous Soul boost, prevents Kommo-o from being OHKOed by Chien-Pao after a Swords Dance and Choice Scarf Dragapult's Dragon Darts, and in return OHKOes Chien-Pao and Dragapult with Vacuum Wave and Clanging Scales, respectively. Taunt may be used to prevent Haze or Whirlwind from Toxapex and Ting-Lu, respectively, although it means Kommo-o misses out on vital coverage. Flash Cannon can be used to aid in the Fairy and Ice matchups, hitting Iron Valiant, Mamoswine, Hatterene, and Alolan Ninetales.

Clangorous Soul (Dragon).description:
Kommo-o cements itself as an excellent setup sweeper on Dragon teams due to it's respectable offensive stats, great bulk, access to Clangorous Soul, and setup ability, using Pokemon like Hisuian Samurott, Kingambit, and Alolan Sandslash as setup fodder, heavily aiding in the Dark and Ice matchups. Clanging Scales is Kommo-o's best move for Pokemon like Toxapex, Gastrodon, and Gliscor. Furthermore, Clanging Scales and Clangorous Soul both trigger Throat Spray, enhancing Kommo-o's wallbreaking capabilities. Vacuum Wave notably picks off Chien-Pao without a Clangorous Soul boost, Meowscarada at +2 Special Attack, and hits other faster threats like Greninja and Baxcalibur. Flamethrower threatens Steel- and Ice-type Pokemon such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Avalugg. Soundproof prevents Kommo-o from being hit by Clanging Scales from opposing Kommo-o as well as being phazed out by Piloswine and Empoleon's Roar.

Baxcalibur threatens walls like Clodsire, Skeledirge, and Ting-Lu; in return, it appreciates Kommo-o weakening Steel-type Pokemon such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit. Hisuian Goodra is an excellent check for Fairy-types, as Kommo-o is effectively helpless against the type, fighting off Flutter Mane, Hatterene, and Clefable as well as helping against Ice-types like Articuno and Alolan Ninetales. Dragapult threatens the aforementioned Flutter Mane with a Choice Specs, Choice Band, or Dragon Dance set and hinders and potentially removes offensive Pokemon such as Iron Valiant and Chien-Pao via Thunder Wave and Will-O-Wisp with a utility Hex set, helping Kommo-o set up easier in the Fighting and Dark matchups. Dragapult appreciates the removal of Steel-types and threats like Meowscarada, Urshifu, and Chien-Pao. Cyclizar's entry hazard removal is greatly valued, and it offers Kommo-o easy setup with Shed Tail. Garchomp enhances Kommo-o's wallbreaking with entry hazard stacking and also helps in the Poison and Steel matchups, weakening walls like Empoleon, Alolan Muk, and Toxapex for Kommo-o late-game. Choice Scarf Roaring Moon outpaces and removes Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Jirachi, Gholdengo, and Flutter Mane and revenge kills Fairy-types like Iron Valiant with Iron Head. Walking Wake is capable of outpacing and OHKOing Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur with its Choice Scarf set and heavily pressuring Steel and Poison team walls like Corviknight, Heatran, and Clodsire with a Choice Specs set, allowing Kommo-o to efficiently clean up late-game. Dragalge offers Toxic Spikes support and provides a check to Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant, Flutter Mane, and Enamorus. Dragonite threatens specially defensive foes like Empoleon, Clodsire, and Alolan Muk and in return appreciates Kommo-o's removal of Corviknight, Air Balloon Gholdengo, and Chien-Pao.

Choice Specs (Dragon).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Clangorous Soul (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Clangorous Booster.description: Kommo-o is a fearsome wallbreaker with its capability to omniboost as soon as it gets an opportunity with Clangorous Soul. Its ability to set up on common Pokemon like Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Volcarona and to potentially use Tera Steel to ignore Toxic from defensive Pokemon like Heatran and Toxapex allows it to start wallbreaking very early with its powerful coverage. Throat Spray grants an extra Special Attack boost when using Clangorous Soul, whereas Kommonium Z gives it Clangorous Soulblaze, which allows it to deal heavy damage while boosting its stats. Boomburst lets Kommo-o neutrally hit much of the metagame for large damage, which, when coupled with STAB Clanging Scales and Flamethrower as coverage for Steel-types, can easily break cores featuring the likes of Great Tusk, Skarmory, Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Gliscor, Landorus-T, and more. Bulletproof along with Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to wall Choice Scarf Tapu Lele looking to revenge kill it as well as set up in front of Gholdengo and Choice Specs Dragapult. Tera Normal gives Kommo-o a stronger Boomburst, while Tera Steel gives it a Toxic immunity and useful resistances to all of its weaknesses, allowing Kommo-o to take would-be checks, such as Dragapult, Tapu Lele, Baxcalibur, and Iron Valiant, by surprise and set up in front of them. However, Kommo-o likes to use its Tera and thus denies its teammates this option, and it can be checked by a well-timed Tera from Pokemon such as Tera Steel Garchomp and subsequently be revenge killed. It is also walled by the likes of Heatran, Garganacl, and Clodsire, which can tank its coverage options even without Terastallizing and cripple it with Toxic or Salt Cure or simply force it out and deny future setup opportunities. Finally, due to the nature of Kommo-o’s setup, it can only reasonably do so once per game, making Kommo-o more suited for offensive teams. Thus, having allies that can take care of Kommo-o’s defensive checks before it sets up can allow it to do its job much more effectively; physical attackers like Iron Valiant, offensive Landorus-T, and Samurott-H can pressure and remove checks for Kommo-o to break and potentially sweep. Hazard support is also valuable in preventing opponents from switching back and forth between Pokemon in a Regenerator core; in particular, Assault Vest Tornadus + Toxapex; Pokemon like Great Tusk and Garchomp can set up Stealth Rock to pressure switches.

Belly Drum.description: With Belly Drum, Kommo-o becomes a fearsome sweeper capable of wiping unprepared teams with relative ease. The HP cuts from Substitute and Belly Drum will immediately activate Salac Berry, giving Kommo-o maximum Attack along with increased Speed to sweep offensive and defensive teams alike. Substitute also allows Kommo-o to dodge status moves like Ferrothorn’s Leech Seed, Garganacl's Salt Cure, Landorus-T's Toxic, and Rotom-W's Will-O-Wisp that could potentially ruin Kommo-o’s sweep, instead giving it a free set up opportunity. Drain Punch is chosen over heavier hitting moves like Close Combat, as the extra damage is not needed, and Drain Punch can heal off the HP lost through Belly Drum and Substitute, making Kommo-o harder to revenge kill. Thunder Punch is used to dent and possibly KO common defensive tanks that can survive Drain Punch, like Skarmory, Toxapex, Tera Water Garganacl, Gholdengo, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Bulletproof stacked on top of Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to surprise opponents like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Specs Dragapult looking to revenge kill it. Although Soundproof blocks moves such as Roar from defensive Garchomp and Bug Buzz from Volcarona, it is generally not preferred due to the lack of relevant sound-based moves in comparison to the bevy of aforementioned qualities gained from Bulletproof. Tera Electric can power up Thunder Punch with STAB to score KOs on the likes of Gholdengo, Tapu Lele, and Tera Fairy Kingambit, while Tera Steel gives it useful resistances that may allow it to reach Salac Berry range without Substitute by tanking a resisted hit from the likes of Tapu Lele or Mega Diancie. Belly Drum Kommo-o fits on hyper offensive teams that appreciate its ability to sweep or clean up teams once its checks are removed. Therefore, it appreciates partners that can lure and remove Pokemon like Clodsire, Tera Grass Heatran, Gliscor, and Landorus-T that check it; Tapu Koko in particular is good, as it can run Hidden Power Ice to bait and KO the latter two and badly chip the former two potentially into Kommo-o’s range while also boosting the power of its Thunder Punch by setting Electric Terrain. Belly Drum Kommo-o also has trouble setting up, as it mainly uses the element of surprise to get up a Substitute —namely, it exploits the opponent's fear of Clangorous Soulblaze and thus forces them to switch. Thus, it appreciates dual screens support from the likes of Grimmsnarl in order to more consistently set up Belly Drum.

Defensive.description: Kommo-o uses its unique typing and excellent bulk to serve as an fantastic physical wall, taking on the likes of Barraskewda, Meowscarada, and Roaring Moon while also taking advantage of the turns it generates by forcing these wallbreakers out to set up Stealth Rock. Body Press chips hazard removal options like Corviknight and Quaquaval, while Dragon Tail forces foes out, quickly racking up entry hazard chip on the opposing team. Iron Defense bolsters Kommo-o's walling capabilities and Body Press's damage output, turning it into a potential late-game wincon. Intimidate Corviknight is a good partner for Kommo-o, taking on the Ice-, Flying-, and Dragon-types that threaten it like Chien-Pao, Galarian Zapdos, and Dragonite, while Kommo-o takes on the Electric- and Fire-types like Hisuian Electrode, Ogerpon-H, and Ceruledge that Corviknight struggles with. Empoleon particularly makes for another good partner with its ability to check Fairy- and Psychic-types like Enamorus-T and Azelf. Offensive pivots like Azelf and Barraskewda appreciate Kommo-o wearing down their checks like Corviknight and Roaring Moon, allowing them to form powerful a VoltTurn core that takes advantage of Kommo-o's Stealth Rock to quickly wear down those checks.

Galvanize.description: Galvanize Kommo-o stands out as one of the tier's few mixed attackers while being flexible in its role as a Stealth Rock setter or setup sweeper depending on what its team requires. Boomburst denies Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Quaquaval from removing hazards by unexpectedly OHKOing them, while Clanging Scales 2HKOes Great Tusk. Close Combat allows Kommo-o to threaten special walls like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey looking to switch into it and tank its special moves freely. With Kommo-o's ability to maintain Stealth Rock, it becomes an extremely effective offensive Stealth Rock setter when running it as its 4th move; alternatively, Clangorous Soul improves its bulk, damage output, and Speed, making it harder to revenge kill and allowing it to clean teams late-game. A Life Orb is preferred on Stealth Rock variants for consistency, while Throat Spray is better for Clangorous Soul variants to reduce the chip taken by Kommo-o while still increasing its damage output. Wallbreakers like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao appreciate Kommo's ability to remove checks like Corviknight and Quaquaval, allowing them to clean up after. Faster offensive pivots like Azelf and Barraskewda appreciate Kommo-o's Stealth Rock when forming a VoltTurn core, which wears down the opposing team quickly, or Kommo-o's ability to clean up with Clangorous Soul after they have heavily chipped the opposing team. Kommo-o requires good defensive pivots like Corviknight and RegenVest Manaphy as teammates, with their ability to switch into revenge killers that threaten Kommo-o like Chien-Pao, Dragonite, and Enamorus-T and pivot out.

Setup Sweeper (Fighting).description: An incredible asset for Fighting teams, Kommo-o is often the best wincon on the type thanks to Clangorous Soulblaze, which helps it overcome otherwise difficult matchups such as Dragon, Flying, and Water. Flamethrower takes care of Steel-type Pokemon neutral to Drain Punch like Mega Scizor and Corviknight. Taunt allows Kommo-o to block status moves from defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Swampert, and Gliscor, preventing them from resetting its boosts with Haze or statusing it with Toxic. Alternatively, Clangorous Soul powers up Kommo-o without using its Z-Move, letting its Clangorous Soulblaze outright OHKO Toxapex and Hippowdon, at the cost of longevity. Bulletproof is Kommo-o's preferred ability to better handle Gholdengo or Aegislash in the Steel matchup. Unboosted Kommo-o's average Speed tier leaves it outsped by threats to Fighting teams like Tornadus-T and Tapu Lele, so Choice Scarf users like Galarian Zapdos and Terrakion are great partners to assist it against them. Iron Valiant's Fairy typing and wide coverage movepool lets it deal with opposing Dragon-types, and it forms a wallbreaking core with Kommo-o by pressuring the likes of Mega Sableye and Ting-Lu. Cobalion and Great Tusk provide Stealth Rock, which maximizes Kommo-o's opportunities to wallbreak after using Clangorous Soulblaze. Great Tusk can also remove entry hazards for Kommo-o with Rapid Spin, and Cobalion has the added bonus of checking Fairy-types like Mega Diancie. Mega Gallade can pressure Poison-, Ground-, and Flying-types like Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T for Kommo-o. It can also outspeed and revenge kill offensive threats to it like Kyurem and Garchomp.

Mixed Omni-Boost Sweeper (Dragon).description: Kommo-o is an exceptional setup sweeper due to its great mixed offensive stats, respectable defenses, and exclusive access to Clangorous Soulblaze; this makes it an amazing tool to clean up Steel, Dark, and Dragon teams late-game. Drain Punch threatens Steel- and Normal-types like Heatran, Blissey, and Porygon-2 as well as increasing Kommo-o's longevity, making it harder for revenge killers to shut it down after using its Z-Move. Additionally, Drain Punch is Kommo-o's best move to hit Ditto, as it copies its ability Soundproof. Flamethrower targets Fighting-resistant or -immune Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Celesteela, and Aegislash. Taunt is preferred to shut down phazers like Haze Toxapex and Hippowdon and bulky walls like Porygon2 and Clodsire, which can inconvenience Kommo-o with Toxic. Meanwhile, Clangorous Soul allows for more boosts and breaking power, notably enabling Clangorous Soulblaze to OHKO the aforementioned Hippowdon and Toxapex. Furthermore, Clangorous Soulblaze allows Kommo-o to set up on Fairy-types and Soundproof Pokemon like Alolan Ninetales, Trace Porygon2, and opposing Kommo-o. Soundproof prevents revenge killing attempts from Ditto or opposing Kommo-o, and a Naive nature permits Kommo-o to outpace Mega Aerodactyl, Mega Lopunny, and Zeraora after obtaining the omni-boost. Mega Altaria is a wonderful teammate, as it helps weaken and clean up opposing Dragon teams; In return, it appreciates Kommo-o dealing with the aforementioned Steel-types. Kyurem aids in matchups against Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Mantine, and Dragonite, as well as Fairy-types such as Azumarill, Tapu Fini, and Mega Altaria. Choice Scarf Latias and Roaring Moon provide speed control; the former offers healing and setup opportunities with Healing Wish, while the latter checks Psychic-types like Deoxys-S, Victini, and Latias. Garchomp offers entry hazards support to pressure and chip down Kommo-o's switch-ins and aids in the Steel matchup with Earthquake. Hisuian Goodra is a huge help in the Fairy matchup, taking on Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Mega Diancie. Mega Latios threatens Flying-type threats with its BoltBeam coverage; in addition, when paired with Garchomp, it puts a lot of pressure on Poison teams, which Kommo-o tends to struggle against. Cyclizar provides entry hazard control with Rapid Spin and extra protection for Kommo-o with Shed Tail, encouraging the use of Clangorous Soul over Taunt. Baxcalibur is excellent in the Dark and Flying matchups, dispatching threats like Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Enamorus with its Swords Dance or Dragon Dance set, and it also ravages Poison teams with Galarian Slowking, which Kommo-o might not be able to handle. In return, Kommo-o removes the aforementioned Steel- and Normal-types that can easily wall Baxcalibur or use it to reverse sweep, specifically Ditto.

Choice Specs (Electric).description: Tapu Koko is a dominant force within Electric teams due to its exceptional ability, Electric Surge, which its teammates benefit from. Tapu Koko further boasts a good Speed tier and valuable Fairy-typing, rendering it a menacing threat in its own right. Dazzling Gleam levels the playing field in the Dragon matchup, eliminating foes such as Kommo-o, Roaring Moon, Baxcalibur, and Mega Altaria, but it's also useful against threats like Mega Lopunny and non-Choice Scarf Great Tusk. Grass Knot provides much needed coverage against troublesome Ground-types, most notably taking care of Swampert, Quagsire, Gastrodon, and Mamoswine. Volt Switch pairs wells with Tapu Koko's speed, allowing it to escape unfavorable matchups and bring in teammates like Zapdos against the likes of Mega Venusaur or Mega Scizor. Hidden Power Ice can be used to deal with Ground-types that aren't threatened by Grass Knot such as Garchomp and Landorus-T. Alternatively, Thunderbolt can be run to increase Tapu Koko's damage output, giving it a chance to OHKO foes like Mega Diancie. Rotom-W and Zapdos are excellent partners to Tapu Koko, as they provide a necessary Ground immunity as well as Defog support, which allows Tapu Koko to pivot more freely. Rotom-W further helps by handling Ground-types and spreading burns to strong physical attackers like Mega Garchomp, Iron Valiant, Dragonite, and Mega Swampert in rain, while Zapdos walls and makes use of Heat Wave to deal with Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Iron Treads and Hurricane to counter pesky Grass- and Fighting-types like Tapu Bulu, Mega Venusaur, and Mega Gallade. Alolan Raichu's Surge Surfer fully capitalizes on Electric Terrain, turning it into a serious revenge killer, capable of outspeeding threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill, Mega Aerodactyl, and Iron Valiant under Quark Drive. Iron Hands and Zeraora are prominent partners for Tapu Koko complementing it as Physical breakers, both being able to take care of foes such as defensive Zapdos, Ursaluna and Alolan Muk which hinder Tapu Koko and other Special attackers. Iron Hands has more bulk and longevity, but Zeraora brings near unmatched Speed to the table. Both of them also appreciate Tapu Koko's ability to remove Mega Sableye and Skeledirge and luring in and critically damaging Landorus-Therian with Hidden Power Ice. Regieleki brings raw Electric-type power in the form of a boosted Rising Voltage, which is capable of sweeping teams that don't have an answer to it, and it also provides hazard removal thanks to Rapid Spin. Magnezone provides an immunity to Poison, which Tapu Koko appreciates, and more importantly traps and removes threats such as Mega Scizor and Excadrill with Hidden Power Fire.

Pivot (Fairy).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Pivot.description: Tapu Koko's high Speed, typing, and Electric Surge make it an excellent pivot, threatening foes such as Tornadus-T, Pelipper, Slowbro, and Toxapex. U-turn allows Tapu Koko to generate momentum, pivoting on switch-ins such as Ferrothorn, Assault Vest Tangrowth, and Clodsire to safely bring in teammates like Zamazenta and Urshifu-R. Grass Knot hits foes such as Gastrodon, Mega Tyranitar, and Mega Swampert, and it takes advantage of Tera Grass to potentially break Ting-Lu. Alternatively, Dazzling Gleam allows Tapu Koko to OHKO Mega Medicham and Weavile after Stealth Rock, and it dents other foes such as Tera Dragon Toxapex and Garchomp. Hidden Power Ice improves the matchup against Landorus-T and Gliscor while still hitting foes such as Garchomp, Tangrowth, and Dragonite. Tera Grass boosts the power of Grass Knot while granting Tapu Koko key resistances, allowing it to lure foes such as Barraskewda, Floatzel, and Mega Swampert, all while improving its matchup against Rotom-W. Tapu Koko must be careful when using Tera, however, as it becomes unable to safely switch into Tornadus-T once it Terastallizes. Pokemon that utilize Electric Terrain such as Iron Valiant, Iron Hands, and Mega Medicham make for excellent teammates, as it activates Quark Drive for the former two and increases the power of Thunder Punch for the latter, 2HKOing foes such as Gholdengo. Tapu Koko also forms strong pivoting cores with teammates like Tornadus-T and Mega Lopunny, which take advantage of its checks such as Ferrothorn and Clodsire to generate momentum. Wallbreakers such as Weavile, Urshifu-R, and Zamazenta also appreciate Tapu Koko letting them switch in against its checks for free, such as Assault Vest Tangrowth. In return, they beat foes such as the aforementioned Tangrowth, Clodsire and Ferrothorn.

Dual Screens.description: Tapu Koko's high Speed and ability make it the premier dual screen setter on hyper offense teams. Taunt denies Defog from foes such as Tornadus-T and Rotom-W while also denying entry hazards from foes such as Ferrothorn. It also prevents foes such as Dragonite and Volcarona from using Tapu Koko as setup fodder. U-turn allows Tapu Koko to generate momentum and pivot into teammates such as Volcarona and Dragapult after setting screens. Tapu Koko will very rarely use Tera since teammates such as Dragonite or Volcarona rely on it to be effective. In a pinch, however, Tera Flying offers a Ground immunity for foes such as Clodsire. Pokemon that take advantage of dual screens, such as Volcarona, Dragonite, and Dragapult, are good partners, as they allow them to set up safely and survive potential revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Kingambit, and Mega Scizor. Iron Valiant also benefits greatly from Tapu Koko setting Electric Terrain in addition to dual screens. Tapu Koko is also weak to Stealth Rock setters such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Garchomp, and it can have difficulty denying entry hazards from them, so it appreciates teammates such as Dragonite and Gyarados pivoting in to Ground-type attacks from them.

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is one of Psychic teams' greatest revenge killers. Its decent Speed tier and astounding offensive prowess combined with its great typing makes it extremely threatening because with access to STAB Moonblast, it is Psychic's best check to most Dark-type threats. Tapu Lele's presence also sets up Psychic Terrain, shielding itself and its team from dangerous priority such as Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak and Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch. Focus Blast lets it easily take care of the pesky Steel-types that resist its STAB attacks such as Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Iron Treads. Future Sight lets Tapu Lele set up an attack for later and then switch out to a teammate such as Victini or Mega Gallade to help it set up or get a KO. Shadow Ball lets it beat Gholdengo and clean up against Psychic and Ghost teams, while Thunderbolt gives it general coverage versus foes like Mantine and Celesteela. Tapu Lele is often not able to beat specially defensive walls such as Alolan Muk and Blissey; hence, it appreciates partnering up with Mega Gallade to eliminate them. Mega Alakazam is a good partner, as it helps in the Electric and Water matchups courtesy of Trace copying Surge Surfer and Swift Swim, respectively, and it appreciates Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain boosting its Expanding Force. Slowbro sponges hits from faster Choice Scarf users such as Terrakion and Galarian Zapdos, and can also pivot Tapu Lele in with Teleport to wreak havoc. Victini and Armarouge can eliminate Steel-types, especially Aegislash and Gholdengo, easing the burden for Tapu Lele. Jirachi can slow teams down with Thunder Wave and pivot Tapu Lele into physical walls such as Mandibuzz and Slowbro with U-turn.

Calm Mind (Fairy).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is the premier speed control option in the tier, outrunning and OHKOing common offensive threats such as Speed Booster Energy Great Tusk, Swords Dance Urshifu-R, and non-Booster Energy Iron Valiant. Additionally, Psychic Terrain blocks priority moves like Mega Lopunny's Fake Out and Weavile's Ice Shard, which is useful for Tapu Lele itself and teammates that aim for a sweep such as Hawlucha and Volcarona. Focus Blast lets Tapu Lele hit common Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn. Psyshock allows Tapu Lele to hit foes with weaker Defense stats like Assault Vest Tornadus-T and Volcarona, along with shutting down Calm Mind Tera Poison Cresselia. Future Sight can be used to hit in tandem with teammates such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta, threatening Toxapex and Zapdos looking to switch into their attacks. Alternatively, Hidden Power Fire nails Mega Scizor along with hitting Ferrothorn more consistently than Focus Blast. Tera Psychic is the premier Tera option, as it boosts Tapu Lele's Psychic STAB attacks to ludicrous heights, smashing through most neutral targets such as Landorus-T, Rotom-W, and Tapu Koko. Tera Fairy is a niche alternative, boosting Moonblast to powerful levels while minimizing the threat of Pursuit from Mega Tyranitar and Weavile. Despite having Focus Blast, Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn are still effective checks to Tapu Lele, so teammates such as Gliscor and Mega Lopunny can be used to mitigate this. Hawlucha can both utilize Psychic Terrain to activate Unburden while helping break through Mega Scizor, allowing Tapu Lele to clean up with ease late-game.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Tapu Lele is one of the strongest in the tier, having no commonly used consistent defensive checks. Hidden Power Fire can OHKO most Mega Scizor and deal heavy damage to Ferrothorn without the chance of missing, unlike Focus Blast. Focus Blast hits Heatran and Ferrothorn and OHKOes Mega Tyranitar. Psyshock can hit Galarian Slowking, 2HKO Chansey, and OHKO Assault Vest Tornadus-T. Future Sight can help teammates like Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny wallbreak, as it deals good damage to switch-ins like Alomomola, Toxapex, and Landorus-T. Late-game cleaners like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, Urshifu-R, and Bulk Up Great Tusk really appreciate Tapu Lele's ability to force damage onto would-be checks such as Corviknight and Heatran. However, Tapu Lele is very prediction reliant and can often invite in Steel-types such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, Iron Crown, and Mega Scizor. Additionally, it struggles against common revenge killers such as Urshifu-R, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Lopunny. Therefore, a strong defensive core is recommended when building around Tapu Lele to minimize the impact of these offensive threats, especially having a switch-in to the aforementioned Steel-types that may come in on a Psychic or Moonblast. Good switch-ins to these include Heatran and Alomomola, with the latter serving as a pivot with Flip Turn to safely get Tapu Lele on the field against passive foes like Toxapex and Gliscor.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Tapu Lele becomes a fearsome breaker after a single boost, threatening common defensive Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Mega Tyranitar. Focus Blast is useful coverage, hitting many defensive staples like Ferrothorn, Garganacl, and Heatran for super effective damage. Fightinium Z in tandem with Focus Blast allows Tapu Lele to reliably OHKO Ferrothorn and Heatran, and heavily damage Mega Scizor and Ting-Lu. Although Tapu Lele is a fearsome wallbreaker, it requires a Calm Mind boost to heavily damage the majority of the metagame, so Pokemon that can provide it a setup opportunity via pivoting such as Urshifu-R, Gliscor, and Alomomola are beneficial. Tapu Lele is also very prone to getting revenge killed by physical attackers that can bypass Tapu Lele's Special Defense boosts, such as Zamazenta, Kartana, and Weavile, so teammates such as Zapdos, Moltres, and Toxapex are appreciated.

Swords Dance (Fairy).description: Tapu Bulu is a fearsome wallbreaker, boasting synergistic coverage moves that help Fairy teams in a variety of matchups like Water, Poison, and Ground. Close Combat targets Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn. Should Fightinium Z be used, All-Out Pummeling heavily damages the likes of Celesteela and Corviknight after a Swords Dance boost. High Horsepower heavily damages Aegislash and Gholdengo and lets Tapu Bulu be a massive asset against Steel and Water teams by hitting Toxapex for heavy damage. Substitute allows Tapu Bulu to set up on passive Pokemon such as Toxapex, Swampert, and Mega Sableye, while Zen Headbutt is its best move against Mega Venusaur and Crobat. Klefki is a great teammate, as it sets up Spikes to ease Tapu Bulu's wallbreaking as well as Reflect and Light Screen to provide more setup opportunities. Mega Diancie threatens Flying- and Fire-types like Zapdos, Dragonite, and Volcarona for Tapu Bulu. In return, Tapu Bulu checks Gastrodon, Heatran, and Clodsire, letting Mega Diancie have more leeway on its moveset. Similarly, Tapu Koko is heavily appreciated, as it also deals with Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y and relieves Tapu Bulu of having to use Fightinium Z, or waste its Z-Move, to threaten Corviknight and Celesteela.

Defensive.description: Investment outruns Magnezone while maximizing bulk. 252 HP / 112 SpD / 144 Spe is an alternative specially defensive spread.

Swords Dance.description: Tapu Bulu sets itself apart from other Grass-types thanks to its high offensive capabilities, Terrain-boosted Horn Leech, good coverage in Close Combat and Stone Edge, and good defensive typing, checking Pokemon like Zamazenta, Urshifu-R and Rotom-W. It also provides Grassy Terrain for its team, giving passive recovery to teammates like Heatran and Toxapex, making them even harder to deal with. Close Combat hits Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Kingambit and Stone Edge threaten Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Dragonite while letting Tapu Bulu beat Volcarona. Rockium Z gives Tapu Bulu a strong nuke, allowing it to break through Zapdos more reliably while also OHKOing would-be checks like Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y on the switch-in. Fightinium Z, on the other hand, helps it break through Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor and KOes Heatran after luring it in. Leftovers gives Tapu Bulu more passive recovery, allowing it to set up multiple times against more balanced teams. The given EV spread ensures Tapu Bulu outspeeds Magnezone and Mega Tyranitar while optimizing its bulk. Tera Water retains Tapu Bulu's utility against rain while making it resist Ice-types moves from Pokemon like Weavile and Fire-type moves from Heatran and Volcarona, while Tera Steel avoids Toxic, grants a helpful Flying resistance against the lieks of Tornadus-T and Zados, and synergizes well with Grassy Terrain, as it weakens Earthquake. Both options also let it resist Make It Rain from Gholdengo, allowing Tapu Bulu to win against it thanks to Horn Leech's recovery. Tapu Bulu fits best on offense and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its strong wallbreaking capability. Heatran checks Fire-types like Volcarona and Skeledirge, Flying-types like Tornadus-T, and appreciates Grassy Terrain weakening Earthquake. In return, Tapu Bulu can check Rotom-W and Urshifu-R, using them as setup fodder. Kartana synergizes well with Tapu Bulu, as Tapu Bulu can break through most of Kartana's checks thanks to Z-Moves (added hyphen) and boosts its Leaf Blade with Grassy Terrain, letting Kartana clean with its Choice Scarf set. In the same vein, Mega Scizor works well with Tapu Bulu, as together they can overwhelm their common checks, like Zapdos and Heatran.

Physically Defensive.description: Tapu Fini's solid typing, good bulk, and vast utility make it an excellent defensive presence in the metagame, holding the tier together against numerous Pokemon, such as Latios, Mega Tyranitar, and Keldeo. Misty Surge makes it excellent at regaining momentum against status users, such as Clefable and Blissey, allowing setup teammates like Mega Tyranitar to more freely set up against these Pokemon. Scald provides Tapu Fini with a STAB move that can burn the likes of Celesteela and Tapu Bulu attempting to take advantage of it while also letting it apply pressure to targets such as Iron Moth and Victini. Alternatively, Nature's Madness allows Tapu Fini to hit defensive Pokemon it would otherwise be unable to punish for switching in, Mega Venusaur and Amoonguss. Defog keeps entry hazards off against walls that its typing enables it to match up well against, like Skarmory. Taunt, besides preventing the aforementioned Pokemon from relaying hazards in front of Tapu Fini, also denies healing and setup attempts from Pokemon like Clefable and Blissey, particularly when used in combination with Nature's Madness to more quickly wear down said targets. 96 Speed EVs ensure that Tapu Fini outruns Adamant Scizor, letting it shut down potential Swords Dance attempts against it, while the rest is put into Defense to maximize its walling capabilities against Pokemon such as Buzzwole, Psyshock Latios, and Excadrill. Defog Tapu Fini fits onto many bulky offense and balance teams for its valuable role compression. Tapu Fini is prone to being overwhelmed and lacks any form of healing outside of Leftovers, which makes other defensive Pokemon that can support it against the aforementioned threats extremely valuable; these include Pokemon such as Skarmory and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Wish users such as Jirachi and Blissey are also highly noticeable in this regard for their ability to keep Tapu Fini healthy throughout the game in addition to synergizing with it immensely by handling special attackers that can threaten Tapu Fini, such as Alakazam. Other defensive Pokemon like Buzzwole and Mega Aggron benefit from Tapu Fini's ability to clear hazards, allowing them to more safely leverage their HP to check the threats they are meant to deal with. Finally, powerful offensive Pokemon that appreciate Misty Terrain's effects, like Bisharp and Choice Band Tyranitar, also enjoy being able to fall back on Tapu Fini to deal with offensive threats like Keldeo and clear hazards, improving their potential to wallbreak throughout the game.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Tapu Fini can outspeed and revenge kill common offensive Pokemon such as Latios and Cinderace. Additionally, Tapu Fini can still uphold its natural defensive qualities and bulk to switch into other threats like Cinderace and Latios when needed, before outspeeding and threatening them too, while also providing Defog support. Hydro Pump is Tapu Fini's strongest move to hit Iron Moth and Excadrill with, OHKOing both after Stealth Rock damage, but Surf can be used instead if accuracy is a concern despite having less power. Trick allows Tapu Fini to cripple an incoming wall that would normally try to take advantage of it, like Blissey and Amoonguss. Defog allows Tapu Fini to clear entry hazards for its team in a pinch, especially once it has Tricked away its Choice Scarf, but if Defog is already found on another Pokemon, Taunt and Nature's Madness are options that can be used instead to further mess with most defensive Pokemon, chipping them down quickly or denying healing attempts. The given EV spread ensures that Tapu Fini survives a +2 Acrobatics from Hawlucha and outspeeds Mega Aerodactyl. Tapu Fini fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its defensive utility and role compression. Wallbreakers that benefit from its ability to check faster offensive threats like Keldeo and Galarian Zapdos include Pokemon such as Choice Band Tyranitar and Mega Heracross, with each additionally benefiting from Misty Terrain's status immunity. On the other hand, Tapu Fini's tendency to lure in defensive Pokemon that it can Trick its Choice Scarf over to, like Blissey and Chansey, can be exploited by Pokemon that normally struggle to break past them, such as Iron Moth and Nasty Plot Hydreigon. As Tapu Fini can struggle to check threats like Latios and Victini in the long run, other Pokemon like Celesteela and Galarian Moltres can help provide extra insurance against these Pokemon.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Tapu Fini's combination of high bulk and Taunt allows it to set up on numerous defensive staples such as Buzzwole, Clefable, and Blissey, making it very adept at punishing the use of common walls and tanks. While Scald cannot burn grounded foes while Misty Terrain is active, it can still annoy and cripple certain foes like Enamorus and Celesteela. While weak, Draining Kiss provides a massive amount of recovery to Tapu Fini, letting it remain healthy as it sweeps through opposing teams. The given EV spread provides enough Special Attack for Tapu Fini to OHKO Excadrill with +1 Scald and lets it outspeed Adamant Bisharp, with the rest maximizing its physical bulk. Tapu Fini best fits on bulky offense and balance teams that want an end-game wincon, supporting wallbreaking teammates such as Iron Hands and Mega Tyranitar. It's overwhelmed by fast offensive foes that can hit it super effectively such as Thundurus-T and Iron Moth. Teammates like Mega Venusaur can check Thundurus-T while Iron Moth checks opposing Iron Moth. Mega Venusaur is another troublesome matchup, and it can be threatened by teammates such as Mega Latias and Latios.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Tapu Fini compresses roles as speed control that provides valuable defensive utility and support. It can outspeed and revenge kill foes like Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, Garchomp, and Iron Valiant while using its typing and remarkable bulk to switch into Pokemon like Heatran, Weavile, and Urshifu-R. Other than shutting down problematic setup sweepers like Volcarona, Trick + Taunt improves Tapu Fini's matchup against defensive Pokemon by crippling and shutting down switch-ins such as Ferrothorn, Clodsire, and Toxapex, especially with Misty Terrain to protect it and its teammates against theirs and the likes of Rotom-W, Heatran, and Gastrodon's status moves. If the team lacks an entry hazard remover, Tapu Fini can run Defog if necessary, as it matches up well against entry hazard setters like Heatran, Landorus-T, and Garchomp. However, its vulnerability to all forms of entry hazards and lack of longevity make it a poor candidate to do it consistently. Ice Beam can be run to potentially 2HKO offensive Tornadus-T and OHKO Landorus-T, while Nature's Madness is an option to dent its checks hard—especially ones that lack reliable recovery—such as Ferrothorn, Galarian Slowking, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. However, forgoing Taunt or Defog loses out on Tapu Fini's utility, which makes shutting down walls and supporting its team needlessly more difficult. Tera Steel allows Tapu Fini to emergency check threats like Tapu Lele and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T; it also provides a better defensive typing against walls like Toxapex and Ferrothorn, which is more useful if using Taunt. The Speed EVs allow Tapu Fini to outspeed +1 Mega Gyarados, while the Special Attack EVs allow it to KO Urshifu-R after Stealth Rock. Gholdengo, Tornadus-T, and Ferrothorn are great teammates to deal with faster threats like boosted Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf users such as Kartana, Tapu Lele, and Landorus-T; Ferrothorn also provides Spikes to chip down foes like Ferrothorn, Garchomp, and Garganacl into Tapu Fini's KO range, compensating for its middling damage output. Offensive teammates like Volcarona, Kartana, and Weavile love its Misty Terrain to protect them against debilitating status from walls like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Skeledirge, letting them set up and attack more safely; Volcarona also enjoys Tapu Fini luring in and crippling their shared checks like Toxapex and Clodsire with Trick, while Choice Band Weavile appreciates Tapu Fini removing Stealth Rock with Defog.

Agility.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

No Retreat.description: Lunala is a threatening setup sweeper thanks to the combination of Simple + No Retreat making it a decent complement to other setup sweepers like Simple Arceus-Ghost. Judgment with Spooky Plate lets Lunala Imposter-proof itself. Stored Power after No Retreat deals a massive chunk to special walls such as Mega Audino, Primal Kyogre, and Arceus formes. Final Gambit with Lunala's above-average HP can clear out walls like Yveltal and Ice Scales + Haze users for its teammates. Lunala can struggle to break past walls like Yveltal and Dialga-O without using Final Gambit, making it pair well with offensive Pokemon like Arceus-Ghost, Magic Guard Mega Mewtwo X, and Mold Breaker Eternatus. Lunala is threatened by Pokemon such as Arceus-Ghost, Kartana, and Wicked Blow or Astral Barrage Mega Mewtwo X, which can force it out by threatening an OHKO and thus prevent it from setting up, so appreciates defensive teammates such as Fur Coat Yveltal, Miraidon, and Ice Scales Arceus-Fairy to check these foes, respectively. Lunala usually Imposter-proofs itself thanks to Spooky Plate, but in the event that a Spooky Plate Imposter user transforms into Lunala, a teammate like Fur Coat Yveltal is highly recommended to not get instantly reverse swept.

Choice Item User (Rock).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Meteor Beam (Rock).description:
The EV Spread lets Nihilego obtain a Speed-boosting Beast Boost.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Stealth Rock.description: EV Spread ensures that Speed is boosted after a KO. 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe is an alternative spread that maximizes Special Attack.

Meteor Beam.description: EV Spread ensures that Speed is boosted after a KO.
The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Defensive.description: Buzzwole is a strong tank with the ability to check many of the physical attackers in the tier such as Tyranitar, Excadrill, and Bisharp. Buzzwole sets itself apart from other physical walls with its high Attack stat and strong moves, allowing it to exert immediate pressure against the opposing team. Close Combat is Buzzwole's STAB move of choice, as its high Base Power is preferred over alternatives like Drain Punch against threats such as Scizor and Iron Hands. Earthquake is a solid coverage move that allows Buzzwole to threaten Iron Moth and Ceruledge, which would otherwise be able to switch in for free. The final moveslot offers a bit more flexibility, with Toxic being used the most in order to status common switch-ins such as Latios, Hippowdon, and Tangrowth. Alternatively, Thunder Punch can be utilized for more immediate pressure against Water- and Flying-types such as Tapu Fini and Enamorus. Finally, Bulk Up can be used on defensive teams to allow Buzzwole to act as a wincon. The Defense boosts can also help in one-on-one situations against other Attack-boosting threats such as Iron Hands. The Attack EVs ensure Buzzwole 2HKOs defensive Celesteela with Close Combat after Stealth Rock damage, while 112 Speed EVs allow Buzzwole to outspeed Adamant Tyranitar. This Speed benchmark is largely trivial, however, and can be adjusted to account for other specific threats such as Bisharp and Scizor. Buzzwole’s ability to switch into Ground- and Fighting-type moves is valued by Pokemon such as Excadrill and Tyranitar, and its resistance to Bug and Dark is greatly appreciated by Psychic-types such as Mega Latias and Slowking. Due to its poor special bulk, Buzzwole can quickly be overwhelmed by strong special attackers and Future Sight. Therefore, it appreciates specially defensive teammates such as Blissey and Hippowdon. Physical wallbreakers are often paired with Future Sight support; therefore, Pokemon such as Celesteela and Mega Aggron can prove helpful because of their high Defense paired with a Psychic resistance. Pokemon that can cover Buzzwole's weaknesses to Flying, Fairy, Fire, and Psychic are also greatly appreciated. As such, Mega Latias, Clefable, and Tyranitar are natural partners.

Choice Scarf (Bug).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Wall.description: Buzzwole serves as a solid wall, as its typing lets it take on some of the most powerful attackers in the tier, such as Zamazenta, Kingambit, and Great Tusk. Ice Punch allows Buzzwole to threaten Ground-types such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Clodsire, as well as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Dragonite. Bulk Up accumulates boosts alongside Pokemon such as Howl Zamazenta, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and defensive Mega Scizor, meaning they cannot overwhelm Buzzwole. Toxic is a niche alternative if Buzzwole's team wishes to play more proactively, as it cripples the likes of Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge that would otherwise take advantage of Buzzwole. Heavy-Duty Boots ignores entry hazards, letting Buzzwole consistently switch into the Pokemon it gets tasked to counter without being worn down. Tera Water gives Buzzwole a Water resistance, allowing it to wall Pokemon such as Urshifu-R, Floatzel, and Barraskewda in rain. The given EV spread maximizes Buzzwole's physical bulk while ensuring it always outspeeds Kingambit. Buzzwole fits best on defensive teams, which appreciate it as a fallback measure against the myriad of physical wallbreakers while not caring for its relative passivity. Pokemon such as Clodsire and Hippowdon can shore up Buzzwole's weakness to common special attackers such as Mega Diancie, Dragapult, and Tapu Koko. Buzzwole appreciates pivots such as Toxapex, Tornadus-T, and Gliscor, which can absorb chip damage from moves like Scald, Salt Cure and—for the latter two—Knock Off. Buzzwole has a tendency to thud into Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Tapu Lele if not using Toxic, so it pairs well with the likes of Gholdengo and Weavile that can exploit them.

Choice Band.description: Pheromosa has one job on most teams: be the fastest thing on the field and fire off very strong U-turn. This allows it to both force out dangerous offensive threats and grab momentum at the same time. Sword of Ruin kicks up Pheromosa's power and makes it a decent supporting wallbreaker for an ally like Mega Mewtwo X or Kartana. Glacial Lance chunks Dragon-types like Eternatus and Giratina for solid damage. Knock Off cuts into the longevity of most physical walls by removing their Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots, making it easier for an ally to pick them off; in addition, removing Covert Cloak opens these up to be poisoned by Mortal Spin, aiding other offensive teammates like Mega Mewtwo X. Pheromosa's best fit is on offense teams that are looking for a reliable way of scaring out fast threats that Imposter isn't very reliable into, like Ultra Necrozma and Ash-Greninja. Pheromosa lacks the power to beat Fur Coat users by itself, so another physical wallbreaker like Kartana, Mega Mewtwo X, or Mega Garchomp is mandatory for it to be useful. Imposter-proof Pheromosa with bulky physical walls that don't mind Knock Off, like Fur Coat Earth Plate Arceus-Poison.

Autotomize Sweeper.description: Celesteela's high Special Attack, good movepool, and snowballing potential with Beast Boost make it a great sweeper when using Autotomize to shore up its poor Speed. Its naturally great bulk and Steel/Flying typing afford it setup opportunities against foes like Scizor and Excadrill, as well as the ability to easily muscle past them. Meteor Beam combined with Power Herb lets Celesteela boost its Special Attack without needing a KO. Given that it's Celesteela's strongest attack, in some situations it should be saved to instead target a foe Celesteela would otherwise have trouble breaking through like Skeledirge or Victini. Air Slash serves as a spammable STAB attack, 2HKOing most of the tier at +1, though it can OHKO many Bug- and Grass-types like Buzzwole and Hisuian Lilligant unboosted. Its chance to flinch its foes can also come in handy against special walls like Gastrodon and Slowking, which could otherwise stop Celesteela's sweep. Fire Blast primarily targets Steel-types, OHKOing foes like Scizor unboosted and opposing Celesteela after a few boosts. Celesteela best fits on offense teams looking for a cleaner, forming a potent offensive combination with other sweepers like Iron Hands and Bisharp. Alternatively, if the opportunity arises, it can instead be used as a mid-game wallbreaker and have a teammate clean using the holes it creates. However, it has no way to break through certain special walls like Blissey and Chansey on its own, making physical attackers like Bisharp and Iron Hands necessary. While they share some overlapping counterplay, special sweepers like Booster Energy Iron Moth and Galarian Moltres also appreciate Celesteela's support for similar reasons, and they can still support each other by weakening some of each other's shared checks, such as Slowbro, Slowking, Latios, and Latias. Entry hazard setters like Lead Mew and Excadrill are crucial for their ability to weaken Celesteela's checks, making it harder for foes like Gastrodon and Tapu Fini to remain healthy enough to check Celesteela.

Defensive.description: Celesteela is a strong defensive staple on balance teams, owing mainly to its fantastic mixed bulk and great type combination, which allow it to check threats such as Excadrill, Clefable, Mega Latias, and Enamorus. Leech Seed is Celesteela’s most defining move, as it is its main way of healing itself and allows it to force progress against would be switch-ins such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Blissey while also discouraging threats such as Mega Latias from setting up against it. Heavy Slam is another vital move that allows Celesteela to pressure threats such as Mega Tyranitar, Clefable, and Enamorus. Protect is good when used with Leech Seed to further wear down threats such as Excadrill and Enamorus without Substitute while also letting it scout Choice-locked foes such as Latios and Victini. Toxic can be used over Protect on more offensive teams to make faster progress against threats such as Mega Latias, Mega Tyranitar, Hydreigon, and Galarian Moltres and also wear down bulky Water-types such as Slowbro and Gastrodon. Flamethrower is an important coverage move to tackle Steel- and Grass-types such as Excadrill, Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Leftovers synergizes very well with Leech Seed and Protect to recover large swaths of HP. Celesteela struggles a lot against Fire-types such as Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Victini, so bulky Fire-resistant teammates such as Slowking, Mega Latias, and Mega Tyranitar are greatly appreciated to keep them at bay. Mega Tyranitar in particular is capable of Pursuit trapping Fire-types to deal with them. Electric-types such as Sandy Shocks and both Thundurus formes also annoy Celesteela greatly with Volt Switch, so Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon are important for halting their pivoting, and in return Celesteela can deal with Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu for them. Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss are good at handling Water-types that annoy Celesteela such as Slowbro and Tapu Fini while also being secondary checks to Electric-types. Dangerous physical attackers such as Galarian Zapdos and Swords Dance Scizor can easily overwhelm Celesteela, so physical walls such as Slowbro, Buzzwole, and Mega Altaria make for great partners to help deal with them. In return, Celesteela can help cover them against Fairy-types such as Clefable and Enamorus while also providing them with extra longevity via Leech Seed support.

Physically Defensive (Flying).description:
Avoids the 2HKO from Choice Specs Greninja's Ice Beam.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Mixed Wall (Steel).description: Boasting incredible defensive stats, an assortment of utility options, and a wonderful typing, Celesteela cements itself as a staple on Steel teams, easing the Ground and Fairy matchups as well as forcing progress against opposing Steel teams due to Flamethrower and Leech Seed. Flamethrower targets Steel-types that resist Heavy Slam such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Mega Scizor, while Air Slash threatens Fighting-types like Mega Gallade, Great Tusk, and Kommo-o. Alternatively, Toxic may be used to put bulkier Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Gastrodon on a timer, however, without Flamethrower, Celesteela is extremely passive in front of the aforementioned Steel-types, as well as Ferrothorn and Gholdengo which are immune to Leech Seed. Giga Drain is another option to improve the Water and Ground matchups, hitting Gastrodon, Mega Swampert, and Slowbro as well as improving longevity, however, it's a lot more matchup reliant than the other listed options. Protect in conjunction with Leech Seed is Celesteela's main method of forcing progress, spreading chip damage while also massively boosting its longevity. The given EV spread allows Celesteela to survive two consecutive uses of Close Combat from the likes of Mega Lopunny in addition to Choice Scarf Buzzwole and Terrakion. Heatran is by far Celesteela's most advantageous teammate due to its immunity to Fire-type moves letting it take on threats such as Volcarona and Blacephalon. In return, Celesteela walls Ground-types like Clodsire and Hippowdon. Ferrothorn is an essential teammate due to its ability to check Water-types such as Barraskewda, Mega Swampert, and Rotom-W as well as provide utility in the form of entry hazards and additional Leech Seed support, wearing down teams greatly. Furthermore, Ferrothorn is a great answer to Electric-type Pokemon like Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Alolan Raichu. Ghost-type teammates such as Aegislash and Gholdengo alleviate the Fighting matchup, lessening the amount of pressure put onto Celesteela as a primary switch-in and also removing threats like Skeledirge, Slowbro, and Toxapex. Choice Scarf Iron Treads and Excadrill provide an immunity against the aforementioned Electric-type Pokemon, while the former checks Landorus with Ice Spinner and the latter hinders Mega Sableye with Toxic. Furthermore, Excadrill and Iron Treads are Steel's best answers to Ogerpon-H. Mega Scizor is a great pivot into Knock Off and can take on Fighting-types due to its neutrality to them and access to Roost. Assault Vest Melmetal is a great blanket check to special attackers like Tapu Koko, Kyurem, and Gholdengo, while Hisuian Goodra is an excellent sponge for Water-type attacks, walling Volcanion, Choice Specs Pelipper, and Basculegion-F.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Kartana is a threatening wallbreaker and sweeper, using its sky-high Attack stat to cut through common defensive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Landorus-T. Sacred Sword allows Kartana to KO common Steel-types such as Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Kingambit. Giga Impact can be used in conjunction with Normalium Z to turn into a devastating Breakneck Blitz, slicing through Flying-type answers such as Tornadus-T, Dragonite, and Zapdos. Knock Off is an alternative to KO Gholdengo and Dragapult reliably, as well as pressure checks such as Skeledirge and Tornadus-T. If using Knock Off, Kartana opts for Fightinium Z to break through Mega Scizor. Swords Dance Kartana pairs well with physical cleaners that capitalize on it dicing up common physical walls such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge. As such, Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Dragonite make for great partners. Kartana also pairs well with Pursuit trappers such as Mega Tyranitar, Weavile, and Kingambit, as they remove common checks such as Tornadus-T, Dragapult, and Gholdengo. Kartana appreciates having pivots that bring it in safely against passive Pokemon; Rotom-W and Tornadus-T bait in the likes of Ferrothorn and Rotom-W to allow Kartana to pivot in and setup safely. Kartana is forced out by common revenge killers such as Iron Valiant, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny, so having teammates that can switch into them such as Tornadus-T, Slowbro, and Landorus-T are ideal.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Kartana is an incredibly dangerous late-game cleaner thanks to its Choice Scarf-boosted Speed and incredible attack. It can outspeed common setup sweepers such as Mega Gyarados and Volcarona, as well as common Choice Scarf users like Tapu Lele. Knock Off removes the items of defensive Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Toxapex in the mid-game for it to clean up later on. Sacred Sword hits Steel-types like Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Kingambit. Smart Strike can be used as Kartana's strongest option against Dragonite and Buzzwole. Alternatively, Defog is an option to remove entry hazards in a pinch for Kartana's team, although being locked into it is unideal. Tera Grass skyrockets Leaf Blade's damage, giving it the opportunity to snowball easily alongside Beast Boost. Choice Scarf Kartana fits best on highly offensive teams which put continuous pressure on its checks, allowing it to cleave through weakened defensive cores. Pokemon such as Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele are great partners, as they weaken common defensive Steel-types, allowing Kartana to spam Leaf Blade freely. Similarly, Pursuit trappers such as Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar force the likes of Tornadus-T, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge to either be heavily weakened or forced to Terastallize into a type not resisting Grass, benefitting Kartana either way. Strong physical attackers such as Zamazenta, Mega Medicham, and Great Tusk weaken physical walls such as Toxapex and Landorus-T, leaving them vulnerable to Kartana.

Bulky Defog.description: Defog Kartana is a solid entry hazard remover that can contribute to wallbreaking if used at the right time. With its impressive 181 Attack stat, Kartana is often able to force opposing entry hazard setters such as Hippowdon and Clodsire out and take advantage of this to use Defog. Furthermore, its resistance to Stealth Rock and immunity to Toxic Spikes helps Kartana to switch into entry hazards multiple times. Synthesis provides Kartana with longevity, especially when paired with sun, which allows it to even outheal damage from defensive Landrous-T and Great Tusk's Earthquake. Grassium Z makes up for its loss in power and enables it to pick off weakened walls like Toxapex and Landorus-T, as well as threatening common Stealth Rock users such as Garchomp, Tyranitar, Hippowdon, and Clodsire. Knock Off hits Gholdengo for super effective damage. Sacred Sword can be used as an alternative choice to hit Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Heatran, which Kartana otherwise struggles with. However, missing out on hitting Gholdengo makes it less helpful in the current metagame. 120 Attack EVs allow Kartana to OHKO offensive Garchomp with Bloom Doom. while the HP investment ensures that Kartana survives Choice Scarf Tapu Lele's Psychic even after taking Stealth Rock damage. Mega Charizard Y has great synergy with this set, since it appreciates Kartana's ability to keep the field clear of Stealth Rock whilst also muscling through common special walls in Chansey and Clodsire. In return, Drought boosts Kartana's longevity by increasing the amount of HP Synthesis recovers. Kartana can also switch into rock moves against Mega charizard Y from opposing Garchomp and Choice Scarf Landorus-T, while Mega Charizard Y removes Steel- and Grass-Type walls such as Skarmory, Ferrothorn, and Tangrowth that this set struggles with. Due to its poor Special Defence, Kartana is vulnerable to special attackers that outspeed it, like Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. This requires it to be paired with a good special wall that can check those threats, such as Tapu Fini or Slowking. Kartana can also struggle with entry hazard setters such as Mega Diancie, Heatran, and Skarmory due to its inability to force them out, so teammates that can limit them such as Slowing and Heatran make for good partners.

Calm Mind.description: A more defensive spread of 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe Timid can be used with Cosmic Power over Calm Mind

Defensive.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Adaptability.description: Adaptability Blacephalon is a powerful mixed wallbreaker. Choice Scarf makes Blacephalon the fastest relevant Pokemon in the meta, outspeeding threats like Miraidon, allowing it to double as a revenge killer and also offsetting V-create's Speed drops against slower checks like Primal Kyogre. Alternatively, Life Orb provides Blacephalon with more firepower, allowing it to hit benchmarks like OHKOing Arceus and Mega Audino after slight chip. Volt Switch retains momentum and chips Pokemon like Ice Scales Primal Kyogre and Ho-Oh into 2HKO range. Poltergeist on Life Orb sets serves as a way to hit the aforementioned Pokemon without receiving Speed drops. Trick lets Blacephalon cripple a defensive Pokemon in matchups where its Choice Scarf is unnecessary. Strength Sap provides crucial longevity to offset Life Orb recoil and entry hazard chip damage. A Naughty nature is chosen to boost V-create's damage, make Imposter users take more damage from Astral Barrage, and improve the matchup against priority moves like Mega Diancie's Extreme Speed and Kartana's Bullet Punch. Blacephalon benefits greatly from entry hazards that chip walls like Primal Kyogre and Fur Coat Arceus formes into 2HKO range. Conversely, due to its Stealth Rock weakness, Blacephalon also strongly appreciates teammates that provide entry hazard removal like Arceus-Ground and Rapid Spin Yveltal. Slow pivots like Primal Kyogre and Mega Steelix can bring Blacephalon in safely. Blacephalon can be Imposter-proofed by Imposter Guzzlord, though other options like Fur Coat Ting-Lu and Mega Audino also work.

Choice Scarf (Fire).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Ghost).description: Boasting an astonishing Special Attack stat, great Speed tier, and deadly STAB combination, Blacephalon is an esteemed revenge killer on Ghost teams, easily cleaning through weakened Steel, Fairy, and Flying teams due to Beast Boost. Fire Blast provides more power to OHKO foes like Tapu Koko and Great Tusk at the cost of lowered accuracy. Hidden Power Ice targets Ground- and Dragon-types that aren't threatened by Blacephalon's STAB combination such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Dragonite. Alternatively, Blacephalon may use Psyshock to break through Clodsire, Kommo-o, and Nihilego. Trick immobilizes switch-ins like Alolan Muk, Iron Hands, and Blissey but can also be used on the aforementioned targets of Psyshock. With a Choice Scarf, Blacephalon manages to outpace Weavile, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Tapu Koko, allowing it to revenge kill them. Mimikyu is a great wallbreaker, capable of weakening Dark, Fighting, and Dragon teams, setting Blacephalon up for success late-game. Mega Sableye prevents the setting of Stealth Rock, allowing Blacephalon to pivot freely. Gholdengo threatens Fairy-type Pokemon like Mega Diancie and Clefable and takes advantage of passive Blacephalon switch-ins like Toxapex and Blissey. Hisuian Zoroark's immunity to Ghost-type moves is heavily appreciated, and it lures in Dark-types such as Hydreigon, Mega Tyranitar, and Ting-Lu with Illusion, hitting them with Focus Blast. Furthermore, Hisuian Zoroark can bluff other Blacephalon switch-ins—such as Heatran and Toxapex—to eliminate them, easing Blacephalon's job later into the match. Froslass and Galarian Corsola offer entry hazards to wear down Blacephalon's switch-ins and spread status ailments to ease Blacephalon's sweeping.

Offensive Pivot.description: A blistering Speed tier, above-average offenses, and potent offensive typing make Zeraora an effective pivot and revenge killer in the tier, threatening important targets in Cinderace, Latios, Enamorus, and Alakazam. Additionally, Zeraora packs significant utility options in Knock Off and Volt Switch that can capitalize on the aforementioned traits and even allow it to make long-term progress against a majority of defensive targets, such as Ting-Lu and Rotom-W. Toxic is usually Zeraora's preferred move in the last slot, allowing it to stifle specific Pokemon that are otherwise able to heal off and withstand its attacks, such as Mega Latias, Hippowdon, and Iron Hands. Alternatively, Zeraora can also make use of Close Combat to pose an immediate threat to most Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon, such as Excadrill, Hydreigon, and Mega Tyranitar, the latter of which it can also outspeed after a Dragon Dance, making it one of the few revenge killers able to remove it from full without the need for a Choice Scarf. On the other hand, Grass Knot is an alternative that puts immediate pressure on Hippowdon and Quagsire, though it becomes more difficult for Zeraora to break through several of the aforementioned targets in Mega Latias, Hydreigon, and Excadrill. Heavy-Duty Boots ensures Zeraora isn't hampered by entry hazards. Zeraora fits best on bulkier teams that appreciate its proficiency in revenge killing offensive threats while possessing added longevity and the ability to generate momentum. Defensive staples such as Ting-Lu, Slowking, and Amoonguss appreciate Zeraora's ability to force out Pokemon that may threaten them, including the likes of Cinderace, as well as Galarian Zapdos lacking Choice Scarf. In return, Ting-Lu can provide entry hazard support to bolster the effects of Zeraora's pivoting capabilities and Knock Off, whereas Slowking can use Future Sight to pressure Pokemon that would otherwise be able to stave off Zeraora's attacks, such as Buzzwole and Mega Venusaur. Similarly, slower wallbreakers like Choice Specs Enamorus, Nasty Plot Hydreigon, and Choice Band Tyranitar appreciate Zeraora's ability to scare out faster Pokemon while also benefitting from the safe switch-in opportunities provided by Volt Switch. While Zeraora's offensive matchups are impressive, it can struggle to contain many offensive threats that are capable of boosting their Speed, such as Sand Rush Excadrill, Dragon Dance Salamence, and Autotomize Celesteela. Thus, specific defensive checks to these Pokemon such as defensive Celesteela, Slowbro, and Thunder Wave Clefable are highly appreciated.

Bulk Up (Electric).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Band.description: Rillaboom's combination of Grassy Glide and Grassy Surge makes it a reliable revenge killer, pressuring faster threats like Mega Lopunny, Mega Medicham, Garchomp, Barraskewda, and Iron Valiant. It also possesses great utility thanks to U-turn and Knock Off. Wood Hammer is Rillaboom's strongest STAB move, dealing massive damage to all non-resistant foes. Knock Off catches would-be checks like Tornadus-T and Zapdos on the switch, getting rid of their item at the same time. Superpower hits Steel-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Ferrothorn. Tera Grass makes Rillaboom even more threatening; with Terrain-boosted Grassy Glide, it becomes near unstoppable, 2HKOing Tornadus-T after Stealth Rock. Rillaboom fits best on bulky offense teams, which appreciate speed control in Grassy Glide. Grassy Terrain sweepers like Hawlucha and Choice Scarf Kartana appreciate Rillaboom weakening their common checks—namely Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Corviknight—so they can clean late-game. Magnezone is a standout partner for Rillaboom, as it can trap and remove Steel-types like Corviknight, Skarmory, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn, letting Rillaboom clean more easily. Heatran appreciates Rillaboom's Grassy Terrain giving it passive recovery and weakening Earthquake from the likes of Galarian Slowking. In return, Heatran pressures Rillaboom's checks, such as Buzzwole, Corviknight, Volcarona, Skarmory, and Skeledirge, while also providing Stealth Rock and checking Tornadus-T.

Bulky Swords Dance.description: Thanks to Grassy Glide and Grassy Surge, Rillaboom forces many switches against Pokemon like Rotom-W and Urshifu-R, meaning it can safely set up with Swords Dance to threaten the opposing team. Knock Off punishes its checks, like Zapdos and Tornadus-T. Superpower allows Rillaboom to threaten Steel-types like Heatran, Kingambit, and Ferrothorn, while Wood Hammer does massive damage to all neutral threats, even without a boost. The given EV spread allows Rillaboom to outspeed Mega Tyranitar while maximizing its bulk. The added bulk maximizes Rillaboom’s longevity, helping it perform long-term and deal with other terrain setters, like Tapu Lele. Life Orb gives Rillaboom a chance to OHKO offensive Tornadus-T with Tera Grass-boosted Grassy Glide, with its recoil being negated by the Grassy Terrain. On the other hand, Leftovers provides increased longevity for Rillaboom, allowing it to setup multiple times throughout a game. Tera Grass gives Rillaboom an even stronger Grassy Glide, allowing it to storm through most offensive teams that have limited resistances to it. Some Flying-resistant Tera types such as Steel and Electric can punish Zapdos and Tornadus-T, but they are usually suboptimal and don't benefit Rillaboom's offensive power. Magnezone works well with this set, as it can trap and remove Steel-types like Corviknight, Skarmory, and Mega Scizor. Hawlucha is a good partner as well, as Grassy Seed will activate Hawlucha's Unburden thanks to Grassy Terrain and Rillaboom can weaken their shared check in Zapdos so it can clean late-game. Since Superpower weakens Steel-types, Pokemon like Weavile and Mega Mawile pair well with Rillaboom. The latter also appreciates Grassy Terrain, as it softens Earthquake from the likes of Gliscor and Landorus-T.

Choice Band.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Assault Vest.description: 168 attack EVs allow you to KO Palkia-O with Wood Hammer + Grassy Glide

Support.description:
• Rillaboom is an excellent glue Pokemon in the tier, with Fake Out pressure, pivoting capabilities, and passive healing from Grassy Terrain making it a excellent partner for setup sweepers and offense teams alike. Rillaboom can also provide offensive pressure with its powerful Wood Hammer in Grassy Terrain and decent coverage.
  • Fake Out generates free turns for setup sweepers like Palafin and Kingambit while also helping allies that can assist with speed control like Tornadus and Cresselia to set up Tailwind and Trick Room, respectively. Rillaboom is the fastest Fake Out user, letting it use Fake Out before a prominent Fake Out user like Iron Hands.
  • Wood Hammer is Rillaboom's main way of exerting offensive pressure, OHKOing Palafin, Diancie, and Flutter Mane after minimal chip, while also doing good damage to most of the unresisted metagame, picking up 2HKOs on the likes of Iron Hands and Volcanion.
  • U-turn allows Rillaboom to bring in teammates like Palafin safely without them taking damage while additionally doing good damage to opposing Rillaboom.
  • Brick Break hits Steel-type Pokemon such as Kingambit and Heatran, while also OHKOing Chien-Pao. Removing dual screens enables the likes of Kingambit and Palafin to continue their own sweeps. On non-Assault Vest sets, Taunt stops Trick Room setters like Diancie and Cresselia, setup Pokemon like Kingambit, entry hazard setters, and other general utility Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Grimmsnarl. Stomping Tantrum 2HKOes common Grass resistances such as Heatran, Armarouge, and Gholdengo.
  • Assault Vest helps Rillaboom match up better against special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Gholdengo, while Sitrus Berry grants a one-time burst recovery and the freedom to use Taunt.
  • This EV spread lets Rillaboom survive an Ice Spinner from Jolly Chien-Pao and, with Assault Vest, two Choice Specs Moonblasts from Flutter Mane after Grassy Terrain recovery.
  • Tera Fire helps Rillaboom match up better against Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Armarouge by inverting its weaknesses, allowing it to trade positively with its coverage options against these Pokemon.

Choice Band.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Pivot.description:
Cinderace is a good offensive pivot thanks to its high Speed, decent Attack, and wide coverage that gains a STAB boost thanks to Libero each time it enters the field. Pyro Ball is its most reliable move, as it can hit hard while preserving Libero. Sucker Punch gives Cinderace a means to hit faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Dragapult super effectively. Alternatively, Gunk Shot can be run to OHKO Iron Valiant and Hatterene while preserving the team's ability to Terastallize. Court Change is an extremely useful move, as it can provide hazard control that is unaffected by Gholdengo's Good as Gold while also stealing Light Screen and Reflect from hyper offensive teams; however, Cinderace can choose to run High Jump Kick instead to hit Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Ting-Lu harder as well as inflicting more damage against Pokemon that resist Pyro Ball like Garchomp and Garganacl. Tera Fire is the Tera type that Cinderace wants to utilize in order to maximize Pyro Ball's damage, giving it the ability to, with an Adamant nature, OHKO Corviknight after Stealth Rock. It also helps Cinderace hit bulkier targets like Hatterene and offensive Great Tusk, especially if it isn't running Gunk Shot or High Jump Kick. A Jolly nature is preferred to augment Cinderace's role as a fast pivot, allowing it to outspeed Iron Valiant, Iron Moth, and Iron Treads. However, an Adamant nature can be run instead to increase its damage output.

Cinderace works best on balance and bulky offense teams, providing utility and entry hazard control while simultaneously exerting offensive pressure. Defensive Water-type Pokemon like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Dondozo can all sponge Water-type attacks while taking neutral damage from Rock- and Ground-type moves, with the exception of Toxapex. In turn, Cinderace can match up well against wallbreakers such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant and Meowscarada, which can all cause difficulties for the aforementioned Water-types. Ground-types that provide entry hazard support such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Ting-Lu make it easier for Cinderace to check threats with Stealth Rock and Spikes, especially if it is running an Adamant nature. Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Iron Valiant pair well with Cinderace, as they can eradicate foes that wall it such as Great Tusk, Dondozo, and Rotom-W. Similarly, Dragonite and Kingambit can check Pokemon such as Hatterene and Skeledirge, which can both cause issues for Cinderace. In return, Cinderace can provide hazard control for all of these partners and help them come in the field more safely without having to worry about chip damage from entry hazards.

Bulky Pivot.description:
Cinderace functions as an excellent bulky pivot thanks to its great Speed tier, serviceable bulk, and access to support moves such as Court Change and Will-O-Wisp. Cinderace can force out important offensive threats like Gholdengo and Iron Valiant with the threat of STAB Pyro Ball while keeping up momentum against defensive switch-ins with U-turn. Will-O-Wisp allows Cinderace to cripple physical attackers such as Kingambit, Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Great Tusk, and it can also negate Leftovers for defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Toxapex, and Ting-Lu. Specifically, Will-O-Wisp offers a safe way for Cinderace to check Kingambit, since it avoids Sucker Punch mindgames. Finally, Court Change offers unmatched utility in providing entry hazard control that cannot be blocked by Gholdengo and is also able to steal opposing dual screens. The 32 Attack EVs guarantee a KO on Gholdengo sets lacking defensive investment and 2HKO on physically defensive Corviknight after Leftovers. Although this set rarely wants to Terastallize, Tera Fire can potentially come in handy for securing KOs with Pyro Ball, especially with a Blaze boost. Alternatively, Tera Flying grants Cinderace an immunity to Ground-type attacks, such as Great Tusk's Earthquake, which can grant it extra opportunities to KO foes or cripple them with Will-O-Wisp. Tera Flying also matches up well against common Ground-type hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk, letting Cinderace safely Court Change against them.

Cinderace works best on bulkier teams where its ability to guarantee hazard removal shines.
