Defensive Pokemon such as Dondozo, Slowking, Toxapex, and Amoonguss are great teammates, as they appreciate Cinderace's ability to ensure hazard removal, freeing them up to run items other than Heavy-Duty Boots. Water-types such as Dondozo and Toxapex have notably strong synergy with Cinderace; Dondozo checks Great Tusk and Tera Fire Kingambit, while Toxapex can check Water-types, such as Walking Wake and Greninja. Hazard-weak breakers such as Iron Moth and Choice Band Dragonite also fit well with Cinderace, as it's able to bring them in with U-turn. These breakers also enjoy bulky Water-types like Toxapex or Dondozo being burnt, making it easier to overwhelm them long-term. Cinderace usually requires the presence of another hazard control Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Hatterene, or Corviknight so it doesn't get overwhelmed. Corviknight synergizes especially well with Cinderace thanks to its Ground immunity and ability to absorb Knock Off from Meowscarada, which outspeeds Cinderace. Skeledirge and Dragapult can take advantage of bulky Cinderace, since both completely wall it and can potentially set up a Substitute. Kingambit is a great partner, as it can offensively check both Skeledirge and Dragapult. In return, it appreciates Cinderace burning Great Tusk and Ting-Lu, opening up the way for it to sweep.

Offensive Pivot.description: With its high Attack and Speed stats, good coverage moves, and inability to be worn down by entry hazards thanks to Heavy-Duty Boots, Cinderace is a versatile pivot that is able to outspeed and offensively respond to various threats such as Latios and Clefable. Pyro Ball is Cinderace's main STAB move, allowing it to hit Steel-types such as Celesteela and Excadrill while also dealing significant damage to other defensive Pokemon such as Buzzwole and Amoonguss; it notably preserves Libero's type-changing ability in the process. U-turn, besides allowing Cinderace to maintain momentum by bringing in a teammate like Hydreigon, can also wear down defensive Pokemon such as Slowbro. Gunk Shot gives Cinderace useful coverage for Pokemon such as Tapu Fini and Mega Altaria, and it also lets Cinderace force out Calm Mind Clefable more reliably. Alternatively, High Jump Kick is an option to OHKO Mega Tyranitar and Hydreigon, which U-turn cannot do. Sucker Punch lets Cinderace revenge kill chipped sweepers such as Agility Iron Moth and Z-Celebrate variants of Victini after their respective boosts while also threatening Choice Scarf users such as Blacephalon. Cinderace fits best on offensive teams that can supply it with the tools needed to break through defensive Pokemon; entry hazard setters such as Mega Tyranitar and Excadrill can support Cinderace in this manner, with Mega Tyranitar also being able to trap Slowbro and Skeledirge with Pursuit after Cinderace pivots against them. Similarly, defensive Pokemon such as Celesteela, Slowbro, and Tapu Fini appreciate Cinderace's ability to threaten out the likes of Amoonguss and Scizor; in return, they can help sponge the Water- and Ground-type moves aimed at Cinderace or provide Future Sight or Taunt support in the case of the latter two. Powerful wallbreakers such as Latios and Gengar also appreciate the safe entry Cinderace can facilitate against most physically defensive Pokemon it commonly invites in on top of Cinderace being able to force out the Steel-types that would otherwise threaten them, like Scizor.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance turns Cinderace into a threatening wallbreaker, using its immense power to break through most defensive Pokemon that would otherwise switch into it comfortably. At +2, Breakneck Blitz manages to OHKO the likes of Slowbro after Libero. High Jump Kick is a necessary coverage option to let Cinderace reliably KO Mega Tyranitar. Cinderace fits best on hyper offense teams that benefit from its ability to break open defensive cores; as Cinderace is often revenge killed by faster Pokemon such as Sand Rush Excadrill and Choice Scarf Latias, other Pokemon that can take advantage of these revenge killers like Galarian Moltres, Swords Dance Scizor, and Bulk Up Galarian Zapdos become valuable teammates, as they also appreciate Cinderace's innate ability to threaten common walls such as Buzzwole and Skarmory. Cinderace also appreciates anti-entry hazard options such as Excadrill and Tapu Fini, which can help alleviate Cinderace's crippling Stealth Rock weakness.

Bulky Pivot.description: Thanks to its good Speed, outspeeding foes like Thundurus and Enamorus, good Attack, and valuable utility like Court Change, which can be helpful for entry hazard-weak teammates, Cinderace is a good bulky pivot that can help bring in its teammates safely against faster foes. Pyro Ball deals with Steel- and Grass-types, 2HKOing defensive Celesteela, Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss; it is also Cinderace's best move, due to its general usability, power, ablilty to OHKO targets like Enamorus, Mega Heracross, and Thundurus-T when boosted by Blaze. Will-O-Wisp can cripple physical attackers, notably setup Pokemon such as Iron Hands, Hawlucha, and Okidogi. This given EV spread allows Cinderace to be as bulky as possible, letting it survive an Earthquake from Salamence, while still outspeeding Latios and being able able to OHKO Enamorus after Stealth Rock chip damage. Cinderace can pair well with other pivots like Rotom-W, Thundurus-T, and Galarian Zapdos, forming a VoltTurn core, being able to pivot each other in to threaten Pokemon that can check each other. Offensive Pokemon like Iron Moth and Galarian Zapdos can be good teammates for Cinderace, being able to threaten its common checks like Tapu Fini, Slowbro, and other Water-types, which generally wall it. In return, Cinderace can keep off hazards, helping them not get chipped, and pivot them in against faster targets like Choice Scarf Keldeo safely. Cinderace can be threatened out by targets like Keldeo, Volcanion, and Sandy Shocks, due to their typing and super effective moves, making it appreciate teammates that can offer a backbone against them like Mega Latias, Latios, and Blissey. Skeledirge is also another Pokemon that can wall Cinderace, forcing it out and using it as an opportunity to setup, making Cinderace pair well with partners like Keldeo, Hydreigon, and Sandy Shocks, which can threaten it. Even though Cinderace can help to keep off hazards, it can still appreciate secondary hazard removers like Tapu Fini and Excadrill.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Cinderace serves as a dangerous wallbreaker, as it easily exploits would-be checks thanks to its ability, Libero. Double-Edge becomes a STAB move after using Swords Dance, allowing Cinderace to not only wound Pokemon like Toxapex and Slowbro but also OHKO them with Normalium Z. High Jump Kick KOes Heatran and Mega Tyranitar, while Sucker Punch threatens faster Pokemon like Dragapult and Tornadus-T. Pokemon that can set entry hazards such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, Ferrothorn, and Ting-Lu help Cinderace break through its checks like Great Tusk and Tera Dragon Skarmory. Cinderace is vulnerable to faster Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Tapu Koko, so Pokemon like Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Landorus-T are good teammates. Cinderace also benefits from dual screens from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl, allowing it to safely set up and start wreaking havoc on the opponent. Pokemon that can wear down Great Tusk, Skeledirge, and Tera Dragon Skarmory such as Iron Valiant, Mega Gyarados, and Dragapult form great offensive cores with Cinderace, which, in return, threatens Pokemon like Toxapex, Kingambit, and Mega Scizor. Entry hazard removers such as Tornadus-T and Great Tusk support Cinderace's Stealth Rock weakness.

Offensive Pivot.description: Cinderace utilizes its solid coverage alongside Libero and its high Attack and Speed to serve as a strong offensive pivot. High Jump Kick OHKOes foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Heatran while hitting others like Garganacl and Ting-Lu, though Cinderace must be mindful of Protect from the former and Tera Ghost from the latter causing it to take heavy recoil. U-turn lets Cinderace generate momentum, pivoting on switch-ins such as Toxapex and Slowbro to bring in teammates like Tapu Koko and Gholdengo that can handle them. Sucker Punch lets Cinderace threaten Dragapult, which would otherwise revenge kill it. Tera Fire boosts Pyro Ball's power, allowing Cinderace to 2HKO foes such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Tera Fairy Garganacl after Stealth Rock. Cinderace must careful when using Tera, however, as Libero will no longer activate, leaving it more vulnerable to foes such as Rotom-W. Cinderace fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its pivoting ability. Tapu Koko forms a potent pivoting core with Cinderace, taking advantage of foes such as Toxapex and Rotom-W while granting Cinderace free entry against foes such as Ferrothorn and Tangrowth. They also overwhelm foes such as Ladorus-T, Gastrodon, and Great Tusk together. Cinderace also appreciates teammates such as Ferrothorn and Gastrodon providing entry hazard support to weaken foes such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk while also checking foes such as Rotom-W and Urshifu-R. Dragapult appreciates Cinderace handling foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit; in return, it threatens foes such as Skeledirge, which Cinderace struggles against. Future Sight support from teammates such as Slowbro and Tapu Lele helps pressure foes such as Toxapex for Cinderace; in return, Cinderace handles foes that threaten them such as Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor.

Choice Scarf.description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Utility.description:
Cinderace is a valuable asset to Fire teams due to its mix of offensive presence and utility. Pyro Ball lets Cinderace threaten out Sableye trying to take High Jump Kick on Dark-type teams while also dealing high amounts of general damage under sun. Libero-boosted High Jump Kick provides valuable coverage, notably hitting Ting-Lu trying to set entry hazards while dealing large amounts of damage to Pokemon with a Fire resistance trying to switch in on its Pyro Ball, such as Hydreigon and Garganacl. Low Kick is an alternative, letting Cinderace deal decent damage to most heavy foes such as Ting-Lu and Iron Hands without the large risk of High Jump Kick's crash damage. Court Change lets Cinderace force the opposing team to deal with their own hazards while making it unlikely that hazards go up again. U-turn lets Cinderace keep momentum against foes it cannot threaten out like defensive Great Tusk and Garchomp. Alternatively, Sucker Punch lets Cinderace pick off weakened threats such as Flutter Mane and Baxcalibur. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Cinderace come in repeatedly to remove hazards without worrying about residual damage from them.

Rotom-H is a great teammate for Cinderace, as its Ground immunity lets it come in on Great Tusk while threatening Water-types such as Toxapex and Dondozo—that Cinderace can't do much against—with its Electric-type STAB moves. Additionally, Rotom-H can beat Poison teams with its Substitute + Nasty Plot set, which Cinderace greatly appreciates. In return, Cinderace can pivot Rotom-H in with U-turn and keep Stealth Rock off its side of the field. Torkoal is another good teammate for Cinderace, as it provides sun to boost Cinderace's Pyro Ball damage to astronomical levels, provides entry hazard support to chip switch-ins, threatens Chien-Pao and physical Dragapult with a burn, and supplies a secondary source of hazard removal. In return, Cinderace can threaten out Ting-Lu, which might try to switch into Torkoal, while also keeping hazards off against Ghost teams. Scovillain deals with the aforementioned Water-types as well as Gastrodon while appreciating Cinderace removing the hazards that hurt Scovillain's longevity. Volcarona appreciates Cinderace chipping away at the opposing team, facilitating an endgame sweep. In return, Volcarona can hit Dark-types such as Ting-Lu and Hydreigon hard with Bug Buzz, ruin Gastrodon through Giga Drain, and damage Poison-types such as Iron Moth, Toxapex, and Glimmora with Psychic. Skeledirge is able to come in on physical hits like Iron Hands's Earthquake and force it out with the threat of a burn. Finally, Ceruledge can remove Ghost-types such as Dragapult that Cinderace can't do much against. In return, Cinderace can eliminate Dark-types and keep hazards off the field for both.

Swords Dance.description: Cinderace's high Attack and Speed combined with great coverage options and Swords Dance turn it into a powerful wallbreaker and cleaner. High Jump Kick threatens Roaring Moon and OHKOes Well-Baked Body Kingambit, while Gunk Shot threatens to cripple switch-ins such as Manaphy, Zapdos, Kommo-o, and physically defensive Garchomp. Life Orb lets High Jump Kick OHKO RegenVest Roaring Moon and lets Gunk Shot 2HKO Primordial Sea Zapdos, while Heavy-Duty Boots increases Cinderace's longevity. Desolate Land lets Cinderace come in on and force out Primordial Sea users like Zapdos if safely pivoted in by a teammate while also letting +2 Life Orb-boosted Pyro Ball OHKO defensive Great Tusk. Sword of Ruin + Heavy-Duty Boots provides more damage on Cinderace's coverage moves at the cost of a worse matchup into Primordial Sea and lowered damage on Pyro Ball. Fast cleaners such as Barraskewda and Dragonite appreciate Cinderace's ability to pressure their walls like Corviknight and Scream Tail, opening up the way for them to sweep late-game. Special pivots like Azelf, Zapdos, and Walking Wake are appreciated, as they can pivot Cinderace in against their switch-ins, such as Empoleon and Hisuian Goodra. Cinderace's frailty means it's easily revenge killed by most Pokemon faster than it like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Azelf, so teammates that can take a hit for it and pivot it in such as Corviknight and Manaphy are appreciated. Cinderace is also completely walled by Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, so teammates that can threaten it like Garchomp and Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Utility.description: Cinderace is a good utility pivot thanks to its high Speed and great supporting movepool. U-turn lets it pivot out against Well-Baked Body Pokemon like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit, as well as Primordial Sea users like Zapdos, Walking Wake, and Manaphy. Court Change punishes opposing teams for setting entry hazards or dual screens. Super Fang can be used instead to chip switch-ins like Kommo-o, Garganacl, and Quaquaval that Cinderace cannot meaningfully damage otherwise. Taunt prevents status moves, entry hazards, and recovery, which can help against foes like Scream Tail, while Will-O-Wisp cripples checks like Garchomp, Kommo-o, and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Cinderace is threatened by Primordial Sea users like Barraskewda, Ogerpon-W, and Walking Wake, which force it out, making walls like defensive Zapdos, Kommo-o, and Empoleon pair well with it. Offensive pivots such as Galarian Zapdos, Meowscarada, and Sandy Shocks pair well with Cinderace, as they form a VoltTurn core with it, being able to pivot it in to threaten walls like Corviknight, Meloetta, Hisuian Goodra. In return, Cinderace can pivot these teammates in to threaten its switch-ins like Kommo-o, Garaganacl, and Quaquaval.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Cinderace provides a blend of utility and firepower in a single teamslot; this in combination with its excellent Speed tier lets it serve as either a strong pivot or wallbreaker. Magic Guard allows Cinderace to fire off its strong Flare Blitz and use Life Orb without recoil while negating entry hazard chip damage. High Jump Kick forces out Garganacl and Well-Baked Body Kingambit as well as being the strongest move against neutral targets like Quaquaval and Mandibuzz. U-turn allows Cinderace to pivot out on switch-ins like Well-Baked Body Corviknight and Quaquaval, while Swords Dance changes its role from a pivot to a wallbreaker and late-game cleaner. Gunk Shot further increases its coverage, preying on Fairy-types like Scream Tail and Enamorus-T and threatening switch-ins like Primordial Sea Zapdos and Dragonite, while Will-O-Wisp allows it to cripple its switch-ins like Regenerator Great Tusk and physically defensive Garchomp, and Court Change allows it to control hazards in a pinch. Cinderace's ability to force out Steel-types like Corviknight is greatly appreciated by other physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Galarian Zapdos, which in return can remove Corviknight if it is running Well-Baked Body for Cinderace so it can clean up afterwards. Cinderace is vulnerable to revenge killers like Dragonite, Barraskewda, and Azelf, making walls like Corviknight, defensive Zapdos, and RegenVest Manaphy good partners that can switch into these revenge killers and pivot out. Well-Baked Body Gholdengo completely shuts down Cinderace, so teammates that can remove it like Gengar and offensive Roaring Moon make for great partners.

Swords Dance (Fire).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned

Primordial Sea.description: Inteleon is a strong wallbreaker that fits well on balance and bulky offense teams. U-turn allows it to pivot out on switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey while also forming strong VoltTurn cores with other pivots like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing that can wear down each other's checks with entry hazards up. Mud Shot allows it to threaten Desolate Land Fire-types like Iron Moth and Cinderace that would otherwise switch into Inteleon freely. Ice Beam allows it to chip specially bulky Dragon-types like RegenVest Roaring Moon and Goodra, while Surf acts as a more reliable option late-game when the opposing team has been heavily chipped or to snipe frailer or slower targets like Azelf and both Zapdos formes. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon appreciate Inteleon pivoting into them on its switch-ins like the aforementioned Hisuian Goodra and Blissey as well as Inteleon's ability to threaten physical walls like Corviknight and defensive Quaquaval. Inteleon brings close to no defensive utility bar a Fire-type move immunity, which means that walls like Corviknight and Goodra are a must-have to make up for the lack of defensive utility; these Pokemon also switch into revenge killing attempts from Slither Wing and Regieleki. Inteleon appreciates Spikes support from Pokemon like Garchomp and Ting-Lu that helps it to wear down RegenVest Pokemon like Meloetta and Alolan Muk.

Physically Defensive.description:
• Corviknight's high physical bulk gives it a strong defensive presence in the tier. It is one of the few consistent counters to strong Ground-types like Great Tusk, physical attackers like Chien-Pao, and some special attackers like non-Choice Specs Iron Bundle. Furthermore, its access to Defog also makes it a solid entry hazard remover, though it struggles against Gholdengo.
  • Body Press provides Corviknight with a way to leverage its high Defense stat, doing significant damage to Fighting-weak Pokemon.
  • Brave Bird allows Corviknight to threaten Flutter Mane and Great Tusk. Alternatively, Iron Head can be used to threaten the former while avoiding recoil damage.
  • Maximum HP investment and enough Defense to check Chien-Pao is combined with Leftovers and 96 Special Defense EVs, which allows Corviknight to take two Mystical Fires from most Flutter Mane, as well as giving it the ability to take on non-Choice Specs Iron Bundle and weaker attacks like Freeze-Dry from Choice Specs Iron Bundle.
  • Tera Steel or Flying can be used to shed the weaknesses of Corviknight's dual typing: Tera Steel allows Corviknight to resist Ice-type attacks from Chien-Pao, while Tera Flying allows Corviknight to resist Great Tusk's Fighting-type attacks. Depending on your choice, Terastallization also amplifies the power of either Iron Head or Brave Bird.
  • Corviknight works well as a part of a defensive core with Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Blissey, which can handle threats like Miraidon that obliterate Corviknight. Additionally, Corviknight makes a great partner for offensive threats like Chi-Yu, which appreciate a teammate that easily switches into Ting-Lu, or Great Tusk, which appreciates opposing Great Tusk being worn down.

Specially Defensive.description:
• Specially defensive Corviknight can switch into foes like Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Gholdengo, and Glimmora.
  • U-turn is used to make Corviknight an effective defensive pivot that can maintain momentum against foes that force it out such as Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Mirror Armor allows Corviknight to check Mystical Fire Flutter Mane, which would otherwise beat it. Alternatively, when paired with Pressure, Protect enables Corviknight to avoid being 2HKOed by Hydro Pump from Choice Specs Iron Bundle, as well as allowing Corviknight to deplete PP with Pressure more effectively.
  • Corviknight can use Tera Steel to get rid of its weakness to Electric and better take on Ice-type moves from Iron Bundle. Alternatively, it can opt to use Tera Ground to become immune to Miraidon's powerful Electro Drift.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight needs help dealing with strong physical wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao from teammates like Dondozo and Scream Tail. Furthermore, Pokemon that are especially threatened by Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, such as Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge, are able to rely on specially defensive Corviknight as a consistent switch-in.

Physically Defensive.description:
Physically defensive Corviknight is a fantastic check to dangerous attackers like Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Dragonite, an effective slow pivot, and one of the few viable entry hazard removers. Brave Bird nails the likes of Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, Meowscarada, Breloom, and Amoonguss, chips at neutral targets such as Azumarill, Hatterene, Dragapult, and Hisuian Zoroark. Body Press is Corviknight's best option against Kingambit and Roaring Moon. Leftovers is the preferred item to provide extra longevity, but Rocky Helmet can further punish physical attackers, especially on weak hits like Scizor's and Meowscarada's U-turn. Tera Water serves as an emergency check to dangerous Fire- and Water-types such as Cinderace and Floatzel. Alternatively, Tera Fighting grants it a resistance to Dark-type attacks and powers up its Body Press, letting it check Kingambit more easily.

Corviknight is a fantastic slow pivot, making it a great partner for frail-but-powerful teammates like Greninja and Iron Valiant. It is also one of the few viable Defoggers, allowing it to partner up with teammates like Dragonite that loathe Stealth Rock. Be warned, Corviknight is utterly unable to Defog against Gholdengo, so secondary entry hazard removal like Great Tusk and a reliable switch-in like Ting-Lu are recommended. Corviknight is unable to handle powerful physical Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge and Electric-types like Iron Hands. Teammates that can cover these weaknesses like Dondozo and Great Tusk are wonderful partners. Its middling special bulk makes teammates like Slowking and Ting-Lu valuable. Slowking has the added benefit of being another slow pivot as well, while Ting-Lu forms a strong entry hazard core with Corviknight and threatens Gholdengo.

Defensive Pivot.description: Corviknight is a poor Defogger in the metagame, but its defensive profile still allows it to check Mega Lopunny, Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Kartana. It also individually beats hazard setters like Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Clodsire. Brave Bird is the preferred option that pressures Dragapult, Zamazenta, Urshifu-R, and Iron Valiant, while Body Press pressures Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Weavile. Iron Defense or Bulk Up can be used over Defog to turn Corviknight into a bulky win condition and to improve its ability to check threats like Kingambit, Urshifu-R, and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Body Press should be used with Iron Defense, while Brave Bird can instead be used with Bulk Up. U-turn allows Corviknight to maintain momentum against the threats that it checks while also bringing in frailer teammates. The given HP and Defense EVs allow Corviknight to live a +2 Continental Crush from Landorus-T, while the rest of the EVs being in Special Defense helps out against Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Rocky Helmet allows Corviknight to chip threats like Mega Lopunny and Weavile. Tera Dragon removes Corviknight's Electric and Fire weaknesses and potentially allows it to turn the tables on Heatran and Rotom-W. Tera Ground can instead be used to halt Volt Switch attempts and surprise Tapu Koko, but the resistances it grants are not as consistently valuable as Dragon. Corviknight's biggest problem by far is Gholdengo, which blocks Corviknight's Defog attempts and sets up on it. Options that deal with it, such as Kingambit, Weavile, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire are therefore mandatory partners. U-turn can bring in the former two to Pursuit trap Gholdengo, while the latter two can stave it off defensively. Kingambit is especially potent with Corviknight, as it appreciates Corviknight's Rocky Helmet applying chip damage onto its checks like Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta. U-turn can also bring in other threats safely, such as Dragapult, Walking Wake, and Heatran. Corviknight's defensive profile gets taken advantage of by threats like Heatran, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona, so options such as your own Heatran, Garchomp, and Toxapex can help out in this regard.

Bulk Up.description: Corviknight is a formidable wincon that takes advantage of its typing and impressive bulk to garner boosts. It also provides a sturdy defensive backbone, consistently checking threats such as Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Dragonite. However, as Corviknight lacks immediate offensive presence and coverage, it suffers from being forced out by the likes of Zapdos and Heatran and being setup fodder from the likes of Kingambit and Gholdengo. Pressure, in conjunction with Substitute, allows Corviknight to PP stall checks like Heatran and Skarmory safely while bypassing status moves like Rotom-W's Will-O-Wisp and Clefable's Thunder Wave. Tera Water improves the matchup against Heatran, Weavile, and Urshifu-R, giving crucial resistances to safely let Corviknight boost up. Alternatively, Tera Dragon lets it take on Electric-types like Zapdos and Rotom-W while also helping against Heatran and Urshifu-R. However, Pokemon like Mega Diancie, Weavile, and Dragapult can now almost always force it out, though they do have to watch out for repeated Brave Bird hits. The given EV spread maximizes special bulk while still being able to survive a +2 Continental Crush from Garchomp followed by Stone Edge after Roost; it also lets Corviknight outspeed Skarmory and become only 3HKOed by Great Tusk's Close Combat. However, note that Corviknight will be taking a super effective Body Press from Skarmory after using Roost. Corviknight fits best on bulkier teams, which appreciate its ability to PP stall threats like Heatran and Toxapex while being a solid wincon. Pokemon like Toxapex and Clefable thus work well with it. Toxapex appreciates Corviknight reliably checking Tapu Lele and Landorus-T for it. In return, Toxapex helps check Weavile, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny, which Corviknight struggles to do. Calm Mind Clefable loves Corviknight draining PP from opposing Toxapex’s Haze; in return, it softens up Heatran. Ground-types like Gliscor and Great Tusk make excellent partners, as they absorb Electric attacks from the likes of Tapu Koko and remove entry hazards from the field. In exchange, Corviknight helps take Kyurem and Iron Valiant’s attacks. Due to Corviknight being walled by Electric- and Steel-types, such as Zapdos and Gholdengo, partners that can threaten them such as Mega Tyranitar and Heatran work well with it.

Physically Defensive (Flying).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defog (Steel).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defog (Flying).description:
Corviknight has easily cemented itself as a staple on Flying teams, acting as an extremely versatile defensive wall that can also remove entry hazards for its teammates. Iron Head allows Corviknight to handle Flutter Mane and other Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Hatterene. Body Press hits Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and other Dark- and Steel-types hard. On the other hand, U-turn safely brings in stronger attackers like Dragonite, Iron Jugulis, and Kilowattrel, providing extra counterplay against Pokemon such as Volcarona and Gholdengo, which commonly switch into Corviknight. Pressure is the preferred ability for PP stalling Stealth Rock, while Mirror Armor counters Flutter Mane and Hatterene, which would otherwise overwhelm Corviknight with Mystical Fire. With the listed EV spread and a Careful nature, Corviknight avoids a 2HKO from Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball while guaranteeing Iron Head OHKOes Flutter Mane in return. The remaining EVs are put into Defense to ease its matchup against physical threats such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Baxcalibur.

Corviknight's capability to take on many offensive threats combined with its Steel typing makes it a stellar asset that almost any offensive Pokemon benefits from. For instance, Iron Jugulis appreciates Corviknight removing Flutter Mane, and Flamigo struggles with Ice Shard variants of Chien-Pao, which Corviknight can safely switch into. Dragonite greatly benefits from Corviknight's ability to soak up Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-type attacks while also covering Corviknight's weaknesses to Fire- and Electric-types such as Cinderace, Magnezone, and Volcarona. Gyarados can also act as a reliable wincon against types like Fire and Ground while also making Chien-Pao significantly more managable with Intimidate. Additionally, Kilowattrel is a great offensive pivot to pair with Corviknight, as it removes threats that could harm Corviknight like Greninja, Volcarona, and Azumarill while also absorbing Electric-type attacks. In return, Corviknight counters Iron Treads and Ting-Lu, which threaten Kilowattrel. Pelipper can be paired with Kilowattrel and Corviknight to form a potent rain core that softens the impact of Fire moves and gives Kilowattrel a Water-type Weather Ball, OHKOing many Fire-types that annoy Corviknight including Skeledirge and Rotom-H. Corviknight appreciates having Talonflame as an alternative option against physical attackers, as Talonflame is able to hold off Chien-Pao and burn Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Dragonite, tremendously easing Corviknight's role.

Bulk Up (Steel).description:
Corviknight is an exceptional wincon for Steel teams due to its unmatched bulk and great dual typing, capable of easily snowballing Ground and Fighting teams. Body Press targets Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon that resist Brave Bird or could take advantage of its recoil like Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Iron Treads, as well as capitalizes off of the Defense boost given by Bulk Up. Alternatively, Taunt prevents Ting-Lu from phazing Corviknight out with Whirlwind and breaks passive teams like Poison due to the prominence of Haze and recovery moves, while Substitute makes it harder to shut down once setup and stalls out Landorus-T's Smack Down. Leftovers provides much-needed recovery and is almost always the preferred item; however, Occa Berry + Body Press can surprise Heatran and Flamethrower Hydreigon. An alternative EV spread of 248 HP / 80 Def / 180 SpD with an Impish nature allows Corviknight to survive Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R after a Swords Dance, as well as prevents Zamazenta from breaking Substitute with Body Press.

Heatran is a great teammate, as it switches into Fire-type moves from Iron Moth, Scovillain, and Moltres and traps and removes Toxapex so Corviknight doesn't need to use Taunt. In return, Corviknight provides an immunity to Ground-type attacks directed at Heatran as well as a Fighting-type neutrality. Gholdengo threatens out Skeledirge and Iron Valiant and takes advantage of walls like Toxapex, opposing Corviknight, and Klefki by setting up Nasty Plot freely. Kingambit checks Ghost-type threats such as Dragapult, Spectrier, and Flutter Mane, as well as heavily wears down teams so Corviknight can setup relatively easily and clean up late-game. Hisuian Goodra is a great specially defenisve tank, taking on Greninja, Basculegion-F, and Volcanion as well as opposing Heatran. Iron Treads offers an Electric-type immunity, handling threats such as Zapdos, Regieleki, and Sandy Shocks, as well as luring Landorus in for a potential KO with Ice Spinner.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Pivot Knight.description:
• Corviknight's fantastic typing makes it one of the best pivots in the metagame; it easily gets dangerous teammates such as Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult in.

  • Body Press versus Iron Head: Body Press has decent damage output and helps massively against common Dark-types like Chien-Pao and Kingambit. Meanwhile, Iron Head ensures that Corviknight will not be walled by Flutter Mane, Mimikyu, and Dragapult.

  • Taunt: Corviknight might not be fast, but it's fast enough to shut down most other defensive Pokemon with Taunt, such as Dondozo and Toxapex.

  • Brave Bird: Brave Bird can be difficult to fit in, but it's a fantastic response against Breloom, and means Corviknight doesn't have to be passive against Amoonguss and Brute Bonnet.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Corviknight's defensive typing is fantastic, so don't Terastallize too hastily, or else it'll lose to threats it normally checks.

  • Dragon: Dragon and Fairy weaknesses are devastating, but in the late-game, resisting Electric and Fire can give Corviknight new win conditions against old foes such as Rotom-W, and a shot to seriously damage Chi-Yu with Body Press. Just note that Modest Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu can still OHKO with Overheat.

  • Fighting: Getting STAB on Body Press can give Corviknight a surprisingly decent chance at cleaning weakened teams, with being able to 3HKO specially defensive Ting-Lu being a highlight.

  • Water: With Tera Water, Corviknight consistently survives all but Modest Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu's Overheat, letting it deal serious damage with Body Press. It also gains a key resistance to Ice for Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur.

  • Flying: While this set doesn't always use Brave Bird, Tera Flying lets Corviknight keep its typing while using Roost, meaning Earthquake and Fissure can no longer hit Corviknight while its restoring health.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: This lets Corviknight wear down physical threats more quickly while pivoting.

  • Safety Goggles: Safety Goggles ensures Corviknight won't be impacted by Spore from Breloom, Amoonguss, or Brute Bonnet, regardless of having Taunt.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers's consistent recovery can be quite helpful for taking repeated hits from Ruination when attempting to stall it out with Pressure.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: Mirror Armor's ability to punish Flutter Mane for using Mystical Fire makes it the best ability choice on Corviknight.

  • Pressure: Corviknight's excellent bulk makes Pressure a good alternative for stalling out foes such as Dondozo, and is particularly good at stalling out Ruination from Ting-Lu and Wo-Chien.

IronPress.description:
• Corviknight stands out as one of the best choices around for sweeping with Iron Defense and Body Press, thanks to its excellent typing and Roost.

  • Taunt: This lets Corviknight effectively shut down slower defensive Pokemon, such as Dondozo and Clodsire.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head helps Corviknight check Mimikyu more easily, especially if not running Rocky Helmet. It also prevents Corviknight from being walled by Flutter Mane and Dragapult.

  • U-turn: While U-turn with this set may seem strange, Corviknight is still a decent pivot even if it must give up Taunt.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Corviknight has a fantastic defensive typing, so only Terastallize if you need to win certain matchups, especially since it becomes vulnerable to Toxic.

  • Fighting: With a Fighting Tera type, Body Press is easier to sweep with, with many Ting-Lu variants now being 2HKOed by boosted Body Press.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Corviknight a way to resist both Chien-Pao's and Chi-Yu's most powerful STAB attacks, though Modest Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu can still OHKO with Overheat.

  • Dragon: A Dragon Tera type lets Corviknight resist common attacks aimed at it, such as Electric- and Fire-type attacks. However, the new weaknesses to Fairy and Dragon make this an especially reactive Terastallization.

  • Flying: A Flying Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing even when using Roost, making it a more reliable check to Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: The passive damage from Rocky Helmet against Mimikyu gives Corviknight a much easier time using Taunt over Iron Head.

  • Covert Cloak: When paired with Taunt, Covert Cloak makes Corviknight an effective Garganacl check, though note Corviknight will no longer drop Flutter Mane's Special Attack with Mirror Armor.

  • Safety Goggles: With Safety Goggles blocking Spore, this Corviknight is now an excellent check against most offensive Breloom, just watch out for the occasional Tera Fire Breloom.

  • Sitrus Berry versus Leftovers: Since this Corviknight attempts to sweep, Sitrus Berry's burst of quick recovery can make it less pressured to spend a turn using Roost. Leftovers on the other hand, will still keep healing Corviknight even after being hit by Ruination, so it can make sense with Pressure.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: Mirror Armor means Flutter Mane can't use Mystical Fire without getting its Special Attack dropped, unless Corviknight is holding Covert Cloak.

  • Pressure: Corviknight's ability to take powerful, low PP moves such as Close Combat after Iron Defense makes Pressure a viable alternative, in addition to giving Corviknight a better chance of dealing with Ruination from Ting-Lu and Wo-Chien effectively.

Bulk Up.description:
• With Bulk Up giving an Attack boost, Corviknight is free from having to use Body Press for good damage output, making it easier to run Taunt against defensive foes without fear of being walled by Ghost-types.

  • Iron Head versus Brave Bird: Iron Head reliably 2HKOs Chien-Pao without a boost, while Brave Bird is the only hope of 2HKOing Chi-Yu.

Other Options

  • Power Trip: Power Trip takes several boosts to get powerful, but it's Corviknight's best shot at dealing decent damage to Gholdengo. It's also an important aspect of Espathra Baton Pass teams, but Ting-Lu has made this team archetype much more difficult to use compared to past regulations.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Remember that most of Corviknight's good Tera types leave it vulnerable to Toxic, so Terastallize carefully and only win a win condition is clear.

  • Flying: This Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing while using Roost, meaning Fissure users such as Dondozo are much easier to handle.

  • Water: Tera Water is an effective tool against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, though note that Choice Specs Chi-Yu can OHKO with Tera Fire boosted Overheat.

  • Dragon: Once Fairy-, Ice-, and Dragon-types are out of the way, the Dragon Tera type allows Corviknight to get around Electric- and Fire-type attacks.

  • Dark: If using Power Trip, Tera Dark is highly recommended to boost its damage output.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: In addition to punishing Flutter Mane for using Mystical Fire when not using Covert Cloak, Mirror Armor also protects Corviknight from Charm, Chilling Water, and Intimidate.

  • Pressure: Pressure is a reasonable alternative for whittling down PP, which can be especially helpful against Ting-Lu's troublesome Ruination.

Items

  • Covert Cloak: When paired with Taunt, Corviknight can effectively take down Garganacl.

  • Safety Goggles: While Substitute and Taunt are effective against slower users of Spore like Amoonguss, Breloom's Speed means Safety Goggles are required to truly check it.

  • Sitrus Berry versus Leftovers: Sitrus Berry is preferred due to the quicker burst of recovery better fitting a sweeper, but Leftovers can work very well with Pressure in an attempt to out-stall Ruination.

Physically Defensive.description: Corviknight's unparalleled role compression as a physical wall, entry hazard remover, and slow pivot that doesn't need Regenerator makes it a defensive staple on the majority of teams. Fluffy provides the most protection against wallbreakers like Choice Band Galarian Zapdos, Iron Boulder, and Roaring Moon while not letting Corviknight fall victim to Scrappy Great Tusk, whereas Intimidate provides additional protection against Chien-Pao and Ogerpon-C at the cost of needing a secondary physical check to deal with the aforementioned threats reliably. Brave Bird is Corviknight's strongest neutral move and hits Ghost-types and key targets like Great Tusk and Galarian Zapdos, while Body Press fits well on Intimidate sets to do more damage to Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-C, and Chien-Pao. Corviknight is exceedingly passive, so it needs powerful and fast offensive teammates like Barraskewda and Azelf to re-gain momentum; in exchange, it provides them safe entry with its slow U-turn and entry hazard removal. Slower wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Ceruledge also appreciate Corviknight's slow pivoting services. Corviknight, especially Fluffy variants, needs a teammate like Swampert, Manaphy, or Well-Baked Body Gholdengo to handle the Fire-types it cannot check. Hazard-weak teammates like Chien-Pao and the Ogerpon formes appreciate Corviknight's ability to remove hazards semi-reliably.

Shell Smash (Rock).description:
Drednaw is a fierce setup sweeper, capable of turning the tide against unfavorable matchups like Ground, Steel, and Water. Stone Edge is Drednaw's hardest hitting move, dealing with Chien-Pao, Pelipper, and Dragonite. Liquidation hits troublesome Ground-types like Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu. Earthquake threatens Water Absorb Clodsire, Toxapex, and Kingambit, while Strong Jaw-boosted Crunch nails switch-ins such as Slowbro, Brambleghast, and Bronzong. Swift Swim is preferred to aid Rock in the matchup against Water rain teams; however, Strong Jaw allows Drednaw to muscle through the aforementioned roadblocks when using Crunch. Air Balloon improves Drednaw's performance in the Ground matchup, allowing for more setup opportunities, while White Herb retains Drednaw's defensive stats to have an improved chance against priority move users like Azumarill, Mimikyu, and Kingambit.

Garganacl's ability to pressure Gastrodon, Quagsire, and Corviknight with Salt Cure is heavily appreciated, easing Drednaw's time sweeping. Glimmora's colorful movepool allows it to check a myriad of threats like Breloom, Meowscarada, and Iron Valiant with Sludge Wave, Great Tusk, Quagsire, and Quaquaval using Energy Ball, Gholdengo, Toxapex, and Toxicroak with Earth Power, and finally Hydreigon, Chien-Pao, and Gallade using Dazzling Gleam. Choice Band Tyranitar heavily dents walls such as Corviknight, Slowbro, and Toxapex and sets up sand to increase Drednaw's bulk. Lycanroc aids in the Dark matchup due to its useful coverage in Close Combat and Play Rough and takes out faster foes like Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane with Accelerock. Coalossal provides entry hazards in Spikes and Stealth Rock, removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin, and helps against Gholdengo and Meowscarada due to its Fire typing.

Physically Defensive (Rock).description:
Coalossal is a decent defensive wall that fits well on Rock teams due to it being able to tank physical hits from Scizor, non-Choice Band Chien-Pao, and Meowscarada, which greatly threaten Rock teams. Coalossal does well in the Steel matchup, as it threatens Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Kingambit. Flame Body allows it to fish for burns to weaken physical threats like Kleavor, Scizor, Kingambit, Mimikyu, and Meowscarada. Body Press is a great move thanks to Coalossal's high Defense stat that allows it to deal incredible damage to Chien-Pao and Kingambit. Rapid Spin combined with Heavy-Duty Boots allows Coalossal to come in and remove hazards without taking any chip damage, so its teammates won't get worn down. Will-O-Wisp allows Coalossal to burn physical threats such as Kleavor, Hoopa-U, and Iron Hands. An alternative EV spread of 252 HP / 92 Def / 164 Spe allows Coalossal to outspeed and burn uninvested Kingambit with Will-O-Wisp. Spikes is another option to run on Coalossal over Will-O-Wisp to help Rock teams stack hazards and wear down foes.

Garganacl helps Coalossal by dealing with defensive Pokemon like Quagsire, Gastrodon, and Heatran with Salt Cure. In return Garganacl appreciates Coalossal checking Meowscarada. Air Balloon Shell Smash Drednaw is another good teammate for Coalossal, providing a soft Ground-type immunity and dealing with Ground- and Steel- types like Landorus-T, Sandy Shocks, Iron Treads, Heatran, and Hisuian-Goodra. Choice Scarf Glimmora with its diverse moveset is another option to pair with Coalossal, as it can outspeed and threaten to OHKO non-Choice Scarf users like Iron Valiant and Greninja. Glimmora can also deal with Water-, Fighting-, Dark-, and Dragon- Types like Quagsire, Hisuian Liligant, Hisuian Samurott, and Hydreigon with its various coverage moves. Furthermore, Glimmora run Air Balloon to act as an alternative Ground-type immunity that can deal with threats like Quagsire and Great Tusk. Tyranitar sets sand for Coalossal to boosts its Special Defense, which can allow Coalossal to tank special attacks from Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Choice Specs Magnezone and threaten them in return. Choice Band Lycanroc-D is a good revenge killer that can help out Coalossal by taking out threats such as Enamorus and Cloyster with Accelerock and Urshifu-R and Clodsire with Psychic Fangs. Hisuian Arcanine is another good revenge killer with Extreme Speed and can act as a wallbreaker, taking out foes such as Toxapex and Clodsire with Head Smash and Flare Blitz, respectively. Kleavor is a good lead for Rock teams, as it can deal damage while setting up Stealth Rock with Stone Axe, which helps with hazard stacking. In return, Coalossal complements Kleavor by dealing with Scizor. Diancie can ease the Fighting match by dealing decent damage to Gallade and Iron Valiant with Moonblast and by being able to take Fighting-type moves due to its Fairy-typing. In return, Coalossal helps Diancie by dealing with Scizor, Kingambit and Meowscarada.

Dragon Dance.description:
Flapple's unique offensive typing, naturally high Attack stat, decent Speed stat, and acess to an amazing boosting move in Dragon Dance allow it to become one of PU's most devastating wallbreakers. Dragon Dance means Flapple is able to boost its damage output while also being able to outspeed common threats such as Charizard, Dachsbun, and Rotom-F. Sucker Punch can gives Flapple priority to finish off weakened foes. Tera Blast can be used with Tera Ground to threaten Steel-types such as Perrserker and Tinkatuff, which would otherwise counter Flapple. On Ripen sets, Flapple can opt for Arcobatics, giving it strong coverage into foes such as Gogoat, Crabominable, and Rabsca. Ripen is normally the preferred ability and should be ran with Sitrus Berry, as it allows Flapple to set up and regain HP on Pokemon such as Carbink and Raichu. However, Heavy-Duty Boots can be ran instead with Hustle for more immediate power. Flapple most commonly runs Tera Dragon, boosting its Outrage to incredible amounts of power, allowing it to OHKO or 2HKO the majority of the tier. Tera Ground gives Flapple a solid defensive typing, allowing it to block Volt Switch from Pokemon like Electrode and Raichu and should be ran with Tera Blast. Finally, Tera Steel gives Flapple a great defensive typing that can allow it to set up on foes it otherwise could not on such as Skuntank and Masquerain.

Flapple's primary struggles are often having issues with setting up safely and Steel-types walling Flapple sets without Tera Blast. Pivots such as Alolan Persian and Rotom-F can help get Flapple in safely to sweep. Alolan Persian is a particularly notable partner, as it can cripple threats that would normally be faster than Flapple even after a boost with Thunder Wave, such as Choice Scarf Skuntank and Lycanroc-N. Fire- and Ground-types such as Charizard and Alolan Dugtrio can check the Steel-types that otherwise give Flapple issues, such as Perrserker and Tinkatuff. In return, Flapple threatens out the defensive Water-types the Fire- and Ground-types would struggle with, such as Whiscash. Poison-types such as Skuntank and Swalot can absorb Toxic Spikes and check opposing Poison-types that cause issues for Flapple. Indeedee-F is also a notable partner, as it can use Healing Wish to heal Flapple back to max health and allow Flapple to be able to set up twice in the game. Spikes from Pokemon such as Carbink and Whiscash help wear down Steel-types for Flapple.

Specially Defensive.description:
Appletun acts as one of the tier's premier special walls thanks to its fantastic defensive typing and plethora of utility options, which let it consistently check Pokemon like Lurantis, Jolteon, and Eelektross. Although Appletun might seem passive, Apple Acid prevents special walls like Umbreon and Ursaring from sitting on it because of the Special Defense drops. Leech Seed helps weaken Poison-, Flying-, and Bug-types like Muk, Articuno, and Scyther that are all capable of shrugging off Apple Acid while also allowing Appletun to check powerful setup sweepers like Coil Eelektross and Dudunsparce thanks to the extra health it provides. Dragon Tail adds another option to deal with setup sweepers while forcing Pokemon that want to switch into Appletun to take another round of entry hazards, working wonderfully in tandem with Spikes setters like Qwilfish. Alternatively, Dragon Pulse makes for a powerful STAB coverage option that can hit Grass-resistant foes like Scyther and Drifblim. Heavy-Duty Boots helps Appletun check strong special attackers like Pyroar, Rotom, and boosted Veluza consistently with hazards up, but Leftovers can also be used for the extra recovery. Tera Steel helps Appletun flip the script on Pokemon like Scyther, Muk, and Tera Ice Jolteon that traditionally answer it. Tera Steel also helps Appletun against Pokemon like Ursaring, Indeedee-F, and Clawitzer that all pack super effective coverage for it.

Because of Appletun's weakness to Poison-types like Muk and Swalot, Sandaconda and Qwilfish make for fantastic defensive partners, also sporting Rocky Helmet to punish U-turns targeted at Appletun. Additionally, Electric-types like Rotom and Eelektross can threaten Flying-types like Scyther and Articuno.

Utility.description:
Sandaconda is one of the best Pokemon in NU and provides teams with several forms of useful utility, including blocking Volt Switch, setting Stealth Rock, spreading paralysis, and sponging Knock Off. Shed Skin lets Sandaconda absorb status and, in combination with Rest, support its team and take on physical attackers like Toxicroak throughout the game. Stone Edge threatens Defoggers and Flying-types like Drifblim and Vivillon and hits Eelektross and Rotom neutrally. Rocky Helmet wears physical attackers like Passimian and Muk down and discourages the use of moves like U-turn, while Leftovers provides Sandaconda passive recovery and makes it less reliant on Rest. Tera Ghost lets Sandaconda completely wall most Fighting-types and other threats such as Zangoose. Tera Dragon is another option that keeps Water- and Grass-types like Bruxish and Lurantis from immediately overwhelming Sandaconda. 80 Speed EVs allow Sandaconda to outrun Drifblim.

Sandaconda can fit well on many different playstyles and will almost always do something for its team. Sandaconda's main flaw is its mediocre special bulk, which, coupled with its weakness to Eelektross's Giga Drain, means it shouldn't be a team's sole response to Electric-types. Pokemon like Chansey, Muk, and Umbreon can serve as backup checks to such foes and also check other special attackers like Cacturne and Zoroark. In addition, Chansey can run Stealth Rock for Sandaconda, thus allowing it to make room for both Glare and EdgeQuake coverage; Muk puts Sandaconda's grounded switch-ins on a timer with Toxic Spikes and annoys setup sweepers like Dudunsparce and Coil Eelektross with Haze; and Umbreon can keep Sandaconda healthy with Wish so it doesn't have to spend as much time asleep. Slower wallbreakers like Medicham and Clawitzer very much appreciate Glare slowing teams down and making them harder to play around.

Coil.description: With rock-solid physical bulk, Shed Skin, and good offensive power, Sandaconda makes for a deadly mid- and late-game Coil sweeper, setting up on Pokemon like Passimian, Muk, and Umbreon. Stone Edge targets Pokemon resistant or immune to Earthquake, like Rotom, Drifblim, and Oricorio. Rest keeps Sandaconda healthy and works well with Shed Skin. Tera Dragon lets Sandaconda set up on Water-types like Vaporeon, Bruxish, and Floatzel as well as Lurantis, while Tera Ghost blanks Fighting-types like Toxicroak and Medicham. Prior to Terastallization, Sandaconda is vulnerable to Water- and Grass-types like Vaporeon, Bruxish, and Cacturne, so checks to them like Toxicroak, your own Cacturne, and Muk can help. Other special attackers like special Dudunsparce and Eelektross can exploit Sandaconda's low special bulk, so special walls like Crabominable and Chansey are good teammates.

Defog.description:
Tera Ground lets Cramorant turn the tables on Electric-types like Eelektross and Rotom, block Volt Switch, and potentially tank coverage moves like Hisuian Sneasel's Gunk Shot in a pinch. Tera Fairy is another option to deal with Tera Dragon Clawitzer as well as check Dark-types like Spiritomb. EV spreads with more physical bulk are also valid to improve Cramorant's matchup against foes like Floatzel, Tera Fighting Passimian, and Poliwrath.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Waterfall may be used to flinch switch-ins, such as Rotom-W, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz, to add extra chip damage; however, Liquidation has a higher Base Power and may provide a Defense drop, significantly hindering their ability to wall Barraskewda.

Choice Band.description:
Barraskewda is a potent wallbreaker due to it's blazing Speed tier, outpacing Flutter Mane and Chien Pao, a great Attack stat, and its ability, Swift Swim, heavily threatening teams with no sturdy resistances to Water like Dark, Fairy, and Flying. Flip Turn forms a pivoting core with teammates like Rotom-W, Pelipper, and Greninja, slowly chipping away at switch-ins like Rotom-W, Corviknight, and Dragonite. Close Combat hits Water-resistant Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra and Empoleon. Ice Fang may be used to hit Dragon-types such as Garchomp and Dragonite. Psychic Fangs nails common switch-ins such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Kommo-o, as well as removes dual screens in the Fairy matchup. Alternatively, Crunch may be used to break Sinistcha, Brambleghast, and Dragapult. A Jolly nature is preferred to outpace Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao outside of rain; however, Barraskewda may opt for an Adamant nature to notably 2HKO Baxcalibur and Zamazenta in rain with Liquidation.

Pelipper sets rain for Barraskewda and brings it in safely with U-turn, as well as weakens walls like Corviknight, Amoonguss, and Toxapex with a Choice Specs set. Gastrodon and Quagsire provide entry hazards and an Electric immunity, allowing Gastrodon to switch into Regieleki and Sandy Shocks while Quagsire walls Iron Hands, Pawmot, and Magnezone. In return, Barraskewda lures in aforementioned Grass-types like Amoonguss and Brambleghast and removes them with the corresponding coverage moves. Toxapex provides a Grass neutrality, notably walling Meowscarada and Ogerpon-W, and offers entry hazards to wear down Barraskewda checks, while Barraskewda removes Ground-types like Landorus, Gliscor, and Mamoswine for it. Empoleon sets up Stealth Rock to wear down Barraskewda's checks as well as walls Dragon-types like Walking Wake and Kommo-o lacking adequate Fighting-type coverage. Quaquaval offers entry hazard removal with Rapid Spin and switches into Steel-types like Empoleon, Hisuian Goodra, and Kingambit. Hisuian Samurott threatens Ghost- and Psychic-type Pokemon like Brambleghast, Slowbro, and Sinistcha while also providing utility support with Knock Off and Spikes set up via Ceaseless Edge. Urshifu-R is great in the Steel and Dark matchups, threatening Hisuian Goodra, Empoleon, and Kingambit. Manaphy forms a wallbreaking core with Barraskewda in the Poison and Steel matchups, taking out Corviknight, Toxapex, and Amoonguss for Barraskewda, while Barraskweda hits Galarian Slowking and Alolan Muk in return. Choice Scarf Walking Wake is great in the Dragon matchup, notably outpacing and removing Baxcalibur, Dragapult, and Kommo-o, while a Choice Specs set weakens walls like Toxapex, Hisuian Goodra, and Slowbro. Basculegion-F is a huge asset in the Ghost and Psychic matchups, taking out Sinistcha, Slowbro, and Brambleghast.

Thanks to its high offensive stats alongside Swift Swim, Choice Band Barraskewda is a premier wallbreaker, offensive pivot, late-game cleaner, and revenge killer on rain teams. Its blistering Speed tier allows it to nearly outpace the entire metagame under rain, including boosted foes like Dragon Dance Dragapult and Mega Swampert. Liquidation's Defense drop lets it potentially 2HKO Pokemon such as Dragapult and Pelipper, while Waterfall's flinches gives Barraskewda slightly better odds to muscle past the likes of Slowbro and Toxapex. Flip Turn keeps up momentum by providing free entry for its teammates while chipping down switch-ins like Dondozo and Tangrowth. Close Combat hits Water-resistant foes such as Ferrothorn, Kartana, and Mega Gyarados, and it provides strong neutral coverage against the likes of Tera Water Great Tusk, Tera Grass Volcarona, and Gastrodon. Aqua Jet prevents Barraskewda from being revenge killed by priority attacks like Kingambit and Mega Mawile's Sucker Punch and—if rain is not active—lets it pick off faster threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill and boosted Volcarona and Iron Valiant. Alternatively, Psychic Fangs pressures Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Water Absorb Clodsire better. Tera Water skyrockets Barraskewda's rain-boosted STAB moves further, potentially 2HKOing even Water-resistant Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Rotom-W. Pelipper is a necessary teammate that spearheads rain teams by reliably summoning rain with Drizzle. Mega Swampert is a fantastic offensive partner that can overwhelm shared checks like Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Slowbro and appreciates Barraskewda's Flip Turn to bring it in safely on foes such as Toxapex, Dragapult, and Dragonite. Tornadus-T and Ferrothorn are rain team staples that support Barraskewda with Knock Off, crippling walls such as Rotom-W and opposing Ferrothorn; Ferrothorn in particular helps threaten Gastrodon with Power Whip and sets entry hazards to soften up foes. The aforementioned Pelipper and Tornadus-T also provide Defog support for Barraskewda to pivot throughout the game unperturbed, bring it in safely via U-turn, and threatens problematic Grass-types like Tangrowth and Tera Grass Heatran.

Rain Sweeper.description: Barraskewda functions as one of the best sweepers on rain Water teams, in part thanks to its high Speed tier, which is increased further under rain due to its ability Swift Swim, allowing it to outspeed the entire tier, as well as its strong coverage options to threaten Water-resistant Pokemon. Liquidation is Barraskewda's strongest spammable STAB option, which under rain 2HKOes Water-resistant targets like Kommo-o after hazard support and OHKOes neutral targets like Iron Valiant and Gholdengo. Flip Turn allows Barraskewda to pivot out of Pokemon like Corviknight and Rotom-W, which are not OHKOed by rain-boosted(AH) Liquidation, while still dealing respectable damage and maintaining momentum to get in its teammates to deal with these Pokemon. Close Combat is the strongest coverage move that Barraskewda has access to and it most notably threatens Ferrothorn, which is able to take Liquidation from Barraskewda. Psychic Fangs in conjunction with an Adamant nature lets Barraskewda 2HKO Mega Venusaur and Toxapex, and its secondary effect of destroying dual screens, while situational, is useful in the Fairy matchup. Crunch is an alternative option to let Barraskewda target Psychic-types like Latios, Mega Latias, and Slowbro, which are able to switch into Liquidation. Poison Jab is also an option to target specifically Tapu Bulu and Azumarill, which resist Liquidation and Close Combat. Barraskewda can run a Jolly nature in order to outspeed base 130 Speed Pokemon outside of rain, in particular Tapu Koko, while also being faster than Mega Lopunny, whereas an Adamant nature can also be run to achieve the aforementioned results with Psychic Fangs. Pelipper is a mandatory partner of Barraskewda, as it not only sets rain but also offers a slow U-turn as a form of pivoting, which lets Barraskewda get on the field safely, and its ability to threaten opposing Grass teams with Hurricane helps Barraskewda get past Pokemon like Mega Venusaur. Mega Swampert can form a potent Swift Swim offensive core with Barraskewda, with its superior bulk and defensive typing allowing it to stay in on certain Pokemon like Baxcalibur to achieve the 2HKO with Earthquake. Swampert also works well with Barraskewda, offering hazard support in Stealth Rock to weaken opposing Pokemon so Barraskewda can secure KOs. It also provides slow pivoting with Flip Turn, and its Ground typing is a must to stave off opposing Electric-types like Regieleki, which are faster than Barraskewda outside of rain. Toxapex is also a strong defensive teammate for Barraskewda, being able to cripple Barraskewda's checks with Toxic and also handle setup sweepers like Mega Altaria and Mega Scizor with Haze. Greninja is able to break past physically defensive walls like opposing Toxapex, Mega Scizor,(AC) and Mega Venusaur, which are reliable answers to Barraskewda, while Greninja appreciates Barraskewda being able to handle specially defensive walls like Blissey and Ting-Lu. Furthermore, Greninja offers Spikes support, which also assists Barraskewda in wallbreaking more efficiently.

Entry Hazard Support (Electric).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Shell Smash.description: Tera Blast in conjunction with Tera Fighting gives Polteageist the necessary coverage to break past Dark-types like Tyranitar, Bisharp, and Iron Jugulis that wall it otherwise. Tera Fighting also allows Polteageist to resist Sucker Punch from Bisharp and Accelrock from Lycanroc-D as well as take neutral damage from Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak.

Uniquely among setup sweepers, Shell Smash + Stored Power gives Polteageist the power to KO most of the tier, the Speed to outspeed most of it, and a tool to plow through Unaware walls, all in one turn. Its Ghost typing also blocks common priority attacks like Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Breloom's Mach Punch, which allows it to sweep even when Psychic Terrain is not active. Though it is resisted by Steel-types, a Psychic Terrain-boosted Stored Power can still heavily damage even Corviknight, 2HKOing physically defensive variants after just one Shell Smash. Shadow Ball is a consistent STAB move with excellent neutral coverage to hit most Steel- and Psychic-types hard, OHKOing Gholdengo and Hatterene. Tera Blast with Tera Fighting fills a gap in Polteageist's coverage, eliminating Dark-types like Roaring Moon, Kingambit while Psychic Terrain is active, and Hydreigon. Tera Fighting can also let it survive their Dark-type attacks. Weak Armor alongside a Focus Sash allows Polteageist to punish a stray physical attack, further boosting its Speed—it can outspeed +1 foes like Roaring Moon, Iron Valiant, and Iron Moth—and Stored Power's damage. Focus Sash also lets Polteageist set up against threats that would otherwise outpace it or survive an attack and OHKO it, such as Kingambit, Choice Specs Dragapult, and offensive Great Tusk. A Timid nature is run to outpace +1 Walking Wake after a single Shell Smash.

Polteageist is a staple on Psychic Terrain offense teams. Indeedee's Psychic Terrain protects Polteageist against priority attacks from Kingambit, Azumarill, and Floatzel while powering up its Stored Power, though Polteageist requires both a Shell Smash and a Weak Armor boost to outpace Swift Swim Floatzel. Indeedee can also let Polteageist set up with Encore or give it a second chance to sweep with Healing Wish, although if Polteageist has already consumed its Focus Sash, it will struggle to set up as reliably a second time. Armarouge is an excellent teammate and another staple on Psychic Terrain teams, as it can eliminate Steel-types like Kingambit with Armor Cannon to enable Polteageist's late-game sweep and it can use Endure to activate Weak Armor multiple times against Dragon Darts Dragapult, which Polteageist cannot reliably set up against. In return, Polteageist can greatly weaken or outright eliminate Unaware walls, set up against specially offensive Dragapult if its Focus Sash is intact, and can safely utilize Tera Fighting to eliminate Roaring Moon and wear down Ting-Lu, which allows Armarouge to sweep. Entry hazard removal is extremely important to maintain Focus Sash's protection. Eject Pack Great Tusk provides both Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock support, can safely get Polteageist in after using a strong Headlong Rush or Close Combat, and can also switch into and threaten Dark-types for Polteageist. Magic Bounce Hatterene deters entry hazards, spreads paralysis with Nuzzle, and can provide Healing Wish support. Also, Eject Button lets it safely pivot Polteageist in, even against U-Turns from Corviknight, Cinderace, or Meowscarada, giving it much easier setup opportunities. Setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Dragapult appreciate Polteageist breaking past Unaware walls and wearing down Steel-types. In return, Dragapult can use its multi-hit attacks to threaten opposing Psychic Terrain teams.
The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Polteageist is a dangerous setup sweeper and cleaner thanks to Shell Smash, Stored Power, and its excellent Special Attack, allowing it to sweep with a single turn of setup. Giga Drain provides coverage for Ting-Lu and Garganacl, Strength Sap gives Polteageist a way to restore its Focus Sash after chip damage and set up on weaker physical attackers, while Substitute allows for safe setup on status-reliant walls like Blissey. Focus Sash the preferred item to safely ensure Polteageist can use Shell Smash. Polteageist can often struggle to get itself onto the field safely, so it appreciates a slow pivot from Corviknight or Shed Tail Cyclizar who can also facilitate Polteageist's setup with screens or a passed Substitute. Polteageist pairs well with physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Cinderace that can break through opposing walls. Due to its reliance on Focus Sash, Polteageist needs reliable entry hazard removal like Cyclizar and Iron Treads.

Defensive.description:
Mystical Fire threatens Steel-types like Orthworm and Alolan Dugtrio, whereas Draining Kiss hits Dark-types like Morpeko and Spiritomb. Eviolite gives Hattrem an easier time taking hits from foes like Hisuian Sneasel and entry hazard setters like Orthworm and Whiscash. Eject Button is an alternative for offensive teams, which don’t always need to preserve Hattrem and benefit a lot from immediate momentum. The Speed investment lets Hattrem outrun uninvested base 50s such as Muk and Perrserker.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Magic Bounce Support.description:
Hattrem's positive matchup against common entry hazard setters like Sandaconda and Qwilfish makes it a valuable support option for hazard-vulnerable Pokemon like Tauros and Choice Scarf Scyther. It can also use Nuzzle to paralyze and check Pokemon that rely on their speed like Tauros, Hisuian Sneasel, and Mesprit, helping slower teammates such as Toxicroak, Abomasnow, and Samurott dish out powerful attacks without needing to worry about getting outsped and taking a hit. Rest + Sleep Talk gifts Hattrem longevity and lets it continuously check Tauros, Medicham, and Muk. Tera Fairy lets Hattrem check Dark-types like Mabosstiff and Hisuian Qwilfish while still maintaining a Fighting-type resistance.

Thanks to Hattrem’s Magic Bounce Pokemon crippled by hazards like Muk, Eelektross, and especially Choice Scarf Scyther can do their job without worrying about being chipped down. When fully invested into physical bulk, Hattrem can fall short against special wallbreakers like Clawitzer, Magneton, and Samurott. Special walls like Blissey, Umbreon, and Articuno compensate for this and also appreciate Hattrem’s Fighting resistance. Hazard setters that can beat Hattrem like Bombirdier and Hisuian Qwilfish are troublesome, so additional hazard control from teammates is appreciated. Hattrem heavily relies on its Eviolite, so Knock Off absorbers like Sandaconda or Sticky Hold Muk are greatly appreciated as partners. Hattrem is best paired with a second physically defensive wall like Avalugg or Sandaconda as it can be easily overpowered if used alone.

Trick Room Sweeper.description:
• Mystical Fire lets Hatterene deal decent damage to Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Kingambit, which it would otherwise fail to hit effectively.

  • Covert Cloak renders Hatterene immune to the secondary effects of moves like Snarl and Fake Out, which, combined with Magic Bounce, greatly limits the ways the opponent can deal with it. Life Orb makes Hatterene a far more threatening sweeper but noticeably hinders its longevity, leaving it more vulnerable to revenge killing from powerful priority moves.

  • Tera Fire lets Hatterene turn the tables on Steel-types, such as Gholdengo looking for a quick KO before it sets up Trick Room. Tera Fairy removes Hatterene's weakness to Ghost and makes Dazzling Gleam hit harder. Tera Steel gives Hatterene a slew of resistances and allows it to surprise Fairy-types like Sylveon with a super effective Tera Blast. Steel-type Tera Blast also OHKOes Garganacl, which would otherwise wall it endlessly. Tera Psychic gives Hatterene a boosted STAB option that isn't resisted by Fire-types.

  • Shadow Ball is a niche option to cover common Ghost- and Psychic-types. After You allows Hatterene to support Pokemon with higher Speed during Trick Room, such as Meowscarada and Gengar. Focus Sash is an option if Hatterene doesn't run a defensive Tera type.

Bulky Calm Mind.description:
• Hatterene is mostly used to deny entry hazards on offensive teams to allow threats to come in unscathed, and stall teams so they have breaking power and an easier time against hazards.
  • The combination of Draining Kiss and Calm Mind with Defense investment helps Hatterene take hits from common walls like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu well, using them for recovery or setup.
  • Psyshock and Stored Power are interchangeable, as Psyshock is better on more balance and offensive teams due to its immediate power, while Stored Power fits better on bulkier teams, helping them break past walls the teams would otherwise struggle with like Dondozo.
  • Mystical Fire is useful coverage to hit Steel-types, such as Corviknight and Iron Treads, while Protect is used to scout double switches, scout Choice item uses, and rack up Leftovers recovery.
  • The Speed EVs are to outspeed Dondozo.
  • Tera Water provides Hatterene with a Fire resistance and Ghost neutrality to better deal with Koraidon and Flutter Mane. Additionally, Tera Water Hatterene resists Steel-type moves from Kingambit and Corviknight and resists Ice- and Water-type moves, allowing Hatterene to tank hits from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle more effectively.
  • Tera Flying gives Hatterene immunity to Ground-type moves from Ting-Lu and Great Tusk while also resisting Fighting moves from Koraidon and Great Tusk. It also gives Hatterene a Spikes immunity, giving it easier entry against offensive teams.
  • Stealth Rock-weak Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle are great partners to Hatterene, since they benefit from Hatterene denying Stealth Rock.
  • Koraidon and Miraidon are great partners, since Hatterene can break their most common checks, being Great Tusk and Toxapex for Koraidon, and Ting-Lu and Clodsire for Miraidon. Hatterene benefits from the breaking power of the Dragon-types, since they can remove offensive threats that annoy Hatterene like Flutter Mane and Miraidon.

Calm Mind.description:
Calm Mind Hatterene is an excellent option on balance teams to deny entry hazards from being set up. With Magic Bounce, it can switch into and reflect entry hazards from Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Blissey. From there, it can begin setting up Calm Mind to pose a greater threat itself and overwhelm the opponent's defensive answers to it. Draining Kiss acts as pseudo-recovery and can help Hatterene heal off damage it's taken from Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk. Psyshock allows Hatterene to deal high damage to special walls such as Blissey and Clodsire and win potential setup wars against other Hatterene. Stored Power fulfills a similar role to Psyshock in enabling Hatterene to break through special walls and other Calm Mind users and can also help Hatterene defeat various Unaware Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Dondozo, but it requires Hatterene to set up multiple Calm Minds before it becomes truly potent. Mystical Fire deals high damage to many of Hatterene's common switch-ins such as Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Kingambit and has the nice bonus of lowering the target's Special Attack, which is particularly useful against Gholdengo that aren't running Covert Cloak. Nuzzle is another option to cripple switch-ins with paralysis, which can act as useful speed control for Hatterene's teammates. Substitute is another alternative that allows Hatterene to more easily set up in the face of weak hits such as Garganacl's Salt Cure and Clodsire's Earthquake. Tera Water nullifies all of Hatterene's weaknesses, which can grant it more opportunities to use Calm Mind against its checks such as Gholdengo, while Tera Fire can similarly neutralize all of Hatterene's weaknesses and comes with additional benefits such as boosting the damage of its Mystical Fire and letting it check Iron Valiant better. However, Tera Fire also comes with notable downsides, namely giving Hatterene a weakness to Ground-type moves and Stealth Rock, which can hinder its matchups against common entry hazard setters. The EV spread allows Hatterene to move reliably switch into physical attacks from common entry hazard setters while also outspeeding Toxapex and Garganacl.

Hatterene's ability to discourage the use of entry hazards will be appreciated by almost any team. Pokemon vulnerable to entry hazards and those that frequently pivot in and out of battle such as Meowscarada, Gholdengo, Garganacl, and Dragapult enjoy Hatterene's support. Entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Corviknight are also good partners, as Hatterene's presence can ease the burden placed on them to remove entry hazards and grants the team greater flexibility in dealing with entry hazard setters. Furthermore, while Hatterene can switch into entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk, it can be worn down quickly from their repeated Ground-type attacks. Great Tusk and Corviknight can reduce Hatterene's need to switch in as often by acting as alternative switch-ins. Due to relying on Leftovers and Draining Kiss for recovery, Hatterene can struggle to stay healthy, particularly if it loses its Leftovers to Knock Off or is hit by Salt Cure, so it is recommended to have teammates that can switch into these moves. Corviknight can switch into Knock Off from hazard setters such as Meowscarada and Great Tusk, while Covert Cloak Gholdengo can neutralize Salt Cure. Pokemon holding Rocky Helmet such as Corviknight can be troublesome for Hatterene, as they will wear Hatterene down when it uses Nuzzle or Draining Kiss. Covert Cloak users, especially Gholdengo, are similarly irritating for Hatterene due to nullifying the secondary effect of its Nuzzle or Mystical Fire. Knock Off support from Meowscarada, Great Tusk, and Iron Valiant is thus appreciated to remove these items from the opponent's Pokemon. Hatterene's weakness to Steel- and Ghost-type attacks can be exploited by strong attackers such as Gholdengo, Dragapult, and Kingambit. Kingambit and Tera Water Garganacl can reliably switch into Gholdengo and Dragapult, while Great Tusk and Dondozo can counter Kingambit.

Healing Wish.description:
Thanks to Magic Bounce and Eject Button, Hatterene functions as a pivot on offensive teams that heavily benefit from keeping entry hazards off of their side. Healing Wish trades Hatterene in exchange for fully healing one of its teammates, allowing wallbreakers such as Kingambit and Roaring Moon to effectively weaken the opposing team twice; Healing Wish has the added benefit of providing teammates with a free switch in and thus maximizing the turns field conditions such as Psychic Terrain, sun, and dual screens are active. Psychic and Dazzling Gleam are STAB moves that let Hatterene remain threatening against hazard setters such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Garchomp. Nuzzle punishes setup sweepers such as Dragonite that would otherwise set up in front of Hatterene. Alternatively, Mystical Fire lets Hatterene punish Steel-types such as Kingambit and Gholdengo that try to switch into it. Eject Button lets Hatterene sponge hits for its teammates and brings an offensive Pokemon safely onto the field. The Speed EVs allow Hatterene to outspeed Ting-Lu and paralyzed Adamant Dragonite, while the rest of its EVs are dedicated to its bulk. Tera Steel removes all of Hatterene's weaknesses which can, in turn, allow it to use Healing Wish in front of Pokemon that would otherwise directly threaten it such as Dragapult, Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Glimmora.

Healing Wish Hatterene finds a place on hyper offense, sun, and Psychic Terrain teams, which all enjoy Hatterene's ability to stop entry hazards from going up and breaking Focus Sash and severely chipping Pokemon weak to Stealth Rock while also keeping momentum thanks to Eject Button. As such, Pokemon usually seen on these archetypes like Dragonite, Ceruledge, Iron Moth, Roaring Moon, and Walking Wake, as well as Focus Sash users such as Breloom, Armarouge, and Polteageist, enjoy the presence of Hatterene. Offensive pivots such as Roaring Moon and Cinderace invite in defensive walls like Dondozo and Toxapex, against which Hatterene can use Healing Wish safely.
