Alternatively, Heavy-Duty Boots lets it switch in more against entry hazard-stacking teams that run Spikes as well, but this may require Wish support for Kingambit to consistently succeed in its role. Covert Cloak is a reliable item to avoid annoying secondary effects such as burns, Salt Cure, and stat drops. Metal Coat and Black Glasses are viable alternative item choices, as they work with Supreme Overlord's multiplier.

The given EV spread lets Kingambit outspeed uninvested slow Pokemon in the tier that would outspeed it otherwise such as Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Sylveon. Tera Flying allows it to completely flip its type matchup, as it makes Kingambit immune to Spikes, resist Fighting-type moves, and immune to Ground-type moves, letting it stay in against Pokemon like Great Tusk, which would otherwise be a fantastic check to Kingambit. Tera Steel allows it to maintain its Mortal Spin blocking capabilities while boosting the power of Behemoth Blade or Behemoth Bash and remaining resistant to Stealth Rock. Good partners are Pokemon that can pivot Kingambit in safely such as Toxapex. Rotom-W and Sandy Shocks are valuable partners against physical walls such as Dondozo and Great Tusk.

Swords Dance Kingambit excels as a mid-game wallbreaker that can boost on passive foes and tear through the opponent's team with its Adaptability-boosted STAB attacks. Kowtow Cleave and Iron Head are Kingambit's main attacks, heavily damaging defensive pivots like Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, Scream Tail, and Garganacl. Sucker Punch lets it predict and punish faster attackers like Quaquaval, Volcarona, and Slither Wing that try and come in to revenge kill. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed uninvested Corviknight and Skeledirge. Black Glasses lets Kingambit OHKO Iron Moth with Sucker Punch. Immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater are options to pick up additional setup chances. Fast endgame sweepers like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Hisuian Electrode benefit from Kingambit's early-game presence, capitalizing on chipped foes and scoring easy KOs. Defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Fluffy Landorus-T can thwart revenge killers targeting Kingambit and use U-turn to bring it in safely again. Finally, Primordial Sea Zapdos can help Kingambit by forcing Corviknight and Quaquaval, two of its most consistent checks, letting it chip them on their switch-in repeatedly.

Thanks to Supreme Overlord, STAB-boosted Sucker Punch acting as vital priority, and its high Attack, Kingambit cements itself as a good late-game cleaner and revenge killer, that offensively checks Arceus and Calyrex-S. Swords Dance-boosted Kowtow Cleave allows Kingambit to 2HKO Toxapex and Landorus-T. Iron head hits Arceus-Fairy and other Tera Fairy Pokemon such as Toxapex and Skeledirge. Dread Plate is the preferred item of choice because it boosts Kingambit's Dark-type moves, allowing Sucker Punch to more effectively clean up late-game. Alternatively, Leftovers provides Kingambit with more longevity throughout the game, allowing it to potentially outlast its checks. 132 Speed EVs allow Kingambit to outspeed Skeledirge. Tera Dark boosts Kingambit's Dark-type moves to horrifying levels, allowing it to OHKO Landorus-T, Eternatus, offensive Arceus-Ground, and Miraidon at +2, and OHKO Toxapex with 1 layer of Spikes at +2. +2 Tera Dark Sucker Punch with 5 allies fainted allows Kingambit to achieve amazing feats, such as OHKOing Extreme Killer Arceus and offensive Arceus-Ground, as well as 2HKOing Koraidon and Zacian-C after 1 layer of Spikes. On the other hand, Tera Flying lets Kingambit set-up against Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Arceus-Ground, Landorus-T, and Koraidon. Tera Fire makes Kingambit immune to Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge, Giratina-O, and defensive Arceus formes and gives it a much-needed resistance to attacks like Koraidon's Flare Blitz and Zacian-C's STAB moves. Kingambit struggles with Toxapex, Landorus-T, and defensive Arceus formes, so offensive checks to them such as Arceus-Ground, Calyrex-S, and Miraidon are appreciated. Kingambit also struggles with Koraidon and Arceus-Ground, so checks to them such as Toxapex, Landorus-T, and Ting-Lu are appreciated. Teammates such as Arceus, Koraidon, and Zacian-C weaken physical walls like Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Landorus-T for Kingambit. Arceus in particular shares the burden of checking Calyrex-S alongwith Kingambit. Glimmora as a suicide lead can set up entry hazards, which Kingambit appreciates to break through defensive Arceus formes.

Offensive.description: Great Tusk possesses a lot of invaluable traits with its amazing physical bulk, solid defensive typing, and role compression, all contributing to making it a good Pokemon. Earthquake can be used over Headlong Rush to have a strong STAB without drawbacks, but the power difference is noticeable. Stealth Rock can be used over Close Combat if the team lacks a Stealth Rock setter, but leaves Great Tusk unable to dent Rotom-W and Ting-Lu. Rapid Spin is essential, since it both boosts Great Tusk's Speed and clears entry hazards, which it won’t have a hard time doing against common hazard setters like Landorus-T and Garchomp. Icium Z + Ice Spinner lets it destroy switch-ins like Zapdos and Tornadus-T while also chipping down Moltres for a good amount of damage. Tera Water lets it emergency check Urshifu-R, while Tera Ground lets it deal large amounts of damage with Headlong Rush against Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Volcarona. Tera Steel lets Great Tusk eat a hit from Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant in a pinch, but gaining a Fighting weakness isn’t so desirable. Great Tusk hates having to deal with Zapdos and Moltres due to being threatened by Static and Flame Body, so Pokemon that can deal with them, such as Tapu Koko and Mega Tyranitar, are appreciated. In return, it clears hazards for both of them and beats their checks like Ferrothorn and Ting-Lu.

Defensive.description: Defensively, Great Tusk is a behemoth that is able to shrug off hits from threats like Mega Lopunny and Dragonite while providing the team with good utility options. Ice Spinner helps Great Tusk to not be fodder against Gliscor, Tornadus-T and Zapdos. Body Press lets it deal with Mega Lopunny and pressure Ferrothorn. 56 Speed EVs let it outspeed Garchomp after one speed boost from Rapid Spin. Tera Water lets it check Pokemon like Mega Swampert and Urshifu-RS in a pinch. Tera Dragon allows it to check Ogerpon-W, and deal with Heatran better. Tera Poison provides a useful Toxic immunity. Great Tusk is often set up fodder for Pokemon like aforementioned Iron Valiant, so Pokemon that can deal with it, like Volcarona and Galarian Slowking, are appriciated. In return, it checks Mega Tyranitar and Gliscor for them while also providing Rapid Spin support.

Defensive Bulk Up.description: Bulk Up boosts Great Tusk’s already high Attack and Defense even further, allowing it to brute force past would-be checks like Ferrothorn, Alomomola, and opposing Great Tusk, turning them into set-up fodder with Terastallization. Earthquake is chosen over Headlong Rush, as the damage is sufficient with Bulk Up boosts, and the Defense and Special Defense drops can make Great Tusk easier to revenge kill. Ice Spinner lets it break past Pokemon like Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Landorus. Rapid Spin acts as a secondary boosting move for Great Tusk, alleviating its mediocre Speed tier and allowing it to sweep undeterred. The given EV spread allows Great Tusk to outspeed Ogerpon-W after a Rapid Spin boost, with the rest used to maximize its physical bulk. Tera Poison prevents Great Tusk from being hit by Toxic while providing crucial resistances to Fairy- and Fighting-type attacks. Tera Electric provides a Flying resistance, allowing Great Tusk to use Zapdos and Tornadus-T as setup fodder while also preventing it from getting paralyzed by Static. Tera Steel combines the Flying resistance from Electric with the Fairy resistance and Toxic immunity from Poison while adding on a Psychic resistance at the cost of being weak to Fighting. Due to its relatively low Speed tier even after a boost, Great Tusk will need help against revenge killers like Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, so Pokemon that can handle the two, such as Mega Scizor, Slowking-G, and Heatran, are appreciated. A more offensive set utilising Booster Energy can also be used on hyper offense teams, but it is generally less effective compared to other choices.

Booster Energy (Speed).description:
• Bulk Up further boosts Great Tusk's naturally high Attack and Defense stats.
  • Booster Energy lets Great Tusk outspeed Meowscarada, Annihilape, and Corviknight.
  • Knock Off can be used to remove Choice items from Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Magnezone.
  • Great Tusk’s EV spread allows for maximum Attack while still procuring the Speed boost from its Booster Energy. The HP investment increases Great Tusk's bulk and ensures its HP remains odd to have a better matchup against Leech Seed.
  • Due to Great Tusk's low Special Defense stat, it's weak to bulky special attackers such as Weakness Policy or Air Balloon Gholdengo and Skeledirge.
  • Great Tusk is strong against Pokemon that it is able to outspeed due to Booster Energy and should use a damaging move against Choice Specs Iron Bundle, Meowscarada, and Chien Pao.

Attack Booster.description:
• Bulk Up allows Great Tusk to reliably beat Choice Band Iron Hands and Choice Band Annihilape. When combined with Taunt, Bulk Up gives Great Tusk a reliable matchup into common Annihilape sets, as the moves work together to disallow Annihilape's own Bulk Up + Taunt combination while playing around Annihilape's Rage Fist and Counter.
  • Close Combat lets Great Tusk reliably beat Slaking, while Knock Off is useful to beat Choice item Magnezone.
  • The Defense EVs let Great Tusk survive Jolly Choice Band Slaking's Giga Impact, while the Speed EVs let it outspeed Adamant Choice Band Slaking.
  • Against non-Air Balloon Skeledirge, Great Tusk has a choice to use either Headlong Rush or Taunt. Headlong Rush OHKOes most Skeledirge sets, like Mental Herb Skeledirge, but has a low chance to OHKO defensive Weakness Policy Skeledirge, which can OHKO in return with Weakness Policy-boosted Blast Burn. However, if Skeledirge uses Will-O-Wisp, Great Tusk's Headlong Rush 2HKOes it. Great Tusk can use Taunt to stop Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp, but this loses to Skeledirge's Torch Song.
  • If Air Balloon Skeledirge uses Will-O-Wisp on the first turn, Great Tusk has to correctly predict this and use Taunt to win. If Skeledirge does not use Will-O-Wisp, Great Tusk can use Knock Off into Headlong Rush to win. However, if Air Balloon Skeledirge uses Torch Song on the first turn while Great Tusk uses Taunt, Skeledirge would win.
  • Against Magnezone, Great Tusk can use Knock Off into Headlong Rush to play around Choice Specs Magnezone's Hyper Beam.
  • If using Knock Off over Close Combat, Great Tusk should use Headlong Rush twice to 2HKO Jolly Choice Band Slaking; however, against Adamant Choice Band Slaking, Great Tusk should use Bulk Up followed by Headlong Rush twice to win.

Choice Scarf.description:
• With maximum Attack and Speed EVs and Choice Scarf, Great Tusk can outspeed and OHKO Meowscarada, non-Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao.
  • Megahorn is for Brute Bonnet and some Wo-Chien
  • Fire Fang is for Scizor.
  • Head Smash is for Volcarona and Iron Jugulis.
  • Heavy Slam is for some Sylveon.
  • Due to Great Tusk's low Special Defense, it is weak to special attackers like Skeledirge, Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, Babiri Berry Sylveon, and Iron Valiant.
  • Since Great Tusk will be locked into an attacking move, opposing Annihilape can set up with Bulk Up and OHKO Great Tusk afterwards.

Choice Band.description:
• Heavy Slam is likely to OHKO non-Babiri Berry defensive Sylveon.
  • Head Smash OHKOes Stall Talonflame, Choice Scarf Meowscarada, and bulky Volcarona. However, other variants of these Pokemon can still beat Choice Band Great Tusk.
  • Knock Off 2HKOes non-bulky Magnezone while removing its item as well as OHKOing Farigiraf.
  • Megahorn OHKOes Iron Leaves and non-Protect Espathra.
  • Ice Spinner OHKOs Garchomp and non-defensive Substitute Roaring Moon so Great Tusk need not risk lowering its Defense from hitting Substitute with Close Combat. However, this will lose against defensive Roaring Moon that use Acrobatics turn 1.
  • Using a Jolly nature allows Great Tusk to outspeed and OHKO non-Choice Scarf Gardevoir and Adamant Slaking. Adamant allows it to reliably OHKO non-Babiri Berry defensive Sylveon with Heavy Slam, have a high chance to OHKO non-defensive Azumarill and Scizor with Headlong Rush, and occasionally OHKO Air Balloon Skeledirge with Head Smash.

Bulk Up (Ground).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Utility (Fighting).description:
Boasting impressive bulk, Great Tusk is a physical wall for Fighting teams that can pivot in and out around hard hitting physical attackers such as Iron Hands and Kingambit. Earthquake is a powerful STAB move that threatens Poison-types such as Clodsire and Toxapex. Knock Off complements Great Tusk's ability to spin by strongly hitting Ghost-types such as Brambleghast, Gholdengo, and Dragapult hard while also removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Lastly, Great Tusk provides Stealth Rock support for the team, which helps to break Focus Sash on Breloom. Heavy-Duty Boots is the premier choice, as it allows Great Tusk to spin away hazards without being poisoned by Toxic Spikes or worn down by Spikes. Leftovers is a solid alternative to provide Great Tusk with passive recovery, but generally avoiding hazard damage is more important. The EV spread outpaces neutral nature Tyranitar and uninvested Brambleghast while maximizing Great Tusk's physical bulk.

Assault Vest Iron Hands is a great partner to Great Tusk, sponging special hits aimed at it while also threatening Pokemon such as Choice Specs Pelipper and Hatterene. Iron Hands also appreciates Great Tusk's ability to keep entry hazards off the field so it doesn't get worn down. Wallbreakers such as Iron Valiant and Breloom appreciate Great Tusk's ability to threaten Poison-types such as Clodsire and Skuntank, allowing them to continue rampaging against the opponent. Due to it being an amazing special attacker, Iron Valiant in particular can threaten physical walls like Quagsire, Sableye, and Dondozo, which like to switch into Great Tusk. Choice Scarf users such as Flamigo, Quaquaval, and Slither Wing pressure special attackers faster than Great Tusk such as Choice Specs Greninja, Dragapult, and opposing Iron Valiant. Gallade is also a really nice partner to handle Pokemon such as Amoonguss, who would otherwise beat Great Tusk one-on-one, thanks to its Psychic STAB attacks.

Choice Scarf (Ground).description:
Choice Scarf Great Tusk is an exceptional revenge killer because of its great bulk, terrifying Attack stat, and unique STAB combination, allowing it to pummel many threats like Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Flutter Mane. Earthquake may be used instead of Headlong Rush to avoid contact and the stat drops at the cost of dealing less damage. Ice Spinner hits Dragonite and Garchomp. Knock Off greatly hinders Leftovers-reliant Pokemon like Bronzong and Rotom-W, and it leaves common Heavy-Duty Boots users such as Slowbro and Amoonguss to be susceptible to entry hazards from teammates like Clodsire and Ting-Lu.

Iron Treads, Quagsire, and Ting-Lu are great switch-ins to faster threats such as Choice Scarf Greninja and Gengar, as well as Baxcalibur after a Dragon Dance. Clodsire appreciates the removal of Ground-types like Ting-Lu and Iron Treads as well as the aforementioned Ice-types and Gastrodon appreciates the removal of Grass-types such as Meowscarada and Breloom. In return, Clodsire and Gastrodon switch into Water-type attacks from Quaquaval and Pelipper and set entry hazards to enhance Great Tusk's wallbreaking. Furthermore, Clodsire cripples Quagsire and Rotom-W with Toxic and Gastrodon prevents setup with Clear Smog. Sandy Shocks and Garchomp can aid against Corviknight and Amoonguss to alleviate Steel and Poison matchups, respectively.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Offensive.description:
• Great Tusk's primal physical prowess and great support options make it a good choice for a bulky Fighting-type.

  • Earthquake versus Headlong Rush: Headlong Rush's defensive drops and vulnerability to Rocky Helmet make it a riskier option than Earthquake, but the extra power OHKOes maximum HP Gholdengo.

  • Ice Spinner: This is highly recommended to avoid getting walled by Dragonite before it Terastallizes, while also dealing good damage to common Tera Flying Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Kingambit.

  • Rapid Spin: Great Tusk is one of the best Rapid Spin users, being able to take advantage of it offensively and heavily pressuring Ting-Lu to Terastallize or switch out.

  • Knock Off: Beyond the usefulness of removing items, this is Great Tusk's best move against Air Balloon Gholdengo.

Other Options

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb is a good speed control option, great for breaking through Dragonite's Multiscale while nullifying its potential Speed boost, while letting other teammates take advantage of speed control. It also lets Great Tusk hit troublesome Focus Sash Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane and Gengar, something Rapid Spin can't do.

  • Iron Head: If using Tera Steel, Iron Head is a decent option for OHKOing Flutter Mane without using Headlong Rush, and it deals heavy damage to Baxcalibur and Tera Fairy Rotom-W.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Terastallization can help with Great Tusk's poor special bulk by resisting certain hits, but it works fine without it.

  • Steel: Tera Steel greatly aids against the many Fairy-, Ice-, and Flying-types that would otherwise prey on Great Tusk, such as Mimikyu, Iron Bundle, and Tera Flying Dragonite.

  • Water: Tera Water massively improves the matchup against Chien-Pao, and can let Great Tusk survive an encounter with offensive Iron Moth or Chi-Yu that lack Choice Specs.

  • Ground: The furious increase in power Tera Ground provides can be useful late game, giving Earthquake a high chance to OHKO even defensive Gholdengo and Headlong Rush the ability to 2HKO Terastallized Skeledirge.

  • Fighting: Not only does Tera Fighting improve the Chien-Pao matchup, but it OHKOs even the bulkiest Ting-Lu with Close Combat.

Items

  • Assault Vest: This patches up Great Tusk's poor Special Defense, which can be paired with the correct Tera Type to help against foes like Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, Iron Moth, and Chi-Yu.

  • Booster Energy: When saving Great Tusk for late-game sweeps, Booster Energy is preferred over Life Orb for preserving its HP against priority attacks.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash on such a bulky Pokemon may seem wasteful, but it vastly improves Great Tusk's matchups against special attackers such as Rotom-W and makes setting up Stealth Rock a far simpler task. If using Focus Sash, consider using the first alternate EV spread below.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 12 Def / 236 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: This EV spread survives Adamant Focus Sash Meowscarada's Flower Trick followed by Sucker Punch, making it a good spread to use if using Focus Sash and Rapid Spin.

Assault Vest EV Spreads

  • All of these EV spreads will at least avoid a 2HKO from Modest Flutter Mane's Mystical Fire if using Tera Steel. If using a different Tera type, 16 Special Defense EVs can be redistributed.

  • 52 HP / 148 Atk / 4 Def / 164 SpD / 140 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom, and the rare Timid Abomasnow.

  • 4 HP / 44 Atk / 4 Def / 164 SpD / 244 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread is for Rapid Spin, outspeeding Iron Bundle after a Speed boost.

Bulk Up.description:
• Great Tusk's fantastic Defense stat makes it a great option for setting up Bulk Up late-game.

  • Taunt versus Substitute: Taunt preys on defensive Pokemon such as Wo-Chien and Corviknight, while Substitute protects Great Tusk from Garganacl's Salt Cure. Dragon Tail from Garchomp and Dragonite, and OHKO moves from the likes of Dondozo and Kingambit.

  • Ice Spinner: Dragonite is such a problematic foe that hitting it hard is worth more than a Fighting-type STAB move.

Other Options

  • Body Press: Although it is difficult to fit in without sacrificing utility or coverage, Body Press is a reasonable option if a Fighting-type STAB move is needed.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat does not gel well with the defensive nature of this set, but it deals far more damage to Ting-Lu than any of Great Tusk's other options.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Great Tusk is a good bulky sweeper on its own, but Terstallization makes it far more difficult to revenge kill.

  • Water: Not only is Tera Water an excellent option against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, but it also means Dondozo will never break Great Tusk's Substitute with Wave Crash, and Assault Vest Azumarill become an easy target to set up on.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is a great option for dealing with Great Tusk's weaknesses, such as Fairy-types and makes Iron Bundle usually fail to 2HKO specially defensive Great Tusk without Choice Specs.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is a decent alternative to Tera Steel, providing the vital Fairy-type resistance without the weaknesses to Fighting- and Fire-type attacks and an extremely useful immunity to being poisoned that eases the match-up against Toxic Spikes foes such as Clodsire and Meowscarada.

  • Fire: Fire is not a great defensive type; however, not only does it do well against Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane, it also protects Great Tusk from fast Will-O-Wisp users such as Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Volcarona.

Items

  • Leftovers: The residual recovery from Leftovers best suits the slow set-up of this set, especially if using Substitute.

  • Booster Energy: Depending on the EV spread, Booster Energy can boost Attack or Speed to increase Great Tusk's late-game cleaning potential.

  • Covert Cloak: If a Garganacl check is desperately needed, Covert Cloak Great Tusk is up for the task.

EV Spreads

  • 188 HP / 140 Atk / 4 Def / 36 SpD / 140 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom and the rare Timid Abomasnow, survives Timid Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry, and has a very good chance of avoiding a 2HKO from Adamant Azumarill after using Bulk Up. The Attack EVs OHKO Chien-Pao and defensive Gholdengo with Earthquake after Bulk Up.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread gains a Speed boost from Protosynthesis, making Great Tusk an even better late-game sweeper at the cost of physical bulk.

  • 244 HP / 20 Atk / 84 Def / 20 SpD / 140 Spe with Impish: This EV spread is meant for use with Tera Steel or Tera Poison, maintaining Great Tusk's Substitute against Dondozo's Wave Crash after Terastallization. It also outspeeds Adamant Breloom and the rare Timid Abomasnow, and survives Timid Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 SpD with Careful: Maximum investment in special bulk makes Great Tusk much more difficult to revenge kill with the likes of Gholdengo and Iron Bundle. The 4 Attack EVs gives an Attack boost from Protosynthesis, which is preferred for improving the Skeledirge matchup and sweeping more easily.

Choice Item.description:
• Great Tusk's high power attacks make it a fine Choice item holder.

  • Headlong Rush versus Earthquake: Headlong Rush is preferred for stampeding over maximum HP Gholdengo, but Earthquake avoids chip damage from Rocky Helmet and makes Great Tusk far less vulnerable to priority attacks from foes like Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and Palafin-H.

  • Ice Spinner: Great Tusk should never leave its cave without a move to hit Dragonite hard!

  • Knock Off: Knock Off deals massive damage to Air Balloon Gholdengo and is almost guaranteed to OHKO offensive Dragapult after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Jolly versus Adamant: A Jolly nature ensures that Great Tusk outspeeds Gholdengo, and Choice Scarf variants outspeed Dragapult. Adamant is still a reasonable option for more power since Great Tusk will still outpace Breloom, and if using Choice Scarf, Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao.

Other Options

  • Iron Head: If using Tera Steel, this is a reasonable option over Knock Off if Tera Fairy Rotom-W is an issue.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Terastallization can help it clean more easily, it's not an important aspect of this set otherwise.

  • Ground: Tera Ground is the best option for late-game cleaning, dealing significant damage to Dondozo and OHKOing Dragapult with Headlong Rush.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting threatens to 2HKO Corviknight, an otherwise decent check to Great Tusk, and OHKO even the bulkiest Ting-Lu.

  • Steel: While Great Tusk's special bulk is mediocre, Tera Steel can prevent it from being OHKOed by foes such as Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Since it outspeeds other major Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Rotom-W, Great Tusk makes for a good revenge killer.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band is a more niche option due to being extremely vulnerable to revenge kills, but does a much better job of wall-breaking, with Tera boosted Great Tusk even being able to 2HKO a maximum Defense Dondozo with Close Combat or Headlong Rush!

Physically Defensive Utility.description: Great Tusk is a fantastic physical wall with a high base HP and Defense stat as well as a good defensive typing in Ground / Fighting. Earthquake provides great coverage against many Pokemon in the tier, such as Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Gholdengo. Thunderous Kick is a powerful Fighting-type move that lowers the target's Defense by one stage; this can be helpful in taking down opposing Pokemon that would otherwise halt Great Tusk like opposing Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Knock Off can cripple foes by removing their items, which is great against a lot of Pokemon, as it gets rid of annoying items such as Heavy-Duty Boots, Leftovers, and opposing Covert Cloak from Pokemon such as Garganacl, opposing Great Tusk, and Skeledirge. Rapid Spin is a potent utility move that allows Great Tusk to remove entry hazards from the user's side, while Spikes is an alternative to Rapid Spin, as it allows Great Tusk to set up hazards of its own if the user's team already has reliable hazard removal. Shore Up is a good recovery move, as it gets powered up by sand, and Great Tusk can use it often due to its decent Speed and bulk. Covert Cloak is the best item choice for Great Tusk, as it allows it to shrug off secondary effects from moves like Mortal Spin, Thunderous Kick, and Salt Cure without getting punished. This EV spread allows Great Tusk to maximize its physical bulk while still outspeeding some slower Pokemon such as Adamant Tyranitar and base 100 Speed Pokemon like Volcarona after a well-timed Rapid Spin. Maximizing Attack instead of HP is an alternative option due to Great Tusk's impressive base Attack stat; however, maximizing HP is the preferred way to go to maximize overall bulk. Tera Water allows Great Tusk to turn the tables on physically offensive Water-types such as Palafin, and Gyarados; this allows Great Tusk to tank their STAB moves if needed. Additionally, Tera Ghost is an option to block Rapid Spin from opposing Great Tusk and punish them for not carrying Knock Off. Good partners for Great Tusk include Corviknight, Tyranitar, Slowking, and Toxapex; these Pokemon can provide a way to take on special attacks and help pivot Great Tusk into the battle. Tyranitar can also set up sand, which can increase Great Tusk's Shore Up recovery.

Choice Item.description:
• Tera Ground can turn Headlong Rush into a devastating STAB attack that can break through bulky targets Great Tusk normally wouldn’t, such as Scream Tail and Dondozo.
  • Tera Fighting lets Great Tusk crush Corviknight with Close Combat, which severely hurts defensive structures reliant on it. This opens up powerful teammates like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.
  • Earthquake makes Great Tusk harder to revenge kill than Headlong Rush does, as it doesn’t drop its defenses.
  • Rapid Spin works well for teams weak to entry hazards. It's a great way to support powerful threats weak to Stealth Rock, like Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle.
  • Knock Off provides fantastic item-removing support, and it especially cripples walls reliant on Leftovers like Scream Tail and Dondozo, allowing its team to more easily break past them.
  • Play Rough can be used to OHKO Koraidon without Terastallizing, as well as beating opposing Great Tusk. However, it has very little practical use outside of this.
  • Choice Scarf Great Tusk functions most effectively as a wallbreaker in the early- and mid-game, suited best for offensive structures that struggle with physical walls like the aforementioned Scream Tail and Dondozo. When building teams, remember Great Tusk must use Terastallization to actually break through said walls, so it may be hard for teammates to Terastallize.
  • Choice Band Great Tusk only functions well on Sticky Web teams, where the stronger and slower set appreciates Sticky Web dropping foes' Speed.
  • Koraidon is a great partner, setting up sun and activating Protosynthesis for Great Tusk. It further resists Water- and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, weakening the former. Koraidon also effectively baits in Skeledirge, which Great Tusk reliably threatens.
  • Miraidon is also a great partner, as it can threaten Flying-types, like Corviknight and the rarer Pelipper and Dragonite. This helps to make Great Tusk’s Headlong Rush much more spammable.
  • Gholdengo is also a good partner for Great Tusk, as it resists Ice-, Fairy-, and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, and it can threaten to KO Ice- and Fairy-types with super effective STAB Make It Rain. In addition, Gholdengo also blocks all hazard removal, helping to wear down walls for Great Tusk's team to eventually break through.

Offensive Utility.description:
• Great Tusk is the best offensive Stealth Rock or Rapid Spin user in the tier thanks to its solid typing and good physical bulk.
  • If Great Tusk is paired with Pokemon such as Corviknight, then Stealth Rock can be run instead of Rapid Spin. If paired with teammates that set Stealth Rock, then the best set would be Rapid Spin / Headlong Rush / Close Combat / Knock Off. Knock Off makes progress on Corviknight and covers the Air Balloon Gholdengo matchup.
  • Tera Ground lets Great Tusk deal incredible damage with Headlong Rush while also letting it survive Flutter Mane's Moonblast from full HP. Tera Steel flips the Fairy matchup and lets Great Tusk take on Ice- and Dragon-type attacks, but the additional weaknesses to Fighting and Ground make Great Tusk unable to take on Koraidon, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads easily.
  • Great Tusk can be used to take on entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Iron Treads one-on-one by forcing them out and removing hazards. Jolly is usually preferred to outspeed Gholdengo, Modest Chi-Yu, and Glimmora, but Adamant lets Tera Ground Headlong Rush OHKO Koraidon and specially defensive Annihilape after one layer of Spikes or Stealth Rock.
  • Great Tusk should be used aggressively to force out and keep entry hazards off the field against other setters, such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads, since Great Tusk is generally difficult to switch into. Great Tusk pairs well with Koraidon thanks to Orichalcum Pulse's sun, letting Great Tusk become an incredibly potent wallbreaker, and Great Tusk can clear entry hazards so that Koraidon can repeatedly come in. Miraidon also appreciates Great Tusk, as it forces out common checks such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads. Great Tusk also appreciates Blissey being able to take on all of the special attackers that force Great Tusk out, such as Flutter Mane, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle.

Setup Sweeper.description:
• Bulk Up allows Great Tusk to be a threatening sweeper. It can comfortably set up on common physical walls like Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and defensive Great Tusk.
  • The STAB combination of Headlong Rush and Close Combat hits most physical walls for at least neutral damage. Earthquake may be used as the Ground-type STAB move to avoid defensive drops, but it is a weaker move, and it can't secure important OHKOs and 2HKOs at +1 Attack against some physical walls such as Toxapex, Scream Tail, and Alomomola.
  • A Jolly nature is used to outspeed all viable unboosted Pokemon after one Rapid Spin. An Adamant nature makes Great Tusk stronger while still letting it outspeed unboosted Iron Bundle at +1 Speed, but it misses out on outspeeding maximum Speed Gholdengo and tying Jolly Great Tusk.
  • Terastallizing into the Ground typing boosts Headlong Rush and guarantees some additional OHKOs and 2HKOs on foes like Toxapex and Scream Tail. Additionally, getting rid of the Fighting typing lets Great Tusk survive Fairy-type attacks such as Dazzling Gleam from Miraidon and Moonblast from Flutter Mane without Life Orb or Choice Specs, and it facilitates taking Dazzling Gleam and Play Rough from Scream Tail and Alomomola.
  • Alternatively, using Tera Steel gives Great Tusk resistances to Fairy-type attacks, Ice-type attacks from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, and Draco Meteor from Miraidon, allowing it to surprise them with a strong attack.
  • Koraidon is a solid partner because its sun activates Great Tusk's Protosynthesis, making its attacks even stronger. In return, Great Tusk can break through or strongly dent common Koraidon checks like Scream Tail, Alomomola, and Skeledirge, which allows Koraidon to clean more easily. Miraidon is also an excellent teammate, since Great Tusk can easily hard switch into its common checks and either threaten them with its attacks or set up on them.
  • Special attackers like Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle hugely threaten Great Tusk, so it is recommended to pair it with appropriate special walls like Blissey, Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire. Gothitelle is a less popular pick but it helps eliminate bulky checks like Dondozo and Pelipper, allowing Great Tusk to sweep more easily.

Defensive.description:
• Thanks to its solid physical bulk under sun and good defensive typing, Great Tusk acts as one of the best checks to Koraidon while also providing teams with entry hazard removal and a fantastic switch-in to other Ground-types in the tier such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Iron Treads.
  • Play Rough threatens a KO on Koraidon after entry hazard damage. Knock Off can be used to take on Air Balloon Gholdengo and wear down foes that want to switch into Great Tusk such as Corviknight and Annihilape, but it is generally outclassed by the sheer utility of Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock. The combination of Knock Off and Body Press can be used to pressure Corviknight switch-ins.
  • Bulk Up is an option to boost alongside opposing Great Tusk and Swords Dance Kingambit and Koraidon.
  • Great Tusk can Terastallize into the Fairy typing to take on physical attackers such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Palafin in sun. However, be wary of Terastallizing against Koraidon that can still Terastallize themselves, as Choice Band Tera Fire Koraidon can take on Great Tusk one-on-one. Great Tusk can also Terastallize into the Ground typing or the Water typing, with both options removing its weakness to Fairy. The former also lets it fire off stronger Earthquakes as well, while the latter provides useful resistances to Fire moves from Koraidon as well as Ice- and Water-type moves, barring Freeze-Dry, from Iron Bundle.
  • Great Tusk fits on most teams as a bulky Stealth Rock setter and Koraidon check. Great Tusk can utilize Rocky Helmet to punish the use of U-turn, though this hurts its longevity, as it then loses Leftovers's passive recovery.
  • Great Tusk pairs well with defensive Scream Tail and Blissey, both of which can take on Iron Bundle while also providing Wish support for Great Tusk. Blissey can also take on Chi-Yu and Miraidon, while Scream Tail can take on Iron Valiant.
  • Great Tusk also pairs well with Gholdengo, as it appreciates Great Tusk forcing out Koraidon while preventing hazard removal in exchange. Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a good partner due to its ability to pressure faster special attackers that trouble Great Tusk such as Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane. Great Tusk also pairs well with Miraidon, as non-Heavy-Duty Boots Miraidon appreciates it removing entry hazards and taking on Clodsire, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu. Finally, Koraidon is a good partner, as it can set up sun, pivot into Great Tusk, and force out most hazard removal options besides opposing defensive Great Tusk.

Offensive Bulk Up.description: A solid offensive typing, a high Attack stat, and wide coverage make Great Tusk a potent wallbreaker. Bulk Up is the main source of Great Tusk's power, increasing its tanking capabilities and offensive prowess. Great Tusk's typing and coverage allow it to set up in front of multiple physical attackers like Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Zamazenta-C. Ice Spinner OHKOes Primordial Sea Zapdos after a Bulk Up, OHKOes Dragonite and 2HKOes Landorus-Therian, while Knock Off threatens Skeledirge and Ceruledge if not running Headlong Rush and cripples defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Quaquaval, and Earth Eater Gholdengo looking to switch in. Close Combat threatens Earth Eater Kingambit and Empoleon, as well as Roaring Moon, while Headlong Rush threatens Iron Moth, Skeledirge and Ceruledge. Fluffy helps Great Tusk set up Bulk Up more easily with its heightened physical bulk, making it a powerful tank. Great Tusk is a potent wallbreaker and entry hazard remover, so Pokemon that are vulnerable to entry hazards like Ogerpon-H and Chien-Pao benefit from its presence. In return, they threaten common defensive Pokemon that wall Great Tusk, such as Manaphy and Corviknight. Great Tusk has terrible special bulk and appreciates pivoting, so special walls like RegenVest Roaring Moon and the aforementioned Manaphy make for great teammates. Despite Great Tusk's high Attack stat, it still requires entry hazard chip damage to pick up KOes, Stealth Rock to OHKO itemless Zapdos at +1 and Stealth Rock and three layers of Spikes to OHKO Toxapex. Therefore, teammates like Sandy Shocks and Garchomp, which can set up Stealth Rock and Spikes, are appreciated.

Choiced Attacker (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Bulk Up (Ground).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defensive.description:
Scream Tail's gargantuan bulk and access to utility moves such as Wish and Encore make it a potent support Pokemon. Its defensive typing and high Speed make it a good answer to Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Walking Wake. Dazzling Gleam is this set's only attacking move, letting it hit Pokemon like Great Tusk, Dragapult, Hydreigon, and Iron Valiant and prevents it from being shut down by Taunt from Pokemon like Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Greninja. Wish gives Scream Tail a recovery move while letting it heal teammates such as Great Tusk, Rotom-W, and Hatterene that lack reliable recovery and are vulnerable to being overwhelmed by repeated hits. Protect synergizes well with Wish, making it much more reliable as a recovery move. Additionally, Protect scouts the intentions of Choice-locked Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, and Hisuian Zoroark. Encore prevents setup sweepers like Volcarona, Calm Mind Iron Valiant, and Bulk Up Great Tusk from using Scream Tail as a setup opportunity, letting Scream Tail's teammates switch in and take advantage of these threats. It can also be used to annoy passive Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Dondozo. Tera Fairy gives Scream Tail better matchups against Hydreigon, Roaring Moon, Dragapult, and Hisuian Zoroark, with the former two being susceptible to being OHKOed by Dazzling Gleam. Alternatively, Tera Water lets Scream Tail maintain a solid defensive typing while also helping it check Walking Wake, Skeledirge, and Greninja. With a Timid nature, 152 Speed EVs let Scream Tail outspeed Hydreigon, while 236 Special Defense EVs ensure that Scream Tail gets a Special Defense boost with Protosynthesis under sun, letting it more easily take on threats such as Walking Wake and Iron Valiant. Alternatively, a spread of 252 HP / 84 SpD / 172 Spe with a Calm nature lets Scream Tail outspeed unboosted Great Tusk and pass beefier Wishes.

Scream Tail fits on many sun, balance, and stall teams thanks to its bulk, ability to pass Wish to teammates, and create momentum with Encore. Bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo make for good teammates, as they are able to check Greninja and Ceruledge, respectively. Moreover, Toxapex also checks Pokemon like Iron Moth and Glimmora as well as spread status, making Encore much more of a detriment to setup sweepers like Volcarona and Iron Valiant, while Dondozo blanket checks physically oriented Pokemon that can overwhelm Scream Tail, namely Booster Energy Roaring Moon and Ceruledge. Entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk, Cinderace, and Corviknight make for excellent teammates, as a lack of hazards means that Scream Tail can accomplish feats such as surviving two Choice Specs Greninja Hydro Pumps from full HP. Additionally, Great Tusk appreciates Wish support in order to more consistently check Scream Tail answers such as Kingambit. Torkoal is a great teammate thanks to its sun activating Scream Tail's Protosynthesis. In addition, Torkoal very much appreciates Wish support in order to more consistently check Pokemon like Kingambit. Meanwhile, Scream Tail is able to sponge special attacks from the likes of Walking Wake. Under sun, Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Ceruledge, and Brute Bonnet appreciate Scream Tail facilitating their sweeps with its combination of Encore and Wish, keeping them healthy while leveraging setup opportunities for them. Hydreigon is another excellent offensive partner, checking Gholdengo and finding more opportunities to set up Substitute thanks to Scream Tail's Wish.

A blend of a great Speed stat and solid mixed bulk, combined with great utility options and an interesting defensive typing, Scream Tail a solid niche in the tier, allowing it to check dangerous threats such as Mega Diancie, Tapu Lele, and Mega Medicham. Wish and Protect provide Scream Tail with recovery, with the latter also scouting Choice-locked Pokemon such as Dragapult and Kartana. Dazzling Gleam punishes Great Tusk and Iron Valiant and prevents them from freely exploiting Scream Tail. Encore pairs excellently with Scream Tail's high Speed, allowing it to shut down setup sweepers such as Urshifu-R, Cresselia, and Garchomp for its teammates to defeat. Leftovers provides Scream Tail with recovery that makes it less susceptible to being exploited by Wish, granting Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Heatran free switches. The given EVs maximize Scream Tail's bulk while allowing it to outspeed Enamorus and shut down Calm Mind variants with Encore. An alternative spread of 120 HP / 236 SpD / 152 Spe can be used to outspeed Hydreigon while receiving a Special Defense boost in Mega Charizard Y's sun, further amplifying Scream Tail's bulk and allowing it to check Charizard under sun. Tera Steel grants a resistance to Ice- and Fairy-type attacks from Kyurem, Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant in a pinch, while Tera Fairy ensures Scream Tail resists Pursuit from Weavile and Mega Tyranitar and increases the power of Dazzling Gleam to potentially 2HKO and OHKO Garchomp and Iron Valiant, respectively. Scream Tail fits best on defensively oriented teams that appreciate its unique defensive attributes while being able to support it sufficiently in return. Pokemon with unreliable recovery such as Great Tusk, Dondozo, and Assault Vest Toxapex appreciate Scream Tail's high-HP Wishes, while in return they check Pokemon Scream Tail struggles with such as Mega Scizor and Volcarona. Due to its reliance on Protect and Leftovers for passive recovery, entry hazard control from teammates such as the aforementioned Great Tusk and Tornadus-T can help mitigate its recovery. Scream Tail's passive nature means it can be exploited by Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Ferrothorn, and Heatran, so Pokemon that aid against them while providing a more dangerous presence such as Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Swords Dance Gliscor pair well with it.

Defensive Support (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Trick Room Support.description:
• Scream Tail's bulk, Speed and diverse support options make it a great all-in-one Trick Room support Pokemon.

  • Misty Explosion : Misty Explosion may limit Scream Tail's offensive reach, but it's key for bringing in sweepers safely after setting Trick Room.

  • Encore: Encore is great at disrupting foes trying to set up in front of Scream Tail.

  • Trick Room Sweepers: Ursaluna-B is the most popular partner for Trick Room setups, but other semi-slow sweepers like Basculegion-M can work as well.

  • EV Spread: The special bulk guarantees that Scream Tail survives Shadow Ball from Choice Specs Flutter Mane. If using Sitrus Berry, the physical bulk guarantees that both formes of Choice Band Urshifu will fail to 2HKO Scream Tail with their signature moves.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Scream Tail's bulk and typing make it easy to set up without having to rely on Terastallization.

  • Water: Tera Water's Steel-type and Fire-type resistances can be key at surviving big attacks from Gholdengo and Chi-Yu.

  • Steel: Tera Steel can help Scream Tail set up against Tera Flying and Extreme Speed Dragonite, while still providing a key Steel-type resistance.

Items

  • Mental Herb: Taunt Flutter Mane can be a big problem for Scream Tail, but Mental Herb can help guarantee that it gets to set Trick Room at least once.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry's healing can give Scream Tail a stronger chance at getting both Stealth Rock and Trick Room down.

Stealth Rock Support.description:
• Scream Tail's incredible support movepool and bulk makes it a fine Stealth Rock supporter.

  • Thunder Wave versus Fling: Thunder Wave is the easiest form of paralysis to fit in, but with Light Ball, Fling can paralyze Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Garchomp, and Gholdengo that lack Covert Cloak, at the cost of leaving Scream Tail extremely vulnerable to Encore. Fling can also get rid of devastating Choice items from Trick users such as Rotom-W.

  • Encore: Scream Tail's great Speed tier makes it an especially effective user of Encore, letting it punish foes that attempt to set up, such as Roaring Moon.

  • Perish Song: Perish Song is another way for Scream Tail to threaten setup sweepers such as Dragonite, and it can become a win condition late in the game. It's also a fantastic response to Baton Pass foes such as Espathra and opposing Scream Tail.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb's additional Speed control is helpful against threats that boost their Speed, such as Dragonite and Baxcalibur.

  • Dazzling Gleam: While a rather weak STAB move, Dazzling Gleam threatening to 2HKO offensive Great Tusk can make it a good way to punish Rapid Spin use.

Other Options

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower 2HKOes Scizor, though it does not 2HKO Gholdengo, making Recover sets still problematic.

  • Disable: Disable is particularly apt at ruining Choice item foes that need a specific move to 2HKO Scream Tail, such as Scizor, though compared to Encore, it's less useful against support moves.

  • Psychic Fangs: In addition to 2HKOing Iron Moth, Psychic Fangs breaking dual screens can be extremely useful, though this doesn't work against Grimmsnarl.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal might seem like an underwhelming defensive option, but taking on Ghost-type attacks while avoiding a 2HKO from Gholdengo can be valuable.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives a vital Steel resistance and is a great defensive typing in general.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy improves Scream Tail's matchup against Dark-types such as Hydreigon.

  • Fire: If using Flamethrower, Tera Fire Scream Taill will have a 97.3% chance to 2HKO Tera Steel Scizor, making it an effective lure.

Items

  • Mental Herb: Blocking the first use of Taunt makes Scream Tail an extremely reliable setter of Stealth Rock.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry is the safest way to increase Scream Tail's longetivity, and it can avoid certain 2HKOs depending on the EV spread, such as that from Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump with specially defensive spreads.

  • Light Ball: Light Ball is a requirement when using Fling, ensuring Scream Tail can inflict paralysis once and get rid of Choice items with one move.

  • Booster Energy: Booster Energy being instantly consumed makes Scream Tail less flexible, but boosting Speed lets it outspeed key threats such as Dragapult. This item can also be used with bulkier EV spreads to make Scream Tail even bulkier, pulling off incredible stunts such as surviving Timid Choice Specs Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

EV Spreads

  • Scream Tail has an incredible number of viable EV spreads at its disposal: consider these as mere examples rather than all of its viable EV spreads!

  • 180 HP / 156 SpD / 172 Spe with Calm or Careful: This EV spread outspeeds Baxcalibur and Great Tusk and survives Timid Choice Specs Iron Moth's Sludge Wave 93.7% of the time.

  • 180 HP / 124 SpD / 204 Spe with Calm or Careful: The Speed investment outspeeds Jolly Annihilape, and Scream Tail avoids OHKOs from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane.

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 68 SpD with Calm or Careful: This EV spread avoids an OHKO from Timid Gholdengo's Make It Rain after Stealth Rock damage, and Scream Tail has a 93.7% chance of surviving Tera Steel Scizor's Choice Band Bullet Punch. If outspeeding Baxcalibur and Great Tusk is a must, a Speed-boosting nature and 68 Speed EVs can be used instead.

  • 252 HP / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid or Jolly: With maximum Speed investment, Scream Tail outspeeds not only Iron Moth, but also major Encore targets such as Garchomp and Annihilape.

Baton Pass.description:
• Scream Tail's diverse setup options and bulk make it one of the most unpredictable Baton Pass Pokemon in the metagame.

  • Encore: Encore is perfect for punishing passive play, giving Scream Tail many new setup opportunities.

  • Sing: Sing is a high-risk, high-reward option to set up in otherwise impossible situations, and it is especially effective with Blunder Policy.

  • Substitute: Not only is Substitute useful to pass with Baton Pass, but it makes weak Pokemon such as Garganacl into easy setup bait.

Other Options

  • Flamethrower: When using Calm Mind, Flamethrower can threaten Gholdengo and Scizor.

  • Psychic Fangs: Psychic Fangs 2HKOes Clodsire and, after a Bulk Up boost, can OHKO Iron Moth that don't invest in Defense. However, Grimmsnarl holds back its dual screens-breaking potential.

  • Drain Punch: Drain Punch gives Scream Tail some offensive presence against Kingambit.

  • Stored Power: When combined with Calm Mind and Blunder Policy, Stored Power can threaten Unaware walls such as Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal gets rid of Scream Tail's key weakness to Steel, and it performs well against Flutter Mane and Gholdengo in particular.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Scream Tail a fantastic defensive typing, resisting Scizor's Bullet Punch in particular.

  • Dark: If Grimmsnarl is particularly problematic for your team, Tera Dark will block its Prankster Taunt from stopping Scream Tail.

Items

  • Mental Herb: Mental Herb is the most reliable option for getting Baton Pass off against faster Taunt users.

  • Blunder Policy: When paired with Sing, Scream Tail can pass Speed when Sing misses.

  • Sitrus Berry: A burst of recovery from Sitrus Berry eases setup in general.

  • Booster Energy: While it's impossible to pass Protosynthesis boosts via Baton Pass, either outspeeding disruptive foes such as Iron Bundle, or surviving Choice Specs holders like Iron Moth and Gholdengo, can be a deadly surprise.

General EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 68 SpD with Careful or Calm: This EV spread gives Scream Tail enough bulk to survive Timid Gholdengo's Make It Rain after Stealth Rock damage, and it has a 93.7% chance of surviving Tera Steel Choice Band Scizor's Bullet Punch.

  • 180 HP / 124 SpD / 204 Spe with Calm or Careful: This spread outspeeds Jolly Annihilape, and with Blunder Policy, it can even outspeed Booster Energy Iron Bundle after missing Sing. The bulk lets Scream Tail survive a hit from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock damage.

  • 252 HP / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly or Timid: Maximizing Speed lets Scream Tail outspeed high-profile targets such as Iron Moth and Garchomp.

Blunder Policy-Specific EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 4 SpA / 4 SpD / 60 Spe with Careful or Calm: This spread gives Scream Tail enough bulk to usually survive Tera Steel Choice Band Scizor's Bullet Punch, and it also outspeeds Booster Energy Iron Valiant after missing Sing. The remaining 8 EVs can only boost Special Defense and an offensive stat of your choice.

  • 180 HP / 212 SpD / 116 Spe with Jolly or Timid and 180 HP / 100 SpD / 228 Spe with Careful or Calm: These functionally identical stat spreads let Scream Tail outspeed even Choice Scarf Dragapult after missing Sing! The Special Defense investment lets Scream Tail survive a hit from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock damage.

Dual Screens.description:
• Scream Tail's bulk and impressive Speed make it a great dual screens setter.

  • Encore: Encore punishing setup is extremely valuable considering Scream Tail's passive nature compared to other dual screens setters.

  • Perish Song: Perish Song can ruin Baton Pass attempts from the likes of Espathra or opposing Scream Tail, and it does well against most setup sweepers, except Gholdengo.

  • Light Clay versus Mental Herb: Light Clay is the preferred choice, but Mental Herb can save Scream Tail from some particularly difficult users of Taunt such as Corviknight and Annihilape.

Tera Types

  • The extreme support focus of this set means that Terastallization should only be used as a last resort, or when it can clearly lead to a win.

  • Normal: In emergencies, Tera Normal can let Scream Tail set up dual screens against Flutter Mane and Gholdengo. Note that Scream Tail is completely passive against Gholdengo, though.

  • Dark: Tera Dark is a niche answer to Prankster Taunt users such as Grimmsnarl.

Offensive.description:
High Attack, decent mixed bulk, and a great stat-boosting ability in Protosynthesis make Brute Bonnet a great wallbreaker on sun teams that can threaten stall teams by taking advantage of common walls such as Dondozo, Toxapex, Clodsire, and Corviknight. Brute Bonnet stands out due to its access to Spore, allowing it to lure in and immobilize incoming foes like Dragonite and Roaring Moon. Sucker Punch allows Brute Bonnet to revenge kill faster Pokemon such as Dragapult and Gholdengo. Tera Fire Tera Blast gives it coverage against Pokemon like Corviknight, Kingambit, and Amoonguss and is further boosted by sun. Loaded Dice is the preferred item for Brute Bonnet, since it can maximize Bullet Seed's damage output. Tera Fire is Brute Bonnet's best Tera type to both take advantage of a sun boosted Tera Blast and change most of its type weaknesses to resistances, improving its matchups against Iron Valiant and Volcarona.

In order to fully reap Brute Bonnet's benefits, it must be used on a sun team. Hence, Torkoal is a mandatory partner to activate Brute Bonnet's Protosynthesis; it can additionally lay down Stealth Rock and act as a secondary hazard remover. Brute Bonnet also appreciates entry hazard support from Garchomp, which can wear down incoming foes for Brute Bonnet. When it Terastallizes, Brute Bonnet becomes highly susceptible to entry hazards. Hence, hazard control from the likes of Hatterene and Great Tusk is greatly appreciated. Lastly, Brute Bonnet struggles against walls such as Tera Fairy Garganacl and Skeledirge as well as faster Pokemon like Garchomp and Volcarona; Roaring Moon and Walking Wake are good teammates to handle said checks. In return, Brute Bonnet can threaten walls they struggle with, such as Corviknight for Roaring Moon and Azumarill for Walking Wake.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Speedy Spore.description:
• Don't be fooled by Brute Bonnet's low Speed stat; after two uses of Trailblaze, it even outspeeds Dragapult, which is a very feasible feat thanks to Spore. With the lack of Sleep Clause, this Speed turns Brute Bonnet into a terrifying sleep inducer!

  • Crunch versus Sucker Punch: Crunch is the preferred STAB move, reliably hitting the most common Spore check, Gholdengo, which makes it the ideal STAB attack to use with Substitute. However, Sucker Punch lets Brute Bonnet pick off threats when it doesn't have the chance to Spore and set up Trailblaze.

  • Close Combat versus Substitute: On one hand, Close Combat deals massive damage to Dark-type resistances, such as Roaring Moon, but it leaves Brute Bonnet fairly vulnerable to priority attacks. On the other hand, Spore gives Brute Bonnet ample opportunity to set up Substitute, easing the cost of early wake ups.

Tera Types

  • Dark: Powering up Crunch makes it easier to sweep with Crunch or Sucker Punch while still leaving it immune to Grimmsnarl's Prankster Taunt.

  • Fire: Tera Fire turns Brute Bonnet's devastating U-turn and Fairy-type weaknesses into resistances, giving it the edge against Flutter Mane and letting it fry Scizor and Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Poison: Tera Poison grants Brute Bonnet important resistances to U-turn, Fighting, and Fairy without compromising itself against Water-types.

  • Fairy: With Tera Fairy, Brute Bonnet deals with Dragon-types far more reliably, and gains a valuable tool against opposing Dark- and Dragon-types with Tera Blast.

EV Spreads

  • 148 HP / 100 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Adamant: With Adamant, Brute Bonnet will still outspeed Great Tusk and Annihilape after Trailblaze and Dragapult after two uses of Trailblaze. Brute Bonnet's bulk lets it survive some powerful attacks, such as Iron Moth's Sludge Wave, Choice Specs Gholdengo's Make It Rain, and almost always surviving Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

  • 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: At the cost of bulk, maximizing Speed lets Brute Bonnet outspeed threats such as Garchomp and Iron Treads after just one use of Trailblaze

Items

  • Booster Energy: Activating Protosynthesis takes dvantage of Brute Bonnet's power, though it means switching out will weaken Brute Bonnet.

  • Leftovers: If using Substitute, Leftovers is by far the preferred item, as Brute Bonnet has plenty of turns to recover its health against sleeping foes.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb is the most consistent way to boost Brute Bonnet's power, letting it switch out after using Spore when needed.

  • Focus Sash: Despite Brute Bonnet's good bulk, Focus Sash is a great option to stop potential sweeps, assuming entry hazards aren't set up.

Bulky Spore.description:
• With good bulk and access to strong priority, Brute Bonnet is a great offensive user of Spore.

  • Bullet Seed versus Seed Bomb: Even when not using Loaded Dice, Bullet Seed is useful for potentially KOing foes like Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane through Focus Sash and punishing Mimikyu switch ins. Nontheless, Seed Bomb is the more reliable option when not using Loaded Dice.

  • Substitute: Substitute is easy to set up thanks to Spore and eases the risk early wake-ups can pose. If using Substitute, using Crunch or Payback over Sucker Punch is preferred due to the issues Substitute Gholdengo can cause.

  • Crunch versus Payback: Having a reliable Dark-type STAB move is helpful when facing foes like Substitute Gholdengo. Payback has higher damage potential, but Crunch won't have its power dropped by foes switching in.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat crushes Roaring Moon and opposing Brute Bonnet, though the drop in bulk can be troublesome for this set.

Tera Types

  • Dark: Tera Dark works fantastically with Sucker Punch, giving Brute Bonnet good revenge killing capability.

  • Poison: Tera Poison covers Brute Bonnet's major weaknesses to U-turn, Fairy, and Fighting, giving it an easy chance to use Spore.

  • Fire: While the Stealth Rock weakness can be troublesome, Tera Fire still does well against Flutter Mane and lets Brute Bonnet melt Scizor and Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Fairy: Powerful Dragon-type attacks such as Outrage and Draco Meteor can be turned into Spore bait with Tera Fairy, in addition to arming Brute Bonnet with a powerful Tera Blast against them.

  • Grass: If using Bullet Seed, Tera Grass can make sense for increasing the chance of shooting down Focus Sash leads such as Flutter Mane and still keeping the Spore immunity against Breloom and opposing Brute Bonnet.

Items

  • Leftovers: The extra recovery pairs very well with Spore and Substitute.

  • Sitrus Berry: If not using Substitute, the quick burst of recovery with Sitrus Berry is preferred.

  • Loaded Dice: Guaranteeing 4 hits with Bullet Seed means Brute Bonnet will always OHKO Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle through their Focus Sash, and the higher chance for 5 hits can even shoot down Mimikyu and offensive Great Tusk.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Ghost

Mystical Fire may be used against Steel-types such as Kingambit and Iron Treads as well as Amoonguss. Power Gem is helpful in the Fire and Flying matchups, hitting Ogerpon-H, Volcarona, Articuno, and Moltres. Substitute may be used to outplay Sucker Punch users such as Kingambit. Calm Mind is an option to capitalize on Flutter Mane's ability to force out most Pokemon, allowing it potentially overpower switch-ins such as Gastrodon and Empoleon. Psyshock threatens specially defensive walls like Clodsire and Blissey.

Choice Specs (Fairy).description:
Flutter Mane has a powerful dual STAB combination in Moonblast and Shadow Ball, as well as a plethora of coverage moves that allow it to choose its good matchups. Mystical Fire hits Steel-types such as Klefki and Iron Treads. Psyshock allows Flutter Mane to punish specially defensive switch-ins like Dragalge, Blissey, and Clodsire. Flutter Mane can run Power Gem to pressure Fire teams, OHKOing foes like Volcarona and Torkoal, and it also benefits from Protosynthesis allowing it to outspeed Scovillain under the sun. Additionally, Flutter Mane usually goes with either Thunderbolt or Energy Ball. Both are useful against Water teams, with the former helping against Toxapex and Pelipper while the latter deals with Gastrodon and Quagsire. Choice Specs further enhances Flutter Mane's wallbreaking power, allowing it to overwhelm foes such as Ting-Lu after some chip damage.

On Fairy teams, Flutter Mane is a menacing wallbreaker that excels at taking down slower foes such as Hydreigon, Skeledirge, and Corviknight. When paired with Iron Valiant, Flutter Mane forms an offensive core that's able to alternate between Fairy-, Ghost-, and Fighting-type STAB to take down a wide range of enemies. Flutter Mane can handle Psychic-type foes such as Espathra and Hatterene, while Iron Valiant takes care of Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads. Flutter Mane can fall back on either Hatterene or Tinkaton when faced with an unfavorable matchup. Both of these Pokemon provide dependable defensive options and some type of entry hazard control, but Hatterene is particularly useful due to it breaking down walls like Dondozo and Clodsire. Flutter Mane also pairs well with setup sweepers like Belly Drum Azumarill and Swords Dance Mimikyu, as it is able to poke holes in the opponent's team, allowing them to clean late-game. In return, Azumarill can take care of priority users, such as Ceruledge and Chien-Pao. In terms of support options, Flutter Mane can rely on Fairy's Prankster users, Klefki and Grimmsnarl, to set up dual screens, therefore allowing it to withstand hits such as Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak and Gholdengo's Make It Rain. Grimmsnarl can then bring in Flutter Mane relatively safely thanks to Parting Shot. Klefki's Spikes and Tinkaton's Stealth Rocks also support Flutter Mane in breaking its checks such as Iron Hands and Ting-Lu. Entry hazard stacking proves particularly useful against less bulky teams, as it highly limits their capacity to scout Flutter Mane without having to sacrifice a member in the process.

Choice Scarf (Ghost).description:
Choice Scarf Flutter Mane is an incredibly potent revenge killer and late-game cleaner thanks to its strong STAB combination, solid coverage options, and blazing Speed tier. Notably, it outspeeds faster Pokemon like Dragapult, boosted threats such as Baxcalibur and Quaquaval, and Choice Scarf users like Greninja and Meowscarada, all of which can threaten the offensive teams that Flutter Mane is part of. Mystical Fire threatens Steel-types such as Corviknight and Iron Treads, while Psyshock revenge kills Choice Scarf Iron Moth and hits specially bulky Pokemon like Clodsire. Thunderbolt pressures Corviknight better and 2HKOes physically defensive Toxapex after Stealth Rock, while Energy Ball takes care of Gastrodon.

Spikes from the likes of Brambleghast and Froslass are terrific support options, chipping down bulky foes like Toxapex and Ting-Lu that would otherwise switch into Flutter Mane freely. Thanks to Good as Gold blocking Defog and its Ghost-typing, Gholdengo is a notable partner to keep Spikes up. Brambleghast also helps threaten Gastrodon and provides Rapid Spin support as well. Wallbreakers like Mimikyu and Gholdengo can pressure the opposition early-game, allowing for Flutter Mane to clean up late-game with ease; moreover, Mimikyu can overwhelm Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads with Drain Punch, while Gholdengo can make use of Trick to cripple walls like Clodsire and Corviknight. Setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Swords Dance Ceruledge are valuable teammates that function as back-up late-game cleaners, especially against types Flutter Mane can struggle with such as Poison and Steel. Moreover, Ceruledge and Mimikyu have the added benefit of safely revenge killing opposing fast threats Flutter Mane can't handle easily, like Choice Scarf Flutter Mane and Dragon Dance Dragapult, with Shadow Sneak. Skeledirge is a notable partner to compensate for Flutter Mane's lack of physical bulk, taking on Bullet Punch users like Scizor and Lucario as well as being fantastic in the Steel, Fighting, and Bug matchups.

Bulky Choice Specs (Fairy).description:
Bulky Choice Specs Flutter Mane serves as a strong specially offensive wallbreaker that can survive one hit from most unboosted physical attacks, such as Ting Lu's Heavy Slam and Baxcalibur's Icicle Crash, with relative safety. Psyshock allows Flutter Mane to break through most Poison cores on its own with proper hazard support, most notably 2HKOing Clodsire, which otherwise walls it. Alternatively, Mystical Fire lets Flutter Mane break through defensive Steel-types like Iron Treads and and surprise more offensive Steel-types like Scizor behind Reflect, while Energy Ball targets would-be Rock-, Water-, and Ground-type walls like Garganacl and Gastrodon. The given EVs let Flutter Mane outspeed Spectrier, always survive +1 Dragonite's Earthquake, and almost always win the one-on-one matchup against Ting-Lu by having a 15/16 chance to survive its Heavy Slam and a 78% chance to 2HKO it with Moonblast in return after Leftovers recovery, using the minimum HP and Defense EVs possible.

Bulky Choice Specs Flutter Mane takes advantage of its unexpected bulk to create surprise KOs, such as versus Dragon Dance Dragonite, while retaining its ability to remove key threats like Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Galarian Slowking. For this reason, setup sweepers like Belly Drum Azumarill and Calm Mind Hatterene are strong partners, as they can take advantage of the holes that Flutter Mane creates in defensive cores. Iron Valiant is another strong partner, as it can take advantage of both the specially defensive Pokemon that Flutter Mane may not be able to remove, such as Hisuian Goodra, Alolan Muk, and Heatran, while creating a generally strong offensive core. As Flutter Mane is slower than Chien-Pao and opposing Flutter Mane, Choice Scarf Pokemon such as the Enamorus and the aforementioned Iron Valiant are necessary to handle these threats. Choice Scarf Enamorus in particular is a strong partner, as it can reduce the necessity of Flutter Mane on the field while threatening its own powerful late-game cleanup with Contrary Superpower, supporting its team with Healing Wish, and using Iron Head to KO opposing Flutter Mane after hazard chip; it also has the added benefit of having a stronger matchup versus Choice Scarf Meowscarada than Iron Valiant. On the other hand, Choice Scarf Iron Valiant is more immediately threatening with a Choice Scarf, allowing it to outspeed Choice Scarf Iron Moth and Gengar, Chlorophyll Scovillain, and Slush Rush Cetitan, and OHKO threats that Enamorus could only dream of removing, such as Ice Shard Chien-Pao. Flutter Mane also struggles versus Steel-types like Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Choice Scarf Iron Treads, so support from Klefki and Tinkaton, along with offensive checks like Azumarill, Iron Valiant, and Enamorus, allows Flutter Mane to break through these cores much more reliably. The Poison-type matchup is particularly difficult, so Steel-types like Klefki and Tinkaton and Magic Bounce support from Hatterene help Flutter Mane, as they can provide hazard support while blocking or punishing Toxic Spikes. In return, Flutter Mane can pressure Clodsire and Galarian Slowking and chip Alolan Muk by capitalizing on the lack of switch-ins to the combination of Psyshock, Moonblast, Shadow Ball, and entry hazards.

All-Out Attacker (Ghost).description:
Heavy-Duty Boots Flutter Mane is a potent offensive pivot and revenge killer, taking advantage of its immunity to entry hazards to stay out of KO range from priority moves such as Swords Dance Urshifu-R's boosted Aqua Jet and Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak as well as bluff Choice Scarf to surprise foes with the ability to switch between moves. Moonblast threatens Dark- and Dragon-type Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Darkrai, and Walking Wake. Energy Ball hits Ground- and Water-type foes such as Mamoswine, Dondozo, Gastrodon, and Quagsire. Thunderbolt nails Water-types like Pelipper, Toxapex, and Empoleon, allowing Flutter Mane to threaten every Water-type Pokemon super effectively in tandem with Energy Ball. Furthermore, Thunderbolt wards off Flying-types such as Corviknight and Moltres. The given EV spread permits Flutter Mane to take a Shadow Sneak from Life Orb Mimikyu, easing the Ghost matchup.

Gholdengo is an excellent teammate, as it takes advantage of Poison- and Steel-type Pokemon like Sneasler, Empoleon, and Amoonguss for Nasty Plot setup, while in return Flutter Mane threatens Ground-types such as Sandy Shocks and Gastrodon. Focus Sash Ceruledge is a really good wallbreaker against Steel and Dark teams, easily taking out Alolan Muk, Hisuian Goodra, and Kingambit. Colbur Berry Spectrier excels in the Poison and Fighting matchups, weakening shared checks like Assault Vest Iron Hands and specially defensive Toxapex using Will-O-Wisp as well as takes out potential revenge killers like Choice Scarf Roaring Moon with Draining Kiss. Additionally, Choice Scarf Spectrier is great in the Ghost mirror matchup, threatening Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Flutter Mane, appreciating Flutter Mane removing Dark-types like Hydreigon and Darkrai in return. Brambleghast and Froslass provide Spikes setup to push Flutter Mane's targets into OHKO ranges, while the former also applies additional pressure on Water and Ground teams. Skeledirge wears down teams by spreading Will-O-Wisp and bypassing Substitute with Torch Song, walling and shutting down setup Pokemon such as Zamazenta and Iron Hands. Hisuian Zoroark provides a Ghost-type immunity, switching into attacks from opposing Ceruledge and Flutter Mane as well as providing utility via Will-O-Wisp and Knock Off, weakening physical attackers that Flutter Mane is vulnerable to such as Clodsire, Corviknight, and Poison Jab Toxapex and rendering foes susceptible to Spikes. Dragapult provides utility via Thunder Wave and Will-O-Wisp, hindering threats like Chien-Pao and opposing Flutter Mane. Furthermore, Choice Scarf Dragapult removes other Choice Scarf users like Meowscarada and Roaring Moon.

All-Out Attacker (Fairy).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2024.overview:
• Flutter Mane's extraordinary Special Attack and Speed combined with its fantastic offensive typing makes it one of the most effective cleaners in the format, 2HKOing the majority of the metagame. Flutter Mane can also play a supportive role for its team thanks to Icy Wind and Speed Booster Energy.

  • Offensive sets appreciate Pokemon that bring speed control like Latias and Tornadus, as well as Pokemon that provide it with longevity like Incineroar and Amoonguss. Supportive sets instead become the speed control and help support slower offensive Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Chi-Yu. Chi-Yu works particularly well as a partner, bolstering Flutter Mane's damage with Beads of Ruin and checking Steel-types like Kingambit while Flutter Mane takes care of Fighting-types like Urshifu-R in return.

  • Bulky Assault Vest users that can take a boosted Moonblast and OHKO Flutter Mane in response like Kingambit and Rillaboom are some of its toughest matchups. Flutter Mane also faces issues into faster threats like Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Additionally, redirectors like Indeedee-F and Ogerpon-W mitigate its damage output when on the field.

Offensive.description:
• Flutter Mane is an effective cleaner thanks to Moonblast, which is its strongest STAB move, and Dazzling Gleam, which provides spread damage.

  • Special Attack Booster Energy is Flutter Mane's strongest boosting item if it wants to keep Protect. Fairy Feather can be used instead, allowing it to retain its offensive boosts when switching at the cost of damage.

  • The EV spread is built to survive an Ice Spinner from Jolly Chien-Pao and to outspeed Tornadus, with the remaining EVs boosting Flutter Mane's Special Attack

  • Flutter Mane appreciates Tera Fairy to further boost its damage on Moonblast and Dazzling Gleam . This also removes its Ghost weakness and makes it resist Dark-type attacks, allowing it to better deal with opposing Flutter Mane and survive a potential Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Kingambit.

Choice Specs.description:
• Choice Specs is Flutter Mane's strongest boosting item and allows it to do immediate damage.

  • Flutter Mane utilizes Icy Wind as a speed control option and as coverage to threaten chipped Landorus. Thunderbolt and Power Gem are strong coverage options for important Pokemon like Tera Water Urshifu-R and Incineroar, respectively.

  • The above spread allows Flutter Mane to survive a Surging Strikes from a Choice Scarf Urshifu-R while outspeeding Adamant Chien-Pao. The remaining EVs are used to maximise its Special Attack.

  • Flutter Mane takes advantage of Tera Fairy by removing its Ghost weakness and giving it a Dark resistance, allowing it to better deal with opposing Flutter Mane and survive a potential Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Chien-Pao. Tera Fairy also allows Flutter Mane to secure an OHKO on Tera Water Urshifu-R.

Speed-Boosting Support.description:
• Flutter Mane requires Icy Wind to accomplish its role as speed control, forcing it to pick between Dazzling Gleam and Moonblast.

  • Speed Booster Energy allows Flutter Mane to outspeed the majority of the metagame.

  • With Booster Energy, Flutter Mane can outspeed opposing Chien-Pao at -1 and Modest Gholdengo in Tailwind. The defensive investment lets it survive Adamant Chien-Pao's Ice Spinner and Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

  • Tera Fairy is appreciated to gain more of an offensive presence and helps against opposing Flutter Mane, as Speed Booster Energy Flutter Mane is unable to OHKO opposing Flutter Mane with Shadow Ball.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Offensive.description:
• Flutter Mane's blistering Speed and Special Attack along with its powerful unresisted STAB combination exerts an oppressive amount of pressure on most teams, making it one of the premier offensive Pokemon in the format.

  • Mystical Fire: Mystical Fire heavily disrupts enemy special attackers, especially in tandem with its already impressive base 135 Special Defense.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock significantly dents defensive checks like Clodsire and Toxapex, deals massive damage to Iron Moth, and gets arounds Special Defense boosting from the likes of Quiver Dance Volcarona.

  • Substitute: Calm Mind + Substitute is a classic duo that grealty assists Flutter Mane's setup attempts, allowing it to set up infront of Toxapex.

  • Calm Mind: A fast Calm Mind utilizes Flutter Mane's naturally strong Special Defense to set up against other special attackers. This is especially strong for winning Flutter Mane mirrors: if your Flutter Mane goes first, it can cushion even an opposing Choice Specs Shadow Ball with the Special Defense boost, then fire back next turn with a +1 Shadow Ball of its own.

  • Perish Song: This is an effective late-game win condition against a wide variety of Pokemon, and is one of the best ways to shut down Baton Pass foes like Espathra in the game.

Other Options

  • Taunt and Thunder Wave: Taunt and Thunder Wave take advantage of Flutter Mane's incredible Speed to disrupt opposing setup strategies, though these options tend to be less reliable than Charm sets.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Flutter Mane's incredible Speed is put to good use, outspeeding almost everything in the metagame with the major exceptions being Booster Energy Iron Bundle and Choice Scarf Dragapult.

  • Choice Specs: With Choice Specs, Flutter Mane becomes a potent wall breaker, 2HKOing almost anything that doesn't resist it.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash patches up Flutter Mane's poor physical bulk, giving it new revenge kill chances.
