  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf's consistent Speed boost allows Flutter Mane to run EV spreads that give a better balance of bulk and power, since Speed no longer has to be the highest stat for Booster Energy boosts.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Flutter Mane benefits from Terastallization, it's generally flexible enough to go without it.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy makes Moonblast a potent sweeping move, while reducing damage against Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch and Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak.

  • Water: Tera Water has a niche for giving a resistance to Steel, Ice, and Fire, giving improved matchups against Scizor, Ting-Lu, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is a purely defensive option, ridding Flutter Mane of its troublesome Ghost-type weakness.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives Flutter Mane a resistance to Steel, most notably living Scizor's Bullet Punch. It also boosts the power of Mystical Fire.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost powering up Shadow Ball can be a devastating surprise against bulky Fairy resistances such as Iron Moth.

EV Spreads

  • Flutter Mane's lack of physical bulk makes it extremely vulnerable to getting revenge killed, so consider these alternative EV spreads if a simple offensive spread is not working well. Note that Flutter Mane has many more viable EV spreads, these are just examples!

EV Spreads That Boost Speed With Protosynthesis

  • 252 HP / 44 Def / 148 SpA / 4 SpD / 60 Spe with Timid: This EV spread outspeeds up to Iron Moth, survives Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash, and almost always avoids a 2HKO from Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump when it lacks Choice Specs.

  • 188 HP / 228 Def / 20 SpA / 4 SpD / 68 Spe with Timid: This spread survives Life Orb Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch after Stealth Rock damage and outspeeds Iron Moth and the rare Scream Tail.

  • 252 HP / 244 Def / 12 Spe with Bold or Timid: This extremely defensive spread allows Flutter Mane to survive Tera Dark Life Orb Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch without needing to Terastallize itself, while still outspeeding Jolly Annihilape. If outspeeding Timid Chi-Yu and Jolly Garchomp is more important, Flutter Mane can use Timid instead of Bold at the cost of some bulk against priority.

  • 116 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 132 Spe with Timid: This EV spread outspeeds Jolly Roaring Moon and survives an opposing Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball without Terastallization. In addition, Life Orb Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak has a fairly low chance of OHKOing, and Iron Bundle fails to KO with the combination of Hydro Pump and Freeze Dry.

EV Spreads That Don't Boost Speed With Protosynthesis

  • 252 HP / 44 Def / 92 SpA / 4 SpD / 116 Spe with Modest: This spread outspeeds Jolly Garchomp and Timid Chi-Yu, survives Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash. and has a very likely chance of surviving two Hydro Pumps from Iron Bundle when it's not using Choice Specs.

  • 188 HP / 228 Def / 76 SpA / 4 SpD / 12 Spe with Modest: This EV spread only outspeeds up to Jolly Annihilape, but in exchange, has more power than most Flutter Mane and survives Life Orb Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch after Stealth Rock damage.

Charm.description:
• The combination of Charm and Pain Split turns Flutter Mane into a devastating control option, massively crippling opposing offensive threats and healing itself with the combination of Pain Split and Draining Kiss.

  • Calm Mind versus coverage: Calm Mind allows Flutter Mane to maintain its role as a sweeper by increasing its damage output while simultaneously reinforcing its longevity. However, this leaves Flutter Mane quite vulnerable to Steel-types, so Shadow Ball and Mystical Fire are reasonable alternatives.

  • Draining Kiss versus Moonblast: Moonblast's far superior damage output is a great option versus more defensive teams, while Draining Kiss supplies superior lasting power against more offensive teams.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Since this Flutter Mane is trying to defeat unexpected physical threats one-on-one, Terastallization is great at patching up some matchups that Charm can't on its own, even if it's not required for this set to work.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy Further boosts Moonblast's impressive damage output while removing Flutter Mane's Ghost weakness.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Flutter Mane a very useful resistance to Steel, Ice, and Fire, giving it improved matchups against Scizor, Ting-Lu, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Fire: Tera Fire helps Flutter Mane deal with Scizor and boosts the power of Mystical Fire.

EV Spreads

  • 124 HP / 252 Def / 132 Spe with Timid: The chosen EVs ensure that Flutter Mane will always outspeed Jolly Booster Energy Roaring Moon. Maximum Defense investment gets the most out of Charm with the rest placed into HP.

Choice Specs.description:
• Flutter Mane is an impressive wallbreaker thanks to its nearly unrivaled Speed under sun and unresisted STAB moves and coverage. Mystical Fire notably hits Zacian-C, OHKOing it while sun is up, while also hitting Corviknight. Psyshock is Flutter Mane's strongest attack versus Clodsire, boosted Calm Mind Arceus formes, and Eternatus. Memento is an alternative to facilitate setup from a sweeping teammate such as Swords Dance Koraidon.
  • Tera Fairy strengthens Flutter Mane's Moonblast to devastating levels, letting it 2HKO Arceus formes, bulky Calm Mind Kyogre, and defensive Eternatus while also OHKOing defensive Landorus-T and defensive Groudon with a layer of Spikes. Tera Fairy also notably prevents Flutter Mane from being OHKOed by Kingambit's unboosted Sucker Punch.
  • Flutter Mane fits well on teams that appreciate its ability to wallbreak for Calm Mind Arceus and Miraidon. Thanks to Protosynthesis, when sun is up, Flutter Mane outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, letting it act as a very strong revenge killer as well. Flutter Mane also has the important niche of being one of three viable Fairy-types, which is key in letting it switch into the myriad of strong Dragon-type moves in the tier.
  • Flutter Mane pairs best with Koraidon, as Koraidon sets up sun to boost Flutter Mane's Speed and also uses U-turn to pivot it into Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Groudon, and Landorus-T. Both Flutter Mane and Koraidon also wear down Arceus-Fairy and Toxapex for each other, making them a very potent core. Flutter Mane also pairs well with Kyogre, as they both pressure a similar subset of checks in Eternatus, Koraidon, Clodsire, and Toxapex. Kyogre can also switch into Choice Scarf Koraidon's Flare Blitz if Flutter Mane doesn't want to risk a Speed tie. Since Flutter Mane is such a potent wallbreaker, it appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Groudon. Groudon in particular is a very potent partner for checking the physical attackers that can take advantage of Flutter Mane while also setting sun for it. Miraidon and Eternatus are other good partners for appreciating Flutter Mane potentially breaking through Ting-Lu and Clodsire.
  • Flutter Mane primarily has issues entering the field versus physical attackers such as Zacian-C, Arceus formes, and Kingambit. As a result, Pokemon such as Groudon, Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Landorus-T pair well with it by checking the aforementioned Pokemon. Kyogre, Clodsire, and Arceus formes can also check Flutter Mane prior to it Terastallizing, so checks to them such as Eternatus, Arceus-Ground, and Koraidon are appreciated.

Life Orb.description:
• Life Orb allows Flutter Mane to become an impressive wallbreaker and sweeper thanks to its strong neutral coverage and extremely fast Speed backed by Protosynthesis.
  • Calm Mind can ease prediction on switches without having Life Orb recoil, and it gives Flutter Mane the strength to clean up teams much more easily.
  • Taunt allows Flutter Mane to take advantage of its huge Speed stat to become an effective anti-lead against Pokemon such as Ribombee and Meowscarada, which are too fast for Taunt Arceus to handle. It can also be useful in a pinch to prevent dangerous setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Arceus formes from boosting.
  • Substitute can take advantage of predicted switches, and it gives Flutter Mane a useful option against Sucker Punch Kingambit, although the HP loss can quickly add up with Life Orb recoil. Its most notable use is to scout for enemy Tera types.
  • Mystical Fire nails Steel-types like Zacian-C and Corviknight, which otherwise wall Flutter Mane. Mystical Fire notably has a chance to OHKO Zacian-C at +1 in the sun.
  • Psyshock obliterates Clodsire, which otherwise walls this set. Additionally, it comes in handy against Calm Mind Arceus formes that may Terastallize into the Poison typing to resist a predicted Moonblast.
  • Tera Fairy powers up Flutter Mane's strongest attack in Moonblast, letting it OHKO Ting-Lu after a Calm Mind.
  • Koraidon is a near necessity as a teammate, setting the sun to activate Protosynthesis. Choice Scarf Koraidon in particular is a great teammate, as it can bring Flutter Mane in easily on common switch-ins such as Skeledirge and Landorus-T. Koraidon also helps break down shared checks such as Arceus formes and Kyogre.
  • Additional special attackers such as Miraidon and Kyogre can assist in overwhelming common specially bulky Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Arceus formes, making them good teammates.
  • Despite its pathetic Defense stat and Life Orb recoil, Flutter Mane offers legitimate defensive utility for teams thanks to its myriad of immunities as well as its decent Special Defense. It features as a prominent Dragon-type switch-in on teams that forgo Zacian-C or Arceus-Fairy, which is especially helpful for Miraidon. Its Normal- and Fighting-type immunities come in handy for both Koraidon and Extreme Killer Arceus. It should be noted, however, that switching into these is very high-risk, high-reward, as while Flutter Mane can take great advantage of its immunities, a wrong prediction will result in an easy OHKO for the opponent.
  • Flutter Mane's extremely threatening nature and low defenses mean that it often forces a reactionary Tera from the opponent, often Tera Fire from Koraidon or Zacian-C or Tera Poison from Arceus formes. Care should be taken to not risk Flutter Mane in such situations when it isn't needed.

Speed Booster.description:
• Flutter Mane is one the strongest Pokemon in DOU thanks to its fantastic Speed and Special Attack, as well its Fairy / Ghost typing that offers practically unresisted STAB coverage on the metagame. Moonblast and Shadow Ball are Flutter Mane's strongest attacks, threatening substantial damage into nearly every Pokemon in the tier. Dazzling Gleam is a source of reliable spread damage that Flutter Mane can use late-game to clean up heavily weakened foes or to provide the chip damage its teammates need to secure KOs.

  • The HP and Defense EVs allow Flutter Mane to survive a Tera Dark Black Glasses Kingambit's Sucker Punch. The Speed EVs with the Timid nature provide enough Speed to outrun Tornadus, as well as making Protosynthesis boost Speed. When Booster Energy activates Protosynthesis, Flutter Mane will outspeed all unboosted Pokemon with the exception of the uncommon Regieleki.

  • Tera Fairy can be used to amplify the wallbreaking power of Flutter Mane's Fairy STAB attacks. It can also be used to gain a resistance to Dark-type attacks, most notably Sucker Punch from the Dark-type powerhouses Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Tera Ghost allows Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball to get the OHKO on Basculegion-F and opposing bulky Flutter Mane. Defensively, it allows Flutter Mane to lose its commonly targeted weakness to Steel-type attacks.

  • Flutter Mane's Ghost typing can often be very valuable for its immunity to Normal-type attacks, particularly against Tera Normal Choice Band Dragonite that are looking to lock into Extreme Speed, so it's sometimes valuable to preserve this and avoid Terastallizing Flutter Mane into a pure Fairy-type.

  • As Booster Energy is a consumable held item, it's important to be careful about when Flutter Mane is brought in for the first time, to take advantage of the Speed boost. This means leading with Booster Energy Flutter Mane is often ill advised against teams with fast Pokemon such as Chien-Pao and common Choice Scarf users like Basculegion-F, as it may need to preserve the Speed boost until the right moment to pressure these fast Pokemon.

  • Against bulky teams with slower Pokemon, Flutter Mane can usually afford to be less cautious with the timing of its Booster Energy use, as it will outspeed many Pokemon without its Protosynthesis active. However, it is very notable that with the Speed boost Flutter Mane is capable of outspeeding many of these slower Pokemon even when they are supported by Tailwind, which can be key tool in these matchups.

  • With the damage output of this set being lower compared to the common Choice Specs, Booster Energy Flutter Mane isn't often getting OHKOs. This means it trades poorly with some of the tier's bulkier Pokemon such as common Assault Vest users like Rillaboom and Iron Hands, if they're still healthy. Because of this, Flutter Mane often wants to come in on weakened foes to pick them off safely using its Speed advantage.

  • Mane can find a spot on practically any style of team. Common checks to Flutter Mane include bulky Fairy-resisting Pokemon such as Volcanion, Heatran, and Amoonguss, which can comfortably take Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball. The former two often aim to respond with their Steel-type attacks, while the latter can shut down Flutter Mane with Spore. One option to handle these is Landorus-T, which threatens the Fire-types with a super effective Stomping Tantrum and shuts down Amoonguss with Taunt. With Stealth Rock, Landorus-T can also significantly weaken Volcanion each time it switches in and chip other foes to put them in Flutter Mane's KO range. Landorus-T's Intimidate also helps Flutter Mane take physical attacks better, as it has very low Defense.

  • Chi-Yu is another strong partner for Flutter Mane. Chi-Yu's Beads Of Ruin boosts Flutter Mane's damage output, as well as Chi-Yu threatening Rillaboom and Amoonguss with powerful Fire-type attacks. In addition, Chi-Yu can use Snarl to make Flutter Mane extremely difficult to take down with special attacks.

  • Two other attack options are Hex and Icy Wind. Hex, as an alternative to Shadow Ball, can be used on teams with abundant status options, such as Glimmora's Toxic Debris, Amoonguss's Spore, and Thundurus's Thunder Wave. Icy Wind on the other hand is a dynamic speed control option with which the high Speed Flutter Mane supports its slower teammates.

Choice Specs.description: This EV spread survives a Tera Dark Black Glasses Kingambit Sucker Punch and outspeeds Tornadus.

Flare Boost.description: Flame Orb + Flare Boost grants Flutter Mane a pseudo-immunity to crippling status like paralysis and poison while granting a power boost that cannot be removed by Knock Off. At +2, Flutter Mane is capable of 2HKOing even Ice Scales Arceus formes with Astral Barrage. Due to Flutter Mane's naturally low HP stat, Pain Split is an effective way to increase its longevity while notably annoying Chansey and being ineffective for Imposter users. Tera Fairy boosts Moonblast's damage while shedding Flutter Mane's Ghost weakness, making it useful against Knock Off and stray Ghost-type moves. Tera Ghost further boosts Astral Barrage, helping Flutter Mane break past walls like Calm Mind Ice Scales Arceus formes, and helps defensively against Dialga-O's Revelation Dance. Tera Steel prevents potential revenge killing from Iron Bundle's Boomburst and Koraidon's Gigaton Hammer, as well as resisting Dialga-O's Revelation Dance. Flutter Mane pairs very well with other special attackers, such as Palkia-O, Eternatus, and setup Arceus formes, that place heavy pressure on opposing special walls like Chansey and Ice Scales Dialga-O. Setup Arceus formes can also inflict Chansey with poison using Toxic or Mortal Spin, greatly increasing Flutter Mane's capability of stalling it out of recovery. Defensive pivots like Ting-Lu can provide entry hazard support, deny momentum from Chansey, and pivot Flutter Mane in safely. Paralysis support from the likes of Ting-Lu can also slow down the troublesome Zacian, which outspeeds and threatens Flutter Mane. Imposter-proof Flutter Mane with a special wall with a relatively low HP stat like Ice Scales Zacian, though your Chansey can also Imposter-proof it at the risk of providing Pain Split healing for the opposing Imposter.

Pixilate.description: Pixilate Flutter Mane takes advantage of the lack of sturdy Fairy-resistant special walls to fire off powerful Pixilate-boosted Boombursts. Volt Switch retains momentum, chips checks like Chansey and Ice Scales Zacian, and scouts Terastallization. Pain Split increases Flutter Mane's longevity while chipping Chansey for good damage. Trick is an alternative to cripple special walls like Chansey for teammates. Tera Fairy further boosts Boomburst's damage output, letting it 2HKO Ice Scales Zacian, as well as 2HKOing Ice Scales Dialga-O and Arceus formes after 1 layer of Spikes. Flutter Mane greatly appreciates Knock Off support from teammates like Ting-Lu to remove items like Assault Vest, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Chansey's Eviolite to enhance its offensive potential. Entry hazards and paralysis support from the likes of Ting-Lu and Dialga-O help chip down special walls into 2HKO range and neutralize faster threats like Zacian, respectively. Other special attackers like Palkia-O and Eternatus can capitalize on crippled special walls from Flutter Mane's Trick. Flutter Mane can be easily Imposter-proofed by your own Chansey, but a Ground-type like Ice Scales Arceus-Ground can deny momentum from the Imposter user's Volt Switch.

Choice Band.description: STAB U-turn and First Impression combined with a massive Attack stat make Slither Wing a solid wallbreaker, revenge killer, and pivot. First Impression clears Pokemon such as Kartana while also denting Bug-resistant Pokemon such as Dragapult and Mega Lopunny. U-turn lets Slither Wing obtain momentum while also chipping switch-ins like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T. Flare Blitz tears through Gholdengo and is Slither Wing's strongest attack against Landorus-T and Gliscor, while Earthquake hits Pokemon like Toxapex and Skeledirge while still threatening Gholdengo as well. Tera Bug bolsters First Impression's power to high levels, maximizing Slither Wing's revenge killing potential and enabling it to spread much more chip damage with U-turn; however, it gains a Stealth Rock weakness. Slither Wing pairs well with Mega Charizard Y, as it enables Protosynthesis, which lets Slither Wing threaten the opposition more often. It also boosts Flare Blitz, letting it dent Landorus-T and Gliscor better. In return, Mega Charizard Y threatens Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo. Special wallbreakers that wear down Slither Wing checks such as Mega Diancie and Tapu Koko pair well with it; they also benefit from Slither Wing breaking their checks. Slither Wing lures in Flying-types such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Dragonite, so Pokemon such as Weavile and Tapu Koko pair well with it, both notably forcing Dragonite to Terastallize into the Normal-type and making it prone to First Impression.

Choice Scarf (Bug).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Wallbreaker (Bug).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Choice Band.description: With a terrifyingly high Attack stat and access to strong STAB moves, Slither Wing stands out as a strong wallbreaker, being able to break through some of the tier's most common physical walls, including Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Quaquaval. First Impression is able to snipe common revenge killers, OHKOing the likes of Chien-Pao, Barraskewda, and all Ogerpon formes. Flare Blitz allows Slither Wing to hit Fluffy users like Zapdos and Great Tusk as well as non-Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, while Earthquake hits the likes of Ceruledge, Skeledirge, and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo, which otherwise resist or are immune to its moves. Sword of Ruin allows Slither Wing to safely 2HKO Corviknight and defensive Great Tusk with Close Combat, while Tinted Lens helps it OHKO offensive Zapdos with First Impression after slight chip damage and also deal solid damage against foes that resist Bug such as Dragonite and Great Tusk. Scrappy is a niche alternative that lets Slither Wing easily OHKO Gholdengo and Gengar and still 2HKO Corviknight. Slither Wing pairs well with fast cleaners like Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, as they can easily take over games after it has chipped down physically defensive walls like Corviknight, defensive Quaquaval, and Great Tusk. Slither Wing is fairly slow and susceptible to being OHKOed from the likes of Dragonite, Iron Moth, and Azelf, so defensive pivots like Corviknight and Manaphy are greatly appreciated, and they can also bring it in safely. Slither Wing also dislikes entry hazards, so hazard removal from the likes of Great Tusk or Corviknight is helpful, as this allows it to come in more often.

Booster Energy.description: Tera Blast should only be used alongside Tera Ice.

Offensive Pivot.description:
Sandy Shocks can work as an excellent pivot on offensive teams, leveraging its high Speed and Special Attack to confound switch-ins with Volt Switch, which significantly chips even most Electric-resistant foes like Dragapult and Breloom and allows for a powerful teammate like Meowscarada to be brought in safely. Tera Fairy Tera Blast also provides Sandy Shocks with incredible coverage alongside its STAB moves, threatening Pokemon such as defensive Garchomp, Hydreigon, and Dragapult that are otherwise mostly satisfactory switch-ins and that threaten Sandy Shocks out in turn. In particular, Great Tusk goes from an adequate check to being cleanly OHKOed by Tera Blast assuming it is safe to stay in. Tera Fairy also lets Sandy Shocks resist Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Stealth Rock and Spikes both provide invaluable entry hazard support for Sandy Shocks and its teammates to wear down counters, while Thunderbolt is a solid option to maintain an Electric-type STAB move without being forced to switch out, especially when it can immediately threaten a KO late-game on chipped targets like Slowking and Rotom-W. With 252 Speed EVs, even a Modest Sandy Shocks still crucially outpaces all variants of Great Tusk, Gholdengo, and Rotom-W; a Timid nature can be run instead to also outpace Hydreigon at the cost of some power. When it comes to the item slot, Heavy-Duty Boots is perhaps the most straightforward item for Sandy Shocks, as being a pivot, Sandy Shocks gaining an immunity to hazards, which allows it to come in and wreak havoc many more times per game. However, Expert Belt provides a much-appreciated power boost, especially when going Modest for extra damage, since Sandy Shocks's Electric + Ground + Fairy coverage hits nearly the entire metagame super effectively. In particular, it guarantees that Earth Power will always 2HKO Clodsire and guarantees the OHKO on bulky Kingambit.

Sandy Shocks shines on momentum-based bulky offense teams, so other Pokemon that can maintain momentum such as Choice item Dragapult, Meowscarada, Slowking, Rotom-W, and Scizor, as well as Eject Button users like offensive Great Tusk are good teammates. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Meowscarada, Garchomp, and Great Tusk is also excellent, since the hazard chip will stack with the numerous switches forced by Sandy Shocks. Additional Stealth Rock users in particular are appreciated because they free Sandy Shocks's fourth moveslot up to run Spikes or Thunderbolt more freely. Meowscarada is an excellent choice with several of its sets, as its Knock Off removes the Heavy-Duty Boots that Sandy Shocks's switch-ins rely on to not get worn down by hazards, it can set hazards itself, its U-turn forms the potent VoltTurn combination with Sandy Shocks, and its Flower Trick is extremely threatening to the Ground-types like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu that can tank Sandy Shocks's Volt Switch assault. If not running Heavy-Duty Boots, Sandy Shocks can be worn down itself by Spikes, minimizing its effectiveness, and so hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight form prurient teammates. Sandy Shocks's relative frailty and weakness-laden typing means that faster Pokemon like Meowscarada, Garchomp, Dragapult, Cinderace, and Walking Wake, as well as Choice Scarf users such as specific variants of Rotom-W and Gholdengo, can immediately force Sandy Shocks out, lest its meager bulk causes it to be unceremoniously OHKOed. Strong priority moves like Kingambit's Sucker Punch and Azumarill's Aqua Jet present similar issues. As such, additional, more defensive pivots such as the aforementioned Corviknight and Rotom-W serve double duty, as they can act as a buffer against these threats without completely ceding momentum.

Booster Energy.description:
Sandy Shocks's appeal comes from its high Special Attack and ability to come in at +1 Speed with Booster Energy to pressure common spinners, letting it be one of the best offensive entry hazard setters in the tier. With the lack of reliable Ground-resistant Pokemon, Earth Power becomes incredibly spammable, targeting opposing hazard setters like Glimmora, Garganacl, Iron Treads, Torkoal, and Iron Moth. Earth Power also deals massive damage to Great Tusk, limiting its spinning capabilities. Thunderbolt is an excellent second STAB move, as it targets Flying-types such as Corviknight, Pelipper, and Iron Jugulis, as well as heavily punishing Rotom-W. Thunderbolt also hits threatening Water-types, 2HKOing Azumarill, Dondozo, and Slowking while also OHKOing Greninja. Both of these STAB moves 2HKO Toxapex as well. Stealth Rock or Spikes are very useful on Sandy Shocks because it threatens out almost every entry hazard remover, namely Great Tusk, Torkoal, Corviknight, Cinderace, Glimmora, and Talonflame. Tera Fairy Tera Blast is the perfect coverage tool for Sandy Shocks because it targets threats that would normally wall it, such as Hydreigon and Meowscarada, and it can land surprise KOs on would-be switch-ins like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Roaring Moon while also 2HKOing Garchomp. The Fairy typing has great defensive utility as well, resisting priority moves such as Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Meowscarada and Mach Punch from Breloom.

Sandy Shocks fits best on hyper offense and bulky offense teams. Its ability to immediately get up entry hazards and threaten other hazard setters is instrumental for the success of hyper offense, and not activating Glimmora's Toxic Debris in the hyper offense mirror match is very useful. On bulky offense teams, it can offer more flexibility, setting up hazards and pressuring opposing defensive cores. With its great Speed stat after a Protosynthesis boost, Sandy Shocks threatens offensive Pokemon that would otherwise outspeed it like Dragapult. It also forces damage on bulkier Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Rotom-W, so teammates such as Iron Moth and Dragonite that appreciate these being weakened work best. Ground-immune teammates like Dragonite and Rotom-W also help Sandy Shocks on bulky offense teams, switching into foes like Great Tusk. Opposing Meowscarada is problematic for this set, as it essentially forces it to Terastallize, so teammates that can handle it like Kingambit and Iron Valiant are also very useful. Amoonguss can generally take advantage of Sandy Shocks too, threatening Spore on teammates, so Gholdengo is another great teammate; it also blocks Rapid Spin and Defog.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks is a valuable form of speed control, outspeeding and revenge killing promient Pokemon like Mega Aerodactyl, Cinderace, and Alakazam, as well as being a great offensive pivot thanks to its high Special Attack and threatening movepool. Thunderbolt is notably effective at targeting the tier's plethora of Water- and Flying-types, OHKOing Galarian Zapdos and Mega Aerodactyl after Stealth Rock and 2HKOing Tapu Fini, Slowbro, and Galarian Moltres. Earth Power targets Rock-, Steel, and Fire-types, OHKOing the likes of Iron Moth and Excadrill while dealing significant damage to foes like Mega Tyranitar. Spikes can be used to chip down foes, though it forces Sandy Shocks out after using it, making it risky against setup sweepers. Alternatively, Power Gem deals super effective damage to Thundurus and Thundurus-T and chips Hydreigon. Sandy Shocks can pair excellently with other entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Mega Tyranitar, and Skarmory, as they help it guarantee a 2HKO on foes such as defensive Celesteela after Stealth Rock chip, and they can also wear down checks like Tapu Bulu and Hippowdon for it. In return, Sandy Shocks can spread hazards alongside them while also threatening removal options like Tapu Fini and Excadrill. Offensive pivots such as Cinderace and Galarian Zapdos form a VoltTurn core with Sandy Shocks, being able to pivot each other in to threaten Pokemon that can wall it like Mega Latias, Mega Venusaur, and Blissey. Sandy Shocks's average defenses make it appreciate having bulky teammates like Skarmory, Tapu Fini, and Teleport Blissey that can pivot into foes like Tapu Bulu, Hydreigon, and Mega Latias, and they can offer a backbone to it whenever it locks itself into Spikes.

Offensive Pivot.description: Sandy Shocks is a niche pivot thanks to its ability to switch into threats like Tornadus-T and Tapu Koko. Tera Blast with Tera Ice allows Sandy Shocks to blast through Ground- and Flying-types that are immune to its STAB moves like Garchomp, Dragonite, and most notably, Landorus-T. Alternatively, Tera Grass with Tera Blast is another option to hit Mega Swampert and Gastrodon super effectively and gives it a resistance to Ground, although it becomes completely ruined by Gliscor. If not using Tera Blast, Stealth Rock and Spikes allow Sandy Shocks to support its teammates by wearing down threats like Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and Tornadus-T. Tera Ground allows Sandy Shocks to boost the power of Earth Power, take less entry hazard damage, and shed its Ground weakness. Pokemon that appreciate being safely brought in like Heatran, Dragapult, and Annihilape against threats to it such as Ferrothorn, Dragonite, and Weavile are great partners for Sandy Shocks. Knock Off support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Great Tusk allows Sandy Shocks to capitalize on chipping down switch-ins like Dragonite and Tornadus-T. Sandy Shocks struggles against Ground-types without Tera Blast or if another teammate Terastallizes, therefore, Pokemon that threaten them such as Kartana, Walking Wake, and Weavile are great teammates.

Entry Hazard Support (Electric).description:
Provides Speed Protosynthesis. Can do an EV spread of 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe to 2HKO physically defensive Quagsire instead.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Gravity (Ground).description:
Sandy Shocks is an incredibly useful part of any Ground team thanks to its combination of being able to threaten common types that Ground struggles against such as Flying and Water and good team support in Gravity, making its teammates' and its Ground STAB attacks more threatening without any Ground-immune Pokemon. Its Speed tier is also good enough to outspeed Urshifu-R, a big threat to Ground-type teams, while allowing Ground teams to muscle past Moltres Flying teams, which can outlast Ground teams. Gravity not only allows it to hit Flying types such as Thundurus-T and Zapdos that don't care about its Electric STAB moves, but it also lets its teammates such as Landorus, Ursaluna, and Choice Scarf Great Tusk spam their Ground-type attacks without worrying about Ground-immune Pokemon. While Gravity is certainly useful, it comes with the drawback that opposing Ground-type moves from Pokemon such as Landorus-T or Iron Treads cannot be avoided. Earth Power is its Ground STAB attack, which also benefits from the Gravity that Sandy Shocks sets up and hits Electric-immune Pokemon such as Clodsire and Quagsire hard. This, along with Thunderbolt, allows Sandy Shocks to threaten the whole of Water teams. Finally, Volt Switch lets Sandy Shocks pivot out into a teammate that can either take an attack for it or deal big damage. Heavy-Duty Boots is Sandy Shocks's item of choice, allowing it to switch in multiple times to set Gravity and pivot out with Volt Switch without worrying about residual hazard damage. An alternative EV spread of 48 HP / 208 SpA / 252 Spe can be used for a Speed-boosting Protosynthesis, but this spread worsens the chance of a 2HKO on Quagsire.

Landorus is a great teammate for Sandy Shocks, as Landorus's already-scary STAB- and Sheer Force-boosted Earth Power gets even scarier when almost nothing is immune to it. Additionally, Landorus can take Ground-type attacks aimed at Sandy Shocks by virtue of its Flying typing while hitting Grass- and Fairy-types hard with Sheer Force-boosted Sludge Bomb. In return, Sandy Shocks can pivot Landorus in using Volt Switch, as well as offensively threatening Water-types that threaten Landorus such as Urshifu-R. Ursaluna is another good teammate, as it is simply terrifying when Flying-types cannot safely switch into its Earthquake alongside being able to smash Grass-types with Fire Punch and crush Ghost-types with the sheer power of its Guts-boosted Earthquakes and its ability to deal with Spectrier thanks to Guts. Additionally, Ursaluna's bulk lets it take a hit when it switches in through Sandy Shocks' Volt Switch. Great Tusk provides Rapid Spin support on Bulk Up sets and speed control by virtue of its Choice Scarf set alongside Ice Spinner to help Sandy Shocks deal with opposing Landorus and Grass-types such as Hisuian Lilligant. Additionally, Great Tusk's power under Gravity cannot be understated, as its Ground STAB moves deal serious damage and can easily break through opposing teams. Clodsire can take Grass- and Fighting-type attacks such as Choice Scarf Meowscarada's Flower Trick and Zamazenta’s Close Combat with ease alongside forming a chip damage core with Sandy Shocks through Volt Switch and Toxic damage. Additionally, Clodsire's Water immunity lets it soak up attacks such as Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes and Basculegion-F's Water STAB move of choice, and it is generally a rather good special wall. Quagsire is a good defensive partner for Sandy Shocks, as it can wall Chien-Pao and Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and threaten them back with Body Press, as well as being able to set hazards. Iron Treads functions as a check to Fairy-types such as Hatterene and Flutter Mane who can take Sandy Shocks' attacks and threaten it back while also having Ice-type coverage to hit Flying- and Grass-types. Alongside those attributes, Iron Treads also has Knock Off, allowing it to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from common users such as Quagsire and Amoonguss, letting Sandy Shocks gradually wear them down over the course of the game. Finally, Ting-Lu's sheer bulk allows it to take strong hits such as Dragonite's boosted Extreme Speed that Sandy Shocks can't while setting up hazards to chip away at common answers to Sandy Shocks such as opposing Ting-Lu.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon might have a niche in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2, though their viability is uncertain. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Hadron Engine.description: Sandy Shocks functions as a great offensive pivot thanks to its excellent offensive typing and ability to set entry hazards. Volt Switch lets Sandy Shocks pivot out of problematic matchups such as RegenVest Roaring Moon and Meloetta. Stealth Rock and Spikes allow Sandy Shocks to set up hazards against foes like Corviknight, Manaphy, and Zapdos, which are normally forced to switch out. Choice Scarf helps Sandy Shocks with its average Speed, turning it into a revenge killer and letting it outpace and OHKO other revenge killers like Barraskewda, Chien-Pao, and Iron Moth, while Heavy-Duty Boots lets it come in safely more often and also does not lock it into a move. Sandy Shocks forms great VoltTurn cores, so other offensive pivots such as Barraskewda, Meowscarada, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon are great teammates. Stronger wallbreakers like Walking Wake and Gengar appreciate Sandy Shocks's ability to chip down special walls such as Empoleon, RegenVest Manaphy, and Hisuian Goodra, which gives them an easier time breaking through these foes. Sandy Shocks is completely walled by the likes of Landorus, Iron Treads, and Volt Absorb Corviknight, so physical wallbreakers like Ogerpon-C and Chien-Pao are helpful in order to pressure them. Sandy Shocks is vulnerable to faster revenge killers like Barraskewda and Chien-Pao if it's not running Choice Scarf, meaning that defensive pivots like Corviknight and Manaphy are appreciated as well.

Immunity Ability.description: Immunity ability Sandy Shocks is a decent physical tank when it gets going due to its access to Iron Defense + Body Press and utility like Spikes. Iron Defense allows it to defend itself from common physical attackers like Great Tusk and Ogerpon-H, and Body Press threatens Electric-immune Pokemon like Volt Absorb Empoleon and Corviknight, as well as Motor Drive Manaphy. However, Spikes + Earth Power is an alternative to Iron Defense + Body Press, as it provides entry hazard utility and a secondary STAB move option. Substitute takes advantage of the free turns it can generate with its immunity ability and can block status from slower walls. Since Sandy Shocks doesn't have any form of reliable recovery, Leftovers is the preferred item. The ability choice comes down to team need; Earth Eater punishes Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Garchomp, while Water Absorb is an excellent check to Barraskewda and Zapdos that also can block pivoting from Empoleon. Sandy Shocks works well on hyper and bulky offense, as it can set up easier and can counter passive walls. Therefore, Pokemon that appreciate this ability like Chien-Pao and Dragonite make for good teammates. Despite its ability to increase its physical bulk, it is very vulnerable on the special side, making Pokemon like Gengar and Iron Moth threatening foes. Because of this, Pokemon like RegenVest Roaring Moon and Manaphy make for good teammates.

Specially Defensive.description:
• A decent defensive typing allows Iron Treads to act as a check to Miraidon and Flutter Mane, and use the opportunity to remove or set entry hazards.
  • Knock Off cripples common switch-ins such as Ting-Lu and Corviknight, while Volt Switch keeps momentum for your team.
  • 16 IVs in Defense mean that Iron Treads will receive a Special Defense boost in Electric Terrain, helping with switching into Miraidon.
  • Iron Treads can use Tera Fairy to remove its weaknesses to Fighting and Fire, which can be helpful versus Koraidon and Chien-Pao, and with taking coverage from Miraidon and Flutter Mane. However, it loses its immunity to Electric and resistance to Fairy. Iron Treads can alternatively use Tera Ground for an extra boost to Earthquake, but it suffers from similar demerits as Tera Fairy.
  • Since both Miraidon and Flutter Mane have Fire-type coverage options, Iron Treads appreciates being paired with Pokemon such as Ting-Lu that can handle those attacks. Choice Scarf Koraidon and Booster Energy Flutter Mane are also good teammates, as they can revenge kill Miraidon and Flutter Mane while benefitting from Iron Treads removing entry hazards.
  • Skeledirge's ability to check Koraidon and Iron Valiant also makes it a great partner for Iron Treads. Teammates that can switch into Great Tusk such as Dondozo and Alomomola also pair well, with Alomomola even providing Wish support to increase Iron Treads's longevity.

Assault Vest.description:
• Assault Vest allows Iron Treads to utilize an offensive spread while still letting it be a fairly safe option against Miraidon and Flutter Mane.
  • Iron Head allows Iron Treads to beat Tera Fairy Miraidon.
  • Knock Off can remove crucial items from foes like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Corviknight.
  • Volt Switch is useful for grabbing momentum on non-Ground-type foes that switch in on Iron Treads like Corviknight, Koraidon, Dondozo, and Pelipper.
  • A Jolly nature gives Iron Treads a Speed boost from Quark Drive, which is often crucial to be able to beat Choice Specs Miraidon one-on-one, and lets it pick off foes that would normally outspeed it without Electric Terrain.
  • Ground is the preferred Tera type to boost the power of Earthquake while weakening incoming Fire- and Fighting-type attacks; alternatively, other Tera types can provide defensive utility but not any offensive boost.
  • This set works best on offensive teams where it is paired up with teammates that are weak to Fairy-type moves, such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao. Iron Treads allows these Pokémon to be played more freely because it can reliably deal with Flutter Mane and opposing Miraidon while applying offensive pressure itself.
  • Flutter Mane is another great teammate because Iron Treads lures Corviknight and weakens it with Knock Off or Volt Switch, this gives Flutter Mane an easier time to break through enemy teams.

Offensive.description:
Iron Treads is a valid offensive spinner in the metagame. With its high Attack and Speed, paired with Booster Energy for more Speed, Iron Treads can threaten a foe with its high-Base Power moves. Earthquake hits Skeledirge, Toxapex, Garganacl, Gholdengo, Glimmora, and Kingambit super effectively, while Iron Head hits Hatterene, Iron Valiant, and Tera Fairy Garganacl super effectively. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can turn Iron Treads into a fast hazard setter that exerts offensive pressure. Knock Off provides utility in removing Leftovers from Dondozo, Rotom-W, and Corviknight. Rapid Spin provides the most utility, as it keeps entry hazards clear to better help its teammates switch in without fearing chip damage. Booster Energy allows Iron Treads to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, notably outspeeding fast threats such as +1 Dragonite, Dragapult, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, Meowscarada, and Iron Valiant. A Ground Tera Type is ideal to maximize Earthquake's damage output against Garganacl, Dragapult, Skeledirge, and Volcarona while removing its weakness to Fire. However, it can instead run Tera Flying for an immunity to Great Tusk's Headlong Rush and Dragonite's Earthquake, as well as a resistance to Breloom's Mach Punch and Great Tusk's Close Combat.

Iron Treads fits well on offensive teams, taking the role of an offensive spinner and potential Stealth Rock user. It can support offensive teammates like Roaring Moon, Iron Moth, and Volcarona with entry hazard control, threatening Gholdengo and deterring it from spinblocking. If running Stealth Rock, other hazard setters like Meowscarada and Greninja can form an effective entry hazard-stacking core with Iron Treads. Iron Treads struggles against Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Dondozo due to their high Defense. As such, wallbreakers such as Iron Valiant and Gholdengo can support it.

Utility.description:
Iron Treads can perform as a decent utility Pokemon thanks to its wide movepool. It faces stronger competition from its counterpart, Great Tusk, due to the latter's typing, better physical bulk, better Attack, and a wider movepool. However, Iron Treads stands out due to its faster Speed and its access to Volt Switch, which allows it to serve as a fast offensive pivot. With Stealth Rock, Iron Treads can wear down Pokemon that dislike entry hazards like Dragapult, Roaring Moon, and Booster Energy Iron Moth, limiting their opportunities to switch in. Rapid Spin allows Iron Treads to remove hazards from its side while also boosting its Speed, allowing it to threaten Pokemon that would normally outspeed it like Cinderace. Volt Switch not only allows Iron Treads to perform as a pivot but also deals super effective damage to Flying-types like Corviknight and Tera Flying Kingambit. Alternatively, Knock Off can be used to remove important items such as Leftovers from defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Garganacl as well as Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon vulnerable to hazards such as Dragonite and Skeledirge. Knock Off also allows Iron Treads to deal super effective damage to Air Balloon Gholdengo. Tera Flying completely removes Iron Treads's weakness to Ground-types and turns it into an immunity, allowing it to switch into Great Tusk. Leftovers grants Iron Treads a form of longevity so it can find more opportunities to pivot into teammates. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used as well to help Iron Treads pivot more consistently into teammates while not getting worn down from hazards.

Iron Treads fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its offensive utility in order for their team members to function in their roles more effectively. Wallbreakers such as Iron Valiant and Iron Moth pair well with Iron Treads, since they appreciate being brought in by Volt Switch. In return, they can take on defensive Pokemon Iron Treads struggles with, such as Ting-Lu for the former and Amoonguss for the latter. Garchomp, Meowscarada, and Greninja make for great partners, since the three of them can stack Spikes with Iron Treads to wear down incoming foes into KO range from one of the team's offensive Pokemon. If Iron Treads is running Volt Switch, it could have a hard time pivoting into its teammates, since Ground-types like Great Tusk and Garchomp can switch into it if its predicted. Hence, teammates that can handle Ground-types like Rotom-W pair well with Iron Treads. Lastly, sweepers such as Walking Wake, Dragonite, and Azumarill appreciate Iron Treads bringing them to sweep. Walking Wake and Azumarill in particular can help in removing Ground-types that can interrupt Iron Treads's pivoting ability.

Choice Scarf (Ground).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Entry Hazard Lead.description: Iron Treads has a niche as an interesting entry hazard lead in the metagame. With both Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, it can lay entry hazards while keeping them off for its teammates, and it is very threatening to Magic Bounce Pokemon in Mega Diancie and Hatterene. Steel Beam allows Iron Treads to sacrifice itself quickly in order to deny Defog attempts from the likes of Tornadus-T, Landorus-T, and Rotom-W. It is also Iron Treads's main tool of pressuring Hatterene, and it is generally powerful enough to chunk certain Ground-resistant and immune Pokemon, like Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Buzzwole. Booster Energy and Quark Drive together allows Iron Treads to outrun the entire unboosted metagame as well as Choice Scarf users like Tapu Lele, Urshifu-R, and Gholdengo, allowing it to consistently lay entry hazards. Tera Ghost allows Iron Treads to block opposing Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk if necessary. Iron Treads should be used as a lead on hyper offense teams, so other support teammates and sweepers are natural partners. Dual screens setters like Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko allow their sweeping teammates another layer of support and safety, and they can use Taunt to consistently deny Defog attempts even after Iron Treads has fainted. Common hyper offense sweepers, like Mega Gyarados, Galarian Moltres, Kingambit, Volcarona, and Baxcalibur appreciate Iron Treads laying Stealth Rock while keeping hazards off at the same time. The former two in particular appreciate this, as Mega Gyarados is weak to Stealth Rock before mega evolving, while Galarian Moltres often prefers other items over Heavy-Duty Boots.

Iron Defense (Ground).description:
Outspeeds Hydreigon.

This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive Utility (Steel).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Special Tank (Ground).description:
Iron Treads complements Ground team's defensive core with its Steel typing—which lets it deal with Fairy- and Ice-types such as Hatterene and Cryogonal— and provides further utility with Rapid Spin. Knock Off dissuades Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Skeledirge from spinblocking and potentially weakens Choice item users such as Meowscarada and Greninja after taking their hit, letting its teammates such as Choice Scarf Great Tusk and Clodsire handle them better. Heavy Slam smashes Fairy-types such as Hatterene and Flutter Mane, while Iron Head better deals with Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur. Protect lets Iron Treads scout common Choice item Pokemon such as Greninja, Flutter Mane, and Iron Valiant while accruing Leftovers recovery. A Jolly nature with 8 Speed EVs lets Iron Treads outspeed Adamant Baxcalibur and Timid Armarouge.

Offensively-inclined teammates such as Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Choice Specs Sandy Shocks, and Garchomp appreciate Iron Treads removing entry hazards and checking Hatterene. In return, Great Tusk deals with Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Choice Specs Greninja; Sandy Shocks breaks down walls such as Corviknight and Skeledirge that take advantage of Iron Treads and is a great asset in the Fire matchup; and Garchomp deals with Water- and Dragon-types such as Barraskewda and Hydreigon. Ting-Lu wears down the opposing team with entry hazards + Whirlwind deals with Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur in a pinch, and runs Throat Chop and Taunt to stop setup threats such as Corviknight and Skeledirge that pose a threat to Ground teams. Water Absorb Clodsire and Gastrodon deals with Water-types such as Dondozo, Quaquaval, and Barraskewda as well as walling Meowscarada and Ice Beam Greninja, respectively, as long as Iron Treads keeps the field free of entry hazards. Alternatively, Clodsire can use Unaware instead to check most special attackers, including Volcarona, Rotom-C, and Gholdengo. Similarly, Unaware Quagsire checks physical setup sweepers such as Belly Drum Azumarill, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao and Mimikyu, and it further wears down the opposing team with Toxic and entry hazards.

Choice Scarf (Steel).description:
Choice Scarf Iron Treads gives Steel teams a much appreciated revenge killer as well as counterplay against Fire-types such as Tauros-Paldea-Blaze and Volcarona, which can overwhelm Steel teams with ease. Heavy Slam utilizes Iron Treads's fairly hefty size to hit Fairy-types such as Hatterene and Mimikyu hard; however, Iron Head can be used as a more consistent STAB to nail heavier targets such as Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Garganacl. Ice Spinner provides great coverage alongside Iron Treads's STAB moves, nailing Grass-types such as Meowscarada before Protean activates and Amoonguss while also nailing Garchomp and Dragonite. Knock Off provides good team support by getting rid of the foe's item, such as Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers from the likes of Dragonite, Volcarona, and Garchomp, whereas Volt Switch allows Iron Treads to pivot out of Pokemon that wall it such as Corviknight and Dondozo.

Corviknight is a fantastic partner for Iron Treads, as it can take Fighting- and Ground-type moves while Iron Treads takes on Electric-types such as Iron Hands and Magnezone for Corviknight. Corviknight can also keep entry hazards off the field with Defog, aiding in Iron Treads's longevity and letting it forgo Rapid Spin. Gholdengo is another great partner, as it not only also helps against Fighting-types that Corviknight can't handle such as Iron Valiant, but it also overwhelms physical walls such as Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Dondozo. Entry hazards from Pokemon such as Tinkaton, Orthworm, and Bronzong also aid in Iron Treads sweeping. Tinkaton specifically ensures Stealth Rock being set due to Mold Breaker while having a decent offensive presence thanks to Gigaton Hammer being so powerful. Orthworm provides a Ground immunity, easing pressure off other teammates such as Corviknight, all while also having Spikes and Stealth Rock. Bronzong can not only set up Stealth Rock, but it can also take on Fire-type moves that are aimed at Iron Treads. Kingambit is a great mid- to late-game sweeper that appreciates Iron Treads's ability to punch holes early-game or clean up after Kingambit has punched holes itself, providing the team with multiple avenues of winning.

Choice Scarf (Ground).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon has a few niches in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Assault Vest.description:
• With a decent defensive typing in Ground / Steel and good bulk, Iron Treads can run an effective Assault Vest set.

  • Iron Head versus Heavy Slam: While Heavy Slam is not as consistent as Iron Head due to Iron Treads's middling weight, it reaches maximum power against targets such as Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant. Heavy Slam gets an OHKO on Iron Valiant and 2HKOes Iron Bundle, which is something that's not achievable with Iron Head, however, Iron Head 2HKOes Baxcalibur, and does non-negligible damage to Dragonite, which isn't possible with Heavy Slam.

  • Rapid Spin: It may seem weird to run Rapid Spin on such a fast-paced-format, but with it, Iron Treads can support teammates like Dragonite and Focus Sash Flutter Mane. Additionally, with a Jolly nature and minimal Speed investment Iron Treads can outrun Timid Iron Bundle after a Rapid Spin.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner gives Iron Treads a move to hit Dragonite, Hydreigon, Garchomp, and Great Tusk hard.

  • Knock Off: Knock Off is Iron Treads's best move against Rotom-W and Rotom-H, and its item removal is valuable all around, crippling both the Pokemon it's supposed to check as well as common switch-ins.

  • Volt Switch: Pivoting can help Iron Treads against physically bulky Pokemon like Dondozo, Corviknight, and Terastallized Garganacl.

  • EV Spread: The EV Spread aims to maximize Iron Treads's ability to take special attacks, especially when coupled with an Assault Vest; the Speed allows it to outspeed Jolly Breloom before a Rapid Spin and Timid Iron Bundle.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying provides Iron Treads with a Ground immunity and a Fighting resistance, along with neutralizing its Fire weakness, which can be useful against Tera Fire Flutter Mane and Sylveon, Skeledirge, Iron Valiant, and Iron Moth.

Offensive Support.description:
• Iron Treads possesses an incredible support movepool along with a great base 106 Speed stat, making it a great support option.

  • Electric Terrain: A manual Electric Terrain may seem odd, but Iron Treads has the bulk to run it and use it to activate its own Quark Drive along with its teammates' if applicable, and the lack of other Terrains in the current series means Electric Terrain can run for its full duration a lot of times. Electric Terrain also blocks sleep moves from foes such as Skeledirge, Espathra, Iron Valiant, Gengar, Breloom, and Brute Bonnet.

  • Rapid Spin: Despite the fast-paced-nature of BSS, Rapid Spin allows Iron Treads to both boost its speed and clear entry hazards from its side of the field, supporting teammates such as Focus Sash Iron Bundle and Dragonite.

  • Knock Off: Along with its item removal ability, Knock Off is Iron Treads's best move to hit Rotom-W and Rotom-H.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner allows Iron Treads to hit foes such as Dragonite and Great Tusk hard, but it should be used carefully if it's run alongside Electric Terrain, as it ends the current active Terrain.

Other Options

  • Heavy Slam: With Heavy Slam, Iron Treads can OHKO Iron Valiant, as well as 2HKO Iron Bundle without Tera Steel. After Terastallizing into Steel, Heavy Slam can OHKO Iron Bundle after a Rapid Spin.

  • Wild Charge: If Iron Treads is holding a Life Orb, Wild Charge is capable of 2HKOing Corviknight in Electric Terrain.

  • Bulldoze: While weaker than Earthquake, Bulldoze is a speed control option for Iron Treads that affects Ghost-types, unlike Rapid Spin.

Tera Types

  • Ground: Tera Ground neutralizes Iron Treads's Fire, Ground, and Fighting weaknesses and ramps up the power of its Earthquake.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gets rid of Iron Treads's Water weakness and gives it resistances to Ice and Grass.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Booster Energy increases Iron Treads's speed even further, allowing it to outspeed Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Dragapult and slower Choice Scarf foes, making it very likely to get a move off first.

  • Terrain Extender: Terrain Extender increases the duration of Terrains to eight turns, giving Iron Treads or one of its Quark Drive teammates more turns to make use of their ability.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash is an option for ensuring Iron Treads can get at least one move off against faster foes that can KO it.

  • Air Balloon: An Air Balloon allows Iron Treads to have an edge against other Ground-type leads such as Garchomp.

  • Life Orb: When used alongside Electric Terrain, Life Orb boosts Iron Treads's offensive pressure, and a Terrain-boosted Wild Charge can 2HKO Corviknight.

Ground Immunity.description: Iron Treads is an excellent spinner that is able to switch into common entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Landorus-T with its own Levitate while also being able to use Knock Off on common switch-ins such as Corviknight. Iron Treads can opt to be a hazard setter itself with Stealth Rock, keep up momentum with Volt Switch on targets like Corviknight, or use Heavy Slam as a strong STAB option for Scream Tail and Chien-Pao. Levitate allows Iron Treads to be immune to Spikes while also being able to spin them away, whereas Earth Eater can be used as an alternative for better longevity against hazard setters like Garchomp and Smack Down Landorus-T. Offensive Pokemon that are weak to hazards such as Chien-Pao and Thundurus-T appreciate Iron Treads's ability to keep hazards off the field, as well as being able to pivot them in safely with Volt Switch. Strong physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Kingambit also are good teammates for Iron Treads, as they can more easily break through Corviknight with Knock Off support from Iron Treads. Iron Treads can be overwhelmed by coverage options from hazard setters such as Liquidation Garchomp, so running Wish Scream Tail, which can increase Iron Treads's longevity, or a secondary hazard remover like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also stave off hits, is recommended. Iron Treads is also vulnerable to strong Fighting-type attackers such as Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing, so it is advised to pair it with a Fighting-resistant teammate such as Scream Tail or Fluffy Zapdos.

Fire Immunity.description: Well-Baked Body Iron Treads is a spinner with a great defensive typing in addition to a Fire immunity and ability to compress several roles such as item and entry hazard removal into one Pokemon. It is notably able to threaten the tier's premier spinblocker in Skeledirge, allowing it to remove hazards freely. If there is already a Stealth Rock user on the team, Iron Treads can instead use Heavy Slam to check Calm Mind Scream Tail and Enamorus-T, Rock Slide to OHKO Talonflame and Volcarona, or Volt Switch to bring in teammates safely. 236 Speed EVs are used to outspeed and threaten an OHKO on Jolly Hisuian Arcanine. Pixilate Scream Tail and Primordial Sea users like Inteleon, Greninja, and Quaquaval all appreciate Iron Treads switching into their checks in Desolate Land Fire-types like Iron Moth and Ceruledge. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Hisuian Arcanine appreciate Iron Treads removing items from shared switch-ins like Corviknight and Quaquaval. Fighting- and Ground- types like Galarian Zapdos, Slither Wing, and Garchomp threaten Iron Treads, so defensive partners like Scream Tail, Quaquaval, and Corviknight are recommended. Iron Treads's Rapid Spin also supports the hazard stacking effort from partners like Garchomp and Ting-Lu. Certain Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge can still threaten Iron Treads with their coverage moves, so it appreciates a secondary check to them like Primordial Sea Zapdos.

Choice Specs.description:
• Hydro Pump OHKOes Skeledirge, Arcanine, non-Passho Berry Volcarona, non-Assault Vest Iron Moth, Iron Treads, and physically defensive Espathra.
  • Freeze-Dry beats Dondozo and non-Speed Booster Energy Walking Wake.
  • Blizzard OHKOes non-Assault Vest Iron Leaves and Wo-Chien.
  • Hyper Beam OHKOes opposing Iron Bundle.
  • Iron Bundle can run an alternative EV spread of 232 HP / 68 Def / 160 SpA / 48 Spe with a Timid Nature. The HP and Defense EVs allow Iron Bundle to live a Giga Impact from Choice Band Slaking after Chilling Water. The Speed EVs allow Iron Bundle to outspeed Iron Moth and Adamant Meowscarada.
  • While Ice Beam has a high chance to beat non-specially defensive Pressure stall Corviknight, if you are sure that Corviknight is a specially defensive Pressure stall set, you can attempt to use Hydro Pump to win, but this is not reliable.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

Santa's Slay.description:
• With nearly perfect coverage and an incredible Speed stat, Iron Bundle's ferocious brand of holiday spirit is a metagame-defining force!

  • Encore: Giving the gift of an encore lets Iron Bundle punish passive Pokemon and naughty sweepers alike.

  • Ice Beam: With a power-boosting item, Ice Beam OHKOes Dragonite through Multiscale, and Ursaluna after one turn of burn damage.

  • Flip Turn: Pivoting is a big help when Iron Bundle is facing Pokemon likely to Terastallize such as Heatran and Ursaluna, or against bulky Assault Vest foes such as Hisuian Goodra and Baxcalibur.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Iron Bundle take further advantage of encored Pokemon and is a decent way to scout for Tera types when using Booster Energy or Life Orb. It's especially effective at punishing Sucker Punch revenge killers such as Chien-Pao.

Other Options

  • Taunt: Taunt will make support Pokemon such as Clodsire and Tinkaton want to take a holiday, though watch out for common users of Mental Herb such as Toxapex.

  • Whirlpool: Although difficult to pull off with Iron Bundle's mediocre bulk, trapping foes with Whirlpool can make Encore especially deadly.

  • Electric Terrain: Giving Iron Bundle a Speed boost via Electric Terrain isn't nearly as flexible as Booster Energy, but it does let Iron Bundle support potentially deadly Quark Drive teammates such as Iron Valiant and Iron Hands.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Iron Bundle's perfect coverage and high Speed means its fairly flexible with a team's Terastallization needs.

  • Water: Besides the power boost for Hydro Pump, Tera Water enables a reliable Water-type STAB move in Tera Blast and avoids an OHKO from Choice Scarf Urshifu-R's Close Combat.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Iron Bundle an important immunity to Extreme Speed, which can especially ruin Dragonite's holiday with Encore.

  • Ice: With Tera Ice, Freeze-Dry will OHKO offensive Dragonite through Multiscale and Ice Beam will OHKO even bulky Dragonite and most Assault Vest Thundurus-T.

  • Ground: An immunity to Electric-type attacks lets Iron Bundle potentially give Zapdos, Thundurus-T, and Rotom-W's momentum a snow day and deal more damage to Gholdengo via Tera Blast.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Quark Drive's Speed boost lets Iron Bundle outpace key Choice Scarf and Booster threats such as Flutter Mane, Urshifu-R, Thundurus-T, Greninja, and Dragonite.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs Iron Bundle regifts support moves so it can wallbreak, with moves such as Tera Water Hydro Pump now OHKOing physically defensive Ting-Lu.

  • Focus Sash: Getting around Iron Bundle's iffy bulk makes it a fantastic lead and revenge killer.

  • Life Orb: While Life Orb compromises Iron Bundle's ability to take priority attacks, it boosts damage without passing on powerful support moves.

Bulkier EV Spreads

  • 44 HP / 12 Def / 148 SpA / 52 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid: This bulkier spread survives Jolly Chien-Pao's Sacred Sword and Timid Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

Heavy-Duty Boots.description:
• Freeze-Dry and Hydro Pump make Iron Bundle incredibly threatening with perfect coverage.
  • Taunt can be used to stop recovery and status attempts from walls like Corviknight, while Flip Turn can gain momentum. Encore is effective at PP stalling recovery attempts from Pokemon while also locking Pokemon into suboptimal moves like Stealth Rock to take advantage of.
  • Tera Ice boosts Freeze-Dry's and Ice Beam's power to high levels and also removes the neutrality to Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle, making a potential mirror match safer.
  • Tera Water Iron Bundle has immense power on Hydro Pump; Tera Water also removes its Fighting-type weakness and Fire-type neutrality, which helps against Choice Scarf Great Tusk and Koraidon trying to revenge kill it.
  • Iron Bundle has to use its high Speed to force out frail Pokemon or force defensive Terastallization, both of which it can take advantage of.
  • Getting Iron Bundle safe switch-ins on defensive Pokemon that are threatened by Hydro Pump is the best way to use its offensive capabilities, allowing for defensive answers to be Taunted or pivoted on to wear down opposing teams.
  • Pelipper and Miraidon are strong teammates for Iron Bundle, providing rain and Electric Terrain support to power it up.
  • Entry hazard setters are also very strong, since Iron Bundle appreciates checks like Corviknight and Annihilape being worn down. It also can use Taunt to stop Defog Corviknight and pressure the premier spinners in Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

Choice Specs.description:
• The combination of Hydro Pump and Freeze-Dry gives Iron Bundle an unresisted STAB combination, making it extremely threatening with Choice Specs.
  • Flip Turn allows Iron Bundle to pivot in order to gain momentum, while Ice Beam OHKOes Koraidon and uninvested Miraidon.
  • Tera Ice allows Iron Bundle to further boost its Ice-type moves and resist Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle and Ditto. Tera Water is a good option on teams with rain support in order to let it 2HKO Heavy-Duty Boots Blissey in rain after slight chip.
  • Choice Specs allows Iron Bundle to 2HKO walls such as Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Scream Tail with Hydro Pump as well as Toxapex with Freeze-Dry.
  • Miraidon is a great teammate, as it can lure in Pokemon weak to Hydro Pump such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads and pivot into Iron Bundle using U-turn. It also sets Electric Terrain, giving Iron Bundle a Speed boost upon entry.
  • Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and defensive Great Tusk are great teammates, as Iron Bundle can get worn down pretty quickly from repeatedly switching into Stealth Rock.

doublesou.overview: Boasting a blistering base 136 Speed stat, outrun only by Dragapult, and impressive Special Attack, Iron Bundle is truly a force to be reckoned with in DOU. Its offense especially shines when paired with Chi-Yu, which greatly increases Iron Bundle's damage output with Beads of Ruin. Iron Bundle has excellent speed control with Icy Wind, which, when combined with its high Speed, can easily ensure that it and its allies outspeed the enemy team. However, Iron Bundle is a fairly fragile Pokemon, especially against powerful special attackers such as Chi-Yu and Gholdengo.
doublesou.comments:
Other Options

Iron Bundle can run Encore over Icy Wind or Protect, easily locking most Pokemon into a move such as Protect or Fake Out thanks to its high Speed. On a snow team with Abomasnow, Iron Bundle can run Blizzard as a powerful spread attack, and it also can maximize its damage output with Tera Ice. Snow also boosts Iron Bundle's Defense, making it particularly more effective against priority spam teams with Dragonite and Palafin. 252 HP and 64 Special Defense EVs can be used with Assault Vest to survive an Overheat from Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle still has above 152 Speed EVs left for outspeeding Meowscarada. 40 HP EVs allow Iron Bundle to avoid a potential OHKO from Chien-Pao's Sacred Sword if Chien-Pao lacks a damage-boosting item, so an EV spread of 40 HP / 216 SpA / 252 Spe on less bulky sets could be used instead.

Fast Sweeper.description:
• Hydro Pump is by far Iron Bundle's strongest STAB move. Tera Water can further amplify its power.

  • STAB Freeze-Dry allows Iron Bundle to hit Water-types hard. It is effective against rain teams, being able to OHKO Pelipper, OHKO Barraskewda, and hit Palafin hard.

  • Icy Wind benefits Iron Bundle's slower allies. It functions well against fast Focus Sash Pokemon such as Chien-Pao and Meowscarada, both dealing damage to nullify the Focus Sash and lowering their Speed, which allows Iron Bundle's ally to KO the foe.

  • Protect is used to predict and avoid attacks that threaten to KO Iron Bundle, extending its longevity. It can also help Iron Bundle stall out Trick Room and Tailwind turns.

  • Tera Water increases the power of Hydro Pump and gives Iron Bundle a better defensive typing against Fire- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Chi-Yu and Gholdengo. It also reduces damage taken from Stealth Rock.

  • Booster Energy activates Iron Bundle's Quark Drive, making it among the very fastest Pokemon in Doubles OU. Boosted Iron Bundle outspeeds Gholdengo and Great Tusk in Tailwind, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and Weak Armor-boosted Armarouge. It also Speed ties Chlorophyll Lilligant in sun.

  • Focus Sash complements Iron Bundle's lacking bulk, letting it survive attacks that would OHKO it.

  • Life Orb increases Iron Bundle's overall damage output, enabling it to OHKO a few Pokemon such as Dragapult with Freeze-Dry. However, it doesn't help Iron Bundle preempt foes or take hits, making it far riskier than other items. Life Orb's recoil damage can also put Iron Bundle into KO range from Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

Assault Vest.description:
• Hydro Pump and Freeze-Dry give Iron Bundle unresisted neutral coverage.

  • Icy Wind provides speed control for allies and breaks opposing Focus Sashes.

  • Ice Beam is a more powerful Ice-type move than Freeze-Dry.

  • Flip Turn can give Iron Bundle momentum against switching opponents.

  • 28 Special Attack EVs are enough for Iron Bundle to OHKO Chi-Yu with Hydro Pump. The remaining 228 HP EVs guarantee is survives Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite's Extreme Speed while Chien-Pao's Sword of Ruin is active. Alternatively, 84 Special Attack EVs can be used to guarantee an OHKO on Dragapult with Ice Beam.

  • Assault Vest negates Iron Bundle's special frailty, enabling it to survive powerful special attacks such as Choice Specs Gholdengo's Make it Rain.

Swords Dance.description: The second EV spread allows Iron Hands with Booster Energy to OHKO SpD Clodsire with Earthquake and 2HKO Phys Def variants with Ice Punch after Stealth Rock.

Swords Dance (Electric).description:
Swords Dance combined with a high Attack stat, great coverage, and well-rounded Defense makes Iron Hands a strong wallbreaker for Electric teams, being able to match up well against various Steel-, Dark-, Flying-, and Fire-types. Drain Punch grants Iron Hands some form of recovery and still hits hard, notably OHKOing Hisuian Goodra and 2HKOing Ting-Lu after a Swords Dance. Thunder Punch OHKOes Articuno and Corviknight after one Swords Dance. Ice Punch allows Iron Hands to threaten several Flying-types its STAB moves aren't very effective against, like both Landorus formes and Dragonite. Earthquake is an alternative option that allows Iron Hands to threaten several Steel- and Fire-types, OHKOing Gholdengo and 2HKOing Torkoal after one Swords Dance boost. With a Shuca Berry, Iron Hands can take STAB Ground-type attacks that could easily revenge kill it, such as Landorus's Earth Power and Choice Scarf Iron Treads's Earthquake. Using a Lum Berry allows Iron Hands to immediately cure status & especially burn, which would otherwise weaken Iron Hands's wallbreaking capabilities. This also allows it to bypass Moltres's Flame Body and punish Sableye for attempting to burn it. 116 Defense EVs in tandem with Lum Berry allow Iron Hands to take a +2 Earthquake from Dragonite and Choice Band Iron Treads's Earthquake, as well as taking a little over 50% damage from Choice Scarf Meowscarada's Play Rough. With 140 Speed EVs, Iron Hands outspeeds Ting-Lu and Corviknight.

Sandy Shocks is mandatory on Electric teams, being the only viable pick with access to entry hazards, allowing Iron Hands to easily take out weakened foes. Iron Hands struggles with various Fairy-types like Hatterene, Flutter Mane, and Enamorus. Hence, it appreciates teammates that can deal with them, such as Assault Vest Magnezone for Hatterene and Choice Scarf Pawmot and Regieleki for the latter two. In return, the three of them appreciate Iron Hands running Ice Punch to deal with the Ground-types that they can struggle against. Choice Specs Zapdos appreciates Iron Hands covering specially defensive walls such as Clodsire and Galarian Slowking, and, in return, Zapdos provides a Ground immunity and the ability to OHKO Great Tusk. Lastly, Iron Hands's wallbreaking opens up sweeping possibilities from the likes of Rotom-W and Choice Scarf Pawmot.

Assault Vest (Fighting).description:
Iron Hands is the premier specially defensive pivot on Fighting teams thanks to its massive HP stat in conjunction with Assault Vest. It is bulky enough to respond to the strongest special attackers in the tier, such as Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, Greninja, and Iron Moth. Drain Punch provides much needed recovery while using Assault Vest while Thunder Punch is used instead of Wild Charge to avoid chip damage. Heavy Slam hits Fairy-types like Hatterene and allows it to revenge kill Flutter Mane. Despite these strengths, Iron Hands is unable to freely switch in on Flutter Mane and Greninja, as they often run Choice Specs and heavily damage Iron Hands or 2HKO it altogether. Volt Switch allows Iron Hands to keep momentum when it forces switches, allowing it to pivot on physically bulky switch-ins like Skeledirge and Amoonguss. Earthquake is a strong coverage option that hits Poison-types like Clodsire and Iron Moth. Rock Slide is an alternative option to hit Kilowattrel and deal with Volcarona without risking a burn from Flame Body.

Great Tusk appreciates Iron Hands's ability to tank neutral special hits like Water-type attacks from Greninja and Pelipper and force them out. In return, Great Tusk takes Ground-type attacks from opposing Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Furthermore, Great Tusk removes Ting-Lu's Spikes and Clodsire's Toxic Spikes, which cut into Iron Hands's longevity. Breloom and Gallade assist Iron Hands with the Ground and Psychic matchups, respectively, threatening foes like Quagsire and Gastrodon for the former, and Amoonguss and Clodsire for the latter. Breloom appreciates Iron Hands switching into Fire-type attacks from Volcarona and forcing Flying-types like Iron Jugulis to switch. Iron Valiant appreciates Iron Hands's slow Volt Switch, allowing Iron Valiant to switch in freely against opposing Fighting teams. Iron Valiant also threatens common physically defensive Pokemon like Dondozo, Skeledirge, Ting-Lu, and Great Tusk. Choice Scarf users such as Quaquaval and Paldean Tauros-F check threats to Iron Hands like Choice Specs Greninja and Flutter Mane, while Iron Hands handles defensive checks such as Calm Mind Hatterene with Heavy Slam in return.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

CATCH THESE HANDS (Assault Vest).description:
• With its great Attack, its good natural bulk, and a healing move in Drain Punch, Iron Hands stands out as a premier Assault Vest attacker.

  • Thunder Punch versus Wild Charge: Wild Charge lets Iron Hands muscle through bulky foes like physically defensive Dondozo at the cost of longevity.

  • Fake Out: Fake Out picks off weakened, normally faster threats, such as Dragonite and Volcarona. It can also beat Focus Sash leads, such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch gives Iron Hands a good option to hit Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam is Iron Hands's best option to hit Fairy-types, notably OHKOing Flutter Mane.

  • Volt Switch: Volt Switch, though incredibly weak, can scout switches and maintain offensive momentum.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: While Iron Hands will function without Terastallizing, it'll be needed to handle Choice Specs Flutter Mane, argubly the most dangerous special attacker in the metagame, as well as handle Ground coverage more reasonably.

  • Ground: Tera Ground gives Iron Hands a strong Earthquake and removes most of its common weaknesses.

  • Grass: Tera Grass giving Spore immunity can stop Breloom cold if it doesn't Terastallize. The Ground-type resistance also lets Iron Hands square up with Ting-Lu much more effectively.

  • Water: Tera Water's Ice and Fire resistances help a lot against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu.

  • Fairy: A Fairy-type Tera allows Iron Hands to take advantage of its great bulk by giving it a better defensive typing, though previously walled Steel-types like Gholdengo and Magnezone become a lot more threatening.

  • Flying: Tera Flying lets Iron Hands completely flip its matchup against Ground-types like Garchomp and Great Tusk and dodge Fissure attempts from the likes of Dondozo and Ting-Lu.

  • Electric:Tera Electric elevates Thunder Punch's power to more acceptable levels, makes Wild Charge very difficult to switch into, and removes Iron Hands's weakness to Fairy.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting allows Iron Hands to deal more damage with Drain Punch while also removing its weakness to Ground-type attacks.

  • Steel: Tera Steel grants a resistance to Fairy and boosts Heavy Slam's power, drastically improving Iron Hands's matchup against Flutter Mane.

EV Spreads
