  • Miraidon is a recommended teammate, as it can provide both sweeping potential and wallbreaking power and appreciates Baxcalibur breaking down Clodsire and Ting-Lu. Another recommended teammate is Koraidon, since it appreciates Baxcalibur removing walls like Toxapex and Skeledirge.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Ghost

Gholdengo's flexible statline gives it the ability to deal with a lot of other threats if it wishes to. For instance, 224 Speed EVs can be invested to outrun Adamant Choice Band Mamoswine, which Ghost teams don't have a defensive answer to. A spread of 252 HP / 108 Def / 84 SpD / 64 Spe with either of the prescribed natures lets Gholdengo survive a hit from non-Choice Band Chien-Pao and Expert Belt Flutter Mane and OHKO back while still being able to outspeed Jolly Azumarill. Hex in conjunction with Thunder Wave is decent in supporting team mates, notably outright OHKOing Gliscor at +2 if running a Modest nature. However, Steel-type coverage is usually more useful, and Ghost has no shortage of Pokemon that inflict status. Focus Blast is also notable, as Gholdengo is not OHKOed by fully Supreme Overlord-boosted Sucker Punch from Kingambit and OHKOes it back with that move. However, this move has low PP and has a big chance to miss. Rocky Helmet is great to wear down and punish physical attackers like Urshifu-R and Iron Hands, but the Ground immunity of Air Balloon is almost too good to pass up on.

Nasty Plot (Steel).description:
Boasting an impressive Special Attack stat, Gholdengo provides Steel teams with a fantastic special attacker, which are scarce on said type. Nasty Plot lets Gholdengo overwhelm walls such as Gastrodon and Amoonguss. Shadow Ball is a fantastic STAB move that has great neutral coverage and allows Gholdengo to threaten Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Gallade. Focus Blast hits Dark-types that resist Shadow Ball like Kingambit and Ting-Lu. A single Nasty Plot boost enables Gholdengo's Focus Blast to OHKO physically defensive Ting-Lu after a layer of Spikes. The last slot is extremely flexible; Make It Rain is a powerful STAB move that hits harder than Shadow Ball against Dark-types like Grimmsnarl and Fairy-types such as Hatterene and Azumarill. Substitute can be used instead to give Gholdengo some security against faster threats that can take it out such as Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Recover is also another option to keep Gholdengo healthy, since it can be worn down fairly easily. Good as Gold allows Gholdengo to switch into status-using Pokemon like Sableye and Grimmsnarl, allowing Gholdengo to set up on them. Air Balloon allows Gholdengo to switch into Pokemon like Great Tusk and Clodsire with ease as well as avoid Spikes as long as it stays intact. This allows Gholdengo to be a decent spinblocker as well.

Kingambit is a fantastic partner, as it not only resists Dark-type moves directed at Gholdengo, but it also has STAB priority in Sucker Punch to threaten opposing Ghost-types that can take out Gholdengo such as Dragapult and Flutter Mane. Kingambit also appreciates Gholdengo's ability to take on Breloom so as to not be revenge killed. Scizor appreciates Gholdengo's ability to take care of physical walls, allowing it to clean up with STAB Bullet Punch. Scizor can also pivot into Gholdengo on physical walls such as Skeledirge, allowing Gholdengo to threaten the opposing Pokemon easier. Nasty Plot Lucario is another fantastic partner thanks to its ability to get rid of Dark-types for Gholdengo and pressure special walls. Choice Scarf Iron Treads also appreciates Gholdengo's ability to break physical walls such as opposing Corviknight and Great Tusk early-game so that it can sweep late-game. Dual screens support from Klefki allows Gholdengo to have an easier time setting up and potentially sweeping. Another good partner for Gholdengo is Corviknight, as it removes entry hazards while also providing a Ground immunity once Air Balloon is gone. Corviknight can also run a Bulk Up or Iron Defense set that appreciates Pokemon like Skeledirge being taken care of while helping Gholdengo have an easier time breaking stall. Orthworm is another good choice, as it provides Shed Tail support as well as having access to Spikes and Stealth Rock. Bronzong is also an amazing partner as well, as it can not only set up Stealth Rock, but it can also tank Fire-type moves thanks to Heatproof.

Nasty Plot (Ghost).description:
Nasty Plot Gholdengo is a bulky setup sweeper for Ghost teams, leveraging its stellar typing and fantastic stats to break down walls such as Articuno, Hisuian Goodra lacking Flamethrower, and Corviknight, which Ghost teams struggle with. Its ability, Good as Gold blocks status moves such as Encore from Sableye and phazing from Empoleon, heavily aiding Gholdengo as a setup sweeper. Make It Rain's extra power makes it a notable option over Flash Cannon, as it OHKOes Ursaluna-B and Articuno at +2 and will always OHKO Flutter Mane and Baxcalibur. However, it can be stalled out by Pressure, and the Special Attack drop can provide setup opportunities for enemies such as Azumarill and Gliscor. Alternatively, Flash Cannon provides a less strong but more reliable STAB move that is extremely helpful in the Fairy and Ice matchup. 104 Speed EVs let Gholdengo outspeed threats like Adamant Scizor and Jolly Azumarill and most walls, including uninvested Gliscor and Articuno. A Bold nature prevents Alolan Muk from 2HKOing Gholdengo before the Air Balloon breaks, while a Modest nature provides Gholdengo with more favorable damage calculations, namely giving it a chance to OHKO Gliscor and Galarian Moltres with +2 Make It Rain and Scizor with a boosted Shadow Ball and knocking out Alolan Muk over two turns with Make It Rain after a Nasty Plot. An Air Balloon lets Gholdengo provide a unique defensive niche, walling out a lot of Ground-types like Gliscor variants with no attacking moves besides Earthquake, Landorus, and Quagsire as long as it isn't popped, protecting Gholdengo from Poltergeist users such as Brambleghast once the item is popped, and also making it a generally safe switch-in to block Mortal Spin from Earth Power Glimmora.

Flutter Mane and Nasty Plot Spectrier appreciate Gholdengo's wallbreaking ability to remove roadblocks like Gliscor, Clodsire, and Articuno. In return, Gholdengo is able to take a hit from non-Choice-Band Chien-Pao and OHKO it back for its teammates. In return, Flutter Mane and Spectrier both act as cleaners and deal with faster-paced matchups like Fighting and Ghost for Gholdengo. Both are also able to remove Dark-types like Greninja, while Spectrier can lure and incapacitate Dark-types like Roaring Moon if using a Colbur Berry. Flutter Mane can also don a Choice Scarf, to deal with Dragapult and Chien-Pao. Gholdengo's vulnerability to Water- and Fire-type coverage is notable, so teammates like Sinistcha to readily deal with Dondozo and Skeledirge to take on Gastrodon and Volcarona benefit Gholdengo. Skeledirge, especially with Earth Power, puts in work in the Steel and Fire matchup, while Sinistcha helps in the Ground matchup, which Gholdengo does not fare well against. Both also have the ability to inflict burn on key walls like Alolan Muk, Clodsire, and Iron Hands, making it easier for Gholdengo to set up. Ceruledge is an exceptional teammate, as it deals with Gholdengo's nemesis, Heatran, and also put in work on matchups like Steel and Fire. Spikes support from Froslass and Brambleghast is also great, as this synergizes with Gholdengo's ability to block Defog; Froslass also is fast enough to deal with Landorus, while Brambleghast's entry hazard removal is rare on Ghost and is appreciated once Gholdengo's Air Balloon gets popped. Dragapult's great Speed tier enables it to fend off Choice Specs Flutter Mane or Choice Scarf Roaring Moon when equipped with a Choice Specs or Choice Scarf of its own, and it can pivot Gholdengo in against walls like Clodsire with U-turn, as well as burn Alolan Muk, Iron Hands, and Ting-Lu for it. Dragapult can also run a Choice Band set, allowing it to 2HKO Alolan Muk as well as take out opposing Ghost-types with Sucker Punch, or even a Dragon Dance set to threaten walls such as Clodsire that bother Gholdengo. Choice Scarf Hisuian Zoroark takes advantage of Gholdengo's Speed tier and typing with Illusion, luring and removing threats like Hisuian Samurott while also being able to eliminate Hoopa-U with U-turn. It is also able to lure in and heavily damage Ghost-types like Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and Spectrier, which use their Ghost-type coverage to defeat Gholdengo. Mimikyu can serve as a check to threats like Hoopa-U and Hydreigon as well as a one-time answer to Darkrai, Greninja, and Chien-Pao using Disguise. In return Gholdengo takes on Corviknight, Iron Defense Iron Treads, and Galarian Weezing.

Choice Scarf (Ghost).description:
Choice Scarf Gholdengo's ability to revenge kill threats such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao lacking Sucker Punch, and Dragapult, come into status-spreading Pokemon such as Klefki and Breloom due to Good as Gold, and inconvenience bulkier teams by preventing all forms of entry hazard removal with its ability and typing make it a prime pick for Ghost teams. Make it Rain greatly weakens Dark- and Normal-types such as Hydreigon and Indeedee, and it OHKOes Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao. Shadow Ball lets Gholdengo clean types such as Psychic and Ghost late-game. Trick neutralizes defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire, which typically switch into it. The last move of choice is dependent on what the Ghost team lacks; Focus Blast gives the team another way to defeat Choice Specs Greninja, Thunderbolt cleans Water- and Flying-teams, or Nasty Plot which turns Gholdengo into a massive threat against bulkier teams especially after their main specially defensive wall has been given a Choice Scarf with Trick.

As Gholdengo provides the needed revenge killing capabilities on Ghost teams, teammates such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult are free to run sets like Choice Specs and Dragon Dance, respectively. Both also break down walls such as Clodsire and Gastrodon; in return, Gholdengo deals with Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Gallade. Skeledirge walls most physical attackers and Fire-types such as Scovillain and Volcarona. Mimikyu provides a safety net against offensive types like rain Water and Ghost, checking Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Flutter Mane for the team, and it loves Gholdengo shutting down defensive walls such as Toxapex with Trick. Entry hazard setters in Brambleghast and Froslass are is also greatly appreciated, as they can set, remove, or prevent entry hazards for Gholdengo; in return, Gholdengo prevents their entry hazards from getting removed by Glimmora. Brambleghast also switches into Ground-types such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk and deals with Water-types like Gastrodon and Dondozo, while Froslass can spread paralysis with Thunder Wave and bring down an opposing Pokemon with its Destiny Bond.

Choiced Attacker.description:
• Make It Rain and Shadow Ball let Gholdengo take out a wide array of common Pokemon such as Armarouge, Annihilape and Sylveon.

  • Dazzling Gleam allows Gholdengo to fight back against the likes of Hydreigon.

  • Thunderbolt threatens to OHKO the likes of Gyarados and Palafin when equipped with Choice Specs. Trick is a good alternative option to lock Pokemon into undesirable moves, such as Indeedee-F into Trick Room.

  • Choice Specs makes Gholdengo one of the most threatening special attackers in the entire metagame. Choice Scarf lets Gholdengo outspeed Meowscarada, Garchomp, and Dragapult with a Timid nature, which it would otherwise need additional speed control to beat.

  • Steel is Gholdengo's preferred Tera type, boosting the damage output of Make It Rain even further and letting it OHKO Garchomp with ease.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Choice Scarf Gholdengo outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, can use Trick to weaken defensive teams, and also blocks Defog and Rapid Spin to keep pressure on defensive Pokemon with entry hazards.
  • Focus Blast deals more damage to Ting-Lu, Chi-Yu, and Iron Treads, while Nasty Plot and Recover can be used after Gholdengo's Choice Scarf has been removed via Trick to turn it into a setup sweeper or give it longevity, respectively.
  • Tera Fighting powers up Focus Blast, which allows Gholdengo to potentially 2HKO Ting-Lu. Alternatively, Gholdengo can use Tera Steel on sets not using Focus Blast to boost Make It Rain and remove its weaknesses to Flutter Mane's and Chien-Pao's STAB moves.
  • Gholdengo should almost always be switched in if Corviknight is on the field and be used sparingly against Great Tusk and Iron Treads if a Rapid Spin is predicted, but this is risky due to its Earthquake weakness.
  • Spikes setters like Ting-Lu and Clodsire on balance teams as well as Froslass on hyper offense teams appreciate Gholdengo keeping up Spikes and it acting as a revenge killer for their respective archetypes.
  • Pokemon like Calm Mind Miraidon, Calm Mind Flutter Mane, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao also benefit from Gholdengo using Trick on defensive Pokemon, forcing them to either heal or be locked into an unfavorable attack while they set up. Gholdengo can also clean up weakened teams if these Pokemon are used to wallbreak first.

Nasty Plot.description:
• Nasty Plot + Recover Gholdengo is the best option for preventing entry hazard removal in the tier.
  • Tera Steel bolsters Make It Rain's power, allowing Gholdengo to overwhelm threats such as Koraidon, defensive Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and bulky Tera Fairy Miraidon after a Nasty Plot boost while removing its Ghost typing.
  • Tera Normal blocks incoming Ghost-type attacks from the likes of Flutter Mane, Choice Scarf Houndstone, and opposing Gholdengo.
  • Air Balloon provides a temporary measure against Ground-type attacks from Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads, allowing Gholdengo to sometimes switch into them.
  • Gholdengo best fits on hyper offense and balance teams that aim to preserve their own entry hazards for as long as possible.
  • Frail leads such as Froslass and Masquerain appreciate their entry hazards staying intact against Great Tusk, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Glimmora.
  • Glimmora and Ting-Lu make for good teammates on balance teams in particular, as they provide similar entry hazard support while having sufficient power and bulk to punish threats.
  • Wallbreakers such as Miraidon, Koraidon, and Chi-Yu appreciate multiple entry hazards to further overwhelm the opposition with their tremendous attacks and power.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Choice Item.description:
• With Trick and an immunity to status moves, Gholdengo is a dangerous Choice item attacker for offensive and stall teams alike!

  • Focus Blast: Though its accuracy can be an issue, Focus Blast is the best way around Dark-types that resist Steel-type attacks, such as Chi-Yu and Kingambit, in addition to dealing severe damage to Ting-Lu before it Terastallizes.

  • Thunderbolt: This 2HKOes Dondozo and deals serious damage to Toxapex and Quaquaval.

  • Nasty Plot: This can be used to give Gholdengo more bite against defensive, slower teams after using Trick.

  • Neutral Nature and Nature Mints: Use a neutral nature Gholdengo that has a Timid or Modest Mint used on it. This way, Gholdengo can eat any Berry without being confused after Trick.

Other Options

  • Dazzling Gleam: Dazzling Gleam deals massive damage to Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon, and pairs well with Tera Fairy.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Choice Gholdengo is perfectly functional without Terastallizing, it's particularly vulnerable to common Pokemon that Terastallization can solve such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Gholdengo gains an extremely useful immunity to Ground, which is especially useful on Choice Specs sets and against users of Fissure such as Dondozo.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting gives Gholdengo a vital resistance to Sucker Punch, and an option to use the more reliable Tera Blast against Kingambit.

  • Normal: A Normal Tera type gives Gholdengo the edge against opposing Ghost-types, at the cost of becoming very vulnerable to Breloom's Mach Punch.

  • Ghost: The extra damage from Shadow Ball can make Gholdengo a more effective late-game cleaner.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is a useful way to resist Sucker Punch without being weak to Fairy-type attacks from Flutter Mane.

  • Water: This Tera type gives Gholdengo a valuable resistance to Fire, massively improving the matchup against Chi-Yu.

  • Steel: Make It Rain becomes very powerful with a Tera boost, at the cost of making Gholdengo vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With this, Gholdengo outspeeds key threats such as Dragapult, Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane. It also outspeeds Chien-Pao and Meowscarada, but beware of Sucker Punch.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs make Gholdengo much more difficult to wall, with foes such as Dondozo getting 2HKOed.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Gholdengo mirror matches are common enough that maximizing Speed is usually a wise idea. Timid is needed to outspeed Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult.

  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 204 SpA / 36 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: This bulkier spread for Choice Specs sets allows Gholdengo to survive an unboosted Shadow Ball from Timid Flutter Mane, while outspeeding Adamant Breloom and Jolly Tyranitar.

  • 36 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 44 SpD / 172 Spe with Timid: This spread allows Choice Scarf Gholdengo to outspeed unboosted Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane while being able survive Tera Water or Choice Specs boosted Hydro Pump from Iron Bundle.

  • 68 HP / 4 Def / 148 SpA / 36 SpD / 252 Spe with Modest: This spread survives an unboosted Shadow Ball from Timid Flutter Mane 93.7% of the time while also outspeeding Breloom.

Nasty Plot.description:
• Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo a terror against slower teams, especially with its good bulk, unpredictable coverage, and diverse Tera Types.

  • Focus Blast: Despite its reliability issues, Focus Blast lets Gholdengo defeat Kingambit, and hits Chi-Yu switch ins very hard.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Gholdengo avoid residual damage from Garganacl's Salt Cure and eases prediction in general.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock lets Gholdengo break through Blissey and Clodsire more easily.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Gholdengo may have a great typing, but common Pokemon such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu will usually revenge kill it without Terastallization.

  • Flying: Flying Gholdengo gets the jump on dangerous Earthquake users such as Ting-Lu, Garchomp, Dragonite, and Great Tusk.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is unlikely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping, and Gholdengo has a much better match-up against Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu.

  • Normal: While it's a much worse defensive typing, Tera Normal does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types like Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult, at the cost of being weak to Mach Punch.

  • Water: With this Tera type and Tera Blast, Chien-Pao, Ting-Lu, Chi-Yu, and Iron Moth have a much harder time revenge killing Gholdengo.

Items

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak prevents Salt Cure from chipping down Gholdengo, making it far easier for it to run Recover against Garganacl.

  • Air Balloon: Air Balloon ruins Breloom's chances of winning the lead war against Gholdengo and makes Hippowdon easy setup bait.

  • Leftovers: This is the most reliable option for keeping Gholdengo healthy and pairs especially well with Substitute.

  • Focus Sash: Despite Gholdengo's good bulk, Focus Sash is useful for giving it new opportunities to sweep.

EV Spreads

  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 204 SpA / 36 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: For sets with Recover, this bulkier spread can make sense, allowing Gholdengo to survive Shadow Ball from Flutter Mane that lack an offensive item, and outpacing Adamant Breloom and Jolly Tyranitar.

  • 252 HP / 172 Def / 52 SpA / 28 SpD / 4 Spe with Modest: This bulky spread survives a Shadow Ball from Modest Flutter Mane assuming it lacks an offensive boost and can use Terastallization to avoid a 2HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's STAB attacks.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Speed is useful on more offensive sets to at least speedtie with opposing Gholdengo, and outspeeding several threats close to this Speed tier, such as Dragonite.

Defensive.description:
• While Gholdengo's defensive stats aren't remarkable, it's fantastic typing and immunity to status moves like Taunt make it a great defensive Pokemon.

  • Thunder Wave: This makes switching into this Gholdengo very difficult, as it can punish its speedier offensive checks like Chi-Yu and Meowscarada.

  • Hex versus Shadow Ball: Hex gives this Gholdengo a good offensive kick against paralyzed foes, but Shadow Ball is worth considering for its consistency.

  • Make It Rain versus Focus Blast: Make It Rain is Gholdengo's most consistent way of dealing damage to Garganacl, but this set's defensive nature makes it difficult to win the one-on-one. Focus Blast isn't nearly as reliable, but it's Gholdengo's best shot at making it past Kingambit and Ting-Lu, and punishing Chi-Yu switch-ins.

  • EV Spread: The given EVs outspeed paralyzed Dragapult, while maximizing physical bulk.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Despite Gholdengo's fantastic typing, Chien-Pao is easily able to break through any Gholdengo that doesn't Terastallize.

  • Fighting: Beyond boosting Focus Blast's power, it provides Gholdengo with a vital Dark-type resistance.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Gholdengo a much better matchup against Dark-type attackers like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada.

  • Flying: Avoiding Earthquake against foes like Garchomp makes Tera Flying extremely useful for Gholdengo; this also gives it protection against Fissure from the likes of Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is not incredible defensively, but it does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Mimikyu.

  • Water: Tera Water is the best Fire-type resistant Tera type for Gholdengo, letting it potentially survive an assault from Chi-Yu and Iron Moth, though their coverage moves will still seriously damage Gholdengo.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet takes advantage of Gholdengo's excellent typing against physical moves, making it a good way to punish contact moves such as Outrage from Garchomp.

  • Covert Cloak: This is Gholdengo's best shot of outstalling Garganacl, since it grants an immunity to Salt Cure's effect.

  • Weakness Policy: While this might seem strange on a defensive Pokemon, Weakness Policy lets Gholdengo beat opposing Gholdengo as long as they lack Choice Specs.

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Gholdengo is an extremely powerful special wallbreaker that takes advantage of Nasty Plot, Life Orb, and Steel Beam, the latter two without recoil, to overwhelm special walls. Shadow Ball provides excellent neutral coverage, hitting Manaphy, Hisuian Goodra, and Empoleon. Hex is an alternative with Toxic Spikes or other status support and bypasses Bulletproof. Recover gives Gholdengo the ability to heal off damage taken while setting up, as well as simply giving it the longevity to attack the opponent's team throughout the battle. Alternatively, Focus Blast hits Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, while Thunder Wave slows down faster attackers like Iron Moth and Roaring Moon that try to threaten Gholdengo while powering up Hex to break down bulkier Pokemon like Manaphy. Gholdengo's ability to beat down balanced cores with the sheer strength of Steel Beam benefits faster cleaners like Barraskewda, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Azelf and Walking Wake. If Gholdengo runs Thunder Wave, it can also support other offensive Pokemon that appreciate faster attackers getting slowed down, such as Great Tusk, Ceruledge, and Dragonite. However, Gholdengo is vulnerable to faster Dark-types like Chien-Pao, so Pokemon that can check them like Corviknight and Quaquaval are appreciated. Corviknight can even safely bring in Gholdengo with its U-turn. Additionally, if Gholdengo is not using Thunder Wave and Hex, RegenVest users like Manaphy and Meloetta completely wall it, so Pokemon that beat them with super effective STAB moves or physical attacks like Desolate Land Ogerpon-H and Roaring Moon are appreciated.

Offensive.description: With Nasty Plot, a fantastic offensive and defensive typing, and solid coverage, Gholdengo is a terrifying wallbreaker that threatens to tear apart teams after a single free turn. Hex can be used over Shadow Ball with Thunder Wave or Toxic Spikes support, with Life Orb sets 2HKOing badly poisoned RegenVest Manaphy while also threatening Bulletproof Gholdengo. Recover gives Gholdengo significant longevity and multiple opportunities to use Nasty Plot, while Substitute gives it a free turn to set up Nasty Plot or Thunder Wave against foes like Corviknight and Kommo-o and dodges phazing attempts from Dragon Tail users like Hisuian Goodra and Roaring Moon. Focus Blast hits Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Hisuian Goodra, while Thunder Wave can boost the power of Hex and spread useful paralysis against threats like Manaphy, Roaring Moon, and Ogerpon-C. Leftovers and Colbur Berry both boost its longevity, with the latter letting Gholdengo survive Knock Off from Roaring Moon or +2 Ogerpon-C, while Life Orb boosts Gholdengo's power significantly, granting it feats such as guaranteeing a 2HKO on specially defensive Garchomp with Make It Rain. If running Focus Blast, Beads of Ruin is an option over Adaptability, boosting Focus Blast's power at the cost of revealing Gholdengo's ability and slightly decreasing the power of its STAB moves. Gholdengo can struggle to break through common special walls like Blissey, Bulletproof Empoleon, and RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta, so it appreciates powerful offensive teammates like Roaring Moon, Ogerpon-C, and Galarian Zapdos that can handle these walls while Gholdengo picks off physical walls like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Kommo-o. Gholdengo appreciates defensive pivots like Corviknight, Manaphy, and Empoleon that can take a hit and bring Gholdengo in against foes it forces out such as Kommo-o, Pixilate Scream Tail, and Galarian Zapdos.

Nasty Plot (Ghost).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Mixed Wall (Grass).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Leech Seed.description:
• With excellent bulk and a unique array of moves to support it, Wo-Chien stands out as a dangerous user of Leech Seed and a prime Pokemon to stall matches out with.

  • Foul Play versus Knock Off: Foul Play is Wo-Chien's most consistent offensive move that also happens to punish setup sweepers, while Knock Off's support is especially helpful against Trick users such as Gholdengo and Rotom-W. Note that both are viable together if you're willing to give up a support move.

  • Substitute: When paired together with Toxic Spikes, Protect and Substitute makes even foes that should beat Wo-Chien get worn down before they can KO it, such as Chi-Yu. Substitute itself protects Wo-Chien from slow users of Yawn such as Dondozo and Hippowdon, and slow OHKO moves from Ting-Lu, Dondozo, and Kingambit.

  • Ruination: Ruination gives Wo-Chien powerful chipping down potential, though it should never be used as Wo-Chien's only attack due to it being extremely difficult to KO with. When paired with Knock Off, it's especially useful against Wo-Chien mirror matches.

  • Giga Drain: With Stealth Rock support, Giga Drain OHKOes Iron Bundle and almost always 2HKOes Chien-Pao. If you allocate 60 EVs to Special Attack, Giga Drain will OHKO Iron Bundle regardless of Stealth Rock.

  • Taunt: Taunt does an excellent job of surprising other Taunt Pokemon switching in, such as Annihilape and Corviknight.

  • Toxic Spikes Partners: Wo-Chien becomes far more deadly with Toxic Spikes support, letting it quickly wear down a wide variety of foes even faster. Toxapex is one of the best options thanks to its good defensive synergy with Wo-Chien, but other options include Iron Moth, Glimmora, Clodsire, Focus Sash Meowscarada, and the niche Gengar.

Other Options

  • Snarl: Snarl makes fearsome special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Chi-Yu far easier to switch into when Wo-Chien needs to escape, though Wo-Chien will need to have the correct Tera Type to outstall these foes itself.

  • Ingrain: In addition to providing some extra recovery, Ingrain makes phazers such as Ting-Lu and Hippowdon fail to stop Wo-Chien consistently, though Wo-Chien being trapped is a serious drawback.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Despite Wo-Chien's fantastic bulk, its vulnerability to Toxic Spikes and poor defensive typing mean it must often Terastallize to stall out teams.

  • Poison: Tera Poison provides a vital resistance to Fairy and Fighting, and it also lets Wo-Chien absorb Toxic Spikes.

  • Fairy: Besides being a great defensive type, Tera Fairy helps Wo-Chien against Fighting-types that'd normally beat it.

  • Water: Tera Water provides Ice and Fire resistances, helpful against Baxcalibur, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives useful resistances to Fairy, Fire, and Ice, which help against major threats like Flutter Mane, Baxcalibur, Chi-Yu, and Chien-Pao.

Items

  • Leftovers: Wo-Chien's stalling playstyle makes Leftovers the most consistent recovery item.

  • Big Root: If another Pokemon desperately needs Leftovers, Big Root is a viable alternative for getting extra recovery from Leech Seed and Giga Drain.

EV Spreads and Adjustments

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish or Bold: Maximizing Wo-Chien's physical bulk lets it pull off some incredible stunts, such as avoiding a 3HKO from Breloom's Mach Punch with Leftovers and, after Terastallization, avoiding a 2HKO from Choice Band Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful or Calm: With the correct Tera Type and maximum Special Defense, Wo-Chien can take on Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle much more effectively.

  • Using 60 SpA EVs: If you're willing to give up a bit of bulk, this investment is required to OHKO Iron Bundle with Giga Drain with either a Bold or a Calm nature.

  • Using 100 Speed EVs: With some sacrifice to bulk, this Speed investment lets Wo-Chien outspeed Adamant maximum Speed Kingambit, and it can be vital in Wo-Chien mirror matches after Terastallization makes it vulnerable to Leech Seed, due to Substitute blocking Leech Seed.

Specially Defensive.description: Wo-Chien's unique typing and movepool backed by its high, Tablets of Ruin-boosted bulk grants it a solid place in the metagame, checking threats such as Calyrex-S, Arceus-Ground, and Kyogre. Leech Seed reduces Wo-Chien's passivity while allowing teammates to heal after switching in. Ruination hits foes like Arceus-Fairy, Ting-Lu, and Giratina-O. Foul Play is a stronger alternative against physical attackers like Arceus and Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground that also does a decent chunk of damage to Koraidon and Zacian-C and allows Wo-Chien to punish physical attackers that have Taunt. Knock Off gives Wo-Chien more of a niche due relevant Pokemon that learn it being rare, and it is useful against foes like Ting-Lu and Landorus-T. However, Arceus formes, which can absorb Knock Off without losing their items, are quite omnipresent. Protect lets Wo-Chien safely rack up Leftovers and Leech Seed recovery. Alternatively, Taunt shuts down setup and entry hazard Pokemon such as Arceus formes and Ting-Lu on the switch. Tera Poison gives Wo-Chien key resistances to attacks like Koraidon's Low Kick, Zacian-C's Play Rough, Double Dance Miraidon's Dazzling Gleam, and the omnipresent U-turn from foes like Landorus-T, Koraidon, and Miraidon while also offering an immunity to Toxic and letting Wo-Chien absorb Toxic Spikes. However, Tera Poison also makes Wo-Chien weak to Ground-type moves from Arceus-Ground and Psychic-type moves from Calyrex-S, respectively. Wo-Chien fits best on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to check Calyrex-S and Arceus-Ground while offering good recovery via Leech Seed to teammates. Wo-Chien benefits from teammates such as Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Landorus-T, which check Koraidon and Zacian-C for it. Special attackers in Arceus-Fairy, Substitute Kyogre, and Eternatus trouble Wo-Chien, so offensive checks to them such as Zacian-C, Choice Scarf Koraidon, Arceus, and Calyrex-S are appreciated. Water Absorb Closdire as a defensive teammate checks Arceus-Fairy, Kyogre, and Eternatus while setting up hazards.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Dark

Chien-Pao can also run Psychic Fangs as an alternative coverage move to hit Toxapex, Iron Hands, Urshifu-R, and Okidogi while also breaking opposing screens or Aurora Veil.

All-Out Attacker (Dark).description:
Chien-Pao is an imposing force for any Dark team with its sky-high Speed, blitzing past threats like Iron Valiant and Greninja, and great Attack. Sword of Ruin lets it beat physical walls like Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Toxapex, though it doesn't have great bulk, has to watch out for super effective priority moves from Scizor, Lokix, and Slither Wing, and struggles to break past walls like Dondozo and Quagsire. With Swords Dance, it can boost up to beat even the likes of Corviknight and Toxapex if it has Crunch. Fighting-type coverage picks off Dark-types like Kingambit and Greninja. Sacred Sword picks off weakened Garganacl, while Brick Break destroys opposing Dark or Fairy team's dual screens. Ice Shard stops common revenge killers like Choice Scarf Meowscarada, Flutter Mane, and Great Tusk.

As Chien-Pao focuses on breaking down foes with its sheer power and Speed, it appreciates support from its teammates. Ting-Lu can set up Stealth Rock and Spikes, while Skuntank can set up Toxic Spikes and pressure Fairy-types, all of which make wallbreaking for Chien-Pao easier. Grimmsnarl provides Chien-Pao with dual screens support, making setting up easier. Sableye can burn opposing Pokemon and cripple them with Taunt and Knock Off, removing Heavy-Duty Boots and making foes susceptible to entry hazards, while also acting as a Fighting-type move switch-in. Choice Specs Greninja can clean up after Chien-Pao has done enough damage while also countering Fire-types that would annoy Chien-Pao such as Skeledirge and Cinderace if Chien-Pao does not have Crunch. Hydreigon can break Steel-types for Chien-Pao if it forgoes Fighting-type coverage or Swords Dance, beating Fighting-neutral Steel-types like Corviknight and Scizor. Choice Scarf Meowscarada is able to threaten Pokemon that counter Chien-Pao such as Quaquaval and Choice Scarf users such as Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, and Great Tusk while also being able to pivot to Chien-Pao with U-turn.

Swords Dance Sweeper (Ice).description:
Chien-Pao's high Speed, solid Attack, and good offensive typing allow it to be a very potent setup sweeper. Icicle Crash is preferred over Ice Spinner for its flinch chance and higher Base Power, the latter of which—among other things—allows it to always 2HKO Sableye and bulky Great Tusk, while Ice Spinner may miss out on these 2HKOs. Crunch allows Chien-Pao to hit Skeledirge and Gholdengo—two problematic Pokemon for Ice teams. Sacred Sword and Brick Break both allow Chien-Pao to threaten Dark-, Steel-, and Ice-types such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao. Sacred Sword is stronger and comes with the ability to ignore Defense boosts, while Brick Break removes Reflect and Light Screen, which is extremely helpful against teams with support from Grimmsnarl or Klefki. Psychic Fangs is an alternative option to Sacred Sword or Brick Break to hit Toxapex and Fighting-types such as Paldean Tauros-F. Sucker Punch is significantly stronger than Ice Shard and allows Chien-Pao to hit Pokemon like Gholdengo, Scizor, and Flutter Mane.

This set very much appreciates Aurora Veil support from Abomasnow, as it allows Chien-Pao to set up on many Pokemon that would otherwise threaten it out as well as allowing it to survive revenge killing attempts from the likes of Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Extreme Speed Dragonite. Spikes support from Froslass is also greatly appreciated, as they wear down Pokemon that may otherwise be difficult for Chien-Pao to break, such as Dondozo and Klefki. Although Chien-Pao is able to fit on practically any team, it pairs especially well with other powerful sweepers such as Baxcalibur and Cloyster, weakening or even KOing their checks such as Air Balloon Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Baxcalibur in particular can take on Pokemon such as Toxapex and Paldean Tauros-F with a powerful Earthquake, allowing Chien-Pao to KO them and sweep the opposing team; furthermore, Choice Band Baxcalibur pressures Chien-Pao answers such as Quagsire and Corviknight. Baxcalibur's Thermal Exchange also allows it to switch into Will-O-Wisp that would cripple Chien-Pao as well as be an emergency switch-in to a Fire-type attack. Shell Smash Cloyster appreciates the removal of Skeledirge and Froslass.

Choice Band Wallbreaker (Ice).description:
Choice Band Chien-Pao is a potent mid-game threat, powerful wallbreaker, and good late-game cleaner. Additionally, it is capable of breaking through physically defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Quagsire, both of which tend to be tough matchups for many other Ice staples. Icicle Crash is preferred over Ice Spinner for its flinch chance and slightly higher Base Power, notably being favored to 2HKO Azumarill and OHKO offensive Pelipper, neither of which are feats Ice Spinner is capable of. Sacred Sword and Brick Break provide crucial coverage for Pokemon such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao, and Sucker Punch allows Chien-Pao to KO faster Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

This set heavily appreciates Spikes from Froslass to wear down its switch-ins, sometimes allowing it to grab KOs it would otherwise miss out on; for example, Crunch always 2HKOes physically defensive Toxapex with one layer of Spikes, but it is favored to not 2HKO without any Spikes. Rapid Spin support from Avalugg is also appreciated, allowing Chien-Pao more opportunities to enter the field. Since this set focuses on opening holes in teams, setup sweepers are excellent partners for it, as Chien-Pao can dent or remove their checks to allow the sweep to happen much more easily. Shell Smash Cloyster in particular appreciates Chien-Pao's ability to beat Gholdengo and significantly damage other Pokemon such as Corviknight that Cloyster may otherwise struggle to break through. Dragon Dance Baxcalibur appreciates Chien-Pao's ability to 2HKO Quagsire and physically defensive Corviknight, which normally would stop Baxcalibur in its tracks. Finally, Belly Drum Cetitan appreciates Chien-Pao's ability to break Unaware walls such as Skeledirge and Quagsire; in return, Cetitan acts as speed control if snow is in effect, aiding in Chien-Pao's weakness to Choice Scarf users such as Iron Moth.

Choice Band (Dark).description:
Chien-Pao is a weapon of destruction for Dark teams, boasting a lofty Speed tier that allows it to outspeed most Pokemon in the metagame like Spectrier, Sneasler, and Tornadus-T. Icicle Crash helps significantly in the Flying matchup, 2HKOing Articuno and defensive Corviknight after Stealth Rock, thus preventing any Flying Pokemon from switching in safely, and in the Dragon matchup, OHKOing Walking Wake after Stealth Rock and 2HKOing Hisuian Goodra. Icicle Crash also OHKOes foes like Ursaluna-B, 2HKOes foes like defensive Great Tusk, and secures a 2HKO on defensive Quagsire. Crunch helps in securing an OHKO on Colbur Berry Spectrier and 2HKOing bulkier foes like Hatterene and mixed Toxapex after one layer of Spikes. Ice Shard's priority allows Chien-Pao to OHKO faster targets such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Enamorus, Landorus, Meowscarada, and Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock. Sacred Sword allows Chien-Pao to secure an OHKO on foes like Kingambit, Choice Specs Greninja, Mamoswine, and Baxcalibur. It also allows Chien-Pao to hit opposing Chien-Pao, albeit with the threat of a Speed tie.

Chien-Pao appreciates Mandibuzz's Defog support to prevent it from being worn down by entry hazards. It can also bring Chien-Pao in safely using a slow U-turn. Mandibuzz is a great switch-in for Fighting-type attacks from enemies like Choice Scarf Sneasler and Choice Scarf Great Tusk as well, which Chien-Pao is extremely vulnerable to, as well as being capable of checking setup sweepers like Azumarill and Scizor with Foul Play. In return, Chien-Pao deals with opponents like Sandy Shocks and Baxcalibur, which can cause problems for Mandibuzz. Kingambit has impressive offensive synergy with Chien-Pao due to its neutrality to Fairy-type attacks, being able to eliminate foes like Hatterene with Iron Head and Choice Scarf Flutter Mane with Sucker Punch after Stealth Rock. In return, Chien-Pao hits threats to Kingambit like Dragon Dance Dragonite, Iron Treads, Landorus-T, and defensive Gliscor, whose Earthquake can prove disadvantageous for Kingambit. Sableye is a great teammate for Chien-Pao, as its Fighting-type immunity helps it switch directly into attacks from threats like Iron Hands and Zamazenta. Paired with Prankster, Sableye can easily burn threats to Chien-Pao like Azumarill and the aforementioned Fighting-types and paralyze foes like Dragapult, Volcarona, Iron Valiant and Flutter Mane, allowing Chien-Pao to break them with ease. Sableye also offers Knock Off support against foes like Articuno and Toxapex, which will suffer damage from hazards after the removal of Heavy-Duty Boots. Greninja is also a great teammate for Chien-Pao due to its excellent coverage, being able to OHKO Fire-type threats like Volcarona and Ogerpon-H after Stealth Rock with Hydro Pump and outspeed Choice Scarf users like Enamorus and Galarian Zapdos and eliminate them with Ice Beam when running Choice Scarf itself. Choice Scarf Greninja also takes care of opposing Chien-Pao and Kingambit with Low Kick, while Extrasensory 2HKOes threats like physically defensive Toxapex and Zamazenta and secures an OHKO on Okidogi. In return, Chien-Pao deals with Ogerpon-W, Alolan Muk, and Articuno, which can take advantage of Greninja. Choice Scarf Meowscarada boasts great synergy with Choice Band Chien-Pao, allowing fast pivoting with U-turn and sweeping in the Dark mirror with the help of Play Rough. It also threatens Quagsire, Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Urshifu-R, and Quaquaval with Flower Trick. In return, Chien-Pao breaks foes like Clodsire, Kingambit, Alolan Muk, and opposing Chien-Pao that can hamper Meowscarada's ability to sweep. Teammates like Ting-Lu and Hisuian Samurott can set Spikes for Chien-Pao, boosting its wallbreaking ability and breaking potential Focus Sashes from opponents like Ceruledge. Alolan Muk absorbs Fairy-type attacks from foes like Flutter Mane, Enamorus, and Hatterene for Chien-Pao and threatens them with Poison Jab. Overqwil, on the other hand, switches in against opposing Chien-Pao and Meowscarada with the help of Intimidate and threatens them back with Barb Barrage. Teammates like Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon are other alternatives that can help break foes like defensive Great Tusk and Heatran, which Chien-Pao appreciates. Hydreigon can switch into Fire-type moves aimed at Chien-Pao from foes like Moltres and Ceruledge and set Stealth Rock to facilitate its wallbreaking.

vgc2024.overview:
• Chien-Pao is an excellent offensive Pokemon bearing a great offensive typing and a fantastic Speed tier. Chien-Pao is capable of taking on the majority of the format, and it's especially strong against Tornadus and Landorus thanks to its typing and Sword of Ruin.

  • Incineroar has Intimidate and resists both of Chien-Pao's STAB attacks, which makes it difficult for Chien-Pao to deal with, therefore Urshifu-R is a strong partner as it utilizes Sword of Ruin and pressures Incineroar.

  • Chien-Pao also struggles to take on Urshifu-R and Iron Hands, which take any of its attacks comfortably and threaten it in return.

Glass Cannon.description:
• Ice Spinner is an alternative Ice-type STAB move that provides increased accuracy and a way for teams to handle Rillaboom and Indeedee-F in exchange for higher power and a flinch chance. However, it prevents Chien-Pao from attacking Rocky Helmet Amoonguss and Latias as freely.

  • Chien-Pao uses Sacred Sword as coverage for relevant Pokemon such as Incineroar and Kingambit.

  • Chien-Pao utilizes Focus Sash to make up for its poor defensive typing combined with its lackluster bulk, as it allows it to stay an extra turn on the field to help partners exploit Sword of Ruin, which is significant for offensive compositions.

  • With Tera Stellar, Chien-Pao has the option to pick up OHKOs on Pokemon it usually wouldn't be able to OHKO, such as Flutter Mane and Amoonguss. However, it has to be wary of pivots and foes using Protect, as the power boost is temporary. Chien-Pao can also use Tera Ghost to remove its Fighting weakness and become immune to priority moves like Fake Out, which is crucial for Focus Sash.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

RUINOUS ATTACKER.description:
• With its high Attack and Speed, and incredible ability in Sword of Ruin, Chien-Pao is one of the strongest physical attackers in the game.

  • Icicle Crash: While Ice Spinner is perfectly accurate, Icicle Crash’s higher power and flinch chance makes it the preferred attack. Additionally, not being a contact move allows Chien-Pao to avoid unnecessary chip damage from Rocky Helmet users.

  • Sucker Punch vs Crunch: Sucker Punch offers priority with a strong base power at the cost of necessitating prediction, while Crunch is a more standard attack whose Defense drop can allow Chien-Pao to potentially break through bulky foes.

  • Ice Shard: Ice Shard is a more consistent albeit weaker alternative to Sucker Punch.

  • Sacred Sword: Sacred Sword provides coverage for Pokemon that resist one or both of Chien-Pao’s STAB attacks, like Heatran, Chi-Yu, and other Chien-Pao. Additionally, ignoring defense boosts allows Chien-Pao to deal more consistent damage to foes who boost their Defense.

  • Swords Dance: While it can be difficult to fit and very reliant on Focus Sash, Swords Dance boosts Chien-Pao’s Attack to unwallable levels, making it a very potent sweeper.

  • 0-1 SpA IV: If using Tera Blast on Jolly Chien-Pao, make sure to to use a SpA IV that's 0-1. This is because if Flutter Mane uses Charm, any SpA IV that's higher will result in Tera Blast becoming a Special Attack.

Other Options

  • Throat Chop: Throat Chop disables the use of sound-based moves from targets like Skeledirge and Sylveon, but these matchups are so uncommon that it generally isn't worth using over Crunch.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner can be used as a more consistent Ice STAB, however it makes Chien-Pao more vulnerable to Rocky Helmet users.

  • Sheer Cold: While it may seem alluring, Sheer Cold is usually a waste of a slot on Chien-Pao sets like this, as its standard attacks already hit most relevant foes. Even if Chien-Pao fails to KO a foe, it will generally leave it within range for a teammate.

Tera Types

  • With few exceptions, Chien-Pao is about all-out offense. However, its choice of item drastically affects its strategy. Tera Types have been organized by item choice to better clarify how each Tera Type works in that context.

Tera Types for Focus Sash and Life Orb

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Chien-Pao offers power in spades without needing to Terastallize, only needing it on very rare occasions to break past specific walls or dodge priority moves aimed at it.

  • Electric: Tera Electric can be used in tandem with Tera Blast to improve Chien-Pao’s matchup against key threats such as Urshifu-R and Dondozo while also making it immune to paralysis.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost doesn’t offer much offensive benefit, but it allows Chien-Pao to dodge Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, which can be particularly useful if using Swords Dance.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Chien-Pao survive Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes, which otherwise threatens to OHKO through Focus Sash. Combined with Tera Blast, Chien-Pao still threatens big damage into Urshifu-R and Dondozo.

  • Dark: Tera Dark boosts Sucker Punch to extreme power levels while making Crunch exceptionally difficult to switch into without a resistance.

  • Ice: Tera Ice can allow Chien-Pao to finish foes off with Ice Shard from higher ranges and makes Icicle Crash an even more formidable tool.

Tera Types for Choice Band

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Chien-Pao is already plenty powerful, Choice Band combined with Tera can elevate 2HKOs to OHKOs on some of the bulkiest walls in the meta. For this reason, Tera can be worth using on Choice Band sets.

  • Dark: Tera Dark turns Choice Band Crunch into a devastating wallbreaker move that few can withstand, OHKOing Max HP Annihilape and Scizor if using an Adamant nature. Neutralizing Chien-Pao’s Steel-type weakness also makes it less vulnerable to Scizor’s Bullet Punch.

  • Ice: Tera Ice gives Choice Band Icicle Crash enough power to challenge even physically defensive Ting-Lu, having approximately a 69% chance to OHKO if using an Adamant nature; be warned, however, that Ting-Lu often Terastallizes in front of Chien-Pao, making this inconsistent. The extra power behind Ice Shard is also a welcome boost.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy combined with Choice Band Tera Blast handily defeats some of Chien-Pao's less common checks, OHKOing standard variants of Annihilape and Assault Vest Iron Hands. It also removes several weaknesses, most notably turning Chien-Pao's 4x Fighting-type weakness into a resistance.

EV Spreads

  • 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly or Adamant: This offensive spread works with all standard sets. Adamant gives Chien-Pao a significant power boost, but Jolly is important for Speed tying with Flutter Mane and opposing Chien-Pao.

  • 252 Atk / 68 Def / 188 Spe with Adamant: This alternate spread is commonly associated with Choice Band, fully maximizing Attack while still maintaining enough Speed to outrun Timid Iron Moth. When used with an appropriate Tera type, the Defense investment lets Chien-Pao survive Life Orb Mimikyu's Play Rough into Shadow Sneak.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Chien-Pao is a strong wallbreaker, being able to blast through many teams on its own. Its high Attack and Speed combined with its good STAB moves and Choice Band to bolster its damage even further make it extremely difficult to handle. Lash Out can be used over Crunch to hit Intimidate Corviknight harder. Ice Shard helps to pick up KOs on weakened, faster foes like Galarian Zapdos and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon; it can also OHKO frail targets like Hisuian Electrode from full HP. Sacred Sword hits Dark-, Steel-, and Rock-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Garganacl. Chien-Pao can have a hard time breaking through defensive Pokemon like Intimidate Corviknight and Quaquaval, making partners like Gouging Fire and Dragonite appreciated. Choice Scarf users like Walking Wake can be tough foes for Chien-Pao, forcing it out; this makes slow pivots like Meloetta and RegenVest Manaphy good teammates, as they can deal with these Choice Scarf users and also help bring it in safely after taking a hit. Chien-Pao's weakness to Stealth Rock can become a problem quickly if not accounted for, so entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Mandibuzz are good partners.

All-out Attacker.description:
• Ice Spinner is an alternative to Icicle Crash because of its better accuracy, but it is slightly weaker, cannot flinch, and is a contact move.
  • Ice Shard hits Miraidon and Koraidon for super effective damage, 2HKOing the former, and 2HKOes Flutter Mane reliably. Sucker Punch may be considered over Ice Shard, as it does more damage to Iron Bundle and can KO Flutter Mane, but it misses out on revenge killing Koraidon and is often prediction-reliant.
  • Sacred Sword allows Chien-Pao to OHKO Chi-Yu, Kingambit, and opposing Chien-Pao, which otherwise resist its STAB moves.
  • Chien-Pao can use Tera Dark to make Crunch stronger and 2HKO Corviknight and Toxapex if it gets lucky with a Defense drop. Chien-Pao can also use Tera Ice in order to 2HKO Corviknight more reliably and boost Ice Shard damage—notably against Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Koraidon. Lastly, Tera Electric Chien-Pao with Tera Blast can easily break through bulky checks like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo.
  • Chien-Pao fits best with other strong wallbreakers that benefit from the removal of defensive walls. These include Koraidon, Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and offensive Great Tusk.
  • Defensive partners like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge are mandatory to handle fast and strong threats like Koraidon and Miraidon, as Chien-Pao cannot OHKO them if they are at full health. Additionally, Great Tusk and Ting-Lu can set up entry hazards, which is crucial for getting chip on defensive walls.

Choice Band.description:
• Icicle Crash 2HKOes Corviknight and avoids Rocky Helmet, while Ice Spinner is more accurate and has the bonus of removing Electric Terrain.
  • Sacred Sword hits checks such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao. Another option is to run a double priority combination with Ice Shard and Sucker Punch. Sucker Punch hits very crucial Pokemon that Ice Shard can't, such as Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Fire Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle.
  • An Adamant nature allows Chien-Pao to achieve ridiculous feats such as revenge killing Flutter Mane from 90% HP with Ice Shard. A Jolly nature lets Chien-Pao Speed tie with Koraidon, Miraidon, opposing Jolly Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane, giving Chien-Pao the freedom to click its strongest moves less reluctantly.
  • Tera Dark allows Chien-Pao to 2HKO the entire tier while letting it still switch into weaker moves such as Shadow Ball. Tera Ice gives Chien-Pao the ability to OHKO Flutter Mane with Ice Shard, making it a terrific late-game cleaner.
  • Choice Band Chien-Pao is a wallbreaker that is best suited for bulky offense structures that love its revenge killing and wallbreaking capabilities.
  • Pokemon like Iron Treads, Hatterene, and Koraidon, which can provide entry hazard control or pivoting, are excellent teammates for Chien-Pao.

Swords Dance.description:
• Swords Dance makes Chien-Pao immensely threatening, letting it break through bulky foes such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, and Corviknight.
  • Ice Spinner is a more reliable option thanks to its perfect accuracy, but Icicle Crash's power and flinch chance greatly help out against all foes that can take a hit from Chien-Pao, such as Corviknight and Great Tusk.
  • Ice Shard is a reliable priority attack mainly used to better deal with Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Sucker Punch can be used as a stronger but prediction-reliant alternative that OHKOes Flutter Mane without a boost and OHKOes the likes of Iron Bundle and Miraidon after a boost. It also provides a favorable roll to OHKO Koraidon if it has Terastallized into the Fire typing.
  • Tera Dark boosts Crunch, allowing Chien-Pao to more reliably beat physically defensive Corviknight and Toxapex. Tera Dark Chien-Pao holding Life Orb can OHKO both Pokemon after a Swords Dance boost.
  • Tera Ice can be used instead to boost Chien Pao's Ice-type attacks. This also makes Ice Shard a better revenge killing option.
  • Sacred Sword can be used to hit foes that resist Chien-Pao's STAB moves, like Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao.
  • Life Orb is the primary item choice because it gives Chien-Pao a lot of power while allowing it to run a Jolly nature and not lose out on potential OHKOs.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots sacrifices a lot of power but gives Chien-Pao the ability to ignore entry hazards, allowing it to come in and potentially set up multiple times throughout a game.
  • Black Glasses in conjunction with an Adamant nature can be used as an alternative to Life Orb to not have recoil while still being able to OHKO the likes of Corviknight and Toxapex after obtaining a Swords Dance boost and using Tera Dark.
  • This set can be used as both an early-game wallbreaker and a late-game sweeper thanks to Chien-Pao's strong STAB attacks and priority moves.
  • Chien-Pao has very little defensive utility, so having a defensive core for it to fall back on is recommended for balance teams. On offensive teams, it can afford to run Focus Sash to take at least one hit from foes that would usually threaten it out.
  • Great Tusk is Chien-Pao's best teammate, as Great Tusk can handle one of Chien-Pao's hardest checks in Koraidon and provide Rapid Spin support. Rapid Spin also helps keep Focus Sash intact.

Cheems Pao.description:
• Chien-Pao is a fantastic physical attacker that can improve its and its teammates' physical damage through Sword of Ruin. It is very effective with priority attackers such as Dragonite and Palafin, as well as other fast physical attackers such as Choice Band Dragapult and Choice Scarf Basculegion-F.

  • Ice Spinner is a STAB option that easily grabs OHKOs on Dragonite and Landorus-T while clearing Psychic Terrain for its own Sucker Punch and teammates' priority moves. Icicle Crash can be used for a slight increase in power, a sizeable flinch chance, and avoiding Rocky Helmet damage, however it comes with a chance to miss and cannot clear Psychic Terrain. If used with Rillaboom, Icicle Crash is recommended to avoid clearing your own Grassy Terrain.

  • Sucker Punch allows Chien-Pao to pick off faster threats such as Booster Energy Flutter Mane and Booster Energy Iron Bundle. Sucker Punch is also crucial to keeping Chien-Pao relevant against Tailwind or Trick Room, and pressures opposing priority users such as Palafin.

  • Sacred Sword OHKOs many relevant Pokemon that resist Chien-Pao's STAB combination such as Kingambit, Chi-Yu, and opposing Chien-Pao. Crunch is a more consistent option for Dark-type STAB, knocking out Indeedee-F through Psychic Terrain and threatening Pokemon such as Cresselia that are using status moves.

  • Life Orb is used to push Chien-Pao's offenses to dizzying heights, OHKOing bulky Rillaboom and Flutter Mane with Ice Spinner and Sucker Punch, respectively. Focus Sash gets around Chien-Pao's poor defenses and allows it to survive a hit against strong, fast attackers such as Flutter Mane and Choice Scarf Chi-Yu. However, the item is rendered useless by Stealth Rock, a relatively common sight.

  • Jolly nature Chien-Pao speed ties Flutter Mane and opposing Chien-Pao. An Adamant nature can be used for more power, giving Life Orb Chien-Pao a chance to OHKO Cresselia with Crunch.

  • Tera Dark boosts the damage of Sucker Punch, allowing it to more effectively pick off weakened foes and score an OHKO on all variants of Flutter Mane. Tera Ghost provides an immunity to Fighting-type moves, improving its matchup into Iron Hands, as well as priority such as Fake Out and Extreme Speed that would otherwise threaten Chien-Pao.

  • In addition to other physical attackers, Chien-Pao appreciates partners that can cover its defensive shortcomings, notably to Fire-, Fairy-, and Fighting-types. Volcanion and Heatran perform well against Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane and can hold off opposing Fire-types. Amoonguss and Landorus-T can be used to switch into Fighting-type attacks from Iron Hands aimed at Chien-Pao.

Specially Defensive.description:
• Ting-Lu is the premier Miraidon check in the tier, being able to avoid the 2HKO from it without needing to Terastallize.
  • It can reliably generate chip damage using Ruination when it forces special attackers out, and it can even force Arceus to use up Recover PP. On these forced switches, it can also set up Spikes or Stealth Rock, which further chips down switch-ins for the rest of the game due to the limited distribution of entry hazard removal in the tier.
  • Whirlwind prevents opposing setup threats such as Double Dance Miraidon and Calm Mind Arceus-Ground from snowballing out of control, as well as using its own Spikes for chip damage. Protect can also be used in this moveslot, which allows for more Leftovers recovery and scouting of Choice item users and Tera types. The preference will come down to how much the team relies on Ting-Lu to phaze setup threats such as Calm Mind Arceus and Miraidon.
  • Leftovers is mandatory on Ting-Lu since it does not have any form of reliable recovery.
  • Ting-Lu will very rarely need to use its Tera types, as its natural typing provides a strong Electric immunity for Miraidon. Tera Steel provides a Dragon resistance versus Miraidon while also letting Ting-Lu handle Dazzling Gleam from Calm Mind + Tera Fairy Miraidon, and it also grants an immunity to Toxic from Eternatus and Toxapex. Tera Fairy provides a Dragon immunity against Miraidon, allowing Ting-Lu to better answer Tera Dragon sets with Calm Mind or Choice Specs, and Ting-Lu becomes resistant or immune to Koraidon's STAB moves. However, this comes at the expense of not resisting Fairy versus Tera Fairy Miraidon. Poison resists Close Combat and Zacian-C's Play Rough, and it allows Ting-Lu to absorb Toxic Spikes. Tera Water allows it to take Kyogre's STAB moves while also resisting Koraidon's Flare Blitz. It also lets Ting-Lu check the rare, but otherwise hard to check, Chi-Yu and Walking Wake. While all of these are good options for Ting-Lu, it benefits much more from its natural typing and should only Terastallize as a last resort.
  • Ting-Lu can also switch in safely against most defensive Pokemon in the tier, such as support Arceus formes, Groudon, Skeledirge, Giratina-O, and Toxapex, and then use this opportunity to set up a hazard or generate chip damage with Ruination.
  • It struggles against physical threats such as Koraidon, Zacian-C, and Arceus, so it is best paired with Pokemon such as defensive Arceus-Fairy, Skeledirge, Groudon, and Toxapex that can switch into them reliably. Ting-Lu can also enable teammates such as Choice Scarf Koraidon, Miraidon, and Kyogre to clean more easily with the chip damage it generates from Ruination.
  • Due to Ting-Lu being unable to reliably check Choice Specs Miraidon long-term, it’s best to have some form of speed control alongside it, whether it be Choice Scarf Koraidon or Zacian-C.
  • Ting-Lu can function as a team's sole special wall, but it does appreciate naturally bulky Pokemon such as Kyogre and Groudon to handle some hits, which lets Ting-Lu remain a reliable Miraidon check. It can also pair well alongside the tier's Defoggers, Giratina-O and Corviknight as it is prone to Spikes chip damage and appreciates avoiding that to better check Miraidon. In a similar vein, Eternatus and Toxapex are good Toxic Spikes absorbers, the former of which can also soft check Kyogre and special Arceus formes.

Ting-Lu is a sturdy specially defensive wall thanks to its high bulk further augmented by Vessel of Ruin. Because of this, Ting-Lu is more than capable of handling common special attackers such as Heatran, Moltres, and Volcarona. Its Dark typing is also useful to check Stored Power setup sweepers such as Cresselia as well as absorb Future Sight from Tapu Lele and Galarian Slowking. Ting-Lu also functions as an exceptional entry hazard setter, as it can easily set up Stealth Rock and Spikes against threats such as Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Heatran. Ting-Lu is capable of checking even more threats with Tera Poison, such as Iron Valiant, Mega Lopunny, Sneasler, and Zamazenta, while also gaining an immunity to poison. Tera Ghost is a good alternative that allows Ting-Lu to block Rapid Spin from Great Tusk while keeping a good matchup into Sneasler and Zamazenta. Ruination helps force progress against potential switch-ins to Ting-Lu such as Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, Mega Charizard Y, and Rotom-W. Alternatively, Spikes can be run in conjunction with Stealth Rock on more offensive structures in order to provide additional entry hazard support, but this makes Ting-Lu a lot more passive against threats such as Tornadus-T, Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Mega Charizard Y. Ting-Lu can also run Stone Edge in order to better check Mega Charizard Y, Volcarona, and Moltres. Finally, Whirlwind is a vital move in order to deter setup sweepers such as Tera Grass Volcarona, and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T. Ting-Lu is great at supporting partners such as Iron Valiant and Zamazenta by dealing with their checks such as Cresselia and Galarian Slowking while providing entry hazard support. In return, they can help deal with threats such as Ferrothorn, Great Tusk, and Baxcalibur. On more defensive teams, partners such as Skarmory and Toxapex appreciate Ting-Lu's ability to take on threats such as Fire-types such as Volcarona and Heatran and Electric-types such as Tapu Koko and Zapdos for them. In return, they can help Ting-Lu deal with dangerous physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny and Sneasler. Ting-Lu hates having to deal with Flying-types such as Tornadus-T and Gliscor, so partners such as Baxcalibur and Rotom-W are apprecated to help deal with them. Grass-types such as Ogerpon-W, Kartana, and Ferrothorn also annoy Ting-Lu, so teammates such as Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Dragonite are good partners to check them for it. Water-types such as Rotom-W and Mega Swampert also give Ting-Lu trouble, so Grass-type partners such as Ferrothorn, Ogerpon-W, and Rillaboom are good at shoring up that weakness.

Weakness Policy.description: This EV spread survives Choice Band Hisuian Avalugg's Avalanche and Timid Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump; the remaining EVs are invested in Attack.

Defensive Hazard Setter (Dark).description:
Ting-Lu is a fantastic asset for Dark teams due to its access to entry hazards and great bulk, supported further by Vessel of Ruin weakening special attackers such as Iron Valiant and Hatterene. Earthquake is a reliable STAB move that hits most of the metagame for decent damage while also scaring Clodsire out and preventing it from setting Toxic Spikes. Heavy Slam hits Fairy-types that would otherwise overpower Ting-Lu, such as Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant, while also threatening Hatterene trying to bounce back hazards. Stealth Rock and Spikes allow Ting-Lu to support wallbreakers such as Meowscarada or Greninja. Whirlwind allows Ting-Lu to phase out setup sweepers such as Dragonite and Curse Dondozo and rack up entry hazard damage, while Ruination provides consistent damage against other walls such as Amoonguss and Corviknight that don't mind any of Ting-Lu's other moves.

Wallbreakers such as Meowscarada, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Greninja all appreciate Ting-Lu's ability to set entry hazards, as they wear down common defensive answers such as Toxapex, Iron Treads, and Dondozo. In return, they can scare out threats to Ting-Lu; Meowscarada can deal with Greninja, Chien-Pao and Greninja can threaten Great Tusk, and Kingambit can force out Fairy-types such as Hatterene. Skuntank is a good partner as well, since it offers a crucial neutrality to Fairy, threatens Fairy-types, and sets and clears Toxic Spikes, augmenting Ting-Lu's entry hazards and improving its longevity. Additionally, Skuntank can utilize Fire Spin to further chip down teams and trap Klefki, improving Ting-Lu's matchup against Fairy. In return, Ting-Lu can assist in Ground matchups through its bulk. Sableye is also a great partner due to its Fighting immunity, taking attacks Ting-Lu can't such as Great Tusk's and Iron Hands's Close Combat.

Physically Defensive (Ground).description:
Ting-Lu's exceptional bulk and utility options make it an invaluable asset to Ground teams, walling threats like Dragapult, Espathra, and Hydreigon. Earthquake threatens Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Volcarona. Alternatively, Throat Chop hits Espathra for more damage and shuts down Air Balloon Gholdengo. Ruination allows Ting-Lu to quickly wear down the likes of opposing Ting-Lu, Hatterene, and Dragonite, while Body Press may be used to deal more damage to Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Hydreigon. Spikes or Stealth Rock in conjunction with Whirlwind sets Ting-Lu apart from other entry hazard setters; it's capable of wearing down the opponent's defensive core and weakens threats such as Greninja, Meowscarada, and Baxcalibur. Additionally, Whirlwind phazes threatening sweepers like Scizor and Ceruledge.

Ting-Lu's entry hazards are heavily appreciated by Great Tusk, which threatens out Choice Specs Flutter Mane, Gallade, and Greninja; Sandy Shocks, which deals with Water-types like Pelipper, Quaquaval, and Dondozo; and Garchomp, which threatens Corviknight, Rotom-C, and Breloom with its Fire-type coverage. Furthermore, Choice Scarf Great Tusk removes Heavy-Duty Boots from Sableye and Brambleghast via Knock Off to enhance Ting-Lu's phazing, which enables Clodsire and Gastrodon as entry hazard setters to wither down threats such as Greninja and Ceruledge more efficiently. Water Absorb Clodsire adds a Water immunity, can switch into attacks from Greninja, Quaquaval, and Meowscarada, and helps wear down the opposing team with Toxic Spikes or Toxic. Gastrodon walls Water-type Pokemon like Pelipper, Dondozo, and Rotom-W and assists with spreading entry hazards. Iron Treads eases Ting-Lu's pivoting by removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin and checks Fairy-types like Flutter Mane and Hatterene. Quagsire stalls out physical setup sweepers such as Mimikyu, Chien-Pao, and Iron Hands and also helps wear down defensive cores using Toxic.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

Stealth Rock Support.description:
• Ting-Lu's absurd bulk and excellent support movepool make it the premier Stealth Rock setter in the metagame!

  • Ruination: Ruination gives Ting-Lu the most consistent option for damage output, without resorting to offensive investment.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam deals serious damage to Fairy-types, with Flutter Mane in particular needing a huge amount of defensive investment to avoid being OHKOed by it.

  • Taunt: While Ting-Lu's Speed is awful compared to most Taunt users, using Taunt against foes like Corviknight on the switch is still useful. Note that while using Taunt against Toxapex can be useful, it is highly likely to run Mental Herb, which risks getting Ting-Lu poisoned.

  • Protect: Protect with Leftovers is a strong choice when running Ting-Lu with high sustain teammates such as Toxapex.

Other Options

  • Fissure: Fissure lets Ting-Lu potentially punish passive Pokemon without Substitute, such as Toxapex.

  • Spikes: Getting Stealth Rock and Spikes together makes Whirlwind a very effective damage dealing tool, in addition to supporting other offensive Pokemon. However, it can be difficult to set up without compromising Ting-Lu's damage output.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Even with Ting-Lu's fantastic bulk, Terastallization greatly increases the amount of Pokemon it can beat one-on-one, such as Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.

  • Fairy: In addition to a useful Fighting resistance, Tera Fairy helps Ting-Lu against powerful Dragon-types like Choice Band Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Poison: Tera Poison gives Ting-Lu an important resistance to Fairy and Fighting, and it lets it absorb Toxic Spikes.

  • Water: With Tera Water, Ting-Lu has a significantly better matchup against Urshifu-R. The Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu matchups can also benefit, but be mindful of potential Tera Blast coverage.

  • Steel: Tera Steel retaining a Fighting weakness is unfortunate, but in exchange, Heavy Slam will OHKO even most bulky Flutter Mane, and it gives Ting-Lu a good matchup against Iron Bundle.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry versus Leftovers: Ting-Lu's lack of reliable recovery usually makes Sitrus Berry the most reliable method of surviving an extra attack. Leftovers is a good alternative if Sitrus Berry is needed somewhere else, and even preferable if running Protect.

  • Mental Herb: Mental Herb can be used to nullify one use of Taunt or Encore, which Ting-Lu is fairly vulnerable to, at the cost of reducing its lifespan with a lack of any recovery.

EV Spreads

  • Maximum Physical Defense versus Maximum Special Defense: Specializing in one defensive stat depends on which threats Ting-Lu needs to handle, with physically defensive variants preforming better against threats like Dragonite, Garchomp, and Kingambit, and when Terastallized, Chien-Pao, Azumarill, and Baxcalibur. For specially defensive variants, major targets include Gholdengo and Iron Moth, and when Terastallized, Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Chi-Yu.

  • 212 HP / 4 Atk / 116 Def / 156 SpD / 20 Spe with Impish: When Terastallized to a neutral typing, Ting-Lu survives up to four Icicle Crashes from Jolly Focus Sash Chien-Pao. With Leftovers and Protect, it also avoids the 2HKO from Choice Band Dragonite's Outrage. The Speed EVs let it outrun uninvested Hippowdon.

  • 44 HP / 252 Def / 212 SpD with Careful: This EV spread is optimized for use with Sitrus Berry, letting Ting-Lu avoid a 2HKO from Choice Band Dragonite's Outrage, and Timid Tera Fairy Flutter Mane's Moonblast when Terastallized to a neutral typing.

Assault Vest.description:
• Assault Vest and Vessel of Ruin combine to make Ting-Lu an especially formidable tank.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam deals far more damage to Flutter Mane and Mimikyu than any other attack, with even Bold Flutter Mane having a good shot at being OHKOed after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Fissure: Fissure is Ting-Lu's best shot at KOing bulky foes like Dondozo.

  • Payback versus Throat Chop: Payback will usually deal more damage thanks to how slow Ting-Lu is, but Throat Chop will punish Pokemon that switch in more.

  • EV Spread: The given EV spread maximizes Ting-Lu's Attack and special bulk.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Ting-Lu doesn't need Terastallization to function, it makes it far more effective at beating a wide variety of Pokemon one-on-one.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy not only helps Ting-Lu against powerful Dragon- and Fighting-type attacks, but it also gives Ting-Lu a good Tera Blast to hit Dragonite with.

  • Electric: Tera Electric's resistances aren't amazing, but they give Ting-Lu a sole weakness to Ground. Futhermore, Tera Blast exploits common Tera Flying and Tera Water users like Gholdengo, as well as helping wear down Dondozo and Corviknight.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Ting-Lu a powerful STAB Heavy Slam, giving it a great matchup against Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.

  • Poison: Tera Poison gives Ting-Lu a vital Fairy resistance against Flutter Mane and Mimikyu, and it lets it absorb the dreaded Toxic and Toxic Spikes.

  • Water: Tera Water is a fantastic defensive typing, letting Ting-Lu avoid a 2HKO from Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu's Overheat.

Defensive Support.description: Ting-Lu is an effective defensive support in STABmons, as with Ceaseless Edge or Spikes, it can serve as a very bulky entry hazard setter. In addition, thanks to its ability, its well-distributed stats, and Shore Up, it is able to check many attackers such as Iron Moth, Ceruledge, and Garganacl. Spikes should be used if reliability and lack of PP are a concern, especially on stall teams. Precipice Blades maximizes damage against Toxapex and other Ground-weak Pokemon like Iron Hands; however, Earthquake is a fine option if accuracy is a concern. There are multiple options for the last moveslot: Parting Shot lets Ting-Lu safely bring in offensive teammates via a slow pivot, Foul Play gives it a better matchup against setup sweepers like Salamence, Whirlwind phazes setup sweepers that Ting-Lu can't handle like non-Taunt Annihilape, and Knock Off can remove items like Heavy-Duty Boots from pivots like Tyranitar. Covert Cloak prevents Ting-Lu from being poisoned from Mortal Spin users like Toxapex, while Leftovers gives to it more passive recovery. Both Tera Ghost and Tera Poison allow Ting-Lu to surprise Fighting-types like Iron Hands; Tera Poison grants it an immunity to Toxic and lets it resist Grass-type attacks, while Tera Ghost allows it to spinblock. Alternatively, Tera Fairy and Tera Water provide great resistances to Roaring Moon and Palafin, respectively. Ting-Lu fits in a variety of teams, ranging from bulky offense to stall. Offensive teammates such as Iron Valiant, Palafin, and Iron Hands appreciate that Ting-Lu can both set Spikes and act as a slow pivot with Parting Shot. These three Pokemon also beat Great Tusk, one of Ting-Lu's biggest checks, as it is able to beat it with Fighting-type moves and remove its entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Dondozo are able to check Pokemon that Ting-Lu can't, which include Azumarill, Rotom-W, and Mimikyu. Ting-Lu struggles to make progress with entry hazards up, so entry hazard removal from the likes of Great Tusk, Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Corviknight is recommended.

Specially Defensive.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Earth Eater Kingambit, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Talonflame and Quaquaval. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Lucario can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammate that also provides Defog.

RegenVest Wall.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Hydreigon and Iron Moth. Throat Chop provides STAB damage and lets it beat Boomburst users, Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options.
